This reality TV show, created by Charlie Parsons in 1992, was first aired as Expedition Robinson in Sweden; it features a group of strangers marooned in a remote location, where they must compete in challenges to secure food, shelter, and immunity from elimination; the contestants, known as “castaways,” are gradually voted off the island until only one remains; it has spawned numerous international adaptations, becoming a global phenomenon. Name this popular series, known for its tagline "Outwit, Outplay, Outlast."

Though this river initially forms at the confluence of the Paranaiba and Grande rivers, it ultimately flows into the Río de la Plata estuary. Forming the border between Paraguay and Argentina, it is the second-longest river in South America. Home to the Itaipu Dam, the world's second-largest hydroelectric power plant, it is a major waterway for transportation and commerce. Which river's name translates to "like the sea" in the Tupi language?

This man's memoir "On Call" debuted as a New York Times bestseller in June 2024. This physician and immunologist, born in Brooklyn, New York in 1940, joined the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in 1968 and became director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) in 1984; he has served as a key advisor to seven US presidents on various public health crises, including HIV/AIDS, Ebola, and Zika; Name this man who became a household name during the COVID-19 pandemic, providing regular updates and guidance to the public.

This MLB team won the World Series in 1984 with a team led by Kirk Gibson and Jack Morris, their most recent World Series appearance was in 2012. Their mascot is Paws and their home stadium is Comerica Park, known for its Ferris wheel and carousel. They have a rich history with legendary players like Ty Cobb, Al Kaline, and Miguel Cabrera. Which Major League Baseball team plays in the Motor City and wears the Old English "D" on their caps?

Though they primarily feed on nectar, some species also consume pollen, tree sap, or even decaying animal matter. Their wings are covered in tiny scales, creating their vibrant colors and patterns. They undergo complete metamorphosis, transforming from egg to larva (caterpillar) to pupa (chrysalis) to adult. Known for their role in pollination and their symbolic representation of transformation, what are these insects belonging to the order Lepidoptera?

Though he initially trained as a lawyer, he later devoted his life to art, co-founding the Der Blaue Reiter (The Blue Rider) group with Franz Marc. Born in Moscow, he was a pioneer of abstract art, exploring the emotional and spiritual power of color and form. Known for his "Compositions" series and his book "Concerning the Spiritual in Art," he taught at the Bauhaus school in Germany. Which artist's painting "Composition VIII" is considered a masterpiece of abstract expressionism?

Though it was initially adapted from a teleplay of the same name, it became a landmark film for its exploration of the American jury system. Set entirely in a jury room, it follows twelve jurors deliberating the guilt or innocence of a young man accused of murder. Known for its tense atmosphere and powerful performances, it features a cast including Henry Fonda, Lee J. Cobb, and E.G. Marshall. Which 1957 drama film examines themes of justice, doubt, and the importance of individual conscience?

Though it initially began as a conflict between Protestant and Catholic states within the Holy Roman Empire, it eventually involved most of the major European powers. Marked by devastating battles like White Mountain and Lützen, it saw the rise of military leaders like Albrecht von Wallenstein and Gustavus Adolphus. Ending with the Peace of Westphalia in 1648, it resulted in significant political and religious changes in Europe. Which war, lasting from 1618 to 1648, is considered one of the longest and most destructive conflicts in European history?

Initially established as a haven for debtors and those imprisoned for minor offenses, it was the last of the original Thirteen Colonies. This state's capital was originally called Terminus due to its location at the end of a railroad line. Named after King George II, it was founded by James Oglethorpe in 1733. Known for its peaches and peanuts, it was the fourth state to ratify the U.S. Constitution. Name this state that was home to Jimmy Carter.

This tennis player became the first African American woman to be ranked No. 1 in the world in the Open Era. Known for her powerful serve and aggressive baseline game, she initially rose to fame alongside her sister Serena. She has won seven Grand Slam singles titles, five at Wimbledon and two at the US Open. She has also won 14 Grand Slam doubles titles with her sister Serena. Which tennis star's signature fashion sense includes designing her own tennis apparel line, EleVen?

Though it initially declared independence in 1948, it traces its historical roots to ancient Judah. Bordered by Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, and Egypt, its topography ranges from the coastal plain to the Negev Desert. Home to the Dead Sea, the lowest point on Earth, it also boasts the port city of Haifa and the ancient city of Jerusalem. Which Middle Eastern country is the world's only Jewish-majority state?

Serving as Secretary of State under James K. Polk, he was the only president from Pennsylvania. His nickname was "Old Buck," and he was a lifelong bachelor. Believing the issue of slavery would be settled by the Supreme Court, his presidency was dominated by the escalating tensions leading to the Civil War. Who was the 15th President of the United States?

Though it primarily functions as a digestive organ, it also plays a role in immune response and hormone production. Its lining contains gastric glands that secrete hydrochloric acid and enzymes like pepsin. It is connected to the esophagus by the cardiac sphincter and to the small intestine by the pyloric sphincter. Known for its J-shape and ability to expand to accommodate food, what is this organ located in the upper left abdomen?

Though it was initially a box office flop, it has become a beloved holiday classic. Set in the fictional town of Bedford Falls, it tells the story of George Bailey, a man who sacrifices his dreams for the sake of his family and community. Featuring iconic scenes like the angel Clarence earning his wings and George wishing he had never been born, it stars Jimmy Stewart and Donna Reed. Which 1946 film explores themes of redemption, kindness, and the value of every life?

Though it initially aimed to restore imperial rule, it led to the modernization and Westernization of Japan. Triggered by the arrival of Commodore Matthew Perry and the signing of unequal treaties, it saw the overthrow of the Tokugawa Shogunate and the return of power to the emperor. It led to the abolition of the feudal system, the establishment of a constitutional monarchy, and the rapid industrialization and militarization of Japan. Which period marked a turning point in Japanese history, transforming the nation into a major world power?

Though it was initially a commercial failure, it is now considered one of the greatest American novels.  Set in the mid-19th century, it features a diverse crew of characters like Starbuck, Queequeg, and Pip. Narrated by Ishmael, a young sailor who joins the crew of the Pequod, it explores themes of obsession, revenge, and the relationship between man and nature. Which novel features Captain Ahab's relentless pursuit of a white whale?

Initially airing on Tuesdays before moving to Sundays, it became the first news program to win a primetime Emmy. Though it once featured a segment called "Point/Counterpoint," it's best known for in-depth investigations and interviews. Originally co-hosted by Mike Wallace and Harry Reasoner, its ticking stopwatch has become an iconic symbol in broadcast journalism. What is this long-running news magazine program?

Though he initially studied under Arnold Sommerfeld, he later became a colleague of Niels Bohr in Copenhagen. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1932 for his work on quantum mechanics. His uncertainty principle states that it is impossible to simultaneously know both the position and momentum of a particle with perfect accuracy. Who led the German nuclear weapons program during World War II?

This geological wonder was initially discovered by the Spanish conquistador Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca in 1541, and it was named after a river which means "big water" in the Guaraní language. Straddling the border between Argentina and Brazil, it is actually a system of 275 waterfalls, with the Devil's Throat being the most impressive.  Surrounded by lush rainforest and home to diverse wildlife, these are one of the New Seven Wonders of Nature. What is this majestic waterfall system located in South America?

Though this team holds the NFL record for most consecutive sold-out home games, their first winning season didn't occur until 1983. Their logo is inspired by a transformation mask from the Kwakwaka'wakw tribe, and their fight song is a parody of the ballad "Louie, Louie." Coached by Pete Carroll from 2010-2023, their "Legion of Boom" defense led them to a Super Bowl victory in 2014. Which NFL team, known for its loud "12th Man" fan base, plays its home games at Lumen Field in Seattle, Washington?

This movie was initially based on a Stephen King novel, but the author famously disliked Stanley Kubrick's film adaptation. Set in the isolated Overlook Hotel, it features a family facing supernatural forces during a harsh winter. Known for its eerie atmosphere and iconic scenes like the twins in the hallway and the "Here's Johnny!" line, it stars Jack Nicholson as Jack Torrance, a struggling writer who descends into madness. What is this 1980 psychological horror film?

Though he initially ran a haberdashery with a friend in Kansas City, he became the 33rd president after Franklin D. Roosevelt's death in 1945. He authorized the use of atomic bombs against Japan and led the U.S. during the early years of the Cold War. Known for his "The buck stops here" sign on his desk, he also implemented the a namesake doctrine and the Marshall Plan. Who unexpectedly won the 1948 presidential election against Thomas E. Dewey?

This TV news network hosted the first 2024 US Presidential Debate between Joe Biden and Donald Trump. The debate was moderated by two of this network's journalists, Dana Bash and Jake Tapper. This network's first broadcast was about the attempted assassination of Vernon Jordan, and anchored by a husband and wife team. Founded by Ted Turner, it was the first all-news television channel in the United States. Name this cable news channel that is headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia.

Though it initially aimed for political and societal reform, it ultimately led to the rise and fall of Napoleon Bonaparte. Sparked by economic inequality and Enlightenment ideals, it saw the storming of the Bastille and the establishment of the First French Republic. The Reign of Terror, led by Maximilien Robespierre, resulted in the execution of thousands by guillotine. Which period of radical social and political upheaval in France and its colonies began in 1789?

Though he initially studied medicine, he switched to English literature and became a pioneer of African literature written in English. Born in Ogidi, Nigeria, he is best known for his debut novel, "Things Fall Apart," which explores the impact of colonialism on Igbo society. His other works include "No Longer at Ease," "Arrow of God," and "A Man of the People." Which author's writings often address the clash between traditional African values and Western influences?

Though he initially worked as a patent clerk in Switzerland, he became a Nobel laureate in Physics in 1921. His theories of special and general relativity revolutionized our understanding of space, time, and gravity. Known for his famous equation E=mc², he also made significant contributions to the development of quantum mechanics. Which scientist, born in Ulm, Germany, is considered one of the most influential figures in the history of science?

Though he initially ruled over a small kingdom in Anshan, he conquered the Median Empire and established the Achaemenid Empire. Known for his tolerant policies towards conquered peoples, he allowed the Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild their temple. His conquest of Babylon was facilitated by diverting the Euphrates River, and his legacy is preserved in the a namesake, alliterative cylinder. Which ruler is considered the founder of the Persian Empire?

This rock formation was initially named after Sir Henry Ayers, the eighth Premier of South Australia. It is composed of arkose, a type of sandstone rich in feldspar. It is a sacred site for the Anangu people, who believe it was created during the Dreamtime. Its surface appears to change color throughout the day, especially at dawn and dusk, due to the sunlight's angle and the rock's mineral composition. What is this large sandstone monolith in central Australia, a UNESCO World Heritage Site often referred to by its Aboriginal name?

Though it was initially conceived as a representation of Dante Alighieri, the poet of the "Divine Comedy," it later became a symbol of universal contemplation and human intellect. Originally part of Rodin's monumental sculptural group "The Gates of Hell," it depicts a nude male figure seated on a rock, deep in thought. Numerous casts of this sculpture exist worldwide, with the most famous one located at the Musée Rodin in Paris. What is this iconic bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin?

Calvin Coolidge is the only US president to have been born on this day. Three US presidents, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, and James Monroe, have died on this date which marks a US holiday. This holiday, established in 1776 to commemorate the signing of the Declaration of Independence, wasn't officially declared a federal holiday until 1870. Most historians have concluded that the Declaration was signed nearly a month after its adoption, on August 2, 1776, and not on this day as is commonly believed. Name this holday that is traditionally celebrated with parades, barbecues, and fireworks displays.

Though this TV show was initially canceled after three seasons, it was revived by Netflix for two additional seasons. Set in Newport Beach, California, it follows the dysfunctional Bluth family after their real estate business goes bankrupt. Known for its satirical humor, meta-references, and recurring jokes like "chicken dance" and "never nude," it features an ensemble cast including Jason Bateman, Portia de Rossi, and Will Arnett. What is this critically acclaimed comedy series narrated by Ron Howard?

This US soccer player was the youngest player to score 20 goals in a calendar year for the U.S. She became a two-time World Cup champion and Olympic gold medalist. Known for her signature "teapot" goal celebration and her advocacy for gender equality in sports, she co-captained the USWNT with Carli Lloyd and Megan Rapinoe from 2018 to 2020. Scoring her first World Cup goal in 2011, she gained early recognition as a member of the U.S. under-20 women's national soccer team. Which striker played for the San Diego Wave FC in 2023?

Though initially founded as a safe haven for English Catholics, it was the seventh state to ratify the U.S. Constitution. Home to Fort McHenry, it was the site of the Battle of Antietam, the bloodiest single-day battle in American history. Known for its blue crabs and Old Bay seasoning, its flag features the coats of arms of the Calvert and Crossland families. Which state is home to the U.S. Naval Academy?

Though it was initially revealed to the Prophet Muhammad over 23 years, it is divided into 114 chapters called surahs. Containing stories of prophets like Abraham, Moses, and Jesus, it also provides guidance on various aspects of life, including faith, worship, morality, and law. Written in classical Arabic, it is considered the holy book of Islam and the word of God. Which book is the central religious text of Islam, revered by Muslims worldwide?

This US state with 99 counties became the 29th state in 1846. Home to the National Mississippi River Museum & Aquarium, it is the only state bordered by two navigable rivers. Known for its rolling plains and cornfields, it is also home to the Bridges of Madison County. Name this state of 3 million people whose capital and most populous is Des Moines.

This politician called for a snap election to be held for the French Parliament on June 30 and July 7, 2024. This man served as Minister of Economics, Industry and Digital Affairs under President François Hollande from 2014 to 2016 and Deputy Secretary-General to the President from 2012 to 2014. He is a part of the Renaissance Party which he helped to found in 2016. Name this French politician who in 2017, was elected the 25th President of France becoming the youngest person to hold the position at age 39.

Founded in 1898 as the Morgan Athletic Club in Chicago, this team is the oldest continuously operating professional American football club. They relocated to St. Louis in 1960 and then to Arizona in 1988. Their mascot is Big Red, and their home stadium is State Farm Stadium, known for its retractable roof and field. They lost to the Pittsburgh Steelers in Super Bowl XLIII. Which NFL team is quarterbacked by Kyler Murray?

Though he initially embarked on a grand tour of Asia, he was forced to return home early after an assassination attempt in Japan. Known for his close relationship with his cousin, Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany, his reign saw the disastrous Russo-Japanese War and the Bloody Sunday massacre. Married to Alexandra Feodorovna, a granddaughter of Queen Victoria, he was the last Emperor of Russia. Who was overthrown in the February Revolution of 1917?

Though she initially gained recognition with hits like "Holiday" and "Borderline," her career skyrocketed with the release of her second album.  Known for her provocative image, elaborate stage shows, and numerous reinventions, she has sold over 300 million records worldwide. Appearing in films like "Desperately Seeking Susan" and "Evita," she has also been a successful businesswoman and fashion icon. Which singer's 1984 performance of "Like a Virgin" at the MTV Video Music Awards became a cultural phenomenon?

Though they primarily walk sideways, some species can also swim. Their exoskeleton is made of chitin, and they must molt to grow. They belong to the order Decapoda, meaning "ten-footed," and their claws are modified legs. Known for their pincers and ability to regenerate lost limbs, what are these crustaceans found in oceans, freshwater, and on land?

Though it is the smallest and shallowest of the world's oceans, it is home to a diverse range of marine life, including polar bears, walruses, and narwhals. Covered in sea ice for most of the year, its central surface is covered by a perennial drifting polar ice pack. It is surrounded by landmasses such as Greenland, Canada, Alaska, Russia, and Norway. Which ocean is home to the North Pole?

This Great Lake is home to over 30,000 islands, including Manitoulin Island, the world's largest freshwater island. It experiences a unique weather phenomenon known as "lake effect snow," which can produce heavy snowfall in the surrounding areas. Its name comes from a Native American tribe that inhabited the region. Name this lake, a crucial route for fur traders and explorers during the early European settlement of North America, which is the second-largest Great Lake by surface area.

This state, not Illinois, was the birthplace of Abraham Lincoln in 1809, and it was also home to Fort Knox, established in 1918, which houses a significant portion of the United States' gold reserves. The state's Mammoth Cave National Park, established in 1941, is the world's longest known cave system.  Daniel Boone, a famous frontiersman, blazed a trail through the Cumberland Gap into this state in 1775, opening it up to westward expansion. Name this state with a capital of Frankfort.

This musician, nicknamed "the quiet Beatle," developed a keen interest in Indian music and spirituality, incorporating sitar and other Indian instruments into his band's music. He wrote several popular songs for The Beatles, including "Here Comes the Sun" and "Something." After the band's breakup, he launched a successful solo career, releasing albums like "All Things Must Pass." Who was this influential musician, known for his distinctive slide guitar style and exploration of diverse musical genres?

This athlete transitioned from judo to mixed martial arts (MMA) after winning a bronze medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. In MMA, she became the first UFC Women's Bantamweight Champion, known for her signature armbar submission. She was also the first woman inducted into the UFC Hall of Fame. Who is this athlete, who also acted in the film Furious 7?

This Shakespearean play, believed to be his last solo work, features a sorcerer named Prospero who conjures a storm to shipwreck his enemies on a remote island. It explores themes of revenge, forgiveness, and colonialism through characters like Ariel, a spirit, and Caliban, a native islander. It includes a famous quote about the world being a stage and life being but a fleeting dream. What is the title of this play, notable for its magical elements and complex characters?

This 1683 battle marked the furthest westward advance of the Ottoman Empire in Europe. Polish King John III Sobieski led the defending forces, utilizing a massive cavalry charge involving over 20,000 horsemen. The siege lasted for two months and resulted in the defeat of the Ottomans, halting their expansion into Europe. What is the name of this battle, named for the capital of Austria, considered a turning point in European history?

This company has come under scrutiny for quality and manufacturing problems related to their largest commercial product. Initially establishing its headquarters in Seattle, Washington, it was founded in 1916. Known for iconic aircraft like the 747 "Jumbo Jet" and the 787 Dreamliner, it merged with McDonnell Douglas in 1997. Currently headquartered in Arlington, Virginia, it is a major player in both commercial and defense aviation. What is this American multinational corporation that designs, manufactures, and sells airplanes, rotorcraft, rockets, satellites, and missiles worldwide?

This bird of prey, which can live up to 30 years in the wild, plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of aquatic ecosystems. It can dive at speeds of up to 100 miles per hour and its nests, called aeries, are often reused and added to each year. Its scientific name, Haliaeetus leucocephalus, comes from Greek words meaning "sea eagle" and "white head." It is not closely related to other eagles found in Europe and Asia. What is the name of this bird, a national symbol of the United States, known for its white head and tail feathers?

This animal, whose scientific name is Equus caballus, has a single toe on each foot, protected by a hoof, and its teeth continually erupt throughout its lifetime. It is a herbivore with a digestive system adapted for grazing, and its eyes are positioned on the sides of its head, providing a wide field of vision. This animal has played a significant role in human history, used for transportation, agriculture, and warfare. What is the name of this majestic creature, known for its speed, strength, and intelligence?

This athlete made her professional tennis debut in 1995 at the Bell Challenge and won her first Grand Slam title at the US Open in 1999. She has won a record 13 Grand Slam doubles titles with her sister. She holds the Open Era record for most Grand Slam singles titles, with 23 wins. She also won four Olympic gold medals, one in singles and three in doubles. Who is this dominant American tennis player, considered one of the greatest athletes of all time?

This country, known for its comic book tradition, has produced internationally acclaimed works like The Adventures of Tintin and The Smurfs. It is also home to the Atomium, a giant model of an iron crystal built for the 1958 Brussels World's Fair.  The country is divided into three distinct regions: Flanders, Wallonia, and Brussels, each with its own language and cultural identity. What is the name of this country, famous for its waffles, chocolate, and beer, located in Western Europe?

This writer, while studying medicine at I.M. Sechenov First Moscow State Medical University, wrote short stories under the pseudonym Antosha Chekhonte. He wrote about the lives of ordinary people in late 19th-century Russia, often with a melancholic and humorous tone. Some of his most famous works include "The Seagull," "Uncle Vanya," and "The Cherry Orchard." Who was this Russian playwright and short-story writer, considered a master of realism and a major influence on modern theater?

This puzzle toy celebrated its 50th birthday in 2024. It was most popular in the 1980s, when it was estimated that one-fifth of the world's population had tried it. The was originally called the Magic Cube, but it now bears the name of its inventor, a Hungarian sculptor and architecture professor. Consisting of 26 smaller cubes, or "cubies," each of the six faces is covered by nine stickers, each of one of six solid colors. Name this this puzzle which requires the solver to strategize to return it to a state where each face shows a single solid color.

This famous civil rights leader was imprisoned for larceny and breaking and entering in 1946. While in prison, he joined the Nation of Islam and became a vocal advocate for Black nationalism. He later made a pilgrimage to Mecca, which led to a shift in his views towards racial reconciliation. Name this civil rights leader, assassinated in 1965, who changed his surname to a single letter to symbolize his rejection of his slave name.

This British band, known for their elaborate stage shows and philosophical lyrics, rose to prominence during the psychedelic rock era of the 1960s. They are renowned for their use of experimental sounds, extended compositions, and concept albums. Their iconic albums, including "The Dark Side of the Moon" and "The Wall," explored themes of alienation, madness, and social critique. Who is this influential band, whose members included Roger Waters, David Gilmour, Nick Mason, and Syd Barrett, considered pioneers of progressive rock?

Born on the island of Corsica in 1769, this military and political leader rose to power during the French Revolution. He crowned himself Emperor of the French in 1804. His military campaigns, including victories at Austerlitz and Jena-Auerstedt, led to the establishment of the French Empire across much of Europe. Who was this influential figure, ultimately defeated at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815, who left a lasting impact on European history?

The opening theme for this podcast is composed by the musical duo Wonderly, which constists of Jim Brunberg and Ben Landsverk. Launched in 2017 as an extension of "The Run-Up," this news podcast quickly garnered a massive following, reaching one million listeners a day within a year. Hosted by Michael Barbaro and Sabrina Tavernise, its weekday episodes typically feature interviews with New York Times journalists about a topical news story. What is the name of this popular podcast?

This state was the site a series of violent confrontations between pro-slavery and anti-slavery forces in the 1850s. It is also known for its significant role in the civil rights movement, as the location of the landmark Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court case in 1954. Amelia Earhart was born in this state in 1897, and it is home to the Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum.  Which state is this, nicknamed "The Sunflower State"?

This epic poem tells the story of the Trojan War, focusing on the wrath of Achilles and his conflict with Agamemnon. It features iconic characters like Hector, Paris, and Helen of Troy, and includes scenes such as the duel between Hector and Achilles and the Trojan Horse stratagem. What is the name of this ancient Greek epic poem, traditionally attributed to Homer, considered one of the foundational works of Western literature?

This Egyptian pharaoh, known as Ozymandias in Greek, had a reign that lasted for 66 years and is believed to have fathered over 100 children. He led his armies in the Battle of Kadesh against the Hittites, resulting in the earliest known peace treaty. He also ordered the construction of the Abu Simbel temples. Who was this pharaoh, often considered one of the greatest rulers of ancient Egypt?

This Martin Scorsese film, set in South Boston, follows an undercover cop infiltrating an Irish-American organized crime ring and a mole leaking information to the mob. It won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director. The film's soundtrack features "I'm Shipping Up to Boston" by the Dropkick Murphys. Starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon, and Jack Nicholson, it is known for its intense plot twists and gritty portrayal of Boston's criminal underworld. What is the name of this critically acclaimed crime thriller?

This insect, which has existed for over 320 million years, can survive for up to a week without its head. It can hold its breath for 40 minutes and run up to three miles per hour. Its exoskeleton contains chitin, a tough, protective substance also found in the shells of crustaceans. There are over 4,000 species of this insect worldwide, but only about 30 are considered pests. What is the name of this resilient creature, often associated with unsanitary conditions?

This mountain range is the source of the Garonne River, which flows through southwestern France. It is home to a special desman, a semi-aquatic mammal found nowhere else in the world. This range played a crucial role in the Reconquista, the centuries-long Christian effort to reclaim the Iberian Peninsula from Muslim rule. It also forms a natural border between Spain and France, and is home to Andorra, a small independent principality. What is the name of this mountain range?

This team, founded in 1901 as the Washington Senators, relocated in 1961 and adopted their current name. Their home stadium, Target Field, opened in 2010 and features a unique limestone façade. They have won three World Series championships, in 1924, 1987, and 1991. They are known for their "Bomba Squad" nickname, referring to their powerful offense and home run hitting ability. What is the name of this Minnesota Major League Baseball team, whose mascot are named T.C. and Minnie?

This artist found his breakthrough with the painting "House by the Railroad" in 1925. His wife, Jo Nivison, was not only his life partner but also his muse and model for many of his paintings. He is best known for his depictions of solitary figures in urban settings, such as "Nighthawks" and "Automat." Who is this American realist painter, considered a master of capturing the mood and atmosphere of modern life?

This athlete, born in Sherwood Content, Jamaica, briefly played professional soccer after retiring from track. He achieved a "triple-triple," winning gold medals in the 100m, 200m, and 4x100m relay at three consecutive Olympic Games. He holds world records in both the 100m and 200m sprints, and his 100m record of 9.58 seconds has stood since 2009. Who is this athlete, considered the fastest person ever recorded?

This movement began in 1517 with the posting of the "Ninety-Five Theses," criticizing the Catholic Church's sale of indulgences. It led to the establishment of new Christian denominations like Lutheranism and Calvinism, emphasizing salvation through faith alone. The printing press played a crucial role in spreading this movement's ideas, leading to widespread religious and political upheaval across Europe. What was this 16th-century movement that challenged the Catholic Church's authority?

This politician was a Democrat from Tennesse and a vocal opponent of the Fourteenth Amendment. He served as a tailor's apprentice before his political career. He often clashed with Radical Republicans over Reconstruction which led him to be the first president to be impeached by the House of Representatives. Name this 17th US President who ascended to the presidency upon Lincoln's assassination.

These bones come in five distinct types: cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal. They are connected by facet joints and discs, allowing for flexibility and shock absorption, and they protect the spinal cord. While humans typically have 33 of these bones, the number can vary slightly from person to person. What are these individual bones that make up the backbone and support the body's structure?

This Great Lake, the smallest by surface area, is the only one that does not border the state of Michigan. It holds four times the water volume of Lake Erie and has the lowest mean surface elevation of all the Great Lakes. Home to the Thousand Islands region, an archipelago of nearly 2,000 islands, this lake was formed by glacial activity during the last ice age. What is the name of this lake, the easternmost of the Great Lakes, that borders both Canada and the United States?

This political commenator reported to prison on July 1, 2024 after being sentenced to four months in prison for contempt of Congress in 2022. This man was the acting director of the research project Biosphere 2 in 1993, and he served as an executive producer of 18 films from 1991 to 2016. He served as the White House's chief strategist for the first seven months of U.S. president Donald Trump's presidency. Name this man who helped found Breitbart news and served on the board of the Cambridge Analytica.

The TV show's theme song, "Frolic," was composed by Luciano Michelini, and its title is a satirical response to the excessive enthusiasm often seen in American society. The HBO comedy series, co-created by and starring Larry David, the co-creator of Seinfeld, is known for its semi-improvised dialogue and cringe humor. What is the name of this critically acclaimed show, which follows the misadventures of a semi-retired television writer and producer in Los Angeles?

This artist apprenticed under Filippo Lippi and was commissioned by the Medici family to paint several works, including portraits of family members. His most famous works, "The Birth of Venus" and "Primavera," depict mythological scenes with graceful figures and intricate details. Who is this Italian Renaissance painter, known for his contributions to the Early Renaissance style in Florence?

This man was born into a Muslim family in the Yunnan Province of China and was captured and castrated as a young boy, later becoming a trusted advisor to the Yongle Emperor. He commanded seven voyages across the Indian Ocean with a fleet of over 300 ships and 28,000 crew members. His expeditions were known for their massive treasure ships. Who is this Chinese explorer, diplomat, and fleet admiral, considered a key figure in China's maritime history during the Ming dynasty?

This inland sea, named for its hydrogen sulfide layer, is connected to the Mediterranean Sea through the Bosporus Strait and the Sea of Marmara. It is bordered by six countries and is a vital waterway for trade and transportation. Ancient Greek colonists once called it the "Inhospitable Sea." Which sea is this, known for its sturgeon population and its role in the geopolitical landscape of Eastern Europe and Western Asia?

This British politician was elected prime minister on July 4, 2024. He was born in London in 1962 and grew up in Surrey. In 2014, he was appointed Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath for his services to law and criminal justice. He has been Member of Parliament for Holborn and St Pancras since 2015. Name this man who has served as the leader of the Labour Party since 2020.

This Netflix political thriller, a remake of a 1990 British miniseries, was the first original series produced for the streaming platform. It follows Frank Underwood, a ruthless politician who manipulates his way to power, and his equally ambitious wife, Claire. Starring Kevin Spacey, Robin Wright, and Michael Kelly, it garnered critical acclaim and numerous award nominations. What is the name of this show, known for its dark and cynical portrayal of Washington, D.C. politics?

This state was home to the Coeur d'Alene people for thousands of years before European explorers arrived. It was admitted to the Union as the 43rd state in 1890 and is known for its vast wilderness areas, including the Frank Church–River of No Return Wilderness, the largest contiguous wilderness area in the contiguous United States. This state's capital is Boise and it was the site of the controversial Ruby Ridge incident in 1992. Which state is this, nicknamed the "Gem State?"

This Scottish-born inventor, inspired by his mother and wife's hearing impairments, initially focused on improving devices for the deaf. He founded the Volta Laboratory, where he collaborated with other scientists on various inventions. He experimented with aeronautics, developing early versions of hydrofoils and airplanes, but he is best known as the inventor of the telephone. Who was this prolific inventor, a founding member of the National Geographic Society?

This team, founded in 1968, starting playing at the Fiserv Forum in 2018. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, formerly known as Lew Alcindor, led this team to their first NBA championship in 1971. In 2021, Giannis Antetokounmpo, nicknamed the "Greek Freak," led this team to their second NBA championship, earning the Finals MVP award. What is the name of this NBA team, known for their green and cream uniforms?

This actor, known for his distinctive method acting style, received an Academy Award nomination for his breakthrough role as Michael Corleone. He is famous for his passionate delivery of lines like "Say hello to my little friend!" in "Scarface." A recipient of the "Triple Crown of Acting," he has won numerous awards, including an Oscar, two Tonys, and two Emmys. Who is this legendary actor, known for his roles in iconic films like "Serpico" and "Dog Day Afternoon"?

This body of water, containing over 250 small islands, islets, and reefs, is a crucial shipping route, with over $3 trillion in trade passing through it annually. Its Spratly Islands are claimed by six different countries, leading to ongoing territorial disputes. Historically, it was a major trade route for Chinese, Indian, and Arab merchants. What is the name of this marginal sea, a major source of geopolitical tension in Southeast Asia?

This author's debut novel, "Go Tell It on the Mountain," explored his religious upbringing in Harlem. His essay "The Fire Next Time" became a powerful meditation on race and religion in the United States. A close friend of Maya Angelou and Toni Morrison, he often explored themes of identity, sexuality, and social injustice. Who was this influential American writer?

This athlete wore the number 99, was nicknamed "The Great One," and began his NHL career with the Edmonton Oilers. He holds the record for most goals and assists in NHL history, with a combined total of 2,857 points. He won four Stanley Cup championships with the Edmonton Oilers and was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy twice. He was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1999. Who is this legendary Canadian ice hockey player, widely regarded as the greatest of all time?

This Italian physicist invented the first electric battery in 1800, known as the voltaic pile, by stacking discs of copper and zinc. He engaged in a scientific rivalry with Luigi Galvani, whose experiments with frogs led to the discovery of animal electricity. The unit of electric potential is named after him. Who was this pioneer in the study of electrical phenomena?

This pop star has a claim to the song of the summer with her hit, "Espresso". The former child actress, who started her musical journey posting covers on YouTube, gained initial recognition for her role in the Disney Channel series "Girl Meets World."  With hits like "Nonsense" and "Skin," which became her first entry on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, this singer-songwriter has cemented her status as a rising star. Who is this pop star?

This battle, one of the final major offensives of World War II in Europe, began on April 16, 1945. It involved over 2.5 million Soviet soldiers and 6,250 tanks, making it one of the largest battles in history. During this battle, Adolf Hitler committed suicide in his Führerbunker. The city's defenders surrendered on May 2, 1945, marking the end of the battle and a significant turning point in the war. What was the name of this battle, which ultimately led to the collapse of Nazi Germany?

This US state was the first home to the Ringling Brothers circus in 1884. Joseph McCarthy began his political career as a circuit judge in 1939 in this state, and the Republican Party was founded here in 1854. This state was historically home to the Menominee and Ho-Chunk tribes and has a capital of Madison. Name this state which is led by Governor Tony Evers.

This Southwestern city broke multiple heat records in July 2024, including reaching its highest temperature of 120 degrees Fahrenheit and having at least 7 days in a row above 115 degrees. The desert city, founded in 1905, is home to the iconic Fremont Street Experience, a pedestrian mall with a 1,500-foot-long LED canopy displaying light shows. Name this city that experiences over 300 days of sunshine annually and is located in Clark County. It is known for iconic gambling and nightlife experiences.

This bustling Southeast Asian city is situated on the Chao Phraya River delta and is often referred to as the "Venice of the East" due to its network of canals. It is home to the Grand Palace, the official residence of the Thai monarch, as well as Wat Arun, a temple famous for its towering spires. Name this city that is about 25 miles from the Gulf of Thailand, that is also known for signature dishes like Pad Thai and Tom Yum Goong.

This Oxford professor, known for his high fantasy works, created the intricate world of Middle-earth, complete with detailed languages and histories. His experiences in World War I had a profound impact on his writing, often drawing parallels between the horrors of war and his characters', such as Frodo Baggins, struggles. His most famous novels, "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy, explore themes of good versus evil, the power of language, and the importance of nature. Who is this beloved author?

This Italian poet's love for Beatrice Portinari, whom he met as a child, is a recurring theme in his poetry. He was born in Florence in 1265 and was deeply involved in the city's political struggles, which led to his exile in 1302. He is best known for his epic poem which describes a journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise. Who is this influential figure in Italian literature and Renaissance thought, the author of the Divine Comedy?

This American heavy metal band, formed in Los Angeles in 1981, is considered one of the pioneers of thrash metal. Their early albums, including "Kill 'Em All" and "Ride the Lightning," showcased a raw and aggressive sound that helped to define the genre. They achieved mainstream success with their self-titled 1991 album, also known as "The Black Album," which featured the hit singles "Enter Sandman" and "Nothing Else Matters." Their music often deals with themes of social injustice, personal struggles, and addiction. Who is this iconic band that has sold over 125 million albums worldwide?

This NBA team reached the NBA Finals in 1995 led by Shaquille O'Neal and Penny Hardaway, but were swept by the Houston Rockets. In 2009, they made it back to the finals with Dwight Howard as their star player, but ultimately lost to the Los Angeles Lakers. The team's colors are blue, black, and silver, and their logo features a stylized basketball with a star. Which team was founded in 1989 and became the first major professional sports franchise in Central Florida?

Fluent in French and skilled in violin playing, this historical figure designed his own unique plow based on European models. He was a passionate advocate for religious freedom, leading to the passage of the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom. During his presidency, the Louisiana Purchase doubled the size of the United States, dramatically expanding its territory. Who is this Founding Father, best known for drafting the Declaration of Independence?

This mathematician collaborated with Charles Babbage on his Analytical Engine, a mechanical general-purpose computer. Her notes on the engine include what is now recognized as the first algorithm intended to be carried out by a machine. She, the daughter of the poet Lord Byron, is often credited as the world's first computer programmer. She recognized the potential of computers to go beyond mere calculation and envisioned their use for broader applications. Who is this pioneering figure in computer science?

This bone, the second longest in the human body, forms the medial part of the ankle joint and articulates with the femur at the knee joint. Its shaft is triangular in cross section and features several important landmarks, including a namesake tuberosity, which serves as the attachment point for the patellar ligament. Fractures of this bone are common, especially in athletes and individuals with osteoporosis. What is this weight-bearing bone that connects the knee to the ankle?

This religious figure is believed to have lived in ancient Persia, sometime between 1700 and 600 BCE, and his teachings are considered the foundation of one of the world's oldest religions. He is said to have received divine revelations from Ahura Mazda, the supreme god of his religion. His name is often associated with the concept of dualism, the eternal struggle between good and evil, which is a central theme in his religion, Zoroastrianism. Who is this prophet and founder of one of the world's oldest religions?

This city is nicknamed "Egoli," meaning "City of Gold," and was founded in 1886 following the discovery of gold on the Witwatersrand ridge. It is the largest city in South Africa by population and houses the Apartheid Museum and Constitution Hill, a former prison and military fort that now houses the Constitutional Court. Despite not being one of the three capitals of the country, it serves as the seat of the Constitutional Court. What is this economic and cultural hub of South Africa?

This politician graduated from Harvard Business School, worked in the oil industry, and owned the Texas Rangers before he served as the governor of Texas from 1995-2000. He was later elected president in an election which was contested in the Supreme Court and signed major tax cuts and the No Child Left Behind Act. Name this 43rd president of the United States who served from 2001-2009.

This NBA team was originally founded in Vancouver in 1995. They have a dedicated fan base known for their "Grit and Grind" mantra, reflecting the team's tough and tenacious playing style. They now have exciting young stars like Desmond Bane, Jaren Jackson Jr., and Ja Morant. What is this NBA team that plays their home games at the FedExForum in Memphis?

This Atlantic hurricane, the second of the 2024 season, rapidly intensified into a Category 5 storm, making it the earliest-forming Category 5 hurricane on record. It caused significant damage in the Caribbean, particularly in the Cayman Islands and Grenada, before making landfall as a Category 1 hurricane in Texas. It caused widespread power outages and flooding in Texas, and was responsible for multiple deaths. What was the name of this atypical hurricane, known for its rapid intensification and early formation in the season?

This American sitcom, which ran for nine seasons from 1989 to 1998, known for its observational humor, quirky characters, and catchphrases like "yada yada yada" and "master of my domain.". It is often described as "a show about nothing." It follows the daily lives of four friends living in New York City: Jerry, a stand-up comedian; George, his neurotic best friend; Elaine, his on-again, off-again girlfriend; and Cosmo, his eccentric neighbor. What is the name of this iconic sitcom that has left a lasting impact on American pop culture?

This French artist, known for his vibrant use of color and light, was a leading figure in the Impressionist movement. His paintings often depicted scenes of everyday life, such as dance halls, cafes, female figures, and portraits. His most famous works include "Bal du moulin de la Galette," "Luncheon of the Boating Party," and "The Bathers." Despite suffering from rheumatoid arthritis in his later years, he continued to paint prolifically. Who is this celebrated painter?

During this period of English history, the Domesday Book, a manuscript record of the "Great Survey" of much of England and parts of Wales, was completed. This historical event began in 1066 with the Battle of Hastings, where William the Conqueror defeated the Anglo-Saxon King Harold Godwinson. It led to profound changes in England's language, culture, and legal system, as Norman French became the language of the ruling class.

This famous Renaissance fresco, painted by Raphael between 1509 and 1511, is located in the Apostolic Palace in Vatican City. It depicts a gathering of ancient philosophers, mathematicians, and scientists engaged in lively discussion and debate. The central figures are Plato and Aristotle, representing the two main schools of ancient Greek philosophy. It is one of four frescoes in the Stanza della Segnatura, each representing a different branch of knowledge. What is the name of this iconic artwork, often considered a masterpiece of Renaissance art?

This Swiss city is situated at the northwestern tip of a lake bearing the same name. The Limmat River runs through it, offering picturesque views and recreational opportunities. Its well-preserved historic center features landmarks like the Grossmünster cathedral and the Fraumünster church. It is the largest city in the country by population and a major financial center, often considered one of the most livable cities in the world. Which city is this?

This US state, not Georgia, is the leading peach producer east of the Mississippi River and is home to the only tea plantation in the contiguous United States. This state also boasts the oldest landscaped gardens in America, Middleton Place, which dates back to 1741. The first state to secede from the Union, this state's flag features a palmetto tree and crescent moon, symbols stemming from the Revolutionary War defense of Fort Moultrie. What is this state?

This American rock band's self-titled debut album, released in 1967, reached number two on the Billboard 200 chart. Their music often explored themes of rebellion, freedom, and the dark side of the American dream. Their hit songs, including "Light My Fire," "Break on Through (To the Other Side)," and "Riders on the Storm," are considered classics of rock music. They are known for their psychedelic sound, poetic lyrics, and charismatic frontman, Jim Morrison. Who are they?

These invertebrates belong to several different phyla, including Annelida, Nematoda, and Platyhelminthes, and their body shape and size vary greatly depending on the species. Some are segmented and have a distinct head and tail, while others are ribbon-shaped and lack distinct body segments. While many are beneficial, some species can be parasitic and cause harm to plants and animals. Name these animals found in nearly all environments on Earth, that play a crucial role in maintaining soil health by aerating and enriching it.

This European prime minister met with former president Donald Trump after the July 2024 NATO Summit. This man leads the Fidesz political party and served as prime minister from 1998-2002. He was then re-elected to the office in 2010 and has held it since. In the wake of the Revolutions of 1989, this man entered politics after studying law at Eötvös Loránd University. Name this nationalistic prime minister of Hungary.

This NFL team, established in 1960, has won five Super Bowl championships and is known for its iconic star logo and enthusiastic fan base. They hold the NFL record for most consecutive winning seasons with 20. They play their home games at a state-of-the-art stadium in Arlington, Texas, and are one of the most valuable sports franchises in the world. Their rich history includes legendary players like Roger Staubach, Emmitt Smith, and Troy Aikman. What is this iconic American football team?

This Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, published in 1960, is set in a fictional Alabama town during the Great Depression. It is narrated from the perspective of a young girl named Scout Finch, who learns valuable lessons about racial injustice and prejudice through the experiences of her father, Atticus Finch, a lawyer defending a black man wrongly accused of rape. The novel deals with themes of morality, compassion, and the importance of standing up for what is right. What is the title of this classic American novel by Harper Lee?

This NFL team, established in 1999, replaced a previous franchise that had relocated to Tennessee. They began play as an expansion team in 2002, making them the youngest franchise currently competing in the NFL. The team's colors are Deep Steel Blue, Battle Red, and Liberty White, and their logo features a bull head with a star. They play their home games at NRG Stadium and are the only NFL team to have never appeared in a conference championship game. Which team is this, representing the fourth-largest city in the United States?

This 1777 battle, fought in upstate New York, was a major turning point in the American Revolutionary War. British General John Burgoyne's invasion from Canada was thwarted, leading to his surrender. The American victory boosted morale and convinced France to ally with the colonists. The battle consisted of two separate engagements, Freeman's Farm and Bemis Heights, fought eighteen days apart. What is the name of this significant Revolutionary War battle?

This drug manufactured by Novo Nordisk, was originally developed to treat type 2 diabetes. It mimics a naturally occurring hormone that regulates appetite and metabolism, leading to decreased food intake and increased calorie burning. While lauded for its effectiveness in managing obesity, this injectable drug has also faced scrutiny for potential side effects like nausea and pancreatitis. Name this that medication gained notoriety in 2023 due to its off-label use for weight loss.

These small canids, found on every continent except Antarctica, are known for their intelligence and distinctive bushy tails. They are opportunistic omnivores, with a diet that includes rodents, rabbits, fruits, and insects. Many species exhibit seasonal changes in coat color, and some, like the fennec variety, have adaptations for surviving in extreme desert environments. What are these resourceful and versatile mammals, often featured in folklore and mythology?

This US state played a crucial role in the development of the American ski industry, with the first ski lift being installed in Gunstock Mountain Resort in 1937. The first colony to declare its independence from British rule, this state's motto, "Live Free or Die," is prominently displayed on its license plates. Home to the tallest peak in the northeastern United States, Mount Washington, what is this state with a capital of Concord?

This major African river has a unique "boomerang" shape, flowing in a wide arc through several West African countries. Its source is in the Guinea Highlands, and it travels northeast into the Sahara Desert before turning southeast and eventually emptying into the Gulf of Guinea. Its fertile basin supports a wide variety of plant and animal life, and its annual floods play a crucial role in agriculture. Which river, the third longest in Africa, is a vital lifeline of West Africa?

This Italian film, set during the Holocaust, combines comedy and drama to tell the story of a Jewish man who uses his imagination and humor to shield his son from the horrors of a concentration camp. The film is partly inspired by Rubino Romeo Salmoni's book, "In the End, I Beat Hitler". The film won three Academy Awards, including Best Foreign Language Film and Best Actor for Roberto Benigni, who also directed and co-wrote the screenplay. Which film, with the italian title La vita è bella, is praised for its heartwarming message and unique approach to a difficult subject matter?

This monarch's desire for a male heir led to the establishment of the Church of England, after his request for an annulment from his first wife was denied by the Pope. Known for his athleticism in his youth, he later became corpulent and suffered from a leg ulcer. He was a patron of the arts and an accomplished musician, even composing a few pieces himself. During his reign, he had six wives, two of whom were executed. Who is this infamous king?

This inventor's Wardenclyffe Tower project, aimed at wireless power transmission, was never completed due to funding issues. He developed the AC induction motor, which is widely used today, and held over 300 patents for various inventions. He engaged in a rivalry with Thomas Edison over the best type of electrical current for widespread use. Born in what is now Croatia, he immigrated to the United States in 1884 and became a naturalized citizen. Who is this pioneering figure in electrical engineering?

This naval base was bombed by Japanese forces on December 7, 1941, resulting in the deaths of an estimated 2,403 Americans and over 3,800 civilians. The attack on this base sank or heavily damaged twelve U.S. Navy ships, including eight battleships, and destroyed 188 U.S. aircraft. The attack on this base ultimately led to the United States' entry into World War II. Name this base which was the subject of the "Day of Infany Speech."

This city, situated on the Yamuna River, is home to the Red Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that served as the residence of Mughal emperors. It is also home to the Jama Masjid, one of the largest mosques in India, and the Lotus Temple, a Baháʼí House of Worship known for its distinctive lotus-shaped structure. This city has served as the capital of several empires and kingdoms throughout history, including the the Mughal Empire. What is the name of this bustling metropolis that is the capital of India?

This Major League Baseball team, originally established in 1961, briefly went by the name "California" before reverting to its original city in its official title in 2005. Their home stadium, in Anaheim, is one of the oldest active ballparks in the MLB. The team's sole World Series victory came in 2002, with a roster featuring players like Troy Glaus and Garret Anderson. What is this team, previos home to two-way sensation Shohei Ohtani, and currently rostering Mike Trout?

This film's iconic shower scene, featuring Bernard Herrmann's screeching violin score, is considered one of the most terrifying moments in cinematic history. Shot in black and white to avoid excessive gore, it took seven days to film. The film's protagonist, Marion Crane, is killed off surprisingly early, defying traditional storytelling conventions. The film's antagonist, Norman Bates, is a motel owner with a deeply disturbed psyche and an unhealthy obsession with his mother. What is the title of this 1960 Alfred Hitchcock thriller that redefined the horror genre?

In this state, a gunman shot at former president Donald Trump while he was holding a campaign rally. The rally was being held near the town of Butler in this state. Prior to becoming a state, the southeast portion of the state was a Swedish Empire colony known as New Sweden between 1638 and 1655. The state is home to cities like Allentown and Reading. Name this state, the fifth largest by population, which is nicknamed the Keystone State.

This play, set in late 1940s Brooklyn, follows the final days of Willy Loman, an aging salesman struggling with disillusionment and despair. The play delves into Willy's fractured relationships with his sons, Biff and Happy, and his wife, Linda, as he grapples with his failures and regrets. It critiques the American Dream and its emphasis on material success and popularity. What is the title of this Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Arthur Miller?

Premiering in 1938, this play, set in the fictional town of Grover's Corners, New Hampshire, explores the universal themes of life, love, and death through the everyday lives of its inhabitants. It features a Stage Manager who narrates the action and interacts with the audience, breaking the fourth wall. This play won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama in 1938 and has become a classic of American theater. What is the title of this three-act play?

This lawyer from Illinois engaged in a series of debates with Stephen Douglas in 1858, focusing on the issue of slavery's expansion. Though he lost the Senate race that year, these debates elevated his national profile, contributing to his successful presidential bid two years later. During these debates, he famously stated, "A house divided against itself cannot stand." Who is this historical figure known for his beard and stovepipe hat?

Early in this philosopher's career, he worked as a journalist, often writing about social and economic issues. His most ambitious work, "Das Kapital," remained unfinished at the time of his death. He collaborated with Friedrich Engels on numerous projects, including the seminal work "The Communist Manifesto." Who is this influential thinker whose ideas have shaped political and economic discourse for generations?

Former president Donald Trump chose this senator to be his vice presidential running mate for the 2024 election. He served in the Marine Corps during the Iraq war before going to Ohio State and then Yale Law School. Prior to becoming a senator for the state of Ohio, he was best known for his memoir which described his troubled upbringing in Middletown, Ohio. Name this author of Hillbilly Elegy.

This TV show, known for its mockumentary style, follows the lives of three interconnected families living in Los Angeles. It features an ensemble cast with memorable characters like Phil Dunphy, the goofy dad, and Jay Pritchett, the patriarch. Winning 22 Primetime Emmy Awards, it tackled themes like adoption, same-sex marriage, and cultural differences. What is the name of this critically acclaimed sitcom that aired for 11 seasons?

This team, initially known as the Montreal Expos, relocated to the United States in 2005. Their mascot, Screech the Eagle, was chosen through a fan contest in 2005.  The team secured their first World Series championship in 2019, becoming the first team in MLB history to win all road games in a World Series. What is the name of this baseball team that plays its home games in Washington, D.C.?

This element, isolated by Daniel Rutherford in 1772, was originally named "noxious air" due to its inability to support life. It exists as a diatomic gas under standard conditions and is relatively inert, making it useful for preserving food and other materials. This element is a key component of amino acids, the building blocks of proteins, and is essential for plant growth. What is this element that makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere?

This city, situated on the northern tip of the North China Plain, is surrounded by mountains on three sides, giving it a strategic location throughout history. Home to the Forbidden City, a vast palace complex that served as the imperial palace for centuries, it also boasts the Temple of Heaven, a UNESCO World Heritage Site where emperors prayed for good harvests. In 2008, it hosted the Summer Olympics, showcasing its modern infrastructure and cultural heritage. What is the name of this city, the capital of China and one of the world's most populous cities?

This former Pakistani prime minister has been accused of treason by the government of his political rival, Shehbaz Sharif. On July 13, while this politician was imprisoned, his conviction for a breach of national marriage laws was overturned on appeal. However, he remains in prison on corruptions charges. Before this man served as prime minister he was the captain of Pakistan's national cricket team in the 1980s and 1990s, including for Pakistan's 1992 World Cup victory. Name this man who leads Pakistan's PTI party.

This geological formation, consisting of approximately 40,000 interlocking basalt columns, is the result of an ancient volcanic eruption. Located on the coast of County Antrim in Northern Ireland, it was declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1986. This natural wonder, featured in legends as a crossing built by the giant Fionn mac Cumhaill, is a popular tourist attraction known for its unique hexagonal columns. What is this natural wonder called?

This author's debut novel, "The Bluest Eye," explored the damaging effects of racism and beauty standards on a young black girl. She was the first African-American woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, awarded for her profound exploration of African-American identity and experience. Her most celebrated work, "Beloved," tells the story of a former slave haunted by the ghost of her daughter. This author also served as an editor at Random House, where she championed the works of many Black writers. Who is this influential novelist and essayist?

This band, formed in Los Angeles in 1983, is known for their eclectic mix of funk, rock, and punk music. Their breakthrough album, "Blood Sugar Sex Magik," released in 1991, catapulted them to international fame. Their iconic logo, a stylized asterisk, has become synonymous with their brand. They have won six Grammy Awards and were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2012. What is the name of this band, known for hits like "Under the Bridge" and "Californication"?

This NFL team, founded in 1960, holds the unfortunate distinction of losing four consecutive Super Bowls between 1990 and 1993. Led by quarterback Jim Kelly and running back Thurman Thomas during their Super Bowl runs, they were known for their high-powered "K-Gun" offense. The team's name was inspired by an All-America Football Conference (AAFC) franchise that played in the same city. Name this team that plays its home games at Highmark Stadium in Orchard Park, New York.

This monarch's reign saw the rise of the British Empire, the Industrial Revolution, and significant social reforms. During her time, Britain abolished slavery, expanded suffrage, and saw advancements in science and technology. She was the first British monarch to travel by train and to be photographed. Known for her strict moral code and devotion to her husband, Prince Albert, she mourned his death for the rest of her life, wearing black until her own passing. Who is this iconic queen?

Found on every continent except Antarctica, this type of bird is known for its ability to mimic human speech and other sounds. With over 350 species, this bird is found in a variety of habitats, from rainforests to deserts. Some species of this bird can live for over 50 years, and many form strong pair bonds with their mates. What is this colorful and intelligent bird known for its curved beak and zygodactyl feet (two toes facing forward and two toes facing backward)?

This city was bombed by a B-29 Superfortress bomber named "Enola Gay" which was piloted by Colonel Paul Tibbets. The bombing of this city resulted in the immediate deaths of an estimated 80,000 people, with tens of thousands more dying later from radiation exposure. This mission was the first use of a nuclear weapon in warfare, leading to Japan's surrender and the end of World War II. It was also a turning point in history, marking the beginning of the Atomic Age. Name this city which was bombed by an atomic bomb nicknamed "Little Boy."

This painting, depicting the Infanta Margarita and her entourage, is known for its complex composition and enigmatic atmosphere. It features a self-portrait of the artist at work on a large canvas, the back of which is visible to the viewer. The painting also includes a mirror reflecting the image of King Philip IV and Queen Mariana, suggesting their presence in the room. What is the title of this famous masterpiece by Diego Velázquez?

This iconic peak, whose name means "meadow peak" in German, has four distinct faces aligned almost perfectly with the cardinal directions. Located on the border between Switzerland and Italy, it stands at 4,478 meters (14,692 feet) tall. The mountain's distinctive pyramidal shape has been featured in numerous works of art and literature and has become synonymous with the Swiss Alps. The first successful ascent of this mountain took place in 1865, but it resulted in tragedy as four climbers died during the descent. What is the name of this iconic mountain?

This state, once part of Massachusetts, became the 23rd to join the Union in 1820 as part of the Missouri Compromise. It's famous for its rocky coastline, lobster industry, and is the easternmost point in the contiguous United States. Additionally, it's the only state with a one-syllable name and the only state that borders just one other state. Name this state.

This inventor's most famous creation, a safer alternative to nitroglycerin, was initially used for mining and construction but also found applications in warfare. He held 355 patents for various inventions, including synthetic rubber and leather. He was a polyglot, fluent in six languages, and had a lifelong interest in literature and philosophy. Upon his death, he bequeathed his fortune to establish the prestigious awards that bear his name. Who is this inventor and philanthropist?

This city hosted the 2024 Republican National Convention. This city is home to the world's largest music festival, Summerfest, and also boasts a rich brewing history, earning it the nickname "Brew City."  Additionally, it is home to the Harley-Davidson Museum, showcasing the legacy of the famous motorcycle brand. Name this city on Lake Michigan's shores which is also known for its iconic Bronze Fonz statue, a tribute to the popular character from the TV show "Happy Days."

This film, featuring a wormhole near Saturn, explores a future where humanity seeks a new home due to Earth's deteriorating environment. The film's scientific advisor, Kip Thorne, ensured the accurate depiction of black holes and gravitational time dilation. A key plot point revolves around the protagonist's daughter, who ages much slower than him due to the effects of relativity. What is the title of this 2014 science fiction film directed by Christopher Nolan?

This NFL team, established in 1919, is the only community-owned franchise in the league. It boasts the most NFL championships with 13 wins, including four Super Bowl titles. Coached by the legendary Vince Lombardi during their first two Super Bowl victories, they were the only team to defeat the AFL before the merger. Name this historic team that plays at Lambeau Field, nicknamed the "Frozen Tundra."

Convened in response to the Protestant Reformation, this council addressed doctrinal challenges and aimed to reform the Catholic Church from within. Held in three sessions over eighteen years in a city in Northern Italy, it reaffirmed traditional Catholic teachings on salvation, the sacraments, and the authority of the Pope. This council also established seminaries for the education of priests and sought to address abuses within the clergy. What was this significant council in Catholic history?

This artist released his debut album at age 12 with Motown Records. He's a talented multi-instrumentalist, playing the harmonica, piano, and drums. He won an Academy Award for Best Original Song for "I Just Called to Say I Love You" from the film "The Woman in Red." A strong advocate for social justice, he campaigned to make Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a national holiday. Who is this legendary musician known for hits like "Superstition" and "Signed, Sealed, Delivered I'm Yours?"

This athlete's number 42 was retired across all of Major League Baseball in 1997, a first for any professional sport. Before breaking the color barrier in baseball, he served in the U.S. Army during World War II. He won the inaugural Rookie of the Year Award in 1947 and was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962. Who is this legendary Brooklyn Dodger?

This region's inhabitants developed the first known written language, cuneiform, used to record everything from laws and religious texts to epic poems like the "Epic of Gilgamesh." It is also home to the ancient city of Babylon, known for its Hanging Gardens, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Situated between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, it is often called the "cradle of civilization." What is this historical region in the Middle East?

This protest movement, sparked by the financial crisis of 2007-2008, began in Zuccotti Park in New York City's Financial District and quickly spread across the United States and globally. Protesters criticized income inequality, corporate greed, and the influence of money in politics, adopting the slogan "We are the 99%." While the occupation of Zuccotti Park ended after two months, this movement's impact on political discourse and activism continues to be felt today. What was the name of this movement?

This former lawyer and military general participated in the War of 1812 and led American forces in the Battle of New Orleans. He was known for his populist appeal and his support for the common man, earning him the nickname "Old Hickory." His presidency was marked by the Indian Removal Act, which led to the forced displacement of Native American tribes in what is now known as the Trail of Tears. Who was this controversial figure who served as the seventh president of the United States?

This shallow body of water, bordered by eight countries including Iran, Iraq, and Saudi Arabia, is a vital waterway for global oil transportation. It is home to numerous islands, including Bahrain, and its warm waters support diverse marine life, such as dugongs and hawksbill turtles. Its strategic importance has led to conflicts, including the Iran-Iraq War and the Gulf War. What is this body of water called?

This organ, inhabited by trillions of bacteria collectively known as the gut microbiota, plays a crucial role in the final stages of digestion. It is also involved in the synthesis of certain vitamins, including vitamin K and some B vitamins. It is responsible for absorbing water and electrolytes from indigestible food matter, forming stool. Divided into four main sections: the cecum, colon, rectum, and anal canal. What is this organ?

This collection of Middle Eastern folk tales, narrated by Scheherazade to King Shahryar, features a vast array of characters like Sinbad the Sailor, Aladdin, and Ali Baba. Its stories, originating from various cultures including Persian, Indian, and Arabic, were compiled over centuries. The frame story involves Scheherazade using her storytelling to delay her execution, keeping the king captivated for almost three years. What is the name of this famous collection?
incorrect2: The Book of the New Sun

question: This sea, home to the deepest point in the Atlantic Ocean, is known for its crystal-clear turquoise waters and white-sandy beaches. It is also a major shipping route, with the Panama Canal connecting it to the Pacific Ocean. Its islands are known for their vibrant cultures, diverse ecosystems, and rich history, including a significant period of European colonialism and the transatlantic slave trade. What is the name of this sea, a popular tourist destination and an important part of the world's ecosystem?

This NBA team achieved its first playoff series victory in 2008, led by Chris Paul, and most recently made the playoffs in 2022 with a roster headlined by Zion Williamson and Brandon Ingram. The team, originally the Charlotte Hornets, relocated to New Orleans in 2002 before adopting their current name in 2013, inspired by the state bird. What is the name of this team, whose colors of navy blue, red, and gold represent the city's Mardi Gras celebrations?

This ruler's reign was marked by the establishment of the oprichnina, a state police force known for its brutality and reign of terror. He came to power at the age of three and was crowned tsar at sixteen. He expanded the Russian territory significantly, conquering Kazan and Astrakhan Khanates. He is also known for his volatile temper and violent outbursts, which earned him his infamous nickname. Who is this first Tsar of Russia?

This mountain, a training ground for climbers preparing for Himalayan expeditions, had five climbers die within one week at the beginning of its climbing season. The active volcano, last erupting in 1707, is the highest peak in its home nation. It is considered one of its nation's "Three Holy Mountains" and is a UNESCO World Heritage site. Its iconic snow-capped peak has been depicted in countless works of art and is a popular tourist destination. What is the name of this stratovolcano located in Japan?

Financed by both state and federal government bonds, as well as by company-issued mortgage bonds, this ambitious project was completed on May 10, 1869, at Promontory Summit, Utah, with the ceremonial driving of a golden spike. It connected the existing eastern U.S. rail network at Council Bluffs, Iowa, with the Pacific coast at the Oakland Long Wharf on San Francisco Bay. This 1,911-mile continuous railroad line was built by three private companies over public lands provided by extensive U.S. land grants. What is this groundbreaking project that revolutionized transportation and spurred economic growth in the United States?

These internal organs are protected by a thin membrane called the pleura and are divided into lobes: three on the right and two on the left. Located in the thoracic cavity, they are essential for respiration and maintaining homeostasis. They are lined with over 300 million tiny air sacs called alveoli and are responsible for the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the body and the environment. What are these vital organs that inflate and deflate with each breath we take?

This first-person shooter franchise, originally developed by Bungie and now by 343 Industries, features a Spartan supersoldier named Master Chief as its protagonist. Its storyline centers on an interstellar war between humanity and a theocratic alliance of aliens known as the Covenant. The series has expanded to include novels, comic books, and a live-action television series. What is the name of this popular video game franchise?

This 14th-century collection of tales, set against the backdrop of the Black Death in Florence, is structured as a frame narrative, with ten young people telling each other stories over ten days while escaping the plague. The stories, ranging from humorous anecdotes to tragic romances, offer a vivid glimpse into medieval society and explore themes of love, wit, and the human condition. What is the title of this masterpiece by Giovanni Boccaccio?

Born in Yuma, Arizona, this labor leader experienced firsthand the hardships of migrant farm work. He advocated for better wages, working conditions, and basic human rights for farmworkers.
