His courageous breaking of baseball's color barrier in 1947 paved the way for countless African American athletes and challenged societal norms. Who was this trailblazing baseball player?

The Historical Axis is a road of monuments in this city, whose avenues were widened by Baron Haussmann. Bone piles are in the catacombs below this city, whose Latin Quarter is part of the 5th and 6th arrondissements. Its Left and Right Banks are separated by the Seine River, and its Champs-Elysees ends at L'Arc de Triomphe. Home to the Louvre name this capital of France.

This television series, set in the early 20th century, follows the lives of the aristocratic Crawley family and their servants in the fictional Yorkshire country estate. It garnered critical acclaim and numerous awards, including multiple Primetime Emmy Awards and Golden Globes. Its storylines explore themes of social change, class conflict, and the changing roles of women in British society during the Edwardian era and the First World War. What is the name of this popular British historical drama?

One poem of this type tells the title bird "thou wast not born for death" and asks "do I wake or sleep?"Another poem of this type calls the title object an "unravish'd bride of quietness" and declares "beauty is truth, truth beauty." Those poems of this type by John Keats are about a nightingale and a Grecian urn. Name this poetic form that is written in praise of something.

This country's fate was decided in the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, which did not follow the historical Curzon Line. In this country, the Charge at Krojanty led to a myth that this country's army charged horses into tanks. An invasion of this country dissolved the Free City of Danzig and began on September 1st, 1939. Name this country whose invasion by Nazi forces officially started World War II a month before its capital, Warsaw, fell.

Xavier Beccara claimed there was "no magic bullet" for ensuring the ability to do this practice. A July 2022 California gun law is based off a Texas law allowing private citizens to sue providers of this practice. Politico released a leaked draft opinion of a court case about this practice. Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, which overturned Roe v. Wade, denied the right to perform what practice?

This hockey legend's iconic image, captured in mid-air after scoring the Stanley Cup-winning goal in 1970, remains one of the most celebrated photographs in sports history. He revolutionized the role of the defenseman, becoming the first to win the Art Ross Trophy as the NHL's leading scorer, a feat he achieved twice. He holds the record for most points in a single season by a defenseman. Despite having a relatively short career, he won eight consecutive Norris Trophies and three consecutive Hart Trophies. Who is this iconic hockey player?

Elementary operations can be used to convert these mathematical objects into reduced row echelon form, helpful in solving systems of equations. The commutative property does not necessarily apply to multiplication of these objects. Coefficients are stored in these objects for use in Cramer's rule, which solves systems of equations by computing determinants of these objects. Give this term for an array of numbers organized into rows and columns.

This mountain range was created by the subduction of the Nazca Plate. The southern part of this mountain range is found in Patagonia and, further south, Tierra del Fuego. The altiplano, a plateau of this range, contains Lake Titicaca. This range contains the highest peak in the Western Hemisphere, Mount Aconcagua. Name this mountain range of South America.

In this book, a character breaks one of the Seven Commandments by drinking alcohol. Old Major teaches the song "Beasts of England" to the characters in this book, and the horse Boxer helps rebuild a windmill after winning the Battle of the Cowshed against humans. Napoleon and his pigs teach the mantra "four legs good, two legs bad" as they govern the title location of what George Orwell novella which allegorizes the Russian Revolution?

This movie features an iconic scene where a therapist, played by Robin Williams, tells his troubled patient, played by Matt Damon, "It's not your fault." The film's screenplay, written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, won an Academy Award. It also features a heartwarming romance between Damon's character and a pre-med student played by Minnie Driver. What is the name of this acclaimed 1997 drama?

This indigenous people recently mourned the passing of their beloved king, Kiingi Tūheitia, who held the position for 16 years. Their traditional greeting, the hongi, involves pressing noses and foreheads together to share the breath of life. Their intricate wood carvings and tattoos, known as tā moko, are significant cultural expressions. Their war dance, the haka, is a powerful display of strength and unity, often performed before sporting events or other important occasions. Who are these indigenous Polynesian people of New Zealand?

This actress began her illustrious career by earning a Tony nomination for her role in the 1976 play "27 Wagons Full of Cotton". Her transformative performances span a wide range of genres and characters, from Miranda Priestly in "The Devil Wears Prada" to the beloved chef Julia Child in "Julie & Julia."  She boasts a record-breaking 21 Academy Award nominations, winning three for her roles in "Kramer vs. Kramer," "Sophie's Choice," and "The Iron Lady."  Who is this versatile and celebrated actress, often hailed as the "greatest living actress"?

This Major League Baseball team, currently managed by Brian Snitker, boasts a rich history that includes multiple World Series championships, including a recent victory in 2021. They play their home games at Truist Park, which opened in 2017 and replaced the iconic Turner Field. Their legendary players, including Hank Aaron, Chipper Jones, and Greg Maddux, have solidified their place in baseball history. What is the name of this team, based in Atlanta, Georgia?

Paul Rusesabagina hid over a thousand people in this country's Hotel des Milles Collines during one event. This country's RTLM radio station used the phrase "cut the tall trees" and referred to one group as "cockroaches" in an event led by the Interahamwe militia. Romeo Dallaire led UNAMIR in this country where Juvenal Habyarimana was assassinated during a civil war won by the RPF. Paul Kagame is the current President of what country where Tutsis were massacred by Hutus in a 1993 genocide?

This province is home to the city of Red Deer and Lesser Slave Lake. While the Great Slave Lake is not in this province, many of its southern tributaries are, such as the Slave River and the Hay River. Along its western boundary are the Jasper and Banff National Parks, which are along the Continental Divide. The 1988 Olympics, which were most famous for the debut of the Jamaican bobsled team, were held in its largest city of Calgary. Home to the largest oil sand deposit in Canada name this province whose capital is Edmonton.

One method for finding these numbers is called the Sieve of Eratosthenes. Euclid added one to the product of some of these numbers to prove that there are infinitely many of them. Two numbers have this property relative to each other if they share no common divisors. The only even example of these numbers is two, and numbers without this property are composite. Name these numbers whose only positive divisors are one and themselves.

This character feels nauseous at the sight of blue oatmeal and befriends Yard Ape. She ends a book report with the line, "I can't believe I ate the whole thing." In one appearance, she makes a gravestone for the cat Picky-Picky and recovers Aunt Bea's wedding ring. Name this pest of Klickitat Street and friend of Howie Kemp, the younger sister of Beezus Quimby in a series of books by Beverly Cleary.

This man led William Jenkins Worth's men down La Veronica Causeway before he was wounded at the Battle of Chapultepec. He was promoted after the wounding of Joseph Johnston at Seven Pines. At Harper's Ferry, he captured John Brown. This man won the battles of Fredericksburg, Chancellorsville, and Second Bull Run while commanding the Army of Northern Virginia. Name this General-in-Chief of the Confederate forces during the American Civil War.

This region, located to the west of the Jordan River, is currently under Israeli military occupation, though it has been the subject of numerous peace negotiations and international disputes. It is home to significant religious sites for both Muslims and Jews, including the Cave of the Patriarchs in Hebron and the ancient city of Jericho. Its major cities include Ramallah, Nablus, and Bethlehem, the birthplace of Jesus Christ. The area is also known for its olive oil production and its rich cultural heritage. What is this region, a central part of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict?

This initiative's participants were scrutinized by the Venona project, which discovered the espionage of Theodore Hall and Klaus Fuchs. Sites like Hanford and Oak Ridge were used for fuel enrichment during this effort. J. Robert Oppenheimer directed this effort, whose successful culmination was the Trinity Test, the first detonation of a nuclear device. What US World War II project created the atomic bomb?

One of this composer's works uses massive intervals of 10ths and 12ths to sound "jumpy." This composer of the Grosse Fuge used a theme from his suite "The Creatures of Prometheus" in the finale to his third symphony, which was originally dedicated to Napoleon. In addition to the Eroica Symphony, another one of his symphonies opens in C minor with a short-short-short-long pattern representing fate. "Ode to Joy" is sung over the final moments of what composer's 9th symphony, though he never heard it himself?

This television show follows the story of Earnest "Earn" Marks as he navigates the complexities of managing his rapper cousin, Paper Boi. It garnered critical acclaim for its unique blend of comedy, drama, and social commentary, earning numerous awards, including two Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series for Donald Glover's performance. What is the name of this groundbreaking series about the Atlanta rap scene?

These devices can be made to "pulse" by a process called Q-switching. Some printers use these devices to create static electric images on a drum. Lidar is a form of radar that uses these devices to measure distances. These devices are often used in computer miceand DVD players by creating photons through stimulated emission. Name these devices that can create an intensely focused beam of light.

A caldera in this location formed after a series of eruptions at Mesa Falls and Huckleberry Ridge, and contains a supervolcano named after this North American park. This national park contains a geyser known for a very predictable eruption pattern. Name this protected area in Wyoming whose Old Faithful helped establish it as America's first national park.

This arid Southern African nation's government is considering allowing the culling and consumption of elephants and zebras to alleviate food shortages and protect other endangered species during their severe drought. The nation borders Angola and Zambia to the north, Botswana to the east and South Africa to the east and south It is also home to the world's oldest desert, the Namib, and the majestic Etosha National Park, a haven for wildlife. What is the name of this country, the driest in sub-Saharan Africa?

After the Autumn Harvest Uprising, this man retreated to the Jianggang Mountains, where he joined forces with Zhu De, creating the Red Army. He was succeeded by Hua Guofeng and went on the Long March after being surrounded by Kuomintang forces. Under his guidance, the Hundred Flowers Campaign and Great Leap Forward were launched. Name this author of the Little Red Book, the first leader of Communist China.

This footballer is known for his powerful shots, technical skills, and versatility on the pitch, having played as a striker, midfielder, and even a defender throughout his career. He is the all-time leading goal scorer for both Manchester United and the England national team, surpassing Sir Bobby Charlton's records for both club and country. He made his professional debut for Everton at the age of 16, becoming the youngest goalscorer in Premier League history at the time. Who is this English football legend, often referred to as "Wazza"?

This 1979 science fiction horror film, directed by Ridley Scott, introduced the iconic Xenomorph, a terrifying extraterrestrial creature with acid for blood. Its tagline, "In space, no one can hear you scream," perfectly captures the film's chilling atmosphere and sense of isolation. It stars Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley, a warrant officer who becomes the sole survivor of the Nostromo crew's encounter with the deadly creature. What is the title of this film, which spawned a successful franchise?

This monarch oversaw the Nine Years' War in Ireland. The Pope Pius V issued the bull Regnans in Excelsis against this monarch, who had the Duke of Norfolk executed after the failed Ridolfi Plot. William Cecil and Sir Francis Walsingham assisted this monarch's reign, the latter of whom discovered the Throckmorton and Babington plots against her life, who had Mary, Queen of Scots, executed. Identify this Tudor "Virgin Queen" from 1558 to 1603 who defeated the Spanish Armada in 1588.

The term regolith can refer to this, although it mostly applies to those found on the moon. Colluvium and alluvium are forms of this. Another form, podsol, is found in boreal forests. It can be separated into O, A, B, and C layers, which are differentiated by their composition. Humus consists of decayed organic matter in this, while it is classified by horizons. Formed from weathering and erosion of rock, components of it include clay, loam, and silt. Plants grow in what kind of ground?

This international multi-sport event first took place in Rome in 1960, with 400 athletes from 23 countries participating. It is held every four years, following the Olympic Games. The event's motto, "Spirit in Motion," embodies the determination and resilience of its athletes. Its logo features three Agitos, swirling shapes in red, blue, and green, representing the three core values of the games' movement: courage, determination, and inspiration. What is the name of this major sporting event featuring athletes with a range of disabilities?

Davis's cyclical theory of this process ends with the peneplain. When the Petermann Range of Australia underwent this process, only Uluru (Ayers Rock) remained. The namesake features of Arches National Park resulted from one form of this process, while a different type carves gullies into hillsides. The weathering of rocks begins what process by which wind and water remove surface material, leaving features like the Grand Canyon behind?

This legendary coach's famous quote, "Winning isn't everything, it's the only thing," encapsulates his relentless pursuit of excellence. His name is immortalized on the trophy awarded to the Super Bowl champions, a testament to his impact on the sport. He led the Green Bay Packers to five NFL championships in seven years, including victories in the first two Super Bowls. Who is this iconic figure in American football history?

In 1839, Thomas Jefferson Farnham led a failed early use of this by the Peoria Party. Its popularity spiked in 1843 when over 800 people used it to reach the Willamette Valley, most beginning near Independence, MO. Its use declined in the 1870s as railroad connections reached Portland. Name this route used by pioneers in Conestoga wagons to travel to a namesake state in the Pacific Northwest.

In one of this author's plays, a man was found as a baby in a handbag at Victoria Station. In that play by this author, both Algernon Moncrieff and Jack Worthing both pretend to have the title name. This author of The Importance of Being Earnest wrote a novel about a portrait that decays and ages while the title character remains young and attractive. Name this Irish author of The Picture of Dorian Gray.

This NBA franchise has a famous "Vice" color scheme. Led by the iconic trio of LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, and Chris Bosh, they achieved back-to-back championships in 2012 and 2013. Prior to this era, they secured their first championship in 2006, with Dwyane Wade earning the Finals MVP. More recently, they made a surprising run to the NBA Finals in 2020, led by Jimmy Butler, showcasing their resilience and determination. What is the name of this team, based in Miami, Florida?

In this nation, Lech Walesa led the "Solidarity Movement." That movement was supported by Pope John Paul II, who was born in this country. A famous photo taken in this country depicts a boy with his hands raised and a yellow star on his coat; that photograph was taken in the aftermath of a Jewish ghetto uprising. Nazi Germany invaded this country in 1939, starting World War II. Name this nation whose major cities include Krakow.

The first case of this disease in Gaza in 25 years was recently diagnosed. This led to a large-scale vaccination campaign and Israel agreeing to limited pauses in fighting to allow for the vaccination. This disease, once a global scourge, primarily affects children under five and can cause irreversible paralysis in a matter of hours. It's transmitted through contaminated food or water. What is the name of this infectious disease, which afflicted FDR, that has mostly been eradicated?

John Ingram led an event in this colony after a member of the House of Burgesses died of dysentery. Indigenous Doeg people were massacred as William Berkeley fled this colony due to Bacon's Rebellion. The "starving time" was a harsh period in this Virginia colony, whose leader John Smith was saved by Pocahontas. Tobacco was farmed by John Rolfe in this colony. Name this first English colony in Virginia.

This band's debut album, released on Friday the 13th in 1970 featuring songs like "N.I.B." Their iconic guitarist, Tony Iommi, lost the tips of two fingers in an industrial accident, leading him to develop a unique playing style. Their lead singer, Ozzy Osbourne, was famously fired from the band in 1979 due to his excessive drug and alcohol use but later rejoined for reunions and tours. Name this British heavy metal band inducted that was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2006.

Its Arusha National Park contains an active volcano, Mount Meru, while the Umba River flows out of the Arusha region and has notable sapphire deposits. Other notable features in this country include the Oldovai Gorge, where the first homo habilis was discovered and where Louis and Mary Leakey made other archeological discoveries. This country also owns Mafia Island and Pemba, while Lake Victoria and Mount Kilimanjaro are in its north. Name this country that owns Zanaibar and which had its capital moved from Dar es Salaam to Dodoma.

The bond order between two atoms of this element differentiates alkynes from alkanes. The 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for the formation of a two-dimensional, hexagonal allotrope of this element that forms fullerenes like the bucky-ball. Another allotrope of this element has a Mohs hardness of 10. Name this element found in graphite and diamond that has atomic number 6 and symbol C.

In one opera by this composer, Eva eventually goes to Walther, who becomes one of the title Mastersingers of Nuremberg. In another of his operas, the hero eventually saves Elsa. He composed Lohengrin and an opera that sees Sigfried rescue Brunnhilde from a ring of magic fire. That cycle contains Gotterdammerung and a opera containing the Ride of The Valkyries. Name this composer of the Ring cycle.

This band's breakout album, "Dookie," released in 1994, catapulted them to global fame. Their energetic live performances and politically charged lyrics resonated with a disenfranchised youth, establishing them as leaders of the pop-punk movement. Their 2004 rock opera, "American Idiot," further cemented their success, tackling themes of social and political disillusionment. They were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2015. What is the name of this California-based punk rock band?

This NFL team, recognized by their distinctive black, blue, and silver uniforms, made a remarkable debut in 1995, securing an impressive seven wins in their inaugural season, a record for an expansion team. They reached the Super Bowl twice, in 2003 and 2015, but unfortunately fell short both times. Their home stadium, Bank of America Stadium, is affectionately known as "The Bank" by fans.  They have been led by notable quarterbacks such as Jake Delhomme and Cam Newton throughout their history. What is the name of this team, based in Charlotte, North Carolina?

This ruler's actions in the first Partition of Poland sparked the Confederation of Bar, and after defeating the Ottoman Empire in the first Russo-Turkish war Crimea was added to Russia. This ruler created the League of Armed Neutrality during the American Revolution while collaborating with many Enlightenment figures, notably Voltaire and Denis Diderot. Married to Peter III identify this ruler, the lover of Grigory Potemkin and suppresser of Pugachev's Rebellion, who after a coup that killed her husband became empress of Russia.

These storms are defined by having winds of at least 74 miles per hour, making them stronger than a tropical depression and a tropical storm. They form from low-pressure centers over warm waters. The Coriolis effect determines which direction these storms spin, and as they rotate, they form an "eye" that is relatively calm. Name these storms that can destroy coastal areas, such as Katrina in 2005.

A proposed amendment for this agreement would have freed slaves "at the age of twenty-five" and was named for James Tallmadge. Although it was already effectively repealed, this agreement was declared unconstitutional in the Dred Scott case, and under this agreement Maine was admitted to the union. Name this agreement, which established a line along the northern boundary of a namesake slave state.

This country is involved in a territorial dispute over possession of the Greater and Lesser Tunb Islands, and the Dasht-e Lut and the Dasht-e Kavir are two deserts in this country's namesake plateau. Lake Urmia is located in this country close to the Turkish border. The Zagros Mountains form the spine of this country, and the cities of Qum, Tabriz, and Esfahan are located in this nation. Name this country located in modern day Persia that has its capital at Tehran.

This country recently made headlines when a court blocked the social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, citing concerns about the spread of misinformation and hate speech. It is also the birthplace of samba, a vibrant dance and music genre that has become synonymous with its annual Carnival celebration. Furthermore, it boasts the iconic Christ the Redeemer statue, overlooking the bustling city of Rio de Janeiro. What is this South American nation, known for its rich culture, biodiversity, and passion for football?

Kuzunoha is one of these creatures, and takes the form of a woman in a Japanese legend. Aesop wrote stories about this animal paired with a sick lion and a crane, and this creature works with Tommy Brock in a story by Beatrix Potter. This creature is known as kitsune in Japan and as Tod in England, and is the title subject of the Reynard cycle in France. Name this archetypical trickster, a red, bushy-tailed mammal.

Hvaldimir, a whale of this species, -- who gained fame for potentially being an escaped Russian military whale -- recently passed away off the coast of Norway. These animals are highly social, often congregating in large pods, earning them the nickname "sea canaries." This species of Arctic and sub-Arctic cetacean is known for its distinctive white coloration and its ability to change the shape of its bulbous forehead, called a "melon." Name this whale that lacks a dorsal fin, an adaptation that helps them navigate through icy waters.

This philosopher's namesake "teapot" analogy, involving a hypothetical object orbiting between Earth and Mars, cleverly shifts the burden of proof in debates about God's existence. He famously challenged the law of the excluded middle by pointing out its potential absurdity when applied to definite descriptions. In collaboration with Alfred North Whitehead, he co-authored a monumental work that attempted to derive all mathematical truths from a set of logical axioms. Who is this author of "Principia Mathematica"?

This man posited that "people who would have never thought that a religious problem could be a serious matter ... are beginning to ask themselves fundamental questions" in his book Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies. This man proposed two perceiving functions of consciousness and two judging functions in Psychological Types. This psychologist also proposed five archetypes, including the anima and animus. Name this Swiss psychologist who proposed the collective unconscious.

Men who undergo the process of Amrit Sanchar are initiated into this religion and are commanded to wear an iron bracelet and wooden comb. This religion's central text, the Adi Granth, is considered its final Guru. Members of this religion, founded by Guru Nanak, practice a form of strict non-violence known as ahimsa and wear the five K's, including kesh, or uncut hair. Name this religion prominent in the Punjab state of India.

To oppose this process, Senator Harry Byrd headed a campaign of "Massive resistance." This process was ordered to be carried out "with all deliberate speed" following a 1954 Supreme Court case that ruled that the notion of "separate but equal" was unconstitutional. The ruling in Brown v. Board of Education called for what process that ended the separation of education institutions based on race?

This jazz vocalist's iconic rendition of "A-Tisket, A-Tasket," a reworking of a nursery rhyme, propelled her to stardom at the young age of 21. She was admired for her impeccable scat singing, a form of vocal improvisation that showcased her remarkable rhythmic and melodic agility. Her collaborations with legendary musicians like Duke Ellington, Louis Armstrong, and Count Basie solidified her status as a jazz luminary. Name this singer who earned the nickname "First Lady of Song."

This golfer comes from a family of athletes, with her father being a former Grand Slam tennis champion and her younger brother a rising star in professional tennis. She kicked off the 2024 season with a historic feat, winning five consecutive LPGA Tour titles, a streak not seen in nearly two decades. Her victory at the 2024 Chevron Championship marked her second major title, solidifying her position as one of the top players in women's golf. She also holds an Olympic gold medal, earned in the 2020 Tokyo Games. Who is this talented golfer?

This state is home to the Ten Thousand Islands, a collection of islets off the coast of this state's largest national park. Big Cypress National Reserve lies north of that national park in this state, which is named a "River of Grass" for being a giant swamp fed by Lake Okeechobee. Crocodiles, manatees, and mangrove trees are among the distinctive features of what state's Everglades National Park?

This NFL team's current head coach, Dan Quinn, was hired in 2024 after previously serving as the defensive coordinator for the Dallas Cowboys. They underwent a name change in 2020 amidst growing controversy surrounding its previous moniker. The team's iconic burgundy and gold colors remain unchanged, representing a visual link to its storied past. They boast three Super Bowl victories, the last of which came in 1991 under the leadership of legendary coach Joe Gibbs. What is the name of this team, based in the nation's capital?

This planet is orbited by the only notable moon with a retrograde orbit. Urbain Le Verrier used Newton's laws to correctly predict the position of this planet. It is home to storms such as the Scooter and the Great Dark Spot. Voyager 2 discovered its moon Proteus and photographed its largest moon Triton. Name this eighth planet from the sun, slightly bigger than its neighbor Uranus and named for a Roman god of the sea.

In this city, the Etemenanki Temple and the Ishtar Gate were constructed by King Nebuchadnezzar. After a ruler of this city destroyed Solomon's Temple, the Jews suffered a namesake "captivity" in this city. Legal principles like "an eye for an eye" were established in this city by its ruler Hammurabi. Name this Mesopotamian city home to some legendary Hanging Gardens.

In this state, a thin layer of melting ice allows some stones to "sail" across the surface of Racetrack Playa. A national park in this state contains the Bridalveil Fall vista and was advocated for by John Muir's Sierra Club. In that national park in this state, Glacier Point gives views of El Capitan and Half Dome. Name this state which contains Death Valley and Yosemite.

This historical drama miniseries features a stellar cast led by Jared Harris, Stellan Skarsgård, and Emily Watson. It received numerous awards, including 10 Primetime Emmy Awards and two Golden Globes. Its unflinching portrayal of the human cost of the 1986 nuclear disaster and its aftermath. Name this HBO miniseries which depicted the Soviet nuclear disaster in what is now Ukraine.

This actor passed away at the age of 93 on September 9, 2024. He was renowned for his deep and resonant voice that brought life to iconic characters. He achieved the coveted EGOT, winning an Emmy, Grammy, (Honorary) Oscar, and Tony Award throughout his illustrious career. He won Tony Awards for his roles in "The Great White Hope" and "Fences." Name this actor who acted as Darth Vader in the Star Wars saga and Mufasa in The Lion King.

This man sent the Great White Fleet on a tour of the world to impress Japan, and ended a conflict between Japan and Russia with the Treaty of Portsmouth. He recruited several college buddies to serve together as the Rough Riders unit during the Spanish-American War. He began "trustbusting" with the Standard Oil Case. Name this president from 1901 to 1909, whose nickname provided the name for a toy bear.

In one of this artist's works, a cornucopia of fruit sits next to a squatting woman near four other prostitutes whose faces are inspired by African masks. In another work by this artist, a man lying on a floor clutches a knife with a flower growing out of it as a lightbulb explodes. This artist painted Boy with a Pipe and co-founded Cubism with works like Les Demoiselles d'Avignon. Name this Spanish painter of Guernica.

This sport's origins can be traced back to 16th-century Scotland, making it one of the oldest team sports still played today. It's known for its unique strategy and precision, requiring teams to carefully plan their shots and anticipate their opponents' moves. This sport involves sliding granite stones across a sheet of ice towards a target area called the "house." Players use brooms to sweep the ice in front of the stone, influencing its speed and direction. What is this sport, often referred to as "chess on ice"?

The protagonist of this work is disappointed to learn that her friend will not be visiting town the summer of her 12th birthday. The protagonist of this work later clashes with her Aunt Alexandria, who has come to town to provide her with a "feminine influence." This work reaches its climax when the protagonist and her brother are attacked on their way home from a Halloween pageant by Bob Ewell, only to be saved by Boo Radley. Identify this Pulitzer Prize winning book about Jem, Scout, and Atticus Finch, a work by Harper Lee.
incorrect3: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone

question: This country's cuisine includes the Portuguese-influenced dish vindaloo. Blocks of cottage cheese known as paneer are a common ingredient in dishes in this country. The tandoor style of cooking originated in this country's state of Rajasthan. Many of this country's curries are eaten with breads like naan and roti. Name this large South Asian country home to the cities of Mumbai and Delhi.

This animated sitcom follows the misadventures of four elementary school boys - Stan Marsh, Kyle Broflovski, Eric Cartman, and Kenny McCormick - in the fictional Colorado town. Created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, it has garnered critical acclaim and controversy for its irreverent approach to tackling sensitive topics, including religion, politics, and pop culture. The show's iconic cut-out animation style and memorable catchphrases, like "Oh my God, they killed Kenny!", have become ingrained in popular culture. What is the name of this long-running animated series?

This event was precipitated in part when John Sharp was not removed from his position by Henry Compton. Compton, along with Henry Sidney, later became one of the "Immortal Seven" of this event. The Williamite War, which included the Battle of the Boyne, occurred as a result of this event, which happened after Mary of Modena married one participant and gave birth to a Catholic heir apparent who would later be called the "Old Pretender." Name this event where James II was replaced as English monarch by William III and Mary II.

In 1999, she received the Congressional Gold Medal and was honored by President Bill Clinton during his state of the union. She is best known for an act of civil disobedience in 1955 in the city of Montgomery, Alabama, for which she was arrested. She had, however, joined the movement in 1943 and was secretary of her local NAACP chapter. Name the civil rights activist best known for her refusal to give up her bus seat.

This function appears in the denominator of all Taylor series, and can be approximated by Stirling's formula. The gamma function extends this operation to inputs other than positive integers, and it is defined as the number of permutations for a number of objects. Name the function, which finds the product of all natural numbers of an input value and below, which is designated by an exclamation point.

The cofounder of this app, Pavel Durov, was arrested in August 2024 for a lack of content moderation on the app. The app allows users to create large group chats with up to 200,000 members and channels for broadcasting to unlimited audiences. The app is cloud-based messaging platform, known for its focus on privacy and security, offers features like encrypted "Secret Chats" and self-destructing messages. Name this app that gained popularity as an alternative to WhatsApp and other messaging apps due to its robust security features and open-source nature.

This man established the system of missi dominici to administer his empire; he patronized the scholar Alcuin of York and the biographer Einhard. He crushed the Lombards at Pavia, though Basques at Ronceveaux Pass massacred his troops under Roland. This son of Pepin the Short had his capital was Aachen, and gained a certain title from Pope Leo III. Name this man who became the first Holy Roman Emperor on Christmas day 800, a "great" Frankish king.

This city is home to the port town of Jebel Ali, a top-10 port in the world southwest of the Strait of Hormuz. Housing in this city is built on artificial, palm-frond-shaped landmasses that sit along the Persian Gulf north of Abu Dhabi. Name this most populous city in the United Arab Emirates, the home of the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa.

This iconic sitcom's theme song, "Where Everybody Knows Your Name," performed by Gary Portnoy. The series finale, aired in 1993, was a major television event, drawing in millions of viewers. It premiered in 1982 and ran for 11 seasons, becoming one of the most beloved and successful sitcoms in television history. This sitcom, set in a Boston bar, featured a cast of memorable characters, including Sam Malone, a womanizing ex-baseball player turned bartender, and Diane Chambers, an intelligent but pretentious waitress. What is the name of this classic sitcom?

This NFL franchise achieved the only perfect season in league history, going 17-0 in 1972 and culminating in a Super Bowl VII victory.  They are led by head coach Mike McDaniel and boast a storied history with legendary players like Dan Marino and Larry Csonka. Their iconic teal and orange color scheme is instantly recognizable, and their home stadium, Hard Rock Stadium, has hosted multiple Super Bowls. Which team is this, based in Miami Gardens, Florida?

Playfair's axiom describes the number of lines that satisfy this property given a line and a point not on the line. When crossed by a transversal, lines with this property have the same corresponding angles. Euclid's fifth postulate is named for this property, and two lines with it have the same slope and are always equidistant from each other. What property do two lines have if they never intersect?

The Word Health Organization recently reported that deaths from this disease rose 71% in 2023. This waterborne bacterial infection primarily affects the small intestine and can cause severe diarrhea and dehydration. It's caused by the Vibrio cholerae bacterium, often found in contaminated food or water sources. While it can be fatal if left untreated, prompt rehydration therapy and antibiotics can effectively combat the infection.  What is this disease, which has historically caused devastating epidemics throughout the world?

The admiral who organized this event was assassinated in the aptly-named Operation Vengeance. This event was known to its perpetrators as Plan Z, and the code phrase "Climb Mount Niitaka" was used to initiate it. Isoroku Yamamoto led this event, which resulted in the sinking of the battleship USS Arizona. Name this "day which will live in infamy", a 1941 surprise attack on a Hawaiian naval base.
answers: Day that will live in infamy

question: This artwork's creator made four versions of it from 1893 to 1910, the last of which lacked eyeballs in its central figure. Scholars have debated whether the eruption of Krakatoa inspired the blood-red sky found in this artwork. Two people stand by a guardrail on a bridge behind the central figure of this artwork. A distorted man features in what Edvard Munch painting showing a figure shrieking?

This motorcycle racing legend, affectionately known as "The Doctor," boasts nine Grand Prix World Championships, with seven of those coming in the premier 500cc/MotoGP class. His signature celebratory move, bowing to his bike, became a beloved tradition for fans worldwide. His retirement in 2021 marked the end of an era in motorcycle racing, leaving behind a legacy of unparalleled success and charisma. Who is this iconic Italian rider?

The Supreme Court case Leser v. Garnett upheld the ratification of this Constitutional amendment. It was the subject of a 1913 parade on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, held the day before Woodrow Wilson's first inauguration; that march was led by Alice Paul. This amendment wasn't ratified until 1920, though it was written in the 1870's by Susan B. Anthony. Suffragettes supported what amendment that guaranteed women the right to vote?
answers: nineteenth amendment to the U.S. Constitution

question: In one work, this man argues about holiness with Euthyphro but learns nothing to help him in his upcoming trial. Later, Crito tries to buy this man out of prison, but he refuses to escape his death penalty for corrupting the youth of Athens. Name this ancient Greek philosopher who was executed via a cup of poison hemlock.

This city hosted the second US Presidential debate -- the first to feature Kamala Harris -- at the National Constitution Center. This city is home to the iconic LOVE sculpture, a popular tourist destination in John F. Kennedy Plaza. It's also where the first American flag was designed and sewn by Betsy Ross. It boasts the oldest continuously inhabited street in America, Elfreth's Alley. Additionally, it is the birthplace of the cheesesteak, a culinary delight that has become synonymous with the city. What is this city, often referred to as the "City of Brotherly Love"?

One porous form of this element is useful for adsorption reactions and in water filtration; that form is known as its "activated" variety. One isotope of this element has a half-life of 5730 years; that mass 14 isotope is used for radiometric dating. Organic compounds must contain this element, which forms an allotrope that is the hardest substance in the world. Name this element with atomic number 6 that can be found in coal, graphite, and diamond.

This artist collaborated with John McLaughlin to write "Shhh/Peaceful" on the album In a Silent Way. This artist included a variation of guitarist Joaquin Rodrigo's "Concierto de Aranjuez" in an album arranged by Gil Evans. He experimented with electronic instruments in the album Bitches Brew, and collaborated with John Coltrane, Cannonball Adderley, and Bill Evans on an album including "Flamenco Sketches" and "So What." Name this jazz trumpeter behind Sketches of Spain and Kind of Blue.

This body of water contains the Ottawa Islands, part of the territory of Nunavut. The only active port on this body of water is Churchill, located in the province of Manitoba. Name this very large Canadian bay which was named for an explorer who was marooned in this bay.

This Netflix series pays homage to 1980s pop culture, drawing inspiration from iconic films like "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial," "The Goonies," and "Stand by Me." The show features a group of young friends, including the telekinetic Eleven and the adventurous Mike Wheeler, who navigate the mysteries and dangers of the Upside Down, a parallel dimension filled with strange creatures. What is the name of this popular science fiction horror series?

This historical epic film, set in ancient Rome, tells the story of Maximus Decimus Meridius, a betrayed general forced into slavery who seeks revenge against the corrupt emperor Commodus. It garnered critical acclaim and box office success, winning five Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Actor for Russell Crowe's powerful performance. Its iconic line, "Are you not entertained?", delivered by Maximus during a gladiatorial battle, has become a memorable quote in popular culture. Name this 2000 historical drama.

One of these events was recently attempted at Makala Central Prison in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo, leaving 129 people dead. In 1962 inmates Frank Morris and the Anglin brothers succeeded in one of these at Alcatraz. Successful attempts at these can capture the public imagination, inspiring books, films, and even folklore. Name this event that involves the unauthorized departure of a prisoner from lawful confinement, often requiring ingenuity, planning, and a bit of luck.

Spiros Antonapoulos commits suicide in a Carson McCullers novel whose title claims that this object "Is a Lonely Hunter". Kurtz exclaims "The horror! The horror!" in a Joseph Conrad novel titled for this object "of Darkness." The narrator murders a "vulture-eyed" old man in a Poe short story named for a "Tell-Tale" example of what organ which the narrator can hear beating under his floorboards?
answers: The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter

question: This basketball legend's signature move, the "skyhook," was a seemingly unstoppable shot that became synonymous with his dominance on the court. He is the NBA's second all-time leading scorer, amassing an impressive 38,387 points throughout his illustrious career. He played for the Milwaukee Bucks and Los Angeles Lakers, winning six NBA championships and six MVP awards. Before converting to Islam and changing his name, he was known as Lew Alcindor and led UCLA to three consecutive NCAA championships. Who is this iconic center?

One of these construction projects required moving the temples of Abu Simbel. In 2017, the spillways at a 770 foot tall one of these projects named Oroville nearly failed, requiring evacuations along the Feather River. The baiji dolphin went extinct in Hubei province after one of these projects, named Three Gorges, was built. Name this type of structure that generates hydroelectric power and holds back immense amounts of water.

The density parameter for the non-relativistic form of this falls off with the cube of the scale factor. This substance dominated the universe from approximately 75,000 years after the Big-Bang until about 4 billion years ago. Deviations in the expected orbital speed of galaxies suggests the presence of the "dark" form of this. When it has the same mass but opposite charge and spin, it is deemed "anti." Solid, liquid, and gas are three states of what term for any substance that occupies space and has mass.

Corn farmer Roswell Garst hosted this man in Iowa during a visit to America that also included a canceled trip to Disneyland. This man attacked the personality cult of his predecessor in a "Secret Speech,"proclaimed "History is on our side. We will bury you!" in a 1956 address, and once banged his shoe on a desk at the United Nations. Name this premier who led the USSR from 1953 to 1964, succeeding Joseph Stalin.

During this conflict, the "Desert Fox" Erwin Rommel lost the Battle of El Alamein in Egypt. One side in this conflict launched Operation Barbarossa, which was defeated at the Battle of Stalingrad. Offenses during this conflict included the Battle of the Bulge and a landing at Normandy that began an invasion launched by the Allies on D-Day. Name this war in which the Allies defeated Nazi Germany.

Rheumatic fever can damage the mitral region of this organ, which uses Purkinje fibers to coordinate activity with the SA node. A murmur results from valves leaking in this organ that is served by the coronary arteries and surrounded by the pericardium. This organ directly connects to the aorta and has two atria and two ventricles. Name this organ of the circulatory system that pumps blood through the body.

During this man's re-election campaign, he ran with Henry Wilson instead of incumbent Vice President Schulyer Colfax, who was under investigation for taking bribes from a railroad construction company, Credit Mobilier. Name this winner of the 1872 and 1868 Presidential elections, a popular former Civil War general.

This NFL team secured their first and only Super Bowl victory in 2018, defeating the New England Patriots in a thrilling Super Bowl LII matchup. Their historic rivalry with the Dallas Cowboys, known for its intensity and competitiveness, has become a staple of the NFL landscape. Their home stadium, Lincoln Financial Field, is located in the heart of Philadelphia and is renowned for its passionate and sometimes boisterous crowds. What is the name of this team, based in Philadelphia?

A shooter killed four people at Apalachee High School in this state on September 4, 2024. This state's highest peak, Brasstown Bald, stands at 4,784 feet. Its coastline along the Atlantic Ocean is dotted with barrier islands, including Jekyll Island and Tybee Island. It is divided into five distinct physiographic regions: the Appalachian Plateau, the Valley and Ridge, the Blue Ridge, the Piedmont, and the Coastal Plain, each showcasing unique landscapes and ecosystems. Name this state home to the Chattahoochee River which provides a vital source of water and recreation for its residents.

The oil field of Statfjord lies in this sea, east of the Shetland Islands. The largest helicopter port in the world lies on the shore of this body of water in Aberdeen. Oil found under this body of water is responsible for Norway's large sovereign wealth fund. The English Channel connects this sea to the Atlantic. What rough sea named after a cardinal direction is between continental Europe, Scandinavia, and Britain?

Frederick Hodgson's attempt to acquire a stool made from this substance sparked a war with Queen Yaa Asantewaa. The price of this substance in Mamluk Egypt deflated after Mansa Musa's hajj. The trade of salt and this substance in the trans-Saharan trade made West African empires, like Mali, prosperous. Name this valuable metal, which sparked many "rushes" throughout history.

This 2014 film's title references a challenging piece of music that serves as a central motif throughout the narrative, symbolizing the relentless pursuit of perfection and the sacrifices made in the name of artistic ambition. J.K. Simmons' portrayal of the tyrannical conductor, Terence Fletcher, earned him an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. Name this film, renowned for its intense portrayal of a driven music student and his abusive instructor, which features a climactic scene where the protagonist delivers a breathtaking drum solo during a jazz competition, defying his mentor's expectations.

This language was used to write "If on a winter's night a traveller", the play "Six Characters In Search of an Author", and a short story collection in which Federigo serves his prized falcon to Monna Giovanna. The Decameron is written in this language, which was used by Calvino, Pirandello, and Boccaccio. Name this European language from a country whose capital is Rome.

The Hamersley Range, in the western part of this country, accounts for over 90% of this country's iron ore production. The Great Artesian Basin covers one-fifth of this country, the Murray-Darling Basin covers another one-seventh, and it is home to the Great Sandy Desert. The Great Dividing Range, in its eastern sections, is the 4th longest in the world and includes Mount Kosiuszko. Bass Strait separates Tasmania from the main island of what country that occupies the Great Barrier Reef has its capital at Canberra and is home to Melbourne and Sydney?

This athlete, known for her exceptional skills in slalom and giant slalom, became the youngest Olympic slalom champion at the 2014 Sochi Olympics at just 18 years old. She holds the record for the most World Cup wins in a single discipline, with an impressive 53 victories in slalom. Her overall World Cup wins tally stands at 88, making her the most successful female alpine skier in history. Name this athlete who has also clinched multiple World Championship titles across various disciplines, demonstrating her versatility and dominance in the sport.

The first one of these was assigned to John Sweeney in 1936, a year after its namesake federal program was established. Identity theft protection companies, like LifeLock, often use one of these belonging to their founder in advertisements, highlighting their commitment to safeguarding sensitive information. They consist of nine digits, grouped in a 3-2-4 format, and serve as a unique identifier for individuals in various government and financial transactions. What is this nine-digit number, essential for working and receiving government benefits in the United States?

This actor's iconic trench coat and fedora from the film "Casablanca" have become enduring symbols of classic Hollywood style. He earned his only Academy Award for his role as a cantankerous boat captain in "The African Queen," opposite Katharine Hepburn. His other memorable performances include the cynical private detective Sam Spade in "The Maltese Falcon" and the world-weary Rick Blaine in "Casablanca," solidifying his status as a Hollywood legend. Who is this actor, known for his tough-guy persona and distinctive voice?

The narrator of one poem by this writer "look'd up in perfect silence at the stars", while in another poem this man "sounds his barbaric yawp." Besides "When I Heard the Learn'd Astronomer" and "Song of Myself", this poet wrote of a man who has "fallen cold and dead" in a poem dedicated to Abraham Lincoln. Name this poet of "O Captain! My Captain!" and the collection Leaves of Grass.

Alberto Fujimori, the president of this nation from 1990-2000, died on September 11, 2024. He was general thought to be a dictator and dissolved Congress in 1992. This country is home to the Nazca Lines, a series of ancient geoglyphs etched into the desert, whose purpose remains a subject of fascination and speculation. Name this nation, home to Machu Picchu, an iconic Incan citadel perched high in the Andes Mountains, often called the "Lost City of the Incas."

This class of animals evolved from synapsids and possess an inner ear formed from former jaw bones. Monotremes are egg-laying examples of these animals, which also include the marsupials and placentals. Along with platypuses and kangaroos, this group includes horses, bears, and primates. Name this class of warm-blooded vertebrates with hair or fur.

This thinker introduced his concept of "the doctrine of the mean" as a balance between excess and deficiency, the ideal expression of virtue. In addition to that work named after his son, he described his impetus theory of motion in his Physics. In Politics, he claimed that the title entity is dynamic and comes before family and the individual. He stated that the objective of tragedy is to invoke catharsis in Poetics. Name this Greek Peripatetic philosopher who wrote The Nicomachean Ethics and was taught by Plato.

Asteroids sharing an orbit with this planet are called trojans. In 1994, the comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 collided with this planet. This planet's moons include the most volcanically active body in the solar system, Io, as well as the three other Galilean moons: Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto. The Great Red Spot is found on what largest planet in the solar system?

"Shogun" won 18 awards and "Hacks" beat out "The Bear" for best comedy at this ceremony. These awards are a statuette, depicting a winged woman holding an atom. The first ceremony was held in 1949, and has since become a glamorous event celebrating the best in television. These awards, bestowed annually by the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences, recognize excellence in American primetime television programming.What is the name of these prestigious awards?

This man's namesake "center" helped to nearly eradicate the Guinea Worm, and he met with Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat to foster peace between Israel and Egypt during the Camp David Accords. This man's failure to rescue U.S. diplomats from an Iranian embassy contributed to his loss in the 1980 election. Name this predecessor of Ronald Reagan, a Democratic peanut farmer from Georgia.

This is the only nation in the world to recognize the Republic of Northern Cyprus as a country. Historically, the terms Asia Minor and Anatolia referred to the region that is now this country. Ships entering the Black Sea pass through the Bosphorus at this country's largest city, which contains the Hagia Sophia and was previously called Constantinople. What Eurasian country is home to Ankara and Istanbul?

This Brazilian crime film, set in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro, follows the intertwined lives of two young men: Rocket, an aspiring photographer, and Zé Pequeno, a ruthless drug dealer. Its non-linear narrative and gritty realism immerse viewers in the harsh realities of life in the favelas. It was co-directed by Fernando Meirelles and Kátia Lund, based on the semi-autobiographical novel of the same name by Paulo Lins. What is the title of this 2002 film, which has been praised for its raw and unflinching portrayal of poverty, violence, and the struggle for survival in a marginalized community?

In this novel, a town is fooled by two men who pull off the Royal Nonesuch, and those men go on to steal the property of the late Peter Wilkes. The Widow Douglas wants to "sivilize" the title character, who misses a turn at Cairo and keeps floating south. Name this novel that sees Jim and the title friend of Tom Sawyer travel down the Mississippi River, a work by Mark Twain.

This country's Kruger National Park, part of the lowveld grassland, is named for a 19th-century leader of its Transvaal region, the site of gold and diamond mines. Lesotho is completely surrounded by this country, which was governed by an "apartheid" regime before it elected Nelson Mandela president in 1994. Pretoria and Cape Town are two capitals of what country at the lowest extremity of the African continent?

This team's iconic home stadium, Shea Stadium, was demolished in 2009 and replaced by Citi Field. They achieved their first World Series victory in 1969, with a team with a "Miracle" moniker. They had historic players such as Tom Seaver and David Wright. Their most recent championship came in 1986, with a dramatic Game 7 victory over the Boston Red Sox. What is the name of this baseball team based in Queens, New York?

This sports executive, who assumed his current position in 2014, demonstrated his commitment to social justice by swiftly banning Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling for life following racist remarks. He has also overseen significant changes within the league, including the implementation of a play-in tournament for postseason seeding and a stricter technical foul policy aimed at curbing on-court complaints toward referees. His tenure has also seen the league's media rights deals skyrocket in value, securing billions of dollars in revenue. Who is this current commissioner of the National Basketball Association (NBA)?

After having much of his legislation overturned by the Supreme Court, this leader proposed his court packing plan. The Tennessee Valley Authority was one piece of New Deal legislation that was not overturned by the Court. Although he led his country for most of World War II, he did not make the decision to drop the atomic bombs on Japan. He succeeded Herbert Hoover. Who is the only President of the United States to be elected to more than two terms in office?

This animated classic features the voice talents of renowned actors like James Earl Jones, Matthew Broderick, and Jeremy Irons. The film's opening sequence, set to the powerful song "Circle of Life," showcases the breathtaking African savanna and introduces the young lion cub Simba. It features a memorable song, "Hakuna Matata," which promotes a carefree philosophy of "no worries." Its villain, Scar, delivers the chilling line, "Long live the king," before betraying his brother Mufasa. What is the title of this beloved 1994 musical film?

This river is the habitat of a parasitic fish called the candiru that supposedly is attracted to urine streams. This river is also the habitat of a namesake pink dolphin. This river meets the ocean near Belem, and one of this river's tributaries is the Rio Negro. This river is also home to the carnivorous piranha, and this river was named for a mythological race of warrior women. Name this longest river in South America.

In two works by this author, Leo attempts to build a Happiness Machine and an automated house functions after its inhabitants are vaporized. Douglas Spaulding's grandmother makes the title Dandelion Wine in one work by this author of The Martian Chronicles, who wrote about a man who works for Captain Beatty as a fireman who burns books. Name this author who wrote about Guy Montag in Fahrenheit 451.

This empire's first ruler defeated the Kaniaga dynasty at the Battle of Kirina and established this empire. That man was named Sundiata Keita, and all of the resulting rulers of this empire were descended from him. One of this empire's greatest cities was Timbuktu, a great center of trade where many libraries and Islamic universities were built. This empire's most famous ruler brought with him sixty thousand people and two hundred camels laden with gold on his hajj. Name this empire, whose ruler Mansa Musa depreciated the value of gold in Cairo during his pilgrimage to Mecca.

Nylon fibers are very strong due to many of these interactions between each polymer molecule. Alpha helices and beta sheets in proteins are stabilized by these interactions. Two of them are found in a base pair between adenine and thymine on opposite strands of the double helix of DNA. Many instances of this interaction in water cause its abnormally high boiling point. Identify this intermolecular force between an atom of nitrogen, oxygen, or fluorine and an atom of the namesake lightest element.

Edward Caban resigned from this position in New York City after he was one of several members of Eric Adam's inner circle to be investigated. Figures like William Bratton, known for his "broken windows" strategy, and Daryl Gates, a controversial figure during the Rodney King era, have shaped the public perception of this role. In fiction, Clancy Wiggum of Springfield to the James Gordon of Gotham City highlight the challenges and complexities of this role.  What is this top leadership position in a police department, responsible for maintaining public safety and upholding the law?

One character in this work is locked in the red room by her cruel aunt, which she believes she is haunted by the ghost of her uncle. While attending school, the protagonist befriends Helen Burns, who later dies of consumption when a typhus epidemic sweeps Lowood. St. John and his two sisters take the title character in after she flees Thornfield, which she later discovers has been burned down by Bertha Mason. Name this novel about the title character eventually marrying the impassioned Mr. Rochester, written by Charlotte Bronte.

This athlete's remarkable achievement of setting three world records and tying another within a single hour at the 1935 Big Ten track meet in Ann Arbor, Michigan, remains a testament to his exceptional athleticism. His four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Olympics, in the face of Adolf Hitler's Aryan supremacy propaganda, made him an international symbol of triumph over prejudice. His victories in the 100-meter dash, 200-meter dash, long jump, and 4x100 meter relay shattered expectations and challenged prevailing racial stereotypes. Who was this legendary track and field athlete?

This vibrant festival, celebrated in many Asian cultures, features a dazzling array of colorful lanterns adorning streets and homes. Mooncakes, pastries filled with sweet or savory fillings, are traditionally enjoyed during this festive occasion. It falls on the 15th day of the 8th lunar month, when the moon is believed to be at its fullest and brightest. The legend of Chang'e, the Moon Goddess, is often associated with this celebration. What is the name of this annual harvest festival?

This element appears in the ion whose sodium compound drives the explosion of airbags, azide. In organic compounds, this element usually has one lone pair and forms three bonds, while it also exists as a diatomic molecule with a triple bond. A compound of this element and hydrogen is used in fertilizer and made in the Haber-Bosch process; that compound is ammonia. Name this element to the left of oxygen on the periodic table, with atomic symbol N.

While docked in this modern-day country, the USS Maine exploded, prompting the US to enter the Spanish-American War. Many refugees from this country traveled north to Florida by boat. This country's leader Fulgencio Batista was deposed in 1959 in favor of Fidel Castro. Guantanamo Bay is leased by the United States from what Caribbean island nation led from Havana?

The northeast part of this nation is home to hundreds of thousands of cave drawings within the Camonica Valley. The easternmost point in this nation is located on the Salentine Peninsula, which lies west of the Strait of Otranto. Traveling south through the Brenner Pass grants access to this nation, the backbone of which is formed by the Apennine Mountains. The nation of San Marino is located entirely within this country, which contains Mount Etna on the island of Sicily. Name this European nation whose capital is Rome.

This band holds the record for the most gold and multi-platinum albums by an American group. Their collaboration with Run-DMC on a remake of "Walk This Way" in 1986 bridged the gap between rock and hip-hop, introducing them to a new generation of fans. "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing," from the 1998 film "Armageddon," became their first and only number-one hit on the Billboard Hot 100. Their high-energy live performances and bluesy rock sound, led by the charismatic Steven Tyler and the guitar prowess of Joe Perry, earned them the nickname "The Bad Boys from Boston." What is this band?

In 1985, a helicopter from this city's police department dropped a bomb on the headquarters of MOVE; this city's fire department let the ensuing blaze destroy 65 other homes. The Battle of Germantown was fought in what is now this city. This city's central grid, between the Schuylkill and Delaware Rivers, is home to a US Mint, Independence Hall, and the Liberty Bell. Name this temporary national capital, the largest city in Pennsylvania.

In one novel set in this country, a glass church is transported hundreds of miles to settle a bet between Oscar and Lucinda. One author from this country described a factory owner who protected Jews during the Holocaust in Schindler's Ark. Jimmie Blacksmith and Ned Kelly live as bushrangers in this country in works by Thomas Keneally and Peter Carey. The Outback is a common setting in what large former British colony?

This tennis star, known for his elegant one-handed backhand and graceful movement on the court, holds the record for the most consecutive weeks at the top of the ATP rankings, an impressive 237 weeks. He has won 20 Grand Slam singles titles, including a record eight Wimbledon championships. His rivalry with Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic captivated fans for years, producing some of the most memorable matches in tennis history. He retired from professional tennis in September 2022, leaving behind a legacy of unparalleled achievements and sportsmanship. Who is this iconic Swiss tennis player?

Agricultural runoff pollution causing algae blooms in one of these things led voters to pass its namesake "Bill of Rights". An "effect" named for one of these things causes heavy snowfall in cities like Buffalo and Cleveland. Artificial examples of these bodies of water are commonly known as reservoirs. Name these bodies of water exemplified by five "Great" ones in the US.

This West African nation recently faced devastating floods in its northeastern region, displacing over 200,000 people and resulting in over 200 fatalities. The floods were triggered by heavy rainfall and the collapse of a major dam, causing widespread damage to infrastructure and farmland. It is the most populous country in Africa and a major oil producer. It is also known for its vibrant Nollywood film industry and its diverse cultural landscape, with over 250 ethnic groups. What is the name of this country, with a capital of Abuja and a largest city of Lagos?

This animated masterpiece won the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature in 2003, the first and only hand-drawn and non-English-language film to do so. The main character, Chihiro, must work in a bathhouse for spirits to free her parents who have been turned into pigs. Its iconic characters, like the enigmatic Haku and the mysterious No-Face, have resonated with audiences worldwide. What is the name of this critically acclaimed Japanese animated film directed by Hayao Miyazaki?

The efficiency of refrigerators was once rated in frigories, a unit equivalent to one of these units per hour. It is not a unit of mass or temperature, but one of these units defines the specific heat of water. There are 4.184 joules in the small version of this unit, and there are nine of their large kind in each gram of fat. Name this non-SI unit that is listed on packages to show the energy content of food.

One event in this country's history was a series of attacks on civilians and foreigners by the Videla Regime known as the Dirty War. Mossad carried out an operation to capture Adolf Eichmann in this country. This country fought a war against Great Britain for control of the Falkland Islands. Identify this country whose former leaders include Nestor Kirchner and Juan Peron.

The "Committee of Five" was assigned to create this document, which ends with signatories pledging "our Lives, our Fortunes and our sacred Honor". A large signature by John Hancock is distinguishable in this document, signed at the Second Continental Congress in Philadelphia, which states that "all men are created equal". Name this work by Thomas Jefferson, adopted on July 4, 1776, that announced the freedom of the colonies.

Lake Ladoga, the largest freshwater lake fully in Europe, is in this country, and this country's exclave of Kaliningrad lies between Poland and Lithuania. The city of Vladivostok is located in the far east of this country, as is the deepest lake in the world, Lake Baikal. The Trans-Siberian Railway traverses what Eurasian country with its capital at Moscow, the largest country in the world by area?

In one work from this country, a naval commander uses straw boats to capture arrows from Cao Cao's archers, and three men swear the Oath of the Peach Garden. In another work from this country, Sandy and Pigsy go to India with Sun Wukong, the Monkey King. Romance of the Three Kingdoms and Journey to the West are two of the Four Classics of what country home to the writers Luo Guanzhong and Wu Cheng'en?

These objects can emit surface helium flash as they accrete matter from binary companions. Their upper mass limit, about 1.44 solar masses, is named for the Indian physicist Chandrasekhar; above it, electron degeneracy pressure fails and they collapse into neutron stars. Largely incapable of undergoing fusion, this is what type of faintly luminous, small stellar remnant, not to be confused with "red" and "brown" stars of the same size?

A collection of some of these works, recited on holidays, is called Hallel, and its fifty-first section is known as the "Miserere". One passage of this book laments "I have so many enemies" as its author flees his son Absalom. Another portion reads, "Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good." Name this Biblical book, written primarily by David, whose twenty-third section begins, "The Lord is my shepherd."

This tennis player holds the record for the most consecutive weeks ranked world No. 1 in women's tennis, with an impressive 186 weeks. Her powerful forehand, often referred to as the "forehand drive," was a fearsome weapon that helped her dominate opponents on all surfaces. She achieved a "Golden Slam" in 1988, winning all four Grand Slam singles titles and the Olympic gold medal in the same calendar year. She retired from professional tennis in 1999, leaving behind a legacy of 22 Grand Slam singles titles and a reputation as one of the greatest players of all time. Who is this German tennis legend?

This event took place on King Street and was ended by Thomas Hutchinson's clearing of the crowd. An inaccurate engraving depicts the perpetrators of this event standing in an organized line; that engraving by Paul Revere also depicts the first victim of this event as a white man. Crispus Attucks was one of five people killed by British soldiers in what March 5, 1770 incident in Massachusetts?

This institution cut interest rates for the first time since 2020 on September 8, 2024. Their current chair, Jerome Powell, was sworn into office in February 2018. It is divided into 12 regional banks across the United States, each with its own president. Its primary functions include conducting monetary policy, supervising and regulating banks, and maintaining the stability of the financial system. It was established in 1913. What is the name of this central banking system of the United States?

This actor's iconic line, "You talkin' to me?", from "Taxi Driver," captures the character's descent into madness. He also co-founded the Tribeca Film Festival, a platform for showcasing independent films and emerging talent. He won two Oscars, for his roles in "The Godfather Part II" and "Raging Bull." He's known for his frequent collaborations with director Martin Scorsese, including "Goodfellas" and "The Departed." Who is this legendary actor?

This sports executive, often referred to as the "Commissioner of the World" for his role in expanding the NBA's global reach, oversaw the creation of the WNBA and the NBA Development League during his tenure. He implemented the NBA draft lottery system in 1985, aimed at discouraging teams from intentionally losing games to secure the top pick. His leadership also saw the introduction of the salary cap and revenue sharing, which contributed to the league's financial stability and competitive balance. Who was this commissioner of the NBA from 1984 to 2014?

This state's second-largest city is home to the BOK Tower, a half-sized replica of the original World Trade Center twin towers designed by the same firm. This state's flagship university is in Norman, a suburb of its largest city. The Choctaw Nation is established in the southeast of this state, which was once labeled Indian Territory. Name this central US state that is home to Tulsa and a prominent panhandle north of Texas.

One variant of this group of people in Iceland existed under the Vistarband system. In one country, this group of people could relocate themselves during the two weeks around Yuri's Day, and that country also saw many members of this group join Pugachev's Rebellion. Freed in Austria in 1848 and Prussia in 1807, this group of people could be owned by the Church and State as well as private landowners. Name this class of peasants who were tied to the land they worked on, finally emancipated in Russia by Alexander II in 1861.

One famous depiction of this event was captured by John Filo, and most prominently featured Mary Ann Vecchio and Jeffrey Miller. Spurred in part by Governor James Rhodes describing participants of a protest as "un-American", this event saw 67 shots fired, which killed 4 people and injured 9 others, some of whom had been protesting the U.S. invasion of Cambodia. Identify this May 4, 1970 incident in which the Ohio National Guard fired into a crowd of unarmed protesters at an Ohio university.

This quantity can be defined as momentum squared divided by two times the mass. This quantity is conserved during elastic collisions but not inelastic collisions, and it is calculated by the formula one-half times mass times velocity squared. A roller coaster maximizes this energy at the bottom of a hill. Name this type of energy that is possessed by all moving objects, often contrasted with potential energy.

In a coordinated attack by Israel against Hezbollah, these devices exploded killing at least 42 people. This technology, once ubiquitous in the 1990s, relies on radio frequencies and specialized networks to transmit brief text messages or numeric codes to a small, portable device. Its iconic numeric display and distinctive beep became synonymous with the era. Though largely eclipsed by smartphones and mobile messaging apps, it still finds use in specific contexts, such as hospitals and critical infrastructure systems, where its simplicity and dependability remain valuable. What is this technology?

This iconic Western film's climactic scene, a three-way Mexican standoff in a cemetery, is renowned for its suspenseful buildup and Ennio Morricone's unforgettable score. The film's protagonist, the "Man with No Name," is played by Clint Eastwood, solidifying his status as a Western icon. Its title refers to the three main characters: Blondie, Angel Eyes, and Tuco, who are all searching for a hidden treasure. The film is the third installment in Sergio Leone's "Dollars Trilogy." What is the title of this epic Spaghetti Western?
answers: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
incorrect1: Once Upon a Time in the West

question: Heidhrun stands on top of this place and produces mead for this building's residents, who are woken daily by Gullinkambi. This building is contrasted with Folkvangr, and a boar is slaughtered every day to feed the Einherjar, who live here. This building's rafters are spears and its ceiling is made of shields. The Valkyries carry half of the heroes slain in battle to what mythological mead hall ruled over by Odin?

This NFL team relocated from Baltimore to Indianapolis in 1984, amidst a controversial midnight move orchestrated by then-owner Robert Irsay. They secured their first Super Bowl victory in 1971 in Baltimore, led by legendary quarterback Johnny Unitas. Their iconic horseshoe logo has become a symbol of the franchise. They experienced a resurgence in the 2000s, led by Peyton Manning, culminating in a Super Bowl XLI victory in 2007. What is the name of this team, whose home games are played at Lucas Oil Stadium?

This author dreams of a ritual surrounding the Valentine's Day mating of the birds in one work. In a poem by this author, three brothers attempt to kill Death, and an old woman teaches a knight what women want in marriage. A group of travelers gather in the Tabard Inn to hear stories from the Pardoner and the Wife of Bath in one of this man's works. Name this English author of The Parliament of Fowls and The Canterbury Tales.

In this state, the Secret Service spotted a potential gunman trying to assisinate Donald Trump on a golf course. This state's iconic citrus industry, particularly its oranges and grapefruits, has earned it the nickname "The Citrus State," though it's more commonly known as "The Sunshine State." It's home to the Everglades, a vast subtropical wetland teeming with unique wildlife like alligators and manatees. The Kennedy Space Center, located on its eastern coast, has been the launch site for numerous historic space missions, including the Apollo 11 moon landing. Name this state.

The first American casualty in this war took place at the Battle of Osan. After UN forces were pushed back to the Pusan Perimeter during this war, Douglas MacArthur led a counterattack from Inchon. A demilitarized zone along the 38th parallel was established after this war, which separated two countries. Name this war that was fought on a namesake Asian peninsula from 1950 to 1953.

This cult classic comedy features a protagonist who enjoys White Russians, bowling, and listening to Creedence Clearwater Revival. The film's iconic line, "The Dude abides," perfectly encapsulates the laid-back attitude of its central charactee. The Dude, mistaken for a millionaire with the same name, finds himself entangled in a bizarre kidnapping plot involving a stolen rug, nihilists, and a pornographer named Jackie Treehorn. The film's eclectic soundtrack, quirky characters, and quotable dialogue have solidified its place as a beloved comedy with a dedicated fan following. What is the title of this 1998 film directed by the Coen brothers?

Some members of this phylum breathe using their plated book lungs while other organs are housed in the hemocoel. This phylum is characterized by, and named for, their jointed legs, and organisms in this phylum have a segmented body protected by an exoskeleton. The classes Trilobita and Arachnida fall under what phylum that includes invertebrates like crustaceans, spiders and insects?

This inventor was nicknamed "The Wizard of Menlo Park." This man invented the movie camera and the phonograph. It is said that he didn't fail, he just "found 10,000 ways that won't work" when creating his most famous invention. What man invented the lightbulb?

Mount Darwin is the highest peak on its largest island, which lies north of the Drake Passage. The cities of Rio Grande and Ushuaia are possessed by one country, while another controls the island of Cape Horn, the southern tip of this archipelago.
