Companies during this period warned customers not to leave bricks of dehydrated grapes in a "cool cupboard for twenty-one days." This period was ushered in by the eighteenth amendment, which was repealed just fourteen years later by the twenty-first amendment. Name this period in American history in which the consumption of alcohol was illegal.

Neil Sloane and Simon Plouffe first defined the "super" form of this expression, which Clifford Pickover used a dollar sign to signify. Sterling's approximation can find large values of these, which are found in the denominator in every term of the Taylor series for e^x (e to the x). Used in combinations and permutations, the only prime one of these is 2, and its value for 4 and 5 is 24 and 120, respectively. Identify this mathematical expression whose value for n is the product of all positive integers less than or equal to n, symbolized as an exclamation point.

An author from this country wrote about Hana caring for Count Almasy in The English Patient. This is the home country of Michael Ondaatje, Nobel Prize winner Alice Munro, and the author of a novel in which Offred tries to escape from her oppressive life in the Republic of Gilead, The Handmaid's Tale. Author Margaret Atwood is from what country north of the United States?

This country hosted the conference that created the Non-Aligned Movement in its city of Bandung. A leader of this country launched a purge of communists after a coup by the 30th of September movement failed to overthrow him and attempted to implement "guided democracy" in this country. That leader was Sukarno. This country's capital was known as Batavia when it was colonized by the Dutch. Name this island nation that has the largest Muslim population in the world, with capital Jakarta.

This team's mascot, Champ, a spirited blue horse, entertains fans with his acrobatic dunks and playful antics. Their home arena, the American Airlines Center, is a state-of-the-art facility that has hosted numerous major sporting and entertainment events. They achieved their first and only NBA championship in 2011, led by Dirk Nowitzki, a German-born power forward who became a global icon. What is the name of this Texas-based NBA franchise?

The women's record time for this race was set by Ruth Chepng'etich in Chicago on October 13, 2024. The first modern one of these was held at the 1896 Summer Olympics in Athens along its namesake route. The world record for the fastest completion of this race is held by another Kenyan in under 2 hours and one minute. This footrace, famously commemorating the legendary run of Pheidippides to Athens in 490 BC, covers a distance of 26.2 miles, or 42.2 kilometers. What is this grueling yet rewarding athletic event?

This rock and roll icon, known for his energetic performances and signature dance moves, was famously nicknamed "the Pelvis" due to his suggestive hip gyrations.  His debut single, "That's All Right," released in 1954, helped popularize rock and roll music and launched him to stardom. He served in the US Army from 1958 to 1960, stationed in Germany, where he met his future wife, Priscilla Beaulieu. His Graceland mansion in Memphis, Tennessee, has become a popular tourist destination and a shrine for fans worldwide. Who is this legendary singer and actor, often dubbed the "King of Rock and Roll"?

Climbers traditionally stop just short of the peak of a mountain in this range named for five treasures, which is called Kangchenjunga. A majority of the so-called "Eight Thousanders" are in this young range. Tenzing Norgay accompanied Edmund Hillary in climbing a mountain in this range "because it's there". What mountain range contains Mount Everest, the tallest mountain in the world?

In 2008, Otis McDonald sued the city of Chicago over a ban on these items; the Supreme Court struck down that ban shortly after deciding a similar case, DC vs. Heller. As the head of an organization advocating for these items, Charlton Heston stated that Al Gore could take one from his "cold dead hands." The Brady Bill requires federal background checks be performed before buying what objects that are the subject of the 2nd Amendment?

A popular method for solving systems of linear equations works one of these objects into reduced "row-echelon form." If one of these objects is square, its trace is simply the sum of values along a diagonal, and these mathematical arrangements have an inverse if and only if their determinant is not zero. Name these rectangular arrays of numbers, arranged in columns and rows.

This NBA team, known for its recent string of playoff appearances, has a history marked by both exciting moments and unfortunate setbacks.  Despite boasting star players like Kawhi Leonard and Paul George, they have yet to reach the NBA Finals, often falling short in crucial playoff series. They shared their home arena, Crypto.com Arena, with their crosstown rivals, the Los Angeles Lakers before the Intuit Dome opened in Inglewood. Name this team who often plays second fiddle to the Lakes in Los Angeles.

This man once refused to escape from prison despite an earthquake having destroyed the building. At the incident of Antioch, he confronted another man about that man's gentile-like behavior. This man frequently traveled with men named Silas and Timothy. His sight was restored by Ananias of Damascus after he had been temporarily blinded, and he had participated in the stoning of St. Stephen before his conversion to Christianity. Name this apostle whose letters comprise more than half of the New Testament of the Bible.

Orthoclase is a type of feldspar that contains this element, whose isotope-40 is used with argon to date rock formations. This element's chloride is used in executions, and nitrates of it are found in saltpeter and fertilizer. This element emits a lilac color in a flame test, and a water-soluble form of this element is found in potash. Name this alkali element, slightly less reactive to air and water than sodium, whose chemical symbol is K.

C/2023 A3 (Tsuchinshan–ATLAS), one of these objects, was discovered in 2023 and is the brighest one since Neowise in 2020. These celestial objects, often described as "dirty snowballs," are composed of ice, dust, and rock, and originate from the outer regions of the solar system.  They are known for their distinctive tails, which are formed when the sun's heat vaporizes the ice and dust, creating a luminous trail that can stretch for millions of miles. Halley's, perhaps the most famous of its kind, is visible from Earth every 76 years. What are these icy wanderers of the solar system?

This band's iconic album, The Joshua Tree, released in 1987, features a stark black and white cover photograph shot by Anton Corbijn in the Mojave Desert. Their politically charged anthem, "Sunday Bloody Sunday," commemorates the 1972 Bogside Massacre in Northern Ireland. They famously performed on a rooftop in Los Angeles in 1987, causing a traffic jam and leading to their arrest. The band's four members—Bono, The Edge, Adam Clayton, and Larry Mullen Jr.—have remained together since their formation in 1976.  What is the name of this Irish rock band known for their anthemic sound and social activism?

British troops were withdrawn to Castle Island after this event. John Adams was among the men who served as defense attorneys in a trial following this event. Henry Pelham and Paul Revere made depictions of this event to serve as propaganda against one side in this event. This event, which followed the passing of the Townshend Acts, saw Crispus Attucks killed by musket fire after a crowd attacked British soldiers. Name this event in 1770, where five people were killed in a city in Massachusetts.

This ruler wrote of his support of witch hunts in his Daemonologie. The Main Plot led to the arrest of Sir Walter Raleigh during this man's rule. The son of Mary, Queen of Scots, this monarch was said to have had a homosexual relationship with the Duke of Buckingham, while he faced an assassination attempt led by Robert Catesby and Guy Fawkes. The Gunpowder Plot occurred during this man's reign, which also saw a translation of the Bible named after him. Name the first Stuart king of England, who succeeded Elizabeth I.

This river divides Minneapolis and St. Paul. In 1927, this river's flood was the worst in US history, causing a system of levees to be built that was the world's longest. Nicknamed the "Big Muddy", this river serves as part of the border between Louisiana and its namesake state. Name this river that, with the Missouri, makes up the longest river system in the United States.

One of these landforms "of Tehuantepec" is found in the Mexican states of Oaxaca and Veracruz. One "of Kra" connects the Malay Peninsula to the rest of Asia. The Suez Canal was built across one of these landforms separating the Red and Mediterranean Seas. Name these narrow strips of land that connect larger land masses, another of which is the country of Panama.

An instrument of this type plays a continuous ostinato for the entirety of Maurice Ravel's Bolero. The tabla is an Indian instrument of this type. A metal kind of this instrument popular in Caribbean music can play several different notes and is called its "steel" type. Timpanis are large, tunable examples of what percussion instruments with "bass" and "snare" types?

The death of two Guyanese immigrants in this city sparked the Crown Heights riots between its black and Jewish populations. In 1969, a police raid of this city's Stonewall Inn sparked the beginning of the modern LGBT movement. Peter Minuit purchased the land that would eventually become this city from Native Americans. Mayor Fiorello La Guardia took down this city's Tammany Hall political machine. In 2001, two planes crashed into its World Trade Center. Name this most populous city in the United States.

This fashion house teamed up with Axiom to design a space suit for NASA's 2026 moon landing. This luxury fashion house, founded in Milan in 1913, initially gained recognition for its high-quality leather goods and travel accessories. Its iconic nylon backpack, introduced in the 1980s, revolutionized the fashion industry with its blend of practicality and luxury.  Name this brand whose signature triangular logo, often discreetly placed on its products, has become a symbol of understated elegance and sophistication.

His wife was part of the Gang of Four, and he supported, then suppressed, the Hundred Flowers campaign. He encouraged a phase in which village furnaces produced low-quality steel and another in which the "Four Olds" were attacked by Red Guards. He retreated on the Long March from Chiang Kai-Shek. The initiator of the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution, and author of the Little Red Book name the first Chairman of Communist China.

This team's legendary double-play combination of Tinker to Evers to Chance, immortalized in a 1910 poem by Franklin Pierce Adams, became a symbol of baseball's golden age. Their home ballpark, Wrigley Field, is the second-oldest ballpark in Major League Baseball and is known for its ivy-covered outfield walls and iconic marquee.  They famously broke a 108-year championship drought in 2016, winning a thrilling World Series in seven games against the Cleveland Indians.  What is the name of this National League MLB team?

This band's 1975 self-titled album, featuring the hit single "Rhiannon," marked a significant shift in their sound, incorporating more pop and rock elements. The album's success propelled them to international stardom and laid the groundwork for their even more successful follow-up. Rumours, released in 1977, became one of the best-selling albums of all time, fueled by interpersonal drama within the band and hit songs like "Go Your Own Way" and "Dreams."  The band's classic lineup consisted of Lindsey Buckingham, Stevie Nicks, Christine McVie, John McVie, and Mick Fleetwood. What is the name of this British-American rock band?

This author wrote about "Irma's Injection" in his 1900 book The Interpretation of Dreams. "Anna O.," "Little Hans," and the "Wolf Man" were some of the patients who sought advice from his Vienna clinic. "Jokes and their Relation to the Unconscious" is an essay by this man, whose "structural theory" proposed that the mind is divided into the id, the ego, and the superego. Name this Austrian founder of psychoanalysis.

This man made a speech stating "I have given my life to this struggle of the African people," and mentioning "an ideal I hope to live for." That speech was due to this man's involvement in Umkhonto We Sizwe, the "Spear of the Nation." This founder of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission stated "I am prepared to die" at the Rivonia Trial and spent 18 years on Robben Island before he was released from prison by F.W. De Klerk. Name this civil rights leader and first black President of South Africa.

This gymnast, the first Hmong-American Olympian, captivated the world with her performance at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, where she secured the all-around gold medal.  She overcame adversity, including a fall on the uneven bars during the team competition and the challenges of competing amidst the COVID-19 pandemic.  Her powerful routines and graceful artistry earned her a silver medal in the team event and a bronze medal on the uneven bars.  Who is this talented athlete, who later competed for Auburn University's gymnastics team while also appearing on "Dancing with the Stars"?

One deity from this myth system received the four winds as a gift from his grandfather and used them to kill its creator goddess, Tiamat. Another deity from this myth system corresponds to the Sumerian Inanna and removed seven objects of clothing at seven different gates in the underworld. Marduk and Ishtar appear in what myth system that also includes the legendary king Gilgamesh?

This international convenience store chain is closing 444 underperforming stores in North America. The company's origins trace back to 1927 as an ice house storefront in Dallas, Texas, where customers could purchase essential groceries like bread and milk.  It was the first convenience store to franchise its operations, paving the way for its rapid expansion and dominance in the industry. The chain, with over 77,000 locations worldwide, holds the record for the most convenience stores globally. Name this chain, home to the iconic Slurpee, a frozen carbonated beverage, which has become a summertime staple and a symbol of the brand.

This FX crime drama, known for its gritty realism and morally ambiguous characters, centered around the Strike Team, a corrupt yet effective unit within the Los Angeles Police Department.  The show's protagonist, Detective Vic Mackey, played by Michael Chiklis, was a complex anti-hero who often blurred the lines between justice and brutality.  The series finale, which aired in 2008, left viewers with a sense of unease and ambiguity, as Mackey's actions finally caught up with him.  What is the name of this acclaimed series, which explored the dark side of law enforcement and the complexities of morality?

Establishments that violated this policy were vandalized by the hatchet-wielding Carrie Nation. This policy was enforced by the Volstead Act, and it was later repealed by the 21st Amendment. Supporters of this policy were known as "drys" while those who opposed it were known as "wets." Groups like the Anti-Saloon League pushed for what policy banning alcohol in the United States?

This property was discovered by Uhlenbeck and Goudsmit in alkali metals. Graviton has a value of 2 for this property, and the Higgs boson has a value of 0 for it. This property causes ferromagnetism when its moment for all atoms line up in the material. Electrons with the same value for it are forbidden to share an orbital due to the Pauli Exclusion Principle. An integer for bosons and half-integer for fermions identify this property, the intrinsic angular momentum of a subatomic particle that is either one-half or negative one-half for the electron.

The peak of Mt. Chimborazo in this mountain range is the farthest point on Earth's surface from the center of Earth, and Tupungato and Cotopaxi are volcanoes found in this mountain range. Ojos del Salado, the world's highest active volcano, is located here, and the Altiplano plateau is the world's second highest plateau. Cities such as Arequippa and Medellin can be found in other plateaus in this mountain range, and Mendoza is a frequent stop for climbers of Aconcagua. Identify longest continental mountain range on Earth, stretching from Colombia and Venezuela to Chile and Argentina.

This state's "Unassigned Lands" were claimed in an infamous 1889 land rush. In this state's capital, 168 people were killed in a 1995 bombing by Timothy McVeigh. In 1921, the wealthiest African-American community in the country, the Greenwood district, was burned during this state's Tulsa race riots. Name this central U.S. state where "Sooners" now live in a panhandle north of Texas.

This singer's powerful rendition of "The Star-Spangled Banner" at Super Bowl XXV in 1991, amidst the backdrop of the Gulf War, became a cultural touchstone and a symbol of national unity.  Her iconic performance in the 1992 film The Bodyguard propelled the soundtrack to become one of the best-selling albums of all time.  She achieved unprecedented success with her debut album, which featured three consecutive number-one singles: "Saving All My Love for You," "How Will I Know," and "Greatest Love of All."  Who is this legendary vocalist, known for her soaring vocals and impressive range?

William the Conqueror commissioned the "Domesday" one of these objects to determine land ownership. One of these objects "of Common Prayer" standardized the practice of Anglicanism. A means of mass-producing these objects was invented by Johannes Gutenberg. A famous one of these objects was produced in Kells, Ireland. Illuminated manuscripts were hand-written examples of what objects which are kept in libraries?

This NFL team, whose iconic purple and gold uniforms and horned helmets are instantly recognizable, plays its home games in a stadium with a unique nautical-themed design, featuring a ship's horn that blasts after every score.  Despite four Super Bowl appearances, the team has yet to claim a championship title, a source of both frustration and enduring loyalty for its passionate fanbase.  Its legendary players, including Fran Tarkenton, Randy Moss, and Adrian Peterson, have left a lasting impact on the franchise and the sport.  What is the name of this team, based in Minneapolis, Minnesota?

These structures may have holes in them called moulins, and elongated hills called drumlins form when they retreat. These features may carve "U" shaped valleys, and they can leave till behind in the form of lateral and terminal moraines. Ice ages are periods of time when continental ones covered most of Earth, and icebergs form by breaking off from these structures. Name these large moving masses of ice.

This author wrote about Pelayo and Elisenda, who charge villagers a fee to see an angel locked in their chicken coop in "A Very Old Man With Enormous Wings." Dr. Juvenal Urbino dies after falling off a ladder, enabling Fermina Daza to marry Florentino Ariza, in a novel by this author. Ursula Iguaran and the colonel Aureliano are part of the seven generations of Macondo's Buendia family in a magical realism novel by this author. Name this Colombian author of Love in the Time of Cholera and One Hundred Years of Solitude.

This city is planning to build a second sphere like the one currently in Las Vegas. Located on a T-shaped island in the Persian Gulf, the city boasts the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque, a stunning architectural marvel that can accommodate over 40,000 worshippers. It is home to a middle eastern Louvre. Its futuristic skyline features iconic structures like the Etihad Towers and the Capital Gate building, which leans at an 18-degree angle. It also hosts the Formula 1 Grand Prix. What is the name of this capital city of the United Arab Emirates?

This body of water contains the Cayman Islands. The Virgin Islands are located in this sea which borders the east coast of Guatemala and Nicaragua. Major islands in this sea are Jamaica and and Puerto Rico. Name this sea located between North America and South America.

Tech giants Amazon, Google, and Microsoft have all invested in this form of energy as they expect increasing energy demand with the growth of artificial intelligence. Despite its potential for clean energy generation, it carries the risk of catastrophic accidents, such as the Chernobyl disaster in 1986 and the Fukushima Daiichi meltdown in 2011. It is also associated with the challenge of safely storing radioactive waste, which can remain hazardous for thousands of years. Name this energy source which is harnessed through the process of fission, and involves splitting the nucleus of an atom, typically uranium, to release immense amounts of energy.

Under his father's command, this man was responsible for defeating the Sacred Band of Thebes in 338 BC. Legend has it that this man solved the Gordian Knot by slicing it with his sword. After this leader's death, his generals, the Diadochi, divided his empire, which stretched from Greece to India. As a youth, this leader was tutored by Aristotle. Name this Macedonian king who conquered the Persian Empire.

This country is home to the world's oldest lighthouse still in use, the Tower of Hercules, in its city of A Coruna. This country's Basque-speaking minority lives in cities like Bilbao, while its eastern portion is known as Catalonia. The slogan "more than a club" is used by a world-famous soccer team from this country's city of Barcelona. What European country is led from Madrid?

When one of these objects' orbit is within Earth's orbit, they are classified in the Aten group, and the Trojan variety of these objects are found within the Lagrangian Points of a larger object. The Alvarez hypothesis states that one of these objects caused the K-T extinction event. The most massive of these objects is Vesta, and the largest was recently classified as a dwarf planet, Ceres. Mame these rocky objects that orbit the sun, most commonly found in the namesake belt between Mars and Jupiter.

This organization filed for bankruptcy in 2020 over payouts to sexual abuse victims. Members of this organization gather for large meetings called Jamborees, and must complete a board of review to attain its highest rank. Members of this organization can earn merit badges for various accomplishments. A special project is required to attain the Eagle rank in what American youth scouting organization?

This critically acclaimed television series, known for its fast-paced dialogue and walk-and-talk scenes, follows the fictional administration of President Josiah Bartlet and his senior staff.  It won numerous awards, including four consecutive Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Drama Series. It tackled complex political and social issues, including healthcare reform, terrorism, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. What is the name of this popular political drama written by Aaron Sorkin?

This team's iconic purple and red dinosaur mascot has been a fan favorite since the franchise's inception in 1995.  Their thrilling victory in the 2019 NBA Finals, led by Kawhi Leonard's clutch performances, marked the first time a Canadian team won the championship. Their home arena, Scotiabank Arena, is located in the heart of downtown Toronto and is known for its passionate and energetic atmosphere.  Drake, a prominent Canadian rapper and global ambassador for the team, is often seen courtside cheering them on. What is the name of this team, the only Canadian-based franchise in the NBA?

A character in this story earns $20 from Madame Sofronie, which she then combines with the $1.87 she had been saving. In this story, a woman assures her husband, Mr Young, that she will soon be able to use the tortoiseshell combs he purchased for her even though, in order to buy a platinum fob chain, she sold her hair. Name this short story in which Jim and Della exchange ironic Christmas presents, written by O. Henry.

This singer's holiday classic, "All I Want for Christmas Is You," released in 1994, has become a perennial chart-topper, re-entering the Billboard Hot 100 every holiday season. Her five-octave vocal range and use of the whistle register are signature elements of her singing style. She holds the record for the most number-one singles on the Billboard Hot 100 by a solo artist, with 19 chart-topping hits.  Her 1995 album, Daydream, featuring the hit "Fantasy," showcased her foray into R&B and hip-hop influences. Who is this iconic singer, often referred to as the "Songbird Supreme"?

This artist notes that he let one girl "lick the wrapper." In one song featuring Rick Ross, this artist claims he can turn security guards into track stars. This creator of songs like "The Sky is the Limit" and "I'm Me" has been sighted coming "straight up out the water wit Marc Jacobs goggles." Name this hip-hop sensation of Cash Money Records who performs songs like "Lollipop," "Stuntin' Like My Daddy" and "Pop Bottles."

This country's flag features a llama and a chichona tree, and the Cordillera Blanca is part of this country's portion of the Andes. In the fifteenth century, the capital of Cuzco was established in this country by the Incan empire. It is bordered by Colombia and Ecuador to the north, Bolivia to the southeast, and Chile to the south. Name this country which contains the westernmost part of the Amazon river and whose capital is Lima.

Before becoming president, this man had started a diplomatic crisis when he tried and executed the British subjects Robert Ambrister and Alexander Arbuthnot. As president, this man had employed Roger Taney to help him dismantle an institution run by Nicholas Biddle. In addition to facing off with the Second Bank of the United States, this man also passed the Indian Removal Act, which forced the Cherokee to undergo the Trail of Tears. Victim of the "Corrupt Bargain" of 1824 name this man nicknamed "Old Hickory," the 7th President of the United States.

This coach, nicknamed the "Zen Master" for his unconventional coaching methods and interest in Eastern philosophy, holds the NBA record for the most championships won as a head coach, with 11 titles to his name. He led the Chicago Bulls to six NBA championships in the 1990s, with Michael Jordan as the centerpiece of his triangle offense strategy. He later guided the Los Angeles Lakers to five championships, utilizing the same offensive system with Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant. Who is this legendary coach, known for his unique approach to leadership and his ability to manage star-studded teams?

Binet's formula is one method of finding numbers of this type. The ratio between consecutive numbers of this type in this sequence is close to those in the Golden Ratio, and it also occurs in the sums of "shallow" diagonals in Pascal's Triangle. A similarly named spiral can be formed when this sequence is tiled and the opposite corners of the squares are connected via circular arcs. Name this sequence where the first numbers are 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, where each subsequent number is the sum of the previous two.

Israel announced the killing of this man in Gaza and released drone footage of the last moments of his life. This man was sentenced to four life sentences in Israel for orchestrating the abduction and killing of two Israeli soldiers and four Palestinians he considered to be collaborators. He spent 22 years in prison until his release among 1,026 others in a 2011 prisoner exchange for Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit. Name this former leader of Hamas, widely believed to have orchestrated the October 7 attacks.

This country's Petsamo province was ceded to its eastern neighbor in 1922, but it recaptured much of Karelia during the Continuation War. This country's Sami people live in its province of Lapland, which was the site of late fighting against the Nazis. Fighters from this country used "Molotov cocktails" against Soviet bombings during the Winter War. Name this Scandinavian country with capital at Helsinki.

Diplomats from this nation were expelled from Canada after prime minister Justin Trudeau claimed this nation tried to assassinate a Sikh separatist on Canadian soil. The United States also indicted an agent from this nation for an attempted murder plot on a American advocating for Sikh independent state. This South Asian nation home to the Taj Mahal, a breathtaking monument of love built in the 17th century, boasts a diverse landscape ranging from the Himalayan mountains to the tropical beaches of Goa. It is the birthplace of yoga and Ayurveda, ancient practices that promote physical and mental well-being. Name this nation that is the world's largest, with a population exceeding 1.4 billion people.

The Laffer curve compares the relationship between these measures and revenue. At the 1988 RNC, George H.W. Bush promised no new ones of these, and Benjamin Franklin stated that nothing is certain except death and these. Ones of these on imported goods are known as tariffs, and versions of these include the "sales" and "income" varieties. Name these financial charges that fund the government.

The "Peace Village" is on the border between these two countries, which was created by a 1953 armistice signed in Panmunjom. The Sunshine Policy attempts to improve relations between these two countries. The 38th parallel was used to demarcate the Demilitarized Zone that separates what two Asian nations that share a peninsula that contains cities like Seoul and Pyongyang?

"Fandango Asturiano" is the final movement of one of this man's orchestral works which was inspired by Spanish folk music, and he composed a suite based on One Thousand and One Arabian Nights. In addition to Capriccio Espagnole and Scheherezade, he is known for an interlude in The Tale of Tsar Sultan in which the Tsar's son is turned into an insect. What Russian composer created "The Flight of the Bumblebee"?

This NBA team, known for its passionate fanbase and vibrant purple and black color scheme, recently broke a 16-year playoff drought, the longest in league history. Their home arena, the Golden 1 Center, is famous for lighting a purple beam after wins. The franchise originated in Rochester, New York, in 1923 as the Rochester Seagrams and has had several relocations and name changes throughout its history.  What is the name of this team, whose current roster features rising stars like De'Aaron Fox and Domantas Sabonis?

This film's fast-paced dialogue and electronic soundtrack, composed by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross, capture the energy and intensity of the tech world. The film, directed by David Fincher and written by Aaron Sorkin, features a memorable scene where Mark Zuckerberg, played by Jesse Eisenberg, writes a scathing blog post about his ex-girlfriend, fueling his desire to create a social networking site. It explores the rise of Facebook, from its humble beginnings in a Harvard dorm room to its global dominance, highlighting the legal battles and personal betrayals that shaped its trajectory. What is the title of this 2010 biographical drama?

Despite suffering from dysentery, this leader commanded a successful retreat during the Braddock Expedition. As a young officer in the British army, this leader surrendered Fort Necessity during the French and Indian War. This leader led an attack against sleeping Hessian troops in the Battle of Trenton after crossing the Delaware River. Name this leader of the Continental Army who became the first President of the United States.

The last known communication from this person was with the ship Itasca. She traveled on her most famous journey with Fred Noonan in the Electra, a craft built by Lockheed. Years earlier than this journey, she was the first woman to cross the Atlantic Ocean as a pilot in an airplane. Name this famous American pilot who disappeared over the Pacific Ocean while attempting to fly around the world in 1937.

This actress, known for her independent spirit and sharp wit, famously clashed with studio executives early in her career, refusing to conform to Hollywood's expectations of female stars.  She was renowned for her on-screen partnerships with Spencer Tracy, starring alongside him in nine films, including Adam's Rib and Guess Who's Coming to Dinner. She holds the record for the most Best Actress wins at the Academy Awards, with four Oscars to her name. Who is this legendary actress, whose career spanned six decades and left an indelible mark on Hollywood?

This legendary basketball coach, with a career spanning nearly four decades, has the fifth-most wins in NCAA Division I basketball history, with an astounding 1,098 victories. Her unwavering dedication to her players and her "Definite Dozen" principles, which emphasized discipline, respect, and responsibility, shaped a winning culture that extended beyond the court.  She led the University of Tennessee Lady Volunteers to eight NCAA championships, solidifying her legacy as one of the greatest coaches in the history of the sport. Who is this iconic figure in women's basketball, whose impact transcended sports and inspired generations of athletes?

This concept's elasticity is typically negative, meaning that as the price of a good increases, the quantity consumers want decreases. However, Veblen and Giffen goods are exceptions to this rule.  It is influenced by factors such as consumer preferences, income levels, and the availability of substitutes.  In economic models, this concept is often represented by a downward-sloping curve that intersects with the supply curve to determine the equilibrium price and quantity of a good. What is this economic concept that describes consumers' desire for a particular product or service?

This literary character is found dead in his laboratory by his servant, Poole, and his friend, J.G. Utterson, to whom this man shows a letter of apology supposedly written by the murderer of Sir Danvers Carrew. Another of this man's friends, Dr Lanyon, dies of shock after seeing this man reveal the "evil side" of his nature by consuming a potion. Name this fictional doctor who transforms himself into Edward Hyde.
answers: The Strange Case of Doctor Jekyll and Mr Hyde

question: In this year, the Treaty of Mortefontaine was signed to end the Quasi War. A plan executed in this year's election involved giving John Jay just one electoral vote. The Twelfth Amendment was passed after John Adams lost in a contingent house election to Thomas Jefferson in this year's election. Name this year in which the fourth presidential election was held, which followed the election of 1796.

This company achieved its first ever "chopsticks" landing on October 13, 2024 when a booster engine for its rocket was caught by giant mechanical arms. This private space exploration company, founded by Elon Musk in 2002, achieved a groundbreaking feat in 2012 when its Dragon spacecraft became the first commercial spacecraft to deliver cargo to and from the International Space Station. It has developed a series of reusable rockets, including the Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy, significantly reducing the cost of space travel. Its ambitious Starship program aims to develop a fully reusable spacecraft capable of transporting humans to Mars and beyond. What is the name of this space company?

A congress named for this legislation created a Declaration of Rights and Grievances which was blocked from discussion in the House of Lords by the second Earl Dartmouth. After the repeal of this legislation, parliament passed the Declaratory Act to reassert their authority. This tax was intended to help pay for the French and Indian War by creating revenue from goods such as playing cards. Name this unpopular 1765 act that taxed most paper products in the American colonies.

During the colonial period, this country was known as the territory of the Afars and Issas. Units of the French Foreign Legion were once based in this country, which is adjacent to the Bab el Mandeb, a strait that connects the Red Sea with the Gulf of Aden. Eritrea, Somalia, and Ethiopia border what small nation on the Horn of Africa?

This film, directed by Christopher Nolan, uses a non-linear narrative structure, jumping between different timelines and perspectives to unravel a complex mystery. It delves into the intense rivalry between two magicians, Robert Angier and Alfred Borden, played by Hugh Jackman and Christian Bale, as they compete for fame and recognition in Victorian London.  Their obsession with creating the ultimate illusion, "The Transported Man," leads them down a dangerous path of deception, sabotage, and even murder.  The film's title refers to the final act of a magic trick, the reveal that leaves the audience astonished. What is the name of this 2006 thriller?

This entity's first case as a legal advocate was Guinn v. United States. Its first president was Moorfield Storey and the leadership of Roy Wilkins saw support for Asa Phillip Randolph's Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters. Formed in response to the 1908 Springfield riots, this organization helped publicize Langston Hughes in The Crisis. This organization, led by Benjamin Jealous, absorbed the Niagara Movement. Name this civil rights organization, founded in part by W.E.B. Dubois.
answers: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

question: A documentary about this man's life titled Piece by Piece was released in 2024 and tells the story using Lego animations. This multi-talented artist, known for his signature hat and infectious blend of hip-hop, funk, and pop, co-founded the production duo The Neptunes with Chad Hugo, crafting hits for artists like Jay-Z and Britney Spears. He has won 13 Grammy Awards, including Producer of the Year, and composed the Academy Award-nominated song "Happy" for the animated film "Despicable Me 2."  Name this musician who also co-founded the rock band N.E.R.D, blending rock, funk, and hip-hop influences.

This country's northwest is home to the Islamic Uighur people. The leader of another religion from this country described the "Five Great Relationships" and listed virtues like "reciprocity" and "culture" in one of the "Four Books." Adherents of a third religion from this country follow the practice of "no action," or wu wei. Identify this country home to Confucianism and Daoism.

This Greek letter represents a quantity equal to negative one over volume times the derivative of volume with respect to pressure. Besides compressibility, a process named for this letter is mediated by the weak force and emits an antineutrino. That form of radioactive decay sees a neutron converted into a proton and an electron, changing the atomic number and not the mass. Identify this Greek letter that names a decay which emits an electron, often contrasted with alpha decay.

This work begins by describing "all the powers of Old Europe" entering into "a holy alliance." All history is "the history of class struggles" according to this work, which discusses the opposing classes of bourgeoisie and proletariat. A new ideology based on workers owning the means of production is described in what revolutionary pamphlet by Friedrich Engels and Karl Marx that inspired the politics of Soviet Russia?
answers: The Manifesto of the Communist Party

question: This legendary basketball coach, nicknamed the "Wizard of Westwood," emphasized the importance of preparation and attention to detail, famously starting each season by teaching his players how to properly put on their socks and shoes. He led UCLA to an unprecedented ten NCAA championships in a 12-year period, including a record seven consecutive titles.  His "Pyramid of Success," a philosophy he developed based on his personal values and coaching experiences, outlines the building blocks for achieving success in any field.  Who is this iconic coach, considered one of the greatest in the history of sports?

The last words of one person to die exploring this location were "I am just going outside and may be some time." This region was the subject of the failed Nimrod and Endurance Expeditions, led by Sir Ernest Shackleton, as well as the Terra Nova Expedition, which ended with the death of Robert Scott. Name this continent on which, in December 1911, Roald Amundsen's team first reached the South Pole.

This coming-of-age film features a memorable scene where the protagonist, Benjamin Braddock, played by Dustin Hoffman, drifts aimlessly in his parents' swimming pool, capturing his sense of disillusionment and uncertainty about the future. The film's iconic soundtrack, composed by Simon & Garfunkel, includes the songs "The Sound of Silence" and "Mrs. Robinson," which perfectly complement the film's themes of alienation and rebellion. The film's controversial ending, with Benjamin disrupting Elaine's wedding and escaping with her on a bus, leaves the audience with a sense of ambiguity about their future. What is the title of this 1967 film, directed by Mike Nichols?

This city launched an anti-aircraft barrage against nothing in February 1942, the day after a Japanese sub attacked Ellwood to the west. In this city in 1947, Elizabeth Short was found murdered; her unsolved investigation became known as the "Black Dahlia" case. The 1965 Watts Riots took place in this city, which hosted a surprisingly profitable Summer Olympics in 1984. Karen Bass is the mayor of what largest city in California?

This country's highest point is the stratovolcano, Nevado Ojos del Salado. The Corcovado Gulf separates its mainland from an island possession, and its longest river is the Loa River which runs through the world's driest desert to its north. It controls Rapa Nui on which stand the mo'ai statues; that is also known as Easter Island. Dominated by the Andes mountains and home to the Atacama, this is what South American country with its national congress in Valparaiso and capital at Santiago?

A huge deposit of this element was recently found beneath the US state of Arkansas. The element, the lightest alkali metal, is so soft it can be cut with a knife and so reactive it must be stored in mineral oil to prevent it from reacting with air and water. Despite its reactivity, it is a key component in rechargeable batteries that power everything from smartphones to electric vehicles. Its compounds have also been used for decades to treat bipolar disorder, though the exact mechanism of action remains unclear.  Discovered in 1817 by Johan August Arfwedson, its name comes from the Greek word for "stone." What is this element, with atomic number 3?

This team's mascot, Rocky the Mountain Lion, is known for his acrobatic dunks and energetic performances during games, adding to the lively atmosphere at Ball Arena. Their iconic rainbow skyline jerseys, a tribute to the city's vibrant culture and mountainous backdrop, have become a symbol of the franchise.  They achieved their first NBA championship in 2023, led by Nikola Jokić, a Serbian center who earned the Finals MVP award. What is the name of this team, whose high-altitude home court is often referred to as the "Mile High City"?

Fubini's theorem details conditions under which two applications of this operation can be performed in either order. Trigonometric substitution can simplify this operation when square roots are involved. This operation may be performed "by parts" on products of two functions. Simpson's rule and the trapezoidal rule are both methods for approximating this operation. The fundamental theorem of calculus states this operation is the reverse of differentiation. Name this operation that, in the xy plane, calculates the area under a function.

This empire's Qhapaq Nan road network was used to transmit information with strings called quipu. Hiram Bingham excavated the ruins of this empire, whose final ruler was Atahualpa. This empire's capital city, Cuzco, was captured by the conquistador Francisco Pizarro. Around 1450, this empire built a stone citadel in the Andes Mountains. Name this South American empire that built Machu Picchu in Peru.

At the beginning of this poem, a group of warriors argue over Briseis and Chryseis. Forces led by Diomedes and Agamemnon are listed in this poem's "Catalogue of Ships." In this poem, Priam begs for the return of his son's body after it is dragged around the walls of his city. Hector kills Patroclus in this poem, which opens by asking the goddess to "sing the rage of Achilles." Name this epic poem attributed to Homer that describes the events of the Trojan War.

Pius X justified this practice with the Gospel of John, in which Jesus breathes on his disciples and tells them to "forgive." Since Vatican II, this ritual may be performed while facing a priest. The Act of Contrition may be read during this practice, which often ends with an order to pray for forgiveness by reciting a number of Hail Marys. Name this Catholic act of admitting one's sins to a priest.

In the 1830s, the US and UK fought over this state's border in the bloodless Aroostook War. Bowdoin College was founded in this state in 1794 in Brunswick. This state's other cities include Lewiston and Bangor. Despite sharing no border, this state was part of Massachusetts until 1820. The Webster-Ashburton Treaty decided the border between Canada's New Brunswick and what northernmost state in New England whose capital is Augusta?

A prehistoric site in this river's watershed is the Marmes Rockshelter. The Celilo Canal and the city of Kettle Falls were built along it. This river's hydroelectric power is monitored by the Bonneville Power Administration. This river joins the Snake and Yakima at the Tri-Cities area. The Grand Coulee Dam lies on what river famous for its salmon runs that comprises part of the Oregon-Washington border?

This NBA team's vibrant blue, orange, and yellow color scheme is a nod to the state's vibrant sunsets and Native American heritage.  They relocated from Seattle in 2008, bringing with them a passionate fanbase that has embraced the team's new identity. This team once rostered 3 future MVPs in Kevin Durant, Russell Westbrook, and James Harden. What is the name of this team, whose history includes a memorable NBA Finals appearance in 2012?

Phil Lesh, the bassist for this band, passed away at age 84 in October 2024. Their iconic "skull and roses" logo, designed by artist Stanley Mouse, became a symbol of the band's countercultural appeal. Their unique blend of rock, folk, bluegrass, and psychedelia, often featuring extended improvisational jams, defied categorization and attracted a diverse following. Their 1967 anthem, "Truckin'," captures the spirit of their nomadic lifestyle and their connection to the open road. What is the name of this influential band, whose fans are known as "Deadheads"?

"The History of Astronomy" is one of his Essays on Philosophical Subjects, and another work by this man talks about "different progress of opulence" and "the nature, accumulation, and employment of stock" and includes a parable about a butcher, baker, and brewer, whose self-interests promote general welfare. This man also defined a metaphor for the self-regulating nature of free markets. Name this Scot who created the "invisible hand," the author of The Wealth of Nations.

This online video game, known for its distinctive building mechanics and vibrant cartoonish graphics, features a "Battle Royale" mode where 100 players compete to be the last one standing. Its ever-evolving map includes named locations like Tilted Towers and Loot Lake, which have become familiar landmarks to players.  It has collaborated with numerous pop culture icons, including Marvel superheroes, Star Wars characters, and musicians like Ariana Grande and Travis Scott.  Its emotes, or dances, have become viral sensations, often imitated in real-life celebrations and social media trends.  What is the name of this popular free-to-play game?

In Larmor precession, this entity causes charged particles to rotate with a frequency proportional to its strength. The Zeeman effect describes the splitting of spectral lines in the presence of one of these. It can be computed with the Biot-Savart law, and Ampere's law states that the integral of it over a closed curve is proportional to the enclosed current. Symbolized B, the one generated by Earth has a strength of approximately 0.6 Gauss. Name this field that is conventionally denoted as travelling from a north pole to a south pole.

In one of this man's plays, a character presents Nina with the title object as a gift, but she is horrified and instead longs to be with Trigorin. In another play by this author, the title character loves Elena, the second wife of Serebryakov, a retired professor whom the title character blames all his problems on and tries to shoot. Known for his namesake gun name this Russian playwright, writer of works such as The Seagull and Uncle Vanya.

For an ideal gas, this property is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the particles. Relative humidity is computed by comparing the wet-bulb and dry-bulb measurements of this quantity. According to the third law of thermodynamics, a perfect crystal has zero entropy when this property is absolute zero. Name this quantity whose SI unit is the kelvin and that can also be measured on the Celsius and Fahrenheit scales.

This country's residents used the hashtag #thisismydam to support the construction of its Grand Renaissance Dam. This country contains Lake Tana, which is the source of the Blue Nile. This country lost its Red Sea coastline after neighboring Eritrea became independent from it, and it comprises the Horn of Africa, along with Djibouti and Somalia. Name this country, home to the capital Addis Ababa.

A leader of this country, who had helped overthrow Farouk I, moved several temples as part of the construction of the Aswan High Dam, and fought a war with the UK, France, and Israel after trying to nationalize the Suez Canal. Gamal Abdel Nasser and Ramses II have led this country, where Napoleon's troops legendarily damaged the Great Sphinx of Giza. Name this country where Anwar Sadat was assassinated in Cairo.

This sport, often described as the fastest field game in the world, features players using a wooden stick called a hurley to hit a small ball called a sliotar.  It is known for its fast-paced action, skillful stickwork, and passionate fans.  Its origins can be traced back to ancient Ireland, with legends claiming it was played as far back as 1200 BC.  The sport's governing body, the Gaelic Athletic Association, also oversees Gaelic football, another popular Irish sport.  What is this exciting sport, primarily played in Ireland?

This man resigned as Secretary of State following the sinking of the Lusitania, and later led the prosecution in the Scopes Monkey Trial. This man supported bimetallism in an 1896 speech in which he exclaimed, "You shall not press down upon the brow of labor this crown of thorns". Name this populist orator of the "Cross of Gold Speech" who ran three times for president as a Democrat.

This country recently sent thousands of troops to Russia to aid the country in its war against Ukraine. This country, known for its mountainous terrain and the Paektu Mountain, a sacred volcano considered the mythical birthplace of its people, shares a heavily fortified border with its southern neighbor, the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ). It is divided into nine provinces and two special cities, with Pyongyang serving as its capital. Name this nation that has history marked by a devastating war in the 1950s which led to its division and an ongoing political conflict with the international community.

This film's iconic opening montage, set to George Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue," captures the romantic and melancholic beauty of New York City.  It features a controversial relationship between Isaac, a 42-year-old writer played by Woody Allen, and Tracy, a 17-year-old high school student played by Mariel Hemingway.  The film's witty dialogue and exploration of themes of love, relationships, and identity in the urban landscape have made it a classic of American cinema.  What is the title of this 1979 romantic comedy-drama?

The power grid of this nation went down twice in the span of 24 hours in October 2024. The island nation, known for its vibrant music scene and classic cars from the 1950s, is home to the Sierra Maestra, a mountain range that served as a base for Fidel Castro's revolutionary forces. Its capital city, Havana, boasts colorful colonial architecture and a lively Malecón boardwalk along the coast.  It is the largest island in the Caribbean and played a pivotal role in the Cold War. What is this country, famous for its cigars, rum, and salsa dancing?

It is hypothesized that one of them would decay into a pion and a positron, though this would take over ten to the thirty years. Stars fuse hydrogen into helium by the chain reaction named after these, and these baryons have two up quarks and one down quark. An alpha particle has two of them and their amount in a particle can be symbolized Z. Have a charge of one point six times ten to the negative nineteen coulombs, these are what positively charged particles found in an atom's nucleus.

Harry Reid International Airport serves this state's biggest city and nearby cities like Henderson. The "Extraterrestrial Highway" is in this state, and Groom Lake is located near a military base in this state. This state's border with Arizona is partially formed by Lake Mead. This state and California share Lake Tahoe. Carson City and Reno are in what state home to Area 51 and many casinos in Las Vegas?

During his execution, this figure was pierced by the Lance of Longinus. In addition to yelling at a fig tree for not bearing fruit, this figure healed a pig-eating man from Gerasa possessed by a horde of devils named Legion. This man was put to death by Pontius Pilate, and drops of his blood fell into the Holy Grail. Name this Messiah and only son of God according to Christianity.

A Nobel Laureate from this country wrote of Madame Pace, whose brothel employs The Mother and The Stepdaughter; that play ends with a complaint by The Manager. A Henry James work set in this country sees Giovanelli court the title girl. In addition to Six Characters in Search of an Author and Daisy Miller, this country sees the frame story surrounding the one hundred tales in The Decameron. Name this European country, the homeland of Luigi Pirandello and Giovanni Boccaccio.

Happy Chandler inspired this movement by condemning the "gentleman's agreement" of his predecessor, Kenesaw Mountain Landis. Larry Doby of Cleveland was the second subject of this movement, which began when a member of the Kansas City Monarchs was signed by General Manager Branch Rickey in 1945. Name this event of the civil rights movement, in which the Brooklyn Dodgers signed eventual Hall of Famer Jackie Robinson.

This gritty 1971 thriller features a gripping car chase scene where the protagonist pursues an elevated train on the streets of New York City.  The film's raw and realistic depiction of police work and drug trafficking earned it five Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Actor for Gene Hackman's portrayal of Detective Jimmy "Popeye" Doyle.  Based on a true story, it follows two New York City detectives as they try to bust a drug smuggling ring.  What is the title of this neo-noir classic directed by William Friedkin?

This team's name, a nod to the iconic "Guardians of Traffic" statues that adorn the Hope Memorial Bridge near their home stadium, was adopted in 2021 after years of controversy surrounding their previous moniker.  Their home ballpark, Progressive Field, boasts a distinctive left field bleacher section known as "The Corner."  They have won two World Series titles, the most recent coming in 1948, ending a then-record 28-year championship drought.What is the name of this American League team, based in Cleveland, Ohio?

The Sieve of Eratosthenes can be used to find all of these numbers up to a limit, and Euclid proved that there is an infinite amount of these numbers. Goldbach's conjecture states that any even integer greater than two can be represented as the sum of two of them. Factorizing a number into them can be used to determine the GCF, and two is the only even one of these. Name these numbers that are only divisible by themselves and one.

This man said that the "alternating domination" of political parties is "frightful." He commanded troops at the Battle of Trenton and trained his forces at Valley Forge during the American Revolution. Name this military leader who became the first President of the United States.

One of this city's most famous attractions features Tritons leading hippocampi and the shell chariot of the central figure, Oceanus. Ostia was the ancient port of this city, which was built in part on the Palatine and Quirinal Hills. Attractions in this city include the Spanish Steps, the Trevi Fountain, and the Colosseum. Name this city on the Tiber, the capital of Italy.

In this country, 30 miners were killed at the Eureka stockade while protesting mining licences. Bands of criminals called Bushrangers terrorized this country in the late 1800s, the most famous of whom wore home-made plate armor. That man was Ned Kelly. Former governors of this country as a colony include Arthur Phillip and William Bligh, and James Cook discovered its Botany Bay. Name this nation that began as a British penal colony, and is currently home to cities like Melbourne and Sydney.

This coach, known for his dry wit and often-curt responses in press conferences, holds the NBA record for the most regular season wins with 1,366 victories. He has led his team to five NBA championships, all with the same small-market franchise. His coaching tree includes successful NBA coaches like Steve Kerr and Mike Budenholzer.  He served as head coach of the US national team, leading them to a gold medal at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Who is this legendary coach, known for his long tenure with the San Antonio Spurs?

John Cage added screws to make a "prepared" form of this instrument, which is silent for four minutes and 33 seconds in another Cage piece. Scott Joplin's Maple Leaf Rag is played on this instrument. Thelonious Monk and Duke Ellington were famous jazz players of this instrument. "Tickling the ivories" refers to playing what instrument with 88 black and white keys?

This science fiction film features a unique method of communication with extraterrestrial visitors, using a five-tone musical phrase.  The iconic Devil's Tower National Monument in Wyoming serves as a key location in the film's climactic encounter.  The film's director, Steven Spielberg, drew inspiration from real-life UFO sightings and the work of ufologist J. Allen Hynek, who even makes a cameo appearance in the film.  The film's special effects, groundbreaking for its time, created awe-inspiring visuals of alien spacecraft and otherworldly beings.  What is the title of this 1977 film, which explores humanity's fascination with the unknown and the possibility of extraterrestrial contact?
answers: Close Encounters of the Third Kind

question: This nation recently voted to amend its constitution to include the aim of becoming a European Union member state. This Eastern European country, nestled between Romania and Ukraine, is renowned for its wine production, boasting vast underground wine cellars that stretch for miles.  Its capital city, Chișinău, features a Triumphal Arch commemorating the victory of the Russian Empire over the Ottoman Empire. Name this country, home to the breakaway region of Transnistria, a self-declared state with its own currency and military.

This sport, known for its fast-paced action and blend of physicality and finesse, features players using a stick with a netted pocket to catch, carry, and throw a ball towards the opponent's goal.  It has its roots in Native American traditions, where it was often played with hundreds of participants and served as a form of conflict resolution and spiritual practice. What is this sport, often referred to as "the fastest game on two feet"?

The northeast part of this state contains the Goshute Valley just east of the Ruby Mountains. A Paiute Indian Reserve surrounds this state's Pyramid Lake, and its most populous city, which has suburbs like Sunrise Manor and Henderson, is served by Harry Reid International Airport and lies west of Lake Mead. Once the site of the Comstock Lode in Virginia City, this state now houses the "biggest little city in the world." Identify this state that lies on the eastern shores of Lake Tahoe and contains cities like Reno, Carson City, and Las Vegas.

This sitcom's iconic theme song, composed by Jonathan Wolff, features a distinctive slap bass line and quirky synthesizer melodies. The show, renowned for its "show about nothing" premise, features a group of four friends living in New York City: Jerry, a stand-up comedian; Elaine, his ex-girlfriend and close friend; George, his neurotic and often unemployed friend; and Kramer, his eccentric neighbor.  The show's quirky characters and relatable situations, often revolving around mundane aspects of daily life, resonated with audiences, making it one of the most popular and influential sitcoms of the 1990s. What is the name of this sitcom, which has left a lasting legacy on television comedy?

An attack by the Kurdistan Workers' Party on the aerospace company's headquarters in this nation left seven people dead in October 2024. This transcontinental country, spanning both Europe and Asia, is home to the Hagia Sophia, a magnificent architectural marvel that has served as a church, a mosque, and now a museum. Its bustling Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world, offers a vibrant tapestry of sights, sounds, and aromas. Name this nation that is bordered by eight countries and three seas, showcasing its strategic location at the crossroads of civilizations.

The syrinx organ is part of this body system in birds. In insects, the openings to this system are called spiracles. A dysfunction of this system in humans is sleep apnea; another disease, emphysema, damages the alveoli that are crucial to this system. Tuberculosis and pneumonia are infections of this body system, that is primarily formed by the gills in fish. Name this body system that includes the trachea and lungs.

The title character of this work is hired on as a burglar after unknowingly advertising for a job through a mark on his door. In this work, an attempt is made to reclaim family treasure and avenge the deaths of the villagers of Dale by a group of dwarves. The dwarves are aided by a wizard named Gandalf, and a less-obviously powerful character named Bilbo. Name this novel written by J.R.R. Tolkien.

Anton Dexler founded this party as the DAP, sponsored by the Thule society. This party was opposed by the White Rose Movement, organized by students who distributed pamphlets against their ideals. Their official song was "The Flag Up High," named in honor of Horst Wessel, a party member who died in a street fight against Communists. Leaders of this party led the purging of the SA and may have burned the Reichstag. The national symbol of this party was the swastika, and it had leaders including Hermann Goering and Heinrich Himmler. Name this German Workers' Party led by Adolf Hitler.

The philosophy of nullification was developed to oppose this form of government. The Ninth and Tenth Amendments specifically create this type of government, which is defined as a power-sharing arrangement between national and state governments. Name this type of government after which a political party including John Adams was named.

This person, the subject of "Decet Romanum Pontificem," wrote a pamphlet entitled "Murderous, Thieving Hordes of Peasants" and drafted the Schmalkald Articles. Threatened with excommunication by Exsurge domine, he discussed the Eucharist at the Marburg Colloquy but is most known for his displeasure with the Catholic practice of selling indulgences. Name this author of the 95 Theses.

This theory originated as an offshoot of Ernst Mayr's concept of genetic revolutions by speciation, but was greatly expanded by the author of a 1971 paper citing fossil records of trilobites, Niles Eldredge, as well as Stephen Jay Gould. It opposes the "phylectic" type of another idea and explains the lack of transitional forms in fossil records. Stating that most sexually reproducing species experience little change for most of their history and that their evolution occurs in short, rapid spurts is what evolutionary theory often contrasted with phylectic gradualism?

Tropical Storm Trami killed more than 120 people in this archipelago nation. The nation, comprised of over 7,000 islands, is renowned for its stunning beaches, including the world-famous Boracay and El Nido. It is home to the Chocolate Hills, a geological formation of over 1,000 cone-shaped hills that turn brown during the dry season. Its capital city, Manila, boasts a vibrant mix of Spanish colonial architecture and modern skyscrapers. It is also the world's second-largest archipelago and a major exporter of coconuts and mangoes. Name this Southeast Asian country.

Rock climbers flock to this country's Grampians National Park at the southern terminus of the Great Dividing Range. Gulf Saint Vincent on the southern shores of this country is home to the port of Adelaide, and the Coral Sea on this country's northeast is home to the endangered Great Barrier Reef. A sacred sandstone formation called Uluru is in the "outback" of what country whose cities include Melbourne and Sydney?

The Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group defended this law after President Obama announced, in 2011, that the Justice Department would no longer do so. It passed Congress with a veto-proof majority and was signed by President Clinton in 1996, but its third section was ruled unconstitutional by the 2013 case U.S. v. Windsor. Name this 1996 law which defined marriage as between one man and one woman, often referred to as "DOMA."

This swimmer's seven gold medals at the 2017 World Aquatics Championships set a record for the most golds won by a swimmer at a single World Championships.  He followed this with another record-breaking performance at the 2019 World Championships, where he became the first swimmer to win eight medals at a single World Championships.  His dominance in sprint freestyle and butterfly events is evident in his multiple world records, including the 100-meter butterfly and the 50-meter freestyle.  He has also achieved Olympic success, winning five gold medals at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.  Who is this American swimmer?

The speaker of this poem notes that, "knowing how way leads on to way", he may never return to its setting. This poem's speaker "shall be telling this with a sigh / somewhere ages and ages hence", and notes that its central action "has made all the difference". "Two roads diverged in a yellow wood" in what Robert Frost poem whose narrator "took the path less traveled by"?
incorrect2: Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening

question: This anthology series, known for its eerie opening narration and twist endings, explored themes of paranoia, morality, and the human condition through a science fiction lens.  Its iconic theme music, composed by Marius Constant, has become synonymous with suspense and the unknown.  The show's creator, Rod Serling, often appeared on screen to introduce and conclude each episode, offering thought-provoking commentary on the stories' themes.  Its memorable episodes, including "Time Enough at Last" and "Nightmare at 20,000 Feet," have become classics of the genre.  What is the name of this influential television series that continues to inspire and unsettle viewers today?

The southern terminus of this mountain range is Lassen, which was the site of a 1921 volcanic eruption. Its "North" part is a national park which contains Mount Baker. The Lewis and Clark expedition named one of its peaks after Thomas Jefferson. One peak in this range, Mt. Mazama, contains Crater Lake, and another, Mt. Hood, was the site of a climbing accident in 2009. Name this volcanic mountain range of the Pacific Northwest, whose peaks include Mt. Rainier and Mt. St. Helens.

This basketball legend's iconic rivalry with Magic Johnson, which began in college and extended throughout their NBA careers, fueled the popularity of the sport in the 1980s. He led the Boston Celtics to three NBA championships and won three consecutive MVP awards from 1984 to 1986. He was also a member of the "Dream Team," the legendary 1992 US Olympic basketball team that dominated the Barcelona Olympics. Who is this Hall of Fame forward, known for his exceptional shooting and all-around skills?

A triangular patch of clouds that circulates this planet quickly is known as The Scooter. Its atmosphere contains the fastest winds in the solar system. Its existence was predicted by Alexis Bouvard, and it was discovered by Johann Galle. It often contains the Great Dark Spot. Its largest moon, which has a retrograde orbit, is Triton. Name this gas giant, the farthest from the Sun in the solar system.

This action-adventure film features a memorable scene where the protagonist outruns a giant rolling boulder, narrowly escaping certain doom.  Its iconic score, composed by John Williams, includes the triumphant "Raiders March," which has become synonymous with the film's adventurous spirit.  The film's protagonist, Indiana Jones, played by Harrison Ford, is a whip-wielding archaeologist who travels the world in search of ancient artifacts.  The film's plot revolves around the Ark of the Covenant, a sacred artifact sought by the Nazis for its rumored power.  What is the title of this 1981 film, directed by Steven Spielberg?
incorrect1: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom

question: The protagonist of a novel by this author encounters the Puma-Woman and kills the Hyena-Swine in self defense; that character, Edward Prendick, had been shipwrecked near the Island of Dr. Moreau. The protagonist of another novel by this author is given white flowers by the Eloi Weena, whom he attempts to save from the Morlocks. In one of this author's novels turned into a radio broadcast, an invasion of Martians is stopped after they are killed by disease. Name this author of The Time Machine and The War of the Worlds.

A tiny species of this type of animal was recently discovered in Brazil. It is the second-smallest known vertebrate species in the world. These amphibians secrete a toxic substance from glands behind their eyes as a defense mechanism against predators. Often confused with frogs, they have drier, bumpier skin and shorter legs adapted for walking rather than hopping. Unlike frogs, they lay their eggs in long chains rather than clusters.  Their young undergo metamorphosis from aquatic tadpoles to terrestrial adults. What are these wart-covered creatures, often found in gardens and woodlands?

This war was triggered by the closing of the Straits of Tiran. The USS Liberty was hit by friendly fire during this war, which opened with Operation Focus, a surprise, pre-emptive airstrike against the Egyptian Air Force. The winner of this war claimed control of Gaza from Egypt, which had mobilized troops in the Sinai Peninsula. Name this war in which Israel attacked its neighbors over the course of a week in June 1967.

In this state in 2013, researchers announced that they had cured a two-year-old girl of HIV. Marco McMillan, one of its towns' mayoral candidates who was openly homosexual, was found murdered in February 2013. Also in 2013, this state finally ratified the 13th Amendment banning slavery. Name this state with military bases at Gulfport and Biloxi whose capital is Jackson.

Ribosome subunits pass through pores in this structure's namesake envelope and are produced in one part of it. In one kind of cloning, this organelle is transferred into an egg that lacks one. The presence of this organelle distinguishes eukaryotes from prokaryotes. This organelle divides in two during mitosis because DNA is found here. Name this information processing area of the cell.

The conspirators in the murder of this man were coordinated by Danilo Ilic. The assassination of this man was preceded by the throwing of a hand grenade by Cabrinovic that blew up the wrong car. This man's killing, which was meant to cause the secession of a certain nation's south-Slav provinces, killed Duchess Sophie. Following it, the Russian, French, German, and Austro-Hungarian armies mobilized. Organized by the Black Hand terrorist cell identify this man who was killed in Sarajevo by Gavrilo Princip that led to World War I.

This quarterback, known for his exceptional longevity and success in the NFL, holds the record for the most Super Bowl wins with seven championships to his name. He famously led his team to an improbable comeback victory in Super Bowl LI, overcoming a 28-3 deficit against the Atlanta Falcons. He played for the New England Patriots for 20 seasons, forming a legendary partnership with coach Bill Belichick. He briefly retired in 2022 but returned for two more seasons with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Who is this quarterback, often considered the greatest of all time?

One composer from this country depicted the demon Chernobog holding court during the titular "Night on Bald Mountain". Another composer from this country depicted a trading caravan In the Steppes of Central Asia and the titular mythical royal in the opera Prince Igor. The "Mighty Handful" from this country included both Alexander Borodin and Modest Mussorgsky, but not the pianist Sergei Rachmaninov. Name the country where Dmitri Shostakovich premiered the Leningrad Symphony.

This dark fantasy franchise features a protagonist, Geralt of Rivia, known for his distinctive white hair and his profession as a monster hunter for hire.  The franchise encompasses a series of novels and short stories by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski, which have been adapted into popular video games, a television series, and graphic novels.  The protagonist's mutations, resulting from rigorous training and alchemical experiments, grant him enhanced strength, speed, and reflexes, making him a formidable warrior against supernatural creatures.  What is the name of this franchise, set in a medieval-inspired world filled with magic, monsters, and political intrigue?

Mark Twain recounted becoming a "pilot" of this technology in his memoir Life on the Mississippi. The first commercially successful example of this technology was Robert Fulton's Clermont. It's not a train, but this technology was made practical by improvements to James Watt's designs of an engine powered by water vapor. River transportation in the 19th century was revolutionized by what kind of boat?

One tributary of this river is the Tapajos, and it is formed by the confluence of the Maranon and Ucayali Rivers. Marajo Island lies at the mouth of this river, and the city of Belem lies near this river's delta. The pororoca, a famous tidal bore, travels up this river, and the city of Manaus lies near this river's confluence with the Rio Negro. Traveling through a namesake rainforest name this longest river of South America.

A seed storage facility in this nation, built to safeguard crop diversity, recently received more than 30,000 new samples from around the world. This country, known for its breathtaking fjords and the Northern Lights, houses a global seed vault on the island of Spitsbergen, safeguarding over a million seed samples from around the world. The vault, built deep inside a mountain, serves as a backup for global food security in the event of natural disasters or global crises. It is also home to the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony, held annually in Oslo. What is this Scandinavian country, known for its rich Viking history and stunning natural beauty?

This football manager, known for his possession-based "tiki-taka" style of play, achieved a historic treble with Barcelona in 2009, winning La Liga, the Copa del Rey, and the UEFA Champions League in the same season.  He managed Bayern Munich from 2013 to 2016, winning the Bundesliga title in each of his three seasons with the club.  He currently manages Manchester City, where he has won five Premier League titles and led the team to their first-ever Champions League title in 2023.  Who is this highly successful manager, considered one of the greatest tactical minds in football history?

Important advances made during this war include the invention of the gatling gun. Guerillas in this war were prominent in rural areas and included Bloody Bill and William Quantrill. Fighting in this war broke out in Charleston Harbor at the Battle of Fort Sumter. This war ended at Appomattox Court House where Robert E. Lee surrendered to Ulysses S. Grant. Name this war fought between the northern United States and the southern Confederate States.

The mouth of this river is located between Ballard County, KY and Cairo, IL and has its deepest and widest point located at the city near the McAlpine Locks and Dam. Tributaries of this river include the Wabash, Kentucky, Saline, and Cumberland Rivers. Its source is formed by the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers near Pittsburgh, PA. Other cities located on this river include Louisville and Cincinnati. Name this tributary of the Mississippi River, which forms the southern boundary of the state that has its capital at Columbus.

This man's achievements include the signing of the Cyprus Convention with the Ottoman Empire, which handed control of the island to Great Britain. In 1876, this man's Royal Titles Act enabled Queen Victoria to be proclaimed as Empress of India, and his Reform Act of 1867 nearly doubled the British electorate, which later lead to his Conservative party's defeat in the 1868 election. Prior to this man becoming prime minister, he wrote the novels Vivien Grey and Venetia. Name this Prime Minister of Great Britain with Jewish roots who engaged in a notorious feud with William Gladstone.

A compound of this element and iodine has been used to seed clouds in order to generate rain, and salts of this element are still used to develop traditional photographs. When placed in an alkaline solution with sugar, this element will form a mirror surface on glass. Exposure of this metal to polluted air will cause a black sulfide layer known as tarnish to form, and it follows only platinum and gold as the precious metal of choice for coins and jewelry. Name this element with atomic number 47 and symbol Ag.

This character says that "life is scientific" to reassure a group of children that "there isn't no fear" after they claim to see "snakes" and "ghosts." After claiming that he is unable to swim, this character is told "sucks to your ass-mar." This character, who complains that everything is "jus' blurs" after his "specs" are taken to start a fire, is described as a "true, wise friend" after a boulder released by Roger crushes both him and a conch shell. Name this pudgy character from William Golding's Lord of the Flies.

This HBO drama, known for its sharp dialogue and dysfunctional family dynamics, features a memorable scene where a family member throws a plate of cheese at their father in a fit of rage.
