The show revolves around the Roy family, owners of a global media and entertainment conglomerate, as they vie for control of the company amid health concerns and power struggles. Its theme song, composed by Nicholas Britell, has a haunting and ominous tone, reflecting the show's exploration of wealth, power, and corruption. What is the name of this Emmy Award-winning series?

This nation experienced deadly flooding around the city of Valencia that led the over 200 deaths. The country, home to the Sagrada Familia, a masterpiece by Antoni Gaudí that has been under construction for over a century, boasts a vibrant tradition of flamenco dancing and music. Its annual Running of the Bulls in Pamplona attracts thrill-seekers and spectators from around the world. It is also the birthplace of paella, a flavorful rice dish that has become a culinary symbol of the nation. What is this European country, known for its rich history, diverse culture, and passion for football?

This city is home to the world's largest two urban forests, the Tijuca and the Pedra Branca, with the former being hand-planted. The 2014 World Cup final was held at its Maracana Stadium, which is now the third largest in South America. Its Sugarloaf Mountain is on a peninsula that separates Guanabara Bay from the Atlantic Ocean. Corcovado Mountain in this city is home to one of the "New Seven Wonders of the World," Christ the Redeemer. Also home to Ipanema and the Copacabana beaches name this city that passed its title of capital of Brazil to Brasilia in 1960.

This musician passed away on November 3, 2024 at the age of 91. The multi-talented artist, who arranged and conducted Michael Jackson's iconic album "Thriller," holds the record for the most Grammy Award nominations, with a staggering 80 nods throughout his illustrious career. He began his career as a trumpeter, playing with jazz legends like Lionel Hampton and Dizzy Gillespie.  He has composed scores for over 30 films, including "In the Heat of the Night" and "The Color Purple." He also produced the charity single "We Are the World," which became a global anthem for famine relief efforts. Name this legendary father of Rashida Jones.

This hockey player, drafted first overall by the Edmonton Oilers in the 2015 NHL Entry Draft, became the youngest captain in NHL history at the age of 19. He has won the Art Ross Trophy as the NHL's leading scorer five times, showcasing his exceptional offensive skills and playmaking ability. He is known for his incredible speed and agility on the ice, often leaving opponents in his wake. He also won the Hart Memorial Trophy as the NHL's most valuable player in 2017 and 2023. Who is this Canadian hockey superstar?

This infamous duo's crime spree captivated the nation during the Great Depression, with their exploits romanticized in the media despite their violent robberies and murders. Their preferred getaway car, a 1934 Ford Model 730 Deluxe, became a symbol of their outlaw lifestyle. They met in Texas in 1930, and their dramatic demise came in a hail of gunfire in a police ambush in Louisiana in 1934. Who are this notorious couple, whose story has been immortalized in film and folklore?
incorrect1: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid

question: This scientist erroneously proposed a triple helical structure for DNA. This man discovered the secondary protein structures of alpha helices and beta sheets, and identified defects in hemoglobin as the cause of sickle cell anemia. Fluorine has a value of 4.0 on this man's scale of electronegativity. Name this Caltech scientist who won Nobel prizes in both chemistry and peace.

Menestheus became king of Athens after slandering this figure, while for a time this figure was trapped in the underworld along with his friend Pirithous. This figure had originally traveled to the underworld to capture Persephone for his friend after they had kidnapped Helen, and on another famous journey, he defeated Cercyon in wrestling, stretched Sinis between his two trees, and placed Procrustes in his own torturous bed. This is what hero who slew the Minotaur and caused his father's death by raising a black sail?

This president's campaign coined the phrase "It's the economy, stupid." This two-time governor of Arkansas signed Don't Ask, Don't Tell and NAFTA into law. This man's vice president, Al Gore, later lost the tightly contested presidential election of 2000. This president was impeached in 1998 after his affair with Monica Lewinsky. Name this president whose wife Hillary lost the 2016 presidential election.

After the disastrous Gallipoli campaign, this politician was forced to resign as First Lord of the Admiralty. This politician, who coined the term "iron curtain," proclaimed that "we shall fight on the beaches" after an evacuation at Dunkirk. This politician achieved his highest post after the resignation of Neville Chamberlain in 1940. Name this Prime Minister of Great Britain during World War II.

This time-travel classic features a memorable scene where the protagonist plays "Johnny B. Goode" at a high school dance in 1955, inadvertently introducing rock and roll to a bewildered audience.  The film's iconic DeLorean time machine, modified by eccentric scientist Doc Brown, requires 1.21 gigawatts of electricity and a speed of 88 miles per hour to travel through time.  The film's sequels further explore the possibilities of time travel, with adventures in a futuristic 2015 and a Wild West setting in 1885.  What is the title of this beloved 1985 film starring Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly?

This composer evoked the image of a demonic entity ringing bells in a choral symphony based on an Edgar Allen Poe poem. The pianist plays a series of chords in C-minor before accompanying the main theme with arpeggios to open this composer's Piano Concerto #2. This composer's Morceaux de Fantaisie includes a piece which ends with a series of dramatic chords, his Prelude in C-sharp Minor. He also wrote a set of 24 variations on the 24th caprice of an Italian violin virtuoso. Name this Russian composer of Rhapsody on a Theme by Paganini.

This state's capital is home to summer festivals called WaterFire which were established under its convicted felon mayor Buddy Cianci. A 2020 ballot measure removed the word "Plantations" from this state's official name. Mansions such as The Breakers are found in this state's town of Newport, which overlooks Narragansett Bay. Roger Williams founded what smallest US state by land area?

This practice, often attributed to Benjamin Franklin's satirical essay suggesting Parisians could save money on candles by waking up earlier, was first legally mandated in Germany during World War I as a way to conserve energy.  It was later adopted by many countries, including the United States, where it was standardized in 1966 with the Uniform Time Act.  The rationale behind it is to make better use of daylight hours by shifting the clock forward during the summer months.  However, its effectiveness and impact on health and productivity remain a subject of debate.  What is this practice of adjusting the clock forward and backward throughout the year?

This country's capital is home to the world's oldest Chinatown, Binondo. This country is the home of a popular condiment called banana ketchup as well as the fast food chain Jollibee. A sauce called adobo, which originated in this country's cuisine, blends Southeast Asian staples with Spanish influences. Quezon City is found on this country's most populous island, Luzon. What country is led from Manila?

This man compared "murderous, thieving hordes of peasants" to mad dogs in one work, despite those peasants being largely inspired by his ideology. This man debated Huldrych Zwingli at the Marburg Colloquy, where he argued for the "real presence" of Christ in the Eucharist. This man refused to recant his writings at the Diet of Worms. The most famous of those writings was inspired by Johann Tetzel and other sellers of indulgences, and it was nailed to a church door in Wittenberg. Name this father of the Protestant Reformation who wrote the 95 Theses.

Sediments in these regions form top-set and bottom-set layers, and the Gilbert type of them marks locations of ancient lakes. An alluvial fan with a bird's-foot pattern is characteristic of many of these regions, though strong tidal forces prevent the St Lawrence from creating one. One of these regions occurs where the Nile meets the Mediterranean. Identify this triangular plain at a river's mouth, shaped like the fourth letter of the Greek alphabet.

This coach, the only one in NFL history to lead a team to a perfect season, achieved this feat with the 1972 Miami Dolphins, culminating in a Super Bowl VII victory. He holds the record for the most career wins by an NFL head coach, with 347 victories. He coached the Baltimore Colts and Miami Dolphins, leading both teams to Super Bowl appearances. He also coached in the famous "Super Bowl III" upset, where his Baltimore Colts lost to the New York Jets. Who is this legendary coach, known for his disciplined approach and winning mentality?

Isamu Noguchi edited out Clara Boothe Luce from this artist's painting of Dorothy Hale. In a painting by a different artist, this artist holds a yin-yang symbol next to La Calavera Catarina in A Dream of a Sunday Afternoon in Alameda Park. This artist grips a bloody pair of scissors after severing a vein to a twin copy of herself in a painting titled "Two" of this artist. A snail and pelvis float around this artist in a painting created from Henry Ford Hospital after miscarrying a child conceived with Diego Rivera. Name this Mexican artist known for her self-portraits with monkeys.

This action role-playing game, set in the Lands Between, features a challenging open world filled with formidable bosses, including Margit, the Fell Omen, and Malenia, Blade of Miquella.  Its lore, created in collaboration with George R. R. Martin, author of the Game of Thrones series, weaves a complex tapestry of myths and legends.  Players can choose from a variety of character classes, each with unique abilities and playstyles.  It was developed by FromSoftware, the studio behind the Dark Souls series, known for its challenging gameplay and intricate world-building.  What is the name of this critically acclaimed game, which won Game of the Year at The Game Awards 2022?

This technology company recently annouced they are working on a search engine powered by their artificial intelligence model Llama. The company faced scrutiny in 2023 for its controversial rebranding and investment in the metaverse, a virtual reality platform still under development. Its CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, co-founded the company in his Harvard dorm room in 2004. It owns popular social media platforms like Instagram and WhatsApp, boasting billions of users worldwide. What is the name of this tech giant, formerly known as Facebook, Inc.?

This empire held together by the use of quipus  was expanded by Pachacuti but weakened by civil war between Huascar and Atahualpa. Cities built in it included the capital, Cuzco, and the city discovered by Hiram Bingham, Machu Picchu. What Native American empire of Peru was overthrown by Francisco Pizarro?

The ANP hormone produced in this organ inhibits the production of sodium, while the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is a malfunction of this organ. Impulses from the Bundle of His are carried by Purkinje fibers in this organ, and the aorta originates here. The mitral valve separates the left atrium and ventricle of which organ made of cardiac muscle that pumps blood through the body?

This sport, with its origins in ancient Shinto rituals, features massive wrestlers, known as rikishi, competing in a circular ring called a dohyō. Before each bout, the rikishi perform a series of symbolic rituals, including throwing salt into the ring for purification.  The highest rank in this sport is yokozuna, a title held by only a select few throughout history. The objective is to force the opponent out of the ring or to make any part of their body other than the soles of their feet touch the ground.  What is this traditional Japanese sport, known for its combination of athleticism, ritual, and cultural significance?

This man was the US Minister to Sweden and France simultaneously. This man used the pseudonym "Silence Dogood" in a series of letters to The New England Courant before becoming the first US Postmaster General. This author of Poor Richard's Almanac urged colonial cooperation with a cartoon captioned "Join or Die." Name this Founding Father who appears on the $100 bill and experimented with a key and a kite.

In this region, concentric circles of eroded rock form the Richat Structure, which is sometimes called its "eye." Specimens of an unusual type of green glass are found in this region's northeast. The Tuareg nomads inhabit the Air Massif in this region. The Qatarra Depression is the lowest point in this region, which also includes the Grand Ergs in Algeria. South of this region lies a belt of grasslands called the Sahel. Name this largest hot desert in the world that covers most of North Africa.

This band's debut album, recorded in 1976 for a mere $6,400, featured short, fast-paced songs like "Blitzkrieg Bop" and "Judy Is a Punk," establishing their signature punk rock sound.  Their iconic look, with their long hair, leather jackets, and ripped jeans, became synonymous with the punk aesthetic.  They were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2002, a year after the death of their lead singer, Joey Ramone. What is the name of this band, whose members all adopted the surname "Ramone" despite not being related?

This swimmer's iconic "death stare" before races became a symbol of his intense focus and determination. He holds the record for the most Olympic gold medals won by an individual, with a staggering 23 golds across five Olympic Games. His signature event, the 200-meter butterfly, showcased his versatility and dominance in the pool. He famously won eight gold medals at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, breaking Mark Spitz's record of seven golds in a single Olympic Games. Who is this legendary swimmer, often referred to as the "Baltimore Bullet"?

At 1,407 feet below sea level, this body of water contains the lowest non-ocean point on Earth. The Jordan River is the main tributary of this deepest salt lake in the world. A hill mostly made of salt near this lake is called Mount Sodom. It is bordered by Israel and Jordan, and is sometimes known as "The Sea of Lot." Name this Middle Eastern body of water where microorganisms cannot survive due to its salinity.

This leader of the 1874 Black Hills Expedition graduated last in his class at West Point with an amazing 726 demerits in four years. This man was the losing commander at a battle also known as the Battle of the Greasy Grass, where Crazy Horse and Sitting Bull led a rout of his 7th Cavalry. Name this US Army officer who died in 1876 at the Battle of the Little Bighorn, also known as this man's Last Stand.

This father of Kebechet had a cult centered at Cynopolis. This Egyptian god was associated with the Greek deity Hermes because of their similar roles. His mother is given as either Bast or Nephthys, and he predates one of his potential fathers, Osiris, as god of the underworld. This god weighs the heart of the dead against Ma'at's feather. Identify this jackal-headed Egyptian god of mummification.

This man was the first to achieve what Donald Trump will now do: serving 2 non-consecutive presidential terms. This president faced a major economic crisis during his second term known as the Panic of 1893. He vetoed more bills than any other president up to that point, earning him the nickname "Grover the Good." He signed the Interstate Commerce Act, which regulated railroad rates, and oversaw the dedication of the Statue of Liberty. Who was this 22nd and 24th president of the United States?

The pigment ochre contains particles of a compound containing this metal. Compounds of this transition metal are characteristic of Precambrian banded rock formations. The disulfide of this element, referred to as its pyrite, is more commonly known as fool's gold. In one oxide of this element, cations of this element have an oxidation number of 8/3; that ore is sometimes called lodestone. Magnetite and hematite are ores of this transition metal with atomic number 26. Name this element with chemical symbol Fe, whose oxide is commonly known as rust.

This colony was aided by Manteo under the leadership of governor John White. The first English child born in the New World, Virginia Dare, was born in this colony. A tree in this colony was inscribed with the letters C-R-O, which may refer to an island home to the Croatoan people. This site was the first English colonial effort in the continental United States. Sir Walter Raleigh established what North Carolina "lost colony?"

Bernard Marcus the co-founder of this retail company died on November 4, 2024 at the age of 95. This home improvement retail giant, co-founded with Arthur Blank in 1978, boasts the largest market capitalization in its industry, surpassing its main competitor, Lowe's. Its first two stores, opened in Atlanta, Georgia, were massive warehouses, pioneering the concept of a home improvement superstore. It is known for its distinctive orange logo and its knowledgeable staff, many of whom have professional experience in various trades. What is the name of this company, a Fortune 500 company and a major player in the DIY and home renovation market?

This ruler established the code of Yassa throughout his empire, which penalized many offenses with death. This brutality was also common in his conquests, as one historian recounted each of this man's fifty thousand troops executing twenty-four Urgench citizens. He also sacked and slaughtered the Khwarezmi city of Samarkand. Born as Temujin, he appointed his son Ogedei as his successor, and his grandson established the Yuan Dynasty. Name this grandfather of Kublai Khan, the leader who united the tribes and founded the vast Mongol empire.

The arrest of John Lawrence Jr. for being one of these people led to a Texas law being ruled unconstitutional in Lawrence v. Texas. Omar Manteen shot 49 of these people at the Pulse nightclub. These people could not openly serve in the military under the "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy. Obergefell v Hodges granted these people a right that was previously restricted under the Defense of Marriage Act. Name these people, who are represented by the rainbow pride flag.

This team's home arena, the Footprint Center, features a distinctive "sandstone" façade that blends with the desert landscape of its home city. They have reached the NBA Finals three times, most recently in 2021, where they fell to the Milwaukee Bucks. Their iconic "Ring of Honor" celebrates legendary players like Charles Barkley and Steve Nash. What is the name of this team, whose history includes a memorable rivalry with the San Antonio Spurs?

This British tragicomedy series, known for its fourth-wall-breaking monologues and darkly comedic tone, features a protagonist who runs a guinea pig-themed cafe and navigates complex relationships with her family and love interests. The show's creator and star, Phoebe Waller-Bridge, also wrote and produced the acclaimed spy thriller series "Killing Eve." It won numerous awards, including six Primetime Emmy Awards for its second season. What is the title of this critically acclaimed series?

One of this director's films ends with a nun ringing a bell after Judy falls to her death. That film uses the dolly zoom to depict Scottie's fear of heights in an effect named for the film. Another film by this director sees a crop duster attempt to kill Roger Thornhill and ends with a climactic scene atop Mt. Rushmore. A character in another of his films pretends to be his dead mother and murders Marion Crane in the shower. Name this director of Vertigo, North by Northwest, and Psycho.

A tiny Prada store is located on the side of US Route 90 near this state's town of Valentine. In 2022, the judge of this state's Loving County, population 64, was arrested for cattle rustling. A national park in this state is named for the "Big Bend" made along its southern border by the Rio Grande River. The Pecos River flows south from New Mexico into what state whose westernmost major city is El Paso?

These entities occupy a belt extending nine degrees on either side of the ecliptic and, because of precession, Ophiuchus should count as one of them. Bright stars within these objects include Aldebaran, Spica, and Pollux, while fifteen stars make up the largest example, Virgo. Name this collection of twelve constellations, including Taurus, Scorpio, and Pisces, that mark divisions along the Sun's path across the sky and are used for horoscopes.

A lost city from this civilization was recently discoverd by a PhD student using aerial lidar under forest canopy in Mexico. This civilization developed a sophisticated calendar system that accurately predicted astronomical events like eclipses. Their hieroglyphic writing system, one of the most complex in the ancient world, recorded their history, mythology, and astronomical observations. They constructed impressive cities, such as Tikal and Chichén Itzá, featuring towering pyramids, temples, and palaces. Their civilization flourished in Mesoamerica from around 2000 BCE to the 17th century. Who were these people, known for their advancements in art, architecture, and science?

Evidence for this property in giant marine reptiles is seen in the rapid bone growth of fossil plesiosaurs. Tuna achieve sudden bursts of speed because their muscular system has this property. A high percentage of brown fat helps infants maintain this property, which is upset during a fever. This property is observed in birds and mammals, but not in amphibians. Name this property with which animals can maintain a constant internal temperature.

With former president George W. Bush, this man established two tsunami funds after the 2005 Asian tsunami. He became the youngest governor at age 32 and raised his state's education system from the worst in the nation to one of the best. During his presidency, he launched Operation Allied Force in the Balkans, signed the NAFTA and Brady Bill into law, appointed Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court, and became the second impeached president. Identify this US president who was preceded by George H. W. Bush.

This team's iconic "rainbow" uniforms, worn during their Astrodome era in the 1970s and 80s, have become a nostalgic symbol of the franchise's past.  They were originally known as the Houston Colt .45s before adopting their current name in 1965, coinciding with their move to the Astrodome, the world's first domed multi-purpose stadium.  They have won two World Series titles, the first in 2017 and the second in 2022, both amidst controversial circumstances. What is the name of this Major League Baseball team, based in Houston, Texas?

The Tibesti Mountains are a prominent feature of this desert that also contains sand seas called ergs. The Tuareg people are nomadic inhabitants of this desert, which was crossed in medieval times by a caravan route to Timbuktu. The Sahel is the southern border of this desert that covers much of Mauritania, Niger, and Libya. Name this desert that covers most of North Africa.

This word refers to the clerical interests of Julien Sorel in the title of a work by Stendhal. There are 12 million of these voices in a folk history by Richard Wright, who also paired this adjective with "boy" to title an autobiography describing Wright's experience growing up in the South and Chicago. A horse called "this word" Beauty narrates a novel by Anna Sewell in first person. Name this color which is also the surname of Harry Potter's godfather Sirius.

One peak in this mountain range is surrounded by Baxter State Park. One subrange of this mountain range, the White Mountains, contains a mountain famed for its excessive wind speeds; that mountain is Mount Washington. Mount Mitchell is the highest mountain in this range, and this range's namesake trail runs from Georgia to Mount Katahdin in Maine. What large mountain range runs through the eastern US?

This film, shot in stark black and white to evoke a documentary feel, features a brutal boxing match scene where the protagonist, Jake La Motta, savagely beats his opponent, showcasing the character's self-destructive rage.  The film's use of slow-motion and close-ups during fight sequences heightens the impact and visceral nature of the violence.  Robert De Niro, who gained 60 pounds to portray the boxer in his later years, delivers a transformative performance that earned him an Academy Award for Best Actor.  What is the title of this 1980 biographical sports drama directed by Martin Scorsese?

A complex in this organelle is made up of a Rieske protein and cytochromes b and c1, while another complex involved in the same process is called succinate dehydrogenase. Ubiquinone is found in this organelle. A protein found here rotates as hydrogen ions move down their concentration gradient. Oxidative phosphorylation takes place here, and ATP synthase is embedded in the cristae of this organelle, which surrounds its matrix. Name this organelle where the Krebs Cycle occurs, the "powerhouse of the cell."

Olaf Shultz, the prime minister of this nation, recently fired his finance minister effectively dissolving his governing coalition. This country, once divided, underwent a reunification process in 1990, marking a pivotal moment in its history. It is the birthplace of influential figures like Johann Sebastian Bach, Albert Einstein, and Karl Marx. Its capital, Berlin, houses the Brandenburg Gate, a historic landmark that has witnessed significant events, from Napoleon's triumphal entry to celebrations of reunification. It also holds the distinction of being the fourth-largest economy in the world and a leading exporter of automobiles and machinery. What is this European nation, known for its rich cultural heritage and contributions to science, philosophy, and the arts?

This event attracted immigrants to a region nicknamed "Jinshan;" the increased population prompted an attack on an outpost on the Fresno River, inciting the Mariposa War. This event began when Charles Bennett and newspaperman Samuel Brannan publicized a discovery made by James Marshall at Sutter's Mill, and instigated a mass migration. Name this 1849 event in which prospectors swarmed west to cities like San Francisco in search of a precious metal.

This team's teal, black, and silver color scheme, adopted in 1993, was a bold departure from traditional baseball uniforms and reflected the vibrant culture of their home city.  They made history in 1997 by becoming the first wild card team to win the World Series, defeating the Cleveland Indians in a thrilling seven-game series. They have won two World Series titles, both as a wild card team, defying expectations and showcasing their resilience.  What is the name of this team, based in Miami, Florida?

The rock-carved Abu Simbel temples had to be relocated to higher ground thanks to a dam on this river creating Lake Nasser. This river's "Blue" and "White" branches merge at Khartoum. The Aswan High Dam lies along this river, whose delta contains most of Egypt's population and agriculture. Identify this African river, the longest in the world.

In this novel, Constance is poisoned by the former wife of the Comte de la Fere, a woman who has a fleur-de-lis brand on her shoulder. An affair between Queen Anne and the Duke of Buckingham is almost revealed in this novel by Milady de Winter, but she is foiled by Aramis, Athos, Porthos, and D'Artagnan. Name this book by Alexandre Dumas about a small group of soldiers who use the motto "one for all and all for one."
incorrect3: The Man in the Iron Mask

question: Missionaries agreed to aid children during this event if they agreed to receive Protestant teachings, an act known as "souperism." Sir Robert Peel repealed the Corn Laws in response to this event, in which thousands died while fleeing to North America in "coffin ships." This event was caused by a strain of the water mold Phytophthora infestans. Name this 1845-1849 disaster, a blight of the staple crop of Ireland.

This romantic comedy-drama, known for its unconventional narrative structure and witty dialogue, features a scene where the main characters, Alvy and Annie, hilariously try to cook lobsters in their New York City apartment.  The film breaks the fourth wall, with Alvy Singer, played by Woody Allen, directly addressing the audience with neurotic and self-deprecating humor.  It won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director for Woody Allen.  What is the title of this 1977 film, often considered one of the greatest romantic comedies of all time?

This footballer's iconic "Siuuu!" celebration, accompanied by a mid-air pirouette and a powerful shout, has become a global phenomenon, imitated by fans and fellow athletes alike. He holds the record for the most goals scored in UEFA Champions League history, a testament to his prolific scoring ability and dominance in European club football. He has won the Ballon d'Or award, given to the world's best player, five times, tied with his rival Lionel Messi. Who is this Portuguese forward, known for his exceptional athleticism and goal-scoring prowess?

In one work by this man, he asked "why 1963?" when discussing a revolution and another work by this man included the line "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere." This author of Why We Can't Wait argued for illegal acts such as the nonviolent direct action used by his Southern Christian Leadership Conference during their Birmingham Campaign, as well as during his leadership of the Montgomery Bus Boycott. Assassinated by James Earl Ray in Memphis name this Civil Rights leader who gave the "I Have a Dream" speech.

Manacapuru and Obidos are cities along this river that is formed by the confluence of the Ucayli and Maranon rivers. The confluence of the largest blackwater river in the world and this river is located at the Meeting of Waters in the city of Manaus, and it is connected by the Casiquiare canal to the Orinoco River. This river is home to a namesake river dolphin, and the Rio Negro is one of its biggest tributaries. Containing one-fifth of the world's total river flow, making it the world's most voluminous river, is what longest river of South America?

This organ's parenchyma cells produce glucokinase, a catalyst for aerobic respiration. This organ's Ito cells store Vitamin A beneath its endothelial lining, and it also contains large amounts of peroxisomes. This organ is the site of gluconeogenesis, while jaundice results from this organ being unable to metabolize bilirubin. This organ is also responsible for the production of urea from protein catabolism. Bile is produced by what organ that develops cirrhosis from alcohol abuse?

Galton used this man's ideas on human civilization to organize the study of eugenics. His work The Descent of Man discusses human sexual behavior. Captain FitzRoy supported this person during their trip on the HMS Beagle, where he discovered that the beaks of finches on the Galapagos were adapted to different food sources. The author of On the Origin of Species name this English naturalist who pioneered evolution theory and natural selection.

This neo-noir psychological thriller features a memorable scene where the protagonist, Travis Bickle, stands in front of a mirror, practicing his gun draw and delivering the iconic line, "You talkin' to me?"  The film's gritty depiction of urban alienation and violence in 1970s New York City earned it the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival.  It stars Robert De Niro as a Vietnam veteran turned taxi driver who descends into madness and vigilantism.  What is the title of this 1976 film directed by Martin Scorsese?

In one work by this playwright, a son traps his father inside a house due to that father's addiction to serving as a juror. In addition to The Wasps, another play by this man describes a trek into Hades by Dionysus to retrieve Euripides that is interrupted by some amphibians who serve as the chorus for that play. This playwright also wrote about a group of females who lock themselves in the Acropolis until the Greek men stop fighting. Name this comedic Greek playwright of The Frogs and Lysistrata.

On October 31, 2024, this rapper was released from jail after he accepted a plea deal for gang-related charges in Georgia. His real name is Jeffery Lamar Williams Jr., but his is known by his stage name. He gained mainstream recognition with his 2014 mixtape "1017 Thug 3."  He popularized the use of high-pitched ad-libs and unconventional vocal inflections, influencing a generation of rappers.  He collaborated with Camila Cabello on the hit song "Havana," showcasing his versatility and crossover appeal.  He is a co-founder of the YSL record label, which has launched the careers of artists like Gunna and Lil Keed.  Who is this Atlanta-based rapper, known for his unique sound and artistic vision?

A suicide bombing by the Balochistan Liberation Army at the at a railway station in this country killed 27 people. This country, home to the Khyber Pass, a strategic mountain pass that has witnessed the passage of armies and traders for centuries, is the world's fifth-most populous nation. Its bustling port city of Karachi serves as a major economic hub and gateway to the Arabian Sea. It is also home to the ancient Indus Valley Civilization, one of the world's earliest urban civilizations. What is this South Asian nation, known for its rich cultural heritage, diverse landscapes, and passion for cricket?

This man's first senatorial reelection bid was challenged by by Manvel Davis. A product of the Pendergast political machine, this man chaired a namesake committee that investigated waste in arms manufacturing during WWII. He called the legislature at the time of his presidency the "Do Nothing Congress", despite Congress passing the Taft-Hartley Act over his veto. As president, he established the containment policy through his namesake doctrine, recognized Israel and desegregated the military. Name this president who was, along with Thomas Dewey, the subject of an erroneous Chicago Tribune headline.

The radix and bucket variety of this algorithm can have better run time than other types, and the bogo variety is of the order of n factorial. The selection and insertion varieties are worse in general than one that is named after a data structure that always allows access to the smallest element, a heap. One type involves the splitting of an array into two and then performing the titular operation recursively. Merge and quick name what class of algorithms that output an ordered list or array.

This iconic thriller's suspenseful score, composed by John Williams, features two alternating notes that evoke a sense of impending danger. The film's tagline, "You'll never go in the water again," became a chilling warning that resonated with audiences, impacting beach attendance worldwide.  The film's mechanical shark, nicknamed "Bruce" by the crew, was notoriously unreliable, leading director Steven Spielberg to rely on suspense and suggestion to create terror.  What is the title of this 1975 film, which became a summer blockbuster and spawned a series of sequels?

This man's "I am prepared to die" speech outlined the aims of the armed group Spear of the Nation. He was "Accused #1" in the Rivonia Trial, after which he was imprisoned at Robben Island. After his release, this member of the ANC was elected President; he established the Truth and Reconciliation Commission to help heal the wounds of Apartheid. Name this first black President of South Africa, who died in December of 2013.

This state's Sawatch Mountains are home to the Collegiate Peaks, including Mount Harvard, Mount Yale, and Mount Oxford. This state's 58 "fourteeners," or mountains with a peak over 14,000 feet, include Mount Elbert, the tallest point in this state, and a mountain named for a man who failed to climb it, Pikes Peak. Greeley, Fort Collins, and Boulder are cities in what state in the Rocky Mountains that is home to a US Mint in Denver?

This paddle sport, invented in 1965 on Bainbridge Island, Washington, combines elements of tennis, badminton, and ping-pong. It is played on a badminton-sized court with a lowered net, using solid paddles and a perforated plastic ball.  Its unique scoring system, where only the serving team can score points, adds a strategic layer to the game.  It has experienced a surge in popularity in recent years, attracting players of all ages and skill levels.  What is this sport, known for its social and recreational appeal?

Two of this composer's preludes bear the nicknames "Devil's Trill" and "Raindrop." This composer wrote a piece in C minor after a rebellion in his country; that work is the "Revolutionary" Etude. This composer of Fantasie-Impromptu also composed a waltz in D flat major more well-known as the Minute Waltz. Name this Polish composer of polonaises, mazurkas, and ballades.

German soldiers and a dog named Princess capture the protagonist of this novel as he flees the Battle of the Bulge. Edgar Derby is executed for stealing a teapot in this novel, and Paul Lazzaro commits murder to avenge the death of Roland Weary. The protagonist travels to Tralfamadore and becomes unstuck in time. "The Children's Crusade" subtitles this Kurt Vonnegut novel about Billy Pilgrim and the firebombing of Dresden.
answers: The Children's Crusade: A Duty-Dance with Death
incorrect3: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

question: Sherrod Brown, a senator from this US state was defeated in the 2024 general election by Bernie Moreno. Mike Dewine currently serves as the governor of this state which is the birthplace of seven U.S. presidents, including Ulysses S. Grant and William McKinley. Its city of Dayton was the home of the Wright brothers, pioneers of aviation who made their first successful flight in 1903. It is also home to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, celebrating the history and impact of rock music. What is this Midwestern state, once a key part of the Western Reserve and a major player in the Underground Railroad?

Two members of this family partially mortgaged their plantation, Montpelier, to free their son from debtors' prison. During the Burning of Washington, DC, a woman who married into this family instructed Paul Jennings to save a portrait of George Washington. After winning the election of 1808, a member of this family was president during the War of 1812. Name this American political family that included Dolley and the fourth President of the US, James.

This leader remarked that "political power grows out of the barrel of a gun". This leader also wrote On Guerrilla Warfare after being forced to retreat to the Jinggang Mountains due to the failed Autumn Harvest Uprising. This leader evaded Chiang Kai-shek's pursuits with the Red Army on the Long March. The Cultural Revolution and the Great Leap Forward were launched by what first leader of Communist China?

The ruins of the saltwater Sutro Baths are in the Lands End park in this city. Irving Morrow designed a bridge that connects this city to Marin County. During the 1967 "Summer of Love," one hundred thousand hippies converged on this city's Haight-Ashbury neighborhood. Nob Hill and Telegraph Hill are other neighborhoods in this city that was significantly damaged by a 1906 earthquake and fire. The "most crooked street in the world," Lombard street, is in what city home to Fisherman's Wharf and the Golden Gate Bridge?

This team's defense, often referred to as one of the most dominant in NFL history, led them to a Super Bowl XXXV victory in 2001.  Their home stadium, M&T Bank Stadium, is known for its passionate and boisterous crowds, creating a challenging environment for opposing teams.  They have a historic rivalry with the Pittsburgh Steelers, a matchup that often features hard-hitting action and intense competition.  What is the name of this team, whose history includes legendary players like Ray Lewis and Ed Reed?

The T2 type of these were labeled with radioactive sulfur and phosphorus in the Hershey-Chase experiment. Latency results when these entities enter a lysogenic cycle. The first discovered one of these causes tobacco mosaic disease, and AZT is a treatment for a widespread "retro" one. A protein capsid surrounds these entities, which are unable to reproduce outside a host cell. Name these non-living pathogens, such as influenza and HIV.

This neo-noir mystery, set in 1930s Los Angeles, features a memorable scene where the protagonist, Jake Gittes, gets his nose sliced open with a switchblade, a symbolic wound that reflects the unraveling of the case and the city's corruption.  The film's complex plot, involving water rights, incest, and murder, is a modern take on classic film noir themes.  It stars Jack Nicholson as a private investigator who gets entangled in a web of deceit and betrayal.  What is the title of this 1974 film directed by Roman Polanski?

This structure is divided into Brodmann areas, and develops from the telencephalon. The corpus callosum connects the two hemispheres of this structure, which is divided into temporal, parietal, occipital, and frontal lobes. Name this largest area of the brain, which controls voluntary thoughts and actions.

The 2024 senate race in this state between Dave McCormick and Bob Casey is undergoing a mandatory recount. The state, nicknamed the "Keystone State" for its central role in the founding of the United States, is home to the Liberty Bell, a symbol of American independence. Its city of Philadelphia was the nation's first capital and the site of the signing of the Declaration of Independence. It is also where Hershey's chocolate was founded, making it a sweet spot for confectionery enthusiasts. What is this state, known for its Amish communities, rolling farmland, and the historic Gettysburg battlefield?

A 1956 revolution in this country targeted Fulgencio Batista and was supported by Che Guevara. A leader of this country finally transferred power to his brother, Raul, in 2006. The U.S. strengthened an embargo against this country following a 1962 crisis over missiles placed here by the Soviets. Name this country that was led by Fidel Castro from Havana.

This comedy film features a protagonist who relives the same day, February 2nd, over and over again, stuck in a time loop in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania.  The film's protagonist, Phil Connors, played by Bill Murray, is a cynical weatherman who gradually transforms from a self-centered cynic to a compassionate and selfless person.  The film's repetitive nature allows for humorous and creative scenarios, as Phil explores the possibilities and consequences of his time loop.  What is the title of this 1993 film directed by Harold Ramis?

A ritual during this practice sees participants walk around a fire seven times. After this practice has been completed, women apply red sindoor powder to their foreheads along with bindi, a colored red dot. The father gives away his daughter in this practice, during which promises are made to keep a home and raise a family. Vows of love are exchanged during what practice that involves a bride and groom?

Martha Wright and 99 other participants in this event signed the Declaration of Sentiments, which notes that "all men and women are created equal." Lucretia Mott was the featured speaker at this 1848 event in upstate New York, which benefited from Quaker ideals of equality. Name this convention organized by Elizabeth Cady Stanton, a landmark moment in the women's rights movement.

This manager guided the New York Yankees to four World Series titles in five years, solidifying his place in baseball history. Before his success in the Bronx, he managed the Mets, Braves, and Cardinals, experiencing varying levels of success. He famously clashed with George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' fiery owner, but their partnership ultimately yielded remarkable results. He also managed the Los Angeles Dodgers, leading them to two National League Championship Series appearances. Who is this Hall of Fame manager, known for his ability to handle high-pressure situations and manage talented teams?

Satellites in geostationary orbit are placed directly above this feature and, as a result, don't appear to move in the sky when viewed from the ground. An African country with capital Malabo and a South American country with capital Quito are named for their location on or near this geographical feature. Zero degrees latitude is defined at what imaginary line that separates the Earth into northern and southern hemispheres?

This technology company was removed from the Dow Jones after 25 years and replaced with a rival, Nvidia. The company, whose iconic "Inside" jingle and logo became synonymous with personal computing in the 1990s, was co-founded by Gordon Moore, whose prediction that the number of transistors on a microchip would double approximately every two years became known as Moore's Law. Its first commercially available microprocessor released in 1971, revolutionized the computer industry by packing the power of a room-sized computer onto a single chip. What is the name of this tech giant, headquartered in Santa Clara, California?

This HBO drama series, created by Damon Lindelof, explores the aftermath of a global event known as the "Sudden Departure," where 2% of the world's population inexplicably vanishes. The series follows the Garvey family and other residents of Mapleton, New York, as they grapple with grief, uncertainty, and the search for meaning in a world forever changed.  What is the name of this critically acclaimed series, known for its exploration of faith, loss, and the human condition?

Jake Paul, the popular YouTuber turned boxer, fought this former boxing champion on November 15. This boxer's infamous bite of Evander Holyfield's ear during their 1997 rematch resulted in his disqualification and a temporary suspension from boxing. He became the youngest heavyweight champion in history at the age of 20, knocking out Trevor Berbick in the second round.  His ferocious fighting style and intimidating persona earned him the nickname "Iron Mike." He has also appeared in films like "The Hangover" and "Ip Man 3," showcasing his personality and acting skills. Who is this legendary boxer, known for his powerful punches and controversial career?

The town of Moshi lies on the south slopes of this mountain, which Douglas Adams climbed in a rhino suit for charity. The highest of this mountain's three cones, Kibo Peak, is a dormant volcano that has lost a significant portion of its ice cap in recent years. It is located roughly 300 miles southeast of Lake Victoria on the border between Kenya and Tanzania. Name this tallest mountain in Africa.

In the Arabian Nights, Sinbad collects diamonds from an island inhabited by enormous ones of these animals called rocs, and later steals one of their eggs. Chanticleer is one of these creatures in French folklore, and a mythical animal of this type is a phoenix. Name this family of animals, exemplified by Chicken Little.

John Crerar founded a library in this city, whose urban planning was done by Daniel Burnham. August Spies was executed in this city for his supposed role in the Haymarket Square bombing. In this city, H.H. Holmes operated a "murder castle" at a hotel built for the 1893 Columbian Exposition; that event also featured the first Ferris Wheel. In 1871, Mrs O'Leary's cow legendarily started a "Great" fire in what largest city of Illinois?

In Euler's formula, this function is multiplied by i. This function's namesake wave is integral to Fourier analysis and represents constant, periodic oscillations. On the unit circle, this function is positive in the first and second quadrants. Additionally, this function is used to represent the y-value of a unit circle arc. Identify this trigonometric function that is the inverse of cosecant and, for a right triangle, gives the ratio of the opposite side over the hypotenuse.

Many people in this country speak Tagalog. Major natural disasters that occurred here include Typhoon Haiyan and the eruption of Mt. Pinatubo. This country was named after a Spanish king even though it is in Asia. Name this country with capital at Manila.

In 1928, this man founded a namesake rubber plantation in the Amazon rainforest that was abandoned within six years. This man published anti-Semitic articles in The Dearborn Independent. He offered a revolutionary five-dollars-per-day wage at his factories in Detroit. Name this businessman who invented assembly lines to churn out millions of Model T cars.

This NFL team's teal and black color scheme, a bold choice in the 1990s, reflects the vibrant energy of their coastal home city.  Their mascot, Jaxson de Ville, is a jaguar known for his daring stunts, including bungee jumping off the stadium lights.  They made a surprising run to the AFC Championship game in 1996, their second season in the league, led by quarterback Mark Brunell.  Their home stadium, TIAA Bank Field, features a unique pool area where fans can watch the game while taking a dip.  What is the name of this team, based in Jacksonville, Florida?

This band's album cover art, often featuring iconic figures from film and literature, included images of James Dean, Truman Capote, and Viv Nicholson. Their melancholic lyrics, coupled with Johnny Marr's jangly guitar melodies, captured the angst and alienation of youth in 1980s Britain. Their song "This Charming Man" became an anthem for the disaffected, with its witty lyrics and catchy chorus.  Despite their relatively short lifespan, disbanding in 1987, their influence on indie and alternative rock is undeniable. What is the name of this influential Manchester band, fronted by Morrissey?

Justin Welby announced his resignation from this position as a result of the John Smyth abuse scandal in the Church of England. This religious figure, the most senior bishop in the Church of England, resides in Lambeth Palace in London and holds the title of Primate of All England.  They are responsible for the spiritual leadership of the Church of England and play a prominent role in national ceremonies and events.  They are appointed by the British monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister, following a selection process by a Crown Nominations Commission. Who is this high-ranking figure in the Anglican Communion?

The highest peak of this peninsula is Mount Baekdu, and this peninsula's northern boundary is demarcated by the Yalu River. At the 2018 Winter Olympics, the two countries on this peninsula fielded a unified women's hockey team. The DMZ separates the Northern and Southern halves of what peninsula in Asia that contains the cities of Pyongyang and Seoul?

Particles emitted by the eruption of Krakatoa inspired this painting's warm, monochromatic background. In the background of this painting, shadowy boat masts float on the swirling blue and yellow water of Oslo Harbor. Two dark figures walk together on the far left side of this painting, next to a railing and behind a tortured central figure. Name this painting by Norwegian artist Edvard Munch, in which a bald figure raises its hands to its head and opens its mouth wide.

The rotational analog of mass is the "moment of" this property. This word describes reference frames in which objects do not accelerate without force acting on them. Newton's first law of motion, also known as the law of this property, states that objects remain in their current state of motion unless acted on by an external force. Name this property of matter which causes objects to resist changes in velocity.

The Greek philosopher Democritus suggested these existed, and provided them a name that meant "uncuttable" in Greek. The plum-pudding model tried to explain these, but a later discovery of the positively-charged nucleus of these things disproved that model. There are three of these things in a molecule of water; two of hydrogen and one of oxygen. Name this basic unit of every chemical element.

A trio of exotic dances in this ballet's second act representing chocolate, tea, and coffee has received scrutiny for its cultural insensitivity. This ballet's notable use of the celesta required its composer to smuggle one in from Germany. In this ballet, a little girl is able to use her slipper to ward off the nefarious Mouse King. In this ballet based on an E.T.A. Hoffman short story, Clara receives the title object from the mysterious Herr Drosselmeyer. Name this Tchaikovsky ballet which features the Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy, commonly performed during Christmas.

Off the southwest coast of this island, the Great Skelling island is home to an abandoned monastery. Port cities on this island include Kinsale and Galway, while Drogheda lies on the River Boyne five miles inland from a sea named for this island. Hibernia was the Latin name for this island, where a political division created a Northern country with capital Belfast. Name this "Emerald Isle" that is home to Dublin, east of Great Britain.

The Biot-Savart law calculates a magnetic field induced by this quantity, of which sums in and out of nodes are equal according to Kirchhoff's junction rule. Inductance measures a material's opposition to changes in this quantity, and power equals voltage times it. This equals voltage divided by resistance, and conventionally is measured in the direction of positive charge. Name this quantity measured in amperes.

In this city, sailors fought groups of Mexican-Americans in the Zoot Suit Riots. In this city, Marquette Frye was hit with a baton in the Watts neighborhood. Korean-owned businesses were targeted during riots in this city, despite a man pleading "can't we all just get along?" In this city, four police officers were filmed beating Rodney King. Name this city in Southern California, the second-largest in the United States.

This Senator, currently serving as the senate minority leader, will cede his position to John Thune in January 2025. He is the longest-service senator from the state of Kentucky, first elected in 1985. He is the longest-serving Senate party leader in U.S. history, serving as both minority leader and majority leader for the Republican Party. Name this former attorney, the senior senator from Kentucky, who has said he will serve until at least the end of his term in 2026.

This football manager, nicknamed "Le Professeur" for his intellectual approach to the game, holds the record for the most FA Cup titles, with seven victories to his name. He managed Arsenal for 22 years, from 1996 to 2018, transforming the club into a Premier League powerhouse. He introduced innovative training methods and a focus on attacking football, leading to an undefeated Premier League season in 2003-04, a feat that earned the team the nickname "The Invincibles." Who is this influential manager, known for his long tenure with Arsenal and his impact on English football?

In the 2012 Olympics, this country's team walked out of a soccer match against Colombia when the wrong flag was displayed on screen. In April 2012, this country failed to launch a satellite when their rocket's second stage did not ignite. Two journalists were detained here in 2009, but were released after a visit by Bill Clinton. An international incident in 2010 was caused by an artillery exchange between this country and its southern neighbor over the island of Yeonpyeong, the most serious military skirmish since a 1953 peace treaty. Name this country whose Supreme Leader is Kim Jong Un, who took over in 2011 after Kim Jong Il died of a heart attack.

This groundbreaking nature documentary series, narrated by David Attenborough, captivated audiences with its stunning footage of diverse ecosystems and wildlife from around the world. Its innovative filming techniques, including high-definition cameras and aerial shots, captured breathtaking scenes of animals in their natural habitats. The series' first episode, "From Pole to Pole," showcased the planet's diverse environments, from the frozen Arctic to the lush Amazon rainforest. What is the name of this BBC series, which has become a benchmark for nature documentaries and raised awareness about the wonders and fragility of the natural world?

This open-world role-playing game allows players to choose their own path, whether it's joining the Imperial Legion, siding with the Stormcloak rebellion, or becoming a master thief in the Thieves Guild. Players can master a variety of skills, including archery, smithing, and enchanting, to enhance their character's abilities.  The game's iconic dragon shouts, powerful vocal attacks learned from ancient dragons, add a unique element to combat.  What is the name of this critically acclaimed game, the fifth installment in The Elder Scrolls series?

This NBA team's iconic teal and purple color scheme, a hallmark of the 1990s, was revived in 2014, bringing back a nostalgic feel for fans who remember the franchise's early days. They were originally established as an expansion team in 1988, led by young stars Larry Johnson and Alonzo Mourning.  Their home arena, the Spectrum Center, is located in the heart of downtown Charlotte and has hosted NBA All-Star games.  What is the name of this team, whose history includes a brief relocation to New Orleans before returning to Charlotte in 2004?

Vitamin B12 deficiency causes these cells to become megaloblasts, which are unusually large immature versions of them. Pulse oximeters measure the absorbance of an important protein in these cells, which can bind extremely tightly to carbon monoxide. Erythropoietin controls the production of these cells in the bone marrow. These cells, which lack nuclei, are shaped incorrectly in sickle-cell anemia. Name these cells that contain hemoglobin, which make up almost half of the cells in blood.

This city is home to a Norman Foster-designed commercial skyscraper formerly known as the Swiss Re Building, nicknamed "The Gherkin." Another skyscraper in this city designed by Renzo Piano is 95 stories tall and nicknamed "The Shard." Inigo Jones was among the architects involved in the design of this city's St. Paul's Cathedral, which sits on Ludgate Hill. A building sometimes referred to as the "Inside-Out Building" in this city is home to an insurance company known as Lloyd's of this city. Westminster Abbey is located in what capital of England?

One leader of this polity gave the "Tryst with Destiny" speech and later, alongside Tito and Nasser, co-founded the Non-Aligned Movement. Another leader from this country led Operation Bluestar, which led to hundreds of deaths in the Golden Temple of Amritsar. One notable resident of this nation taught satyagraha and led a salt march in opposition to the British government, which granted this nation independence in 1947 along with Pakistan. Identify this Asian nation once led by Jawaharlal Nehru and Indira Ghandi.

This historic landmark is reopening to the public for the first time after a fire in 2019. This iconic cathedral, ravaged by a devastating fire in 2019 that destroyed its spire and roof, is renowned for its stunning stained-glass rose windows, intricate stonework, and imposing gargoyles. Located on the Île de la Cité in Paris, it has served as a symbol of French culture and history for over 850 years.  Its construction began in the 12th century, showcasing Gothic architectural styles.  It is home to numerous religious relics, including the Crown of Thorns believed to have been worn by Jesus Christ. Name this cathedral which is the setting of a famous novel with a "Hunchback."

This creature is told "Still, thou art blest, compared wi' me!" because it cannot lament the past or fear the future. The speaker of a 1785 poem calls this "fellow-mortal" creature a "wee, sleeket, cowran, tim'rous beastie," and uses the phrase "gang aft agley," which is often translated from Scottish as "often goes awry."Name this rodent subject of a Robert Burns poem that remarks on "the best laid plans o'" these creatures "an' men."

This two-minute speech followed a much longer one by Edward Everett. It claims that "we are engaged in a great civil war... (to test) whether that nation or any nation so conceived and so dedicated can long endure." This speech stated its speaker's goal that "government for the people, by the people, shall not perish from this earth." Name this famous speech on a battlefield by Abraham Lincoln which begins "Four score and seven years ago."

This classic coming-of-age comedy features a memorable scene where the protagonist, feigning illness to skip school, lip-syncs "Twist and Shout" on a parade float in downtown Chicago. The film's witty narration and breaking of the fourth wall, with the protagonist directly addressing the audience, add to its charm and humor. The film's antagonist, Principal Ed Rooney, played by Jeffrey Jones, becomes increasingly determined to catch the protagonist in his deception, leading to hilarious situations. What is the title of this 1986 film directed by John Hughes?

This NFL team, whose iconic "Monsters of the Midway" defense led them to a dominant Super Bowl XX victory in 1985, holds the record for the most enshrinees in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Their classic navy blue and orange uniforms, with the distinctive "C" logo on their helmets, are instantly recognizable symbols of the franchise. Their home stadium, Soldier Field, is the oldest stadium in the NFL and sits on the shores of Lake Michigan. What is the name of this team, whose history includes legendary players like Walter Payton and Dick Butkus?

Made up of what is left over of Lake Bonneville, the lake is now fed by the Weber River, the Bear River, and the Jordan River. This lake has both brine shrimp and brine flies, but does not have any fish species living in it. The winter winds blowing over this lake create significant snowfall to its east, including in a capital named for this lake. Name this landmark lake found near the capital of the state of Utah.

A vehicle-ramming attack in this nation recently killed 35 people. The country is birthplace of inventions like paper, gunpowder, and the compass, which have had a profound impact on human civilization. This country, home to the Great Wall, a vast fortification spanning over 13,000 miles, boasts the world's largest population, with over 1.4 billion people.  Its capital city, Beijing, has hosted the Summer Olympics twice, in 2008 and 2022.  What is this East Asian nation, known for its rich history, diverse culture, and rapidly growing economy?

After this man loses a case to a group including Anytus and Lycon, this man ironically suggests he be given free meals in the Prytaneum. He notes that the unexamined life is not worth living and is accused of atheism by Meletus. This man's trial and conviction for corrupting the youth of Athens are described in the Apology by Plato. Name this Ancient Greek philosopher who was sentenced to death by drinking hemlock.

Grignard reagents can react with carbonyl groups to form these compounds. Their primary type can be oxidized to aldehydes and then to carboxylic acids, but their secondary type normally terminates the process at the ketone stage. In Fischer esterification, they are reacted with carboxylic acid to form the namesake compounds. Having a general formula of C-n-H-2n-plus-1-O-H identify these organic compounds in which a hydroxyl group is bound to a carbon atom that include methanol and ethanol.

One book by this author sees Max Ophuls, a United States ambassador to India murdered by the title character, who is skilled at the tightrope, Shalimar the Clown. Another book by this author features Saleem, who is telepathic and was born at the exact time of India's independence. In addition to writing Midnight's Children, a fatwa was issued against this man for writing a book concerning Gibreel and Saladin, who find themselves on a hijacked airplane. Name this British-Indian author of The Satanic Verses.

This President served during the Arbuthnot-Ambrister affair and appointed Roger Taney to the Supreme Court. The Peggy Eaton affair rocked his cabinet, nicknamed the "kitchen cabinet." He killed the Nicholas Biddle-led Second Bank of the U.S. with the Specie Circular and signed the Indian Removal Act. Nicknamed "Old Hickory," name this man, who left Martin Van Buren the Panic of 1837, the seventh U.S. President.

Nancy Schon designed a set of sculptures for this city's Public Garden to commemorate the Robert McClosky children's book Make Way for Ducklings. Frederick Law Olmstead designed this city's Emerald Necklace, which includes a Common near this city's Financial District. This city's Back Bay contains the poorly-designed John Hancock Tower. Kenmore Square is near the oldest American baseball park in what Massachusetts city whose Fenway Park is home to the Red Sox?

This man's roommate, who fought in the Second Anglo-Afghan War, is disdainful of his strong addictions to opiates. This man met Irene Adler, the only woman to beat him in a battle of wits, in the story "A Scandal in Bohemia". This man dies in combat with his rival Professor Moriarty at the Reichenbach Falls. Name this detective created by Arthur Conan Doyle and accompanied by John Watson.

This band's iconic tongue and lips logo, designed by artist John Pasche in 1971, has become a symbol of rock and roll rebellion and enduring popularity. Their 1969 album, Let It Bleed, featuring tracks like "Gimme Shelter" and "You Can't Always Get What You Want," captured the tumultuous spirit of the era.  Their legendary guitarist, Keith Richards, known for his distinctive riffs and swaggering stage presence, has become a rock icon in his own right.  They have released 30 studio albums and countless hit singles. What is the name of this British rock band, whose career has spanned over six decades?

President Elect Donald Trump announced the formation of this agency to be led by Vivek Ramaswamy and Elon Musk. It's acronym shares its name with a notorious cryptocurrency with a Shiba Inu mascot. Despite its name, it is not expected to be a federal executive department and its formation is not expected to require approval from the U.S. Congress. Name this proposed presidential advisory commission that Trump claims could save the government $2 trillion.

After a 1895 Supreme Court case briefly struck down this policy, a 1913 Constitutional amendment made it legal. Florida and Nevada are two of seven states that don't use this policy, whose introduction reduced the importance of tariffs for federal government revenue. The Sixteenth Amendment authorized what type of tax that is reported on IRS Form 1040 and which taxes money made by the taxpayer?

This phylum's class Anthozoa is mostly sessile. Its class Cubozoa includes the deadly sea wasp. Members of this phylum have a jelly-like layer called the mesoglea. This phylum's polyp body plan is exhibited by hydras. This phylum's name is derived from the name of its harpoon-like stinging cells. Name this radially-symmetric invertebrate phylum that includes corals and jellyfish.

The dog Pompey allegedly stopped the attempted assassination of a leader of this country, whose Sea Beggars seized the port of Brielle. The iconoclast Beeldenstorm took place in this country where the Bourse stock exchange was established for the United East India Company. A tulip bubble occurred in this country led by the stadtholder William of Orange in the Eighty Years' War. Dikes allowed polders to be reclaimed from the sea in this Low Country. Name this country with capital Amsterdam.

This manager, known for his fiery temper and record-setting 159 ejections throughout his career, led the Atlanta Braves to an unprecedented 14 consecutive division titles from 1991 to 2005.  He managed the Toronto Blue Jays and Atlanta Braves, winning a World Series title with the Braves in 1995.  He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 2011, alongside fellow Braves legends Greg Maddux and Tom Glavine.  Who is this manager, known for his calm demeanor and strategic brilliance?

This US city, located in Mid Michigan is the fifth largest in the state. Mona Hanna-Attisha led a 2015 study at the Hurley Medical Center in this city that was initially dismissed by the Department of Environmental Quality. This Genesee County city also experienced an outbreak of Legionnaires' Disease after switching to drawing water from its namesake river instead of from Detroit. Name this Michigan city whose water supply was found in 2015 to have dangerous levels of lead.

This artist depicted seven men in white collars observing the title physician in one work; that work also depicts a cadaver with exposed arm muscles and is titled The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp. This artist is also known for his series of self-portraits, including one "with two circles" and one with "beret and turned-up collar." In this artist's best-known work, a dog barks at a drummer on the far right of the canvas, and a red sash is worn by Captain Frans Banning Cocq, the leader of the title militia. Name this Dutch artist of The Night Watch.

This comedic news organization announced this week that it had won a bid to buy Infowars, the website founded by the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, out of bankruptcy. The satirical website, known for its outlandish headlines and deadpan humor, was founded in 1988 by two University of Wisconsin-Madison students, Tim Keck and Christopher Johnson. Its name is a nod to the humble vegetable that was reportedly the only food the founders could afford when they started the publication. What is the name of this website, whose tagline is "Tu Stultus Es," Latin for "You Are Dumb"?

This classic Western film, based on the true story of two legendary outlaws, features a memorable scene where the protagonists jump off a cliff into a raging river to escape a posse.  The film's iconic theme song, "Raindrops Keep Fallin' on My Head," sung by B.J. Thomas, won an Academy Award for Best Original Song.  The film stars Paul Newman and Robert Redford as the charismatic leaders of the Hole-in-the-Wall Gang.  The film's ending, with the protagonists facing a Bolivian army regiment in a final shootout, leaves their fate ambiguous.  What is the title of this 1969 film directed by George Roy Hill?
answers: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid

question: The goal of this policy was supported in Horace Greeley's "The Prayer of Twenty Million." New Orleans and recently-occupied Tennessee were excluded from this policy, as it only applied to territory in rebellion. This war measure was announced after the Union victory at Antietam, and it was bolstered by the Thirteenth Amendment after the Civil War. Abraham Lincoln issued what executive order that freed slaves in the South?

This ruler invited scholars like Einhard and Alcuin of York to his court as part of a period of cultural revival called his dynasty's "Renaissance." This son of Pepin the Short was the grandson of Charles Martel, the founder of the Carolingian dynasty. On Christmas Day in 800, Pope Leo III crowned this ruler as Holy Roman Emperor. Name this medieval-era Frankish ruler who united most of Western Europe.

This sport's scoring system, with its unique terminology of "love," "15," "30," and "40," has puzzled newcomers for centuries.  Its four major tournaments, held in Melbourne, Paris, London, and New York, are known as the Grand Slams and represent the pinnacle of achievement in the sport.  The sport's origins can be traced back to 12th-century France, where it was played as a hand-ball game called jeu de paume.  What is this racquet sport, known for its fast-paced rallies, strategic shot-making, and iconic players like Serena Williams and Roger Federer?

A special form of the endoplasmic reticulum stores this element, which is used for muscle contraction. Limestone is this element's carbonate. This element is needed for strengthening bones and can be obtained by drinking milk. Name this element symbolized Ca.

This satirical black comedy, featuring a memorable scene where a general rides a nuclear bomb like a rodeo bull, explores the dangers of Cold War paranoia and the potential for accidental nuclear war.  The film's title character played by Peter Sellers, is a wheelchair-bound former Nazi scientist with a disconcerting tendency for his right hand to involuntarily salute.  The film's iconic line, "Gentlemen, you can't fight in here! This is the War Room!", highlights the absurdity of the situation.  What is the full title of this 1964 film directed by Stanley Kubrick?

This work notes that "Pope and Czar" have allied to exorcise the title group. It lists ten demands, including free public education and a progressive income tax, that would lead to the end of class struggles between the ruling bourgeoisie and the working proletariat, who have "nothing to lose but their chains." Ending "Working men of all countries, unite!" name this 1848 anti-capitalist work written by Marx and Engels.

This country is currently fighting for control of the Essequibo region with its neighbor Guyana. This country's largest lake is Lake Maracaibo, which is connected to the Caribbean Sea by low-lying sandbars. It contains some of the largest oil reserves in the Western Hemisphere. This country is home to the highest waterfall in the world, Angel Falls. Name this South American country with capital at Caracas.

This nation, where a recent coup d'état ousted the transitional government led by Abdalla Hamdok, faces ongoing political instability and a humanitarian crisis. The conflict in its Darfur region, though less intense than in the past, continues to displace populations and cause suffering.  The country is bordered by Egypt to the north and Ethiopia to the east, and its capital, Khartoum, lies at the confluence of the White Nile and Blue Nile rivers. What is this African nation, which gained independence from British and Egyptian rule in 1956?

This man signed the Elkins Act, fining railroads for offering rebates. One of his policies, including the "three Cs" of Control of Corporations, Consumer Protection, and Conservation, was called the Square Deal. He resigned as Assistant Secretary of the Navy to organize the Rough Riders, and 45 trusts were "busted" in his tenure. Known for running for the Bull Moose party in 1912 and losing name this Republican, the president before William Howard Taft.

This football manager, known for his energetic sideline presence and his trademark "heavy metal" football style, led Borussia Dortmund to two consecutive Bundesliga titles and a Champions League final appearance. He took over as manager of Liverpool in 2015, guiding them to their first Premier League title in 30 years and a Champions League victory in 2019. His passionate and charismatic personality has made him a fan favorite, and his tactical innovations have revitalized Liverpool's attacking prowess. Who is this German manager, known for his "gegenpressing" strategy and his infectious enthusiasm?

This painter grew up and lived in La Casa Azul in Mexico City. She painted many self-portraits because she often felt alone, even in the company of her artist husband Diego Rivera. Name this Mexican artist, famous for her prominent unibrow.

This holiday, originally known as Armistice Day, was first celebrated in 1919 to commemorate the end of World War I.  It was later expanded to honor all veterans of the U.S. armed forces.  It is observed on November 11th, the anniversary of the signing of the armistice that ended hostilities in World War I.  In 1938, it became a national holiday, a day dedicated to thanking those who have served in the military.  What is the name of this holiday, a day of remembrance and recognition for veterans' sacrifices?

The 29th annual edition of this conference recently ocurred in Baku, Azerbaijan. This annual gathering, the largest of its kind, brings together world leaders, scientists, and activists from nearly 200 countries to discuss and negotiate solutions to the global climate crisis. The first such gathering was held in Berlin in 1995, and subsequent meetings have led to significant agreements like the Kyoto Protocol and the Paris Agreement. What is the name of this conference, which plays a crucial role in shaping international climate action?

The Paseo de la Reforma runs through this city, which sinks about a meter every year due to the drainage of the basin of Lake Texcoco. The ancient ruins of Tenochtitlan were replaced by the construction of what largest North American city, the capital of the southern neighbor of the USA?

This man, who made the "Appeal of the 18th of June," was criticized for shouting "Long live free Quebec!" in 1967. A wildcat strike begun by student protesters caused this man to flee to Germany in May 1968. This leader, who granted independence to Algeria, founded the Fifth Republic in 1958 and opposed the Vichy government. Name this President of France and leader of the Free French Forces during World War II.

This football manager, known for his tactical acumen and often controversial personality, earned the nickname "The Special One" during his first stint at Chelsea, where he proclaimed himself a top manager. He has managed top clubs across Europe, including Porto, Inter Milan, Real Madrid, and Manchester United, achieving success in multiple leagues. He led Porto to an unexpected UEFA Champions League title in 2004 and Inter Milan to a historic treble in 2010. Who is this Portuguese manager, known for his mind games and his ability to win trophies?

This film, set in medieval Sweden during the Black Death, features a memorable scene where a knight plays a game of chess with Death, a personification of mortality.  The film's allegorical imagery and exploration of existential themes, including faith, death, and the meaning of life, have made it a classic of world cinema.  Its director, Ingmar Bergman, is known for his introspective and often bleak portrayals of the human condition.  What is the title of this 1957 Swedish historical drama?

While drunk on rum, this character hallucinates an angel aflame floating down from a black cloud. After seeing a single footprint in the beach, this character hides in his "castle" for two years before the chapter "I See the Shore Spread with Bones." This character settles in Brazil after freeing a group of Spaniards from cannibals, who spot mutineers which allowed this character and Friday to return to England. Name this Daniel Defoe character who spends years trapped on an island.

A leader of one of these groups went missing outside the Machus Red Fox in 1975. Terence Powderly founded one that declined after Chicago police shot at protesters in Haymarket Square, and Jimmy Hoffa once led one called the Teamsters. Wal-Mart switched to selling prepackaged meats after its meatcutters created one of these organizations. Name these organizations that collectively bargain to achieve workplace goals.

One of his equations shows that there is no electric field in any neutrally grounded area, which is why it's safer to be in your car than outside during a lightning strike. His equations also state that no monopoles exist in nature, and that most magnetic charges are dipoles.
