He lends his name to the surface used in finding electric fields, and he also found the formula for summing a long list of numbers at the age of 8. Name this German scientist who contributed two of the Maxwell Equations.

This agreement was negotiated by ambassadors James Monroe and Robert Livingston, who included a fifteen million collar payment that was to be used to invade England. After this agreement, Thomas Jefferson launched the Lewis and Clark Expedition. Name this agreement that nearly doubled the size of the United States by buying, among other territory, New Orleans.

One concerto for this instrument pairs a handbell with each playing of the rondo theme. L'estro armonico and The Contest Between Harmony and Invention are sets of concerti for this instrument. One virtuoso player of this instrument wrote 24 caprices for it; that composer of "La Campanella" is Niccolo Paganini. La primavera, or Spring, from Vivaldi's Four Seasons is a concerto for what string instrument pitched higher than a viola?

This celebrity doctor was recently selected by Donald Trump to be his nominee to lead the Centers of Medicare and Medicaid. This television personality gained fame as a frequent guest on "The Oprah Winfrey Show," where he offered health advice and promoted his books. He hosted his own syndicated talk show for 13 seasons, dispensing medical advice and showcasing personal stories. He made a surprising career shift in 2022, running for a U.S. Senate seat in Pennsylvania, ultimately losing to Democrat John Fetterman. Who is this celebrity doctor turned politician?

The Kreutz group of these objects are called sungrazers. Short-period examples of these come from the Kuiper belt, while long-period ones are thought to originate in the Oort cloud. Due to the effects of solar radiation, these objects form a dusty atmosphere called a coma. Famous examples are Hale-Bopp and one named after Edmond Halley. Name these small, icy bodies that often have tails.

A leader of this county committed suicide with an AK-47 in the La Moneda palace. In 1973, a CIA-backed coup overthrew that socialist leader, Salvador Allende, after he nationalized this country's copper mines in the Atacama Desert. Dissidents were brutally suppressed during the dictatorship of Austugo Pinochet in what South American country led from Santiago?

This racquet sport, often described as a mix of tennis and squash, is played on an enclosed court about one-third the size of a tennis court. It features underhand serves and the use of the court walls in play, adding a dynamic element to the game.  The sport originated in Acapulco, Mexico, in 1969 and has gained popularity in Spain and Latin America.  It is typically played in doubles, with teams of two players competing against each other.  What is this fast-paced sport, known for its social and recreational appeal?

This film, a landmark in Japanese cinema, features a climactic battle scene where a village of farmers defends itself against a band of 40 bandits with the help of seven skilled samurai.  The film's influence on Western cinema is evident in its remake, "The Magnificent Seven," and its inspiration for the "Star Wars" franchise.  Its director, Akira Kurosawa, is renowned for his masterful use of cinematography and storytelling, blending action, drama, and social commentary.  What is the title of this 1954 epic adventure film?

Declared functionally extinct in 2006, the baiji species of freshwater dolphin was found only in this river. This river has its source at Geladaindong Mountain on the Tibetan Plateau in Qinghai Province and converges with the Jialing River at Chongquing. Hangzhou and Nanjing are major cities in this river's delta, sometimes referred to as the "golden triangle." The world's largest hydroelectric power station was created as a result of the Three Gorges Dam on this river and it empties into the East China Sea at Shanghai. Name this Chinese river, the longest in Asia.

Margarita Island is a popular tourist destination in this country where the Catatumbo River is home to a lightning storm for over 260 days of the year. Table-top mountains called tepuis can be found in this country's Canaima National Park, which is also home to the world's tallest waterfall. The Llanos plain is drained by the Orinoco River in this country home to Angel Falls. Lake Maracaibo is the center of the oil industry in what country once led by Hugo Chavez from Caracas?

The protagonist of this novel steals a coin from Petit Gervais, but changes his outlook on stealing after Bishop Myriel gives him silver. That reformed thief changes his name to Monsieur Madeleine and adopts the child of a disgraced factory worker, who grows up to wed Marius. Gavroche and Eponine are killed during the June Rebellion of 1832 in this work. Name this novel where Cosette is raised by Jean Valjean while being chased by Inspector Javert, written by Victor Hugo.

This NBA team's home arena, the Wells Fargo Center, has witnessed memorable moments like Allen Iverson's iconic "step-over" of Tyronn Lue in the 2001 NBA Finals.  They have won three NBA championships, with their most recent victory coming in 1983, led by Julius Erving and Moses Malone.  Their passionate fanbase, known for their unwavering support and "Trust the Process" mantra, has endured years of rebuilding and anticipation for a return to championship contention.  What is the name of this team, whose history includes legendary players like Wilt Chamberlain and Charles Barkley?

This man wrote "The spirit and the gifts are ours through Him who with us sideth" in the hymn "A Mighty Fortress is Our God." This man was the subject of the Exsurge Domine bull when his refusal to recant at the Diet of Worms led to his excommunication from the Catholic church. Criticisms of the sale of indulgences in the Ninety-Five Theses were written by what German monk-turned-reformer who started the Protestant Reformation?

In 1993, the British newspaper The Independent published a positive personal relations story about this man's efforts to build a rural highway in Sudan using mujahideen labor. A controversial polio vaccination program was used by the CIA to gain intelligence on this man. Operation Neptune Spear targeted this man, who was killed in Abbottabad, Pakistan in 2011 by Navy SEALs. Name this leader of Al Qaeda and mastermind of the 9/11 attacks.

This web browser, the most popular globally with over 60% market share, is at the center of a recent antitrust lawsuit filed by the U.S. Department of Justice. The lawsuit alleges that the browser's parent company is using its dominance to stifle competition and maintain a monopoly in the digital advertising market. The DOJ is seeking a court order that would require Google to sell off this browser business, a move that could significantly reshape the landscape of the internet. Which web browser, known for its speed and simplicity, is facing this legal challenge?

This war epic, loosely based on Joseph Conrad's novel Heart of Darkness, features a memorable scene where a helicopter attack is set to the music of Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries."  The film's production was notoriously troubled, with filming in the Philippines plagued by typhoons, drug use, and Martin Sheen suffering a heart attack.  The film's ending, with Captain Willard's assassination of Colonel Kurtz, leaves the audience with a sense of ambiguity and moral complexity.  What is the title of this 1979 Vietnam War film directed by Francis Ford Coppola?

The AM-GM inequality compares two types of this measure for a set of n non-negative numbers. One type of this is the nth root of the product of n numbers; that is the geometric type of this measure. The usual type of this measure is called the arithmetic type, which equals the sum of n numbers divided by n and is often contrasted with the median and mode. Name this measure, the average value of a set of numbers.

This iconic horror film features a shocking shower scene where the protagonist, Marion Crane, is brutally murdered, a moment that redefined cinematic violence and audience expectations.  The film's score, composed by Bernard Herrmann, with its screeching violins and jarring strings, heightens the suspense and terror.  The film's antagonist, Norman Bates, played by Anthony Perkins, is a seemingly mild-mannered motel owner with a dark secret and a disturbingly close relationship with his mother.  What is the title of this 1960 Alfred Hitchcock masterpiece?

A group of empires named for this substance due to their military technology includes the Safavid, Ottoman, and Mughal Empires. A plot to kill English king James I that was planned by Guy Fawkes was named for this substance. Like paper, this substance was one of the Four Great Inventions of China, where it was used to make fire arrows. Name this explosive powder used in firearms.

This golfer, known for his long drives and aggressive style of play, achieved the rare feat of winning each of the four World Golf Championships events. He captured his first major title at the 2016 U.S. Open, overcoming a controversial penalty to win by three strokes. He also won the 2020 Tour Championship by three strokes. Who is this American golfer, who has spent over 130 weeks ranked as the world's number one golfer?

Betty Friedan wrote a book about these people's "mystique". Title IX advanced these people's participation in sports, and Gloria Steinem founded a magazine for these people. The failed Equal Rights Amendment would have guaranteed equal protection for these people. Simone de Beauvoir's The Second Sex examined the oppression of what people whose rights are the primary focus of feminism?

Layers of this substance are called its horizons, which make up its profile, while types of it include peaty, saline, and loamy. A yellowish-gray type of it is deposited by wind and glaciers is called loess. Two to ten percent of this substance is humus, while the rest is water, air, and rock. Its texture is classified by the amount of sand, silt, and clay it contains. Name this organic substance in which plants grow.

One playwright in this language wrote a work in which a judge is impersonated by The Maniac, Accidental Death of an Anarchist. In addition to Dario Fo, another writer in this language wrote Six Characters in Search of an Author. Older writers in this language include the author of numerous sonnets for Laura and the author of a collection of stories told by nobles fleeing the black death. Name this language of Pirandello, Petrarch, and Bocaccio.

The last wild herd of bison in the United States was located in this park, where today they are hunted by grizzly bears and wolves reintroduced in the 1990s. This site that became America's first national park in 1872 is located north of the Grand Teton Range. Geothermal features like the Old Faithful geyser are found in what national park of northwestern Wyoming?

This former Florida congressman was recently chosen as Donald Trump's nominee for attorney general. He promptly resigned from the House of Representatives and eventually withdrew from the attorney general nomination process. The House ethics committee was set to release a report into his behavior, but voted not to release the report of this man's resignation from office. He was investigated for charges relating to sex trafficking and having sex with a minor. Name this avid supporter of President Elect Donald Trump.

Some of the earliest settlers of this modern day country landed at Port Jackson. Bushrangers were outlaws in this country who thrived during its gold rushes. The 1808 Rum Rebellion occurred in this country against William Bligh in New South Wales. Subjugation and persecution of Aboriginal people stemmed from this country's use as a penal colony by the British Empire. What country is home to Melbourne and Sydney?

A theorem named for Lagrange says that all integers can be written as the sum of this many perfect squares. All maps can be colored with this many colors without having any adjacent regions of the same color. An integer is divisible by this number if its last two digits are divisible by this number. This number is the number of faces of a tetrahedron. How many sides does a square have?

Title 2 of this law expanded the use of pen registers to Internet communication. Wisconsin's Russ Feingold was the only Senator who voted Nay on this bill, whose Title 4 permits indefinite detention of immigrants. It was passed in October 2001, shortly after the anthrax letters and 9/11 attacks. Name this controversial act whose name is an acronym for "Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism."

This band's gothic and melancholic sound, characterized by Robert Smith's distinctive vocals and jangly guitar riffs, earned them a devoted following in the 1980s alternative rock scene. Their 1989 album, Disintegration, featuring the hit song "Lovesong," is considered a masterpiece of gothic rock and cemented their status as a leading alternative band. Their early music, with its punk and post-punk influences, helped define the sound of the early 1980s. What is the name of this British band, known for their dark and introspective lyrics and their frontman's signature look of smeared lipstick and backcombed hair?

A palace in this country contains the Court of the Myrtles, and was built during the Nasrid Dynasty. In this country, an eighteen-spired cathedral combining Gothic and Art Nouveau styles has been under construction since 1882, and was designed by Antoni Gaudi. The Alhambra in Granada is within what European country, where the Sagrada Familia cathedral is being built in Barcelona?

This holiday's traditional feast often includes stuffing, a savory dish made with bread and herbs, which was not present at the first celebration in 1621. President George Washington designated November 26th as a day of public holiday in 1789. The holiday's modern date, the fourth Thursday in November, was established by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1939.  It is often associated with a historical narrative of Pilgrims and Native Americans sharing a harvest feast, though the accuracy of this depiction is debated.  What is this holiday, celebrated primarily in the United States and Canada?

This province is home to the city of Red Deer and Lesser Slave Lake. While the Great Slave Lake is not in this province, many of its southern tributaries are, such as the Slave River and the Hay River. Along its western boundary are the Jasper and Banff National Parks, which are along the Continental Divide. The 1988 Olympics, which were most famous for the debut of the Jamaican bobsled team, were held in its largest city of Calgary. Home to the largest oil sand deposit in Canada name this province whose capital is Edmonton.

This team's iconic "pinwheel" logo, introduced in 1970, symbolizes the dynamic movement and flow of the game of basketball. Their passionate fanbase, known as "Rip City," creates an electrifying atmosphere at their home arena, the Moda Center. They achieved their only NBA championship in 1977, led by Bill Walton, a dominant center and counterculture icon. Their legendary players, including Clyde Drexler and Damian Lillard, have solidified their place in franchise history. What is the name of this team, based in Portland, Oregon?

Along this river is the New Madrid Seismic Zone, which lies southwest of its namesake city in Missouri. Lake Itasca is the source of this river, whose delta is located in southeast Louisiana. This river, which runs through Memphis and St. Louis, has tributaries like the Arkansas and Ohio rivers, and the final city it passes through is New Orleans. Name this US river that flows from Minnesota down to the Gulf of Mexico.

This annual shopping extravaganza, often associated with chaotic crowds and deep discounts, has a disputed origin story, with some attributing the term to retailers using black ink to signify profits and red ink for losses.  It traditionally falls on the day after Thanksgiving in the United States, marking the unofficial start of the holiday shopping season.  In recent years, it has expanded into a multi-day event, with deals starting earlier and extending throughout the weekend.  What is this shopping frenzy, known for its doorbuster deals and competitive shoppers?

This science fiction series, known for its iconic tagline "The truth is out there," followed two FBI agents, Fox Mulder and Dana Scully, as they investigated paranormal phenomena and unexplained cases.  The show's eerie theme music, composed by Mark Snow, with its distinctive whistle and echo effects, became synonymous with the series and its mysterious atmosphere.  The series' mythology revolved around government conspiracies, alien encounters, and the search for extraterrestrial life.  What is the name of this popular 1990s series that spawned two feature films and a revival series?

After this man made his brother Joseph an unpopular King of Spain, he had to fight the Peninsular War. This man forced the Treaty of Pressburg, which gave this man large amounts of land from the Austrian Empire. This man beat the Third Coalition at the Battle of Austerlitz in 1805, two months after his navy lost at Trafalgar. Name this emperor whose French army was defeated at Waterloo.

In this battle, an attack by Ewell's troops forced Union soldiers onto a hill, but Longstreet attacked late, allowing them to entrench. Several days before this battle, Hooker resigned the command of the Army of the Potomac. During this battle, Culp's Hill was bombarded by the Union, Little Round Top was defended by a Union bayonet charge, and Meade's position on Cemetery Ridge could not be reached by Pickett's Charge. Name this battle, upon whose battlefield Abraham Lincoln would later give a namesake address.

This religious event killed the Nephilim, although Shem, Ham, and Japheth survived and were commanded to "be fruitful and multiply." Another survivor of this event received a covenant represented by a rainbow after he spent almost a year with fourteen of each clean animal and two of each unclean animal on an enormous ark. Name this biblical event in which God drowned everyone except a group of believers led by Noah.

This team's iconic mascot, Brownie the Elf, a mischievous elf with a penchant for pranks, was retired in the 1960s due to its perceived childishness.  Their classic brown and orange color scheme, a nod to the team's namesake and original owner, Paul Brown, has remained a symbol of the franchise throughout its history.  They have won eight NFL championships, four in the pre-Super Bowl era and four AAFC championships, but have yet to win a Super Bowl title. The team is known for its passionate and dedicated fanbase, often referred to as the "Dawg Pound."  What is the name of this team, whose history includes legendary running back Jim Brown and controversial quarterback Johnny Manziel?

This psychologist wrote of Aboriginal incest in Totem and Taboo, and described the "oceanic feeling" that inspires religion in Civilization and Its Discontents. He wrote about the "death instinct" in Beyond the Pleasure Principle, treated patients known as Rat Man and Little Hans for neurosis, and outlined the Oedipus complex in The Interpretation of Dreams. Name this Jewish Austrian who defined the id, ego, and superego and founded psychoanalysis.

A six-parameter "standard model" for the universe is named for lambda and the "cold" type of this substance. This substance doesn't interact with light or other electromagnetic radiation, making it impossible to observe directly.  Mass discrepancies in galaxy clusters, first observed in the 1930s, provided early evidence for its existence.  What is this mysterious substance that makes up about 27% of the universe, according to current cosmological models?

This structure's finial was originally made of gold and is topped by a crescent. Its four arch-shaped doorways are flanked by several vaulted archways, which can also be found on its chamfered edges, and four kiosks surround its main dome. In front of this structure sits a garden, which contains a reflecting pool, and the four corners of this structure each contain a minaret. Its main chamber contains false sarcophagi of its only two permanent residents, Mumtaz and Jahan. Identify this UNESCO world heritage site, a notable white marbled mausoleum in Agra, India.

This dystopian film, notorious for its graphic violence and disturbing scenes, features a protagonist who undergoes a controversial aversion therapy treatment, forcing him to watch violent images while strapped to a chair. The film's distinctive visual style, with its bold colors and use of wide-angle lenses, creates a surreal and unsettling atmosphere. The protagonist, Alex DeLarge, played by Malcolm McDowell, leads a gang of "droogs" who engage in acts of "ultra-violence" and speak in a stylized slang called Nadsat. What is the title of this 1971 film directed by Stanley Kubrick, based on the novel by Anthony Burgess?

This body of water is plagued with Karenia brevis, which caused a massive red algae bloom in August 2018. Ixtoc I, an underwater rig in this body of water's Bay of Campeche, blew out in 1979. Thirty-one years later, that disaster was surpassed at this gulf's Macondo Prospect, where the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded. The Yucatan Peninsula, Cuba, and Florida lie along the edge of what large gulf south of the United States?

These people were kicked out of England in 1290 due to Edward I's "Edict of Expulsion," and these people's readmission to Britain was debated at the Whitehall Conference convened by Oliver Cromwell, who supported this people's return. This people's return was also championed by Manasseh ben Israel, and Benjamin Disraeli later became the first of these people to become Prime Minister, although he had converted to Anglicanism. Name these people who worship in synagogues.

Israel and this organization recently agreed to a 60 day cease fire. This organization, whose name translates to "Party of God," has a militia force that rivals the Lebanese Army in strength and was a key player in the 2006 Lebanon War against Israel. It operates a television station, Al-Manar, which broadcasts its messages and propaganda. It was founded in 1982, during the Lebanese Civil War, with support from Iran. It has been designated a terrorist organization by several countries, including the United States and Canada. What is this Shia Islamist political party and militant group based in Lebanon?

This man served as Secretary of State during Thomas Jefferson's presidency. Along with John Jay and Alexander Hamilton, he penned the Federalist Papers . During the siege of Washington, the Lansdowne Portrait of Washington was saved by this man's wife, Dolley. His copious notes taken during the constitutional convention have given him the nickname "the father of the Constitution," and he was president during the War of 1812. Name this fourth U.S. President who preceded James Monroe and followed Thomas Jefferson.

This driver recently secured his fourth Formula One driver's champhionship. Known for his aggressive driving style and overtaking prowess, this driver the record for the most wins in a single Formula One season, achieving 15 victories in 2022. He became the youngest driver to compete in Formula One at the age of 17, making his debut with Toro Rosso in 2015. He is the son of former Formula One driver Jos Verstappen, who competed in the sport in the 1990s. He won his first Formula One World Championship in 2021 in a dramatic final race, overtaking Lewis Hamilton on the last lap. Who is this Belgian-Dutch driver, currently racing for Red Bull Racing?

The Patawomeck tribe helped Samuel Argall kidnap this woman; during her captivity, she was baptized and a possible husband, the chief Kocoum, was killed. After taking the name Rebecca, she was introduced to King James. She prevented her father, Powhatan, from killing an English settler by throwing herself over his body. A 1995 Disney movie was loosely based on this woman's life. Name this Native American, the wife of John Rolfe, who assisted John Smith's Jamestown colony.

Possessions of this nation include Franz Joseph Land and the disputed Kuril Islands, and this country's major cities include Kazan, Yekaterinburg, and Nizhny Novgorod. This country contains the tallest mountain in Europe, Mount Elbrus, and the deepest lake in the world, Baikal. The Ural Mountains divide Asia and Europe in this country. Name this country with capital at Moscow that is, by area, the largest in the world.

This author wrote of a language which lacks nouns in Tlon, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius. In another story, he wrote of a wizard who creates a young man with his dreams. This author of The Circular Ruins wrote of an almost infinite series of hexagonal rooms containing books of all possible information. Name this Argentine author who wrote of a point that contains the universe in El Aleph, in addition to including stories such as The Garden of Forking Paths and The Library of Babel in his collection Ficciones.

This animated sci-fi sitcom features a recurring character, Mr. Poopybutthole, a seemingly friendly yellow creature who often appears in post-credit scenes with nonsensical messages. The show's main characters, Rick Sanchez, a cynical and alcoholic scientist, and Morty Smith, his anxious and impressionable grandson, embark on bizarre and often dangerous adventures across the multiverse. What is the name of this Adult Swim series, known for its dark humor, philosophical themes, and pop culture references?

Whether these objects are one of two types is dependent on a ratio known as the Ginzburg-Landau parameter. One theory explaining these objects claims that they create condensed boson-like electron pairs known as Cooper pairs. Described in BCS theory, they exhibit the Meissner effect, as they lack an interior magnetic field. Identify these objects, which when cooled down to extremely low temperatures, have zero electrical resistance.

This nation recently passed a law which bans the use of social media for children under the age of 16. This country's parliament consists of two houses - the Senate and the House of Representatives - which meet in its capital, Canberra. Its legal system is based on common law, inherited from its British colonial past. The leader of its government is the Prime Minister, currently Anthony Albanese, of the Labor Party. What is this country, known for its unique wildlife, stunning beaches, and landmarks like the Sydney Opera House?

One hero of this nation converted to Christianity shortly after taking Kruje and waging a lifelong war against the Ottomans and was known as the "Dragon of" this country, while another leader of this nation fled after this nation was invaded by Italy in 1939. Yet another leader of this home of King Zog broke off relations with Communist China and built thousands of pillboxes on its border with Yugoslavia. Skanderberg is the national hero of what country that was ruled by communist dictator Enver Hoxha from the city of Tirane?

This hockey player has won three Stanley Cups with the Penguins, solidifying his status as one of the greatest players of his generation. Nicknamed "Sid the Kid," he led his team to a gold medal victory at the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, scoring the game-winning goal in overtime against the United States. He was drafted first overall by the Pittsburgh Penguins in the 2005 NHL Entry Draft, and has become the face of the franchise. Who is this Canadian hockey superstar, often considered one of the best to ever play the game?

This manager, knighted in 1999 for his services to football, holds the record for the most Premier League titles, with 13 wins to his name, all with the same club. He famously used a "hairdryer treatment" to motivate his players, delivering a passionate and intense scolding when necessary. He managed Aberdeen to a European Cup Winners' Cup victory in 1983, a rare feat for a Scottish team. He retired from management in 2013, after leading Manchester United to a 20th league title. Who is this legendary Scottish manager, known for his fiery personality and his unparalleled success with Manchester United?

This quantity is subtracted from a related quantity to find the Lagrangian; those quantities are added to find the Hamiltonian. One form of this quantity is proportional to the square of the displacement of a spring; that "elastic" type is given by one half k x squared, while the gravitational type is given by mgh. Denoted U name this energy a physical system has because of its configuration, contrasted with kinetic energy.

The Supreme Court ruled that this amendment applied to state governments in Mapp v. Ohio. This amendment specifically names "houses, papers, and effects" as under its protections, but a 1924 case ruled it did not apply to open fields. This amendment requires probable cause for a specifically-designated warrant to be issued. Name this Bill of Rights amendment that protects against unreasonable searches and seizures.
answers: fourth Amendment to the US Constitution

question: This nation recently chose Gintautas Paluckas as the prime minister. This country, the southernmost of the Baltic states, boasts the Hill of Crosses, a pilgrimage site adorned with thousands of crosses of various sizes and styles. It is the birthplace of former NBA player Arvydas Sabonis. Its capital, Vilnius, is known for its charming Old Town, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and its vibrant street art scene. It was the first Soviet republic to declare independence in 1990, paving the way for the dissolution of the Soviet Union. What is this country, bordered by Latvia, Belarus, and Poland?

This historical drama series, which boasts a meticulously crafted wardrobe with costumes inspired by actual royal attire, features a different cast every two seasons to portray the aging of the characters. It chronicles the life of Queen Elizabeth II, from her early days as a young monarch to her later years as a seasoned head of state. It has garnered critical acclaim for its performances, historical accuracy, and lavish production values. What is the name of this Netflix series, which offers a fictionalized yet insightful look into the personal and political life of the British monarch?

The Passaic River flows over a 77-foot waterfall in this state's city of Paterson. Coastal cities in this state include Cape May and the popular gambling destination of Atlantic City. Residents of this state's cities of Hoboken and Newark often commute to New York City across the Hudson River. Name this Eastern seaboard state sandwiched between New York and Pennsylvania.

Frank Gehry designed Beekman tower at 8 Spruce Street in this city. One building in this city has two lion statues named Patience and Fortitude and is in Bryant Park. An art-deco style building in this city has ornamentation resembling radiator caps and is the tallest brick building in the world. The Metropolitan Opera is at Lincoln Center is in this city where the Fearless Girl statue faces Charging Bull. The Chrysler Building and Wall Street are in what city?

This city, home to the iconic Tower Bridge, a Victorian-era bascule and suspension bridge, was founded by the Romans in 43 AD as Londinium. It served as the capital of the Roman province of Britannia and later became the heart of the British Empire. Its historic landmarks, including Buckingham Palace, the Houses of Parliament, and Westminster Abbey, have witnessed coronations, royal weddings, and state funerals. What is this city, a global financial center and a melting pot of cultures?

This team's iconic mascot, Mr. Redlegs, a mustachioed gentleman with a handlebar mustache and a pillbox hat, has been entertaining fans since 1955. Their home stadium, Great American Ball Park, features a unique smokestack that shoots fireworks after every home run. They were the first professional baseball team, founded in 1869. They have won five World Series titles, including back-to-back championships in 1975 and 1976 as part of the "Big Red Machine" dynasty. What is the name of this National League team, based in Cincinnati, Ohio?

President-elect Donald Trump recently selected Scott Bessent to serve in this Senate-confirmed role in his upcoming administration. This role is fifth in line to the presidency. The person in this role leads a department established in 1789. The first person to hold this role was Alexander Hamilton. The role serves as the principal advisor to the president of the United States on all matters pertaining to economic and fiscal policy. Name this presidential cabinet role currenly held by Janet Yellen which is the head of the U.S. Department of the Treasury.

These entities can be found by using the Sieve of Eratosthenes. According to Goldbach's conjecture, every integer greater than two can be expressed as a sum of two of them. Every positive integer can be expressed as a factorization of these numbers. Identify these natural numbers whose only divisors are themselves and one.

This island was home to the settlement of Brattahlid beginning in the 10th century. In 2005, an island now called "Warming Island" was found off the coast of this island. Off the west coast of this island are Davis Strait and Baffin Bay. Its largest cities are Sisimiut and Nuuk, and it is an autonomous country within Denmark. Name this huge island that lies between Iceland and Canada.

On character in this work recalls a parable that his mother told him about Mosquito and Ear. That character's wife had nine children die in infancy, which is attributed to an ogbanje by a medicine man. Later in this work, James Smith replaces the more tolerant Mr. Brown. The protagonist of this work is expelled from his village after his gun explodes, accidentally killing a boy. That character's adopted son is Ikemefuna. Okonkwo kills himself in the end of what novel, a work of Nigerian author Chinua Achebe?

This band's iconic 1991 debut album, Ten, featuring songs like "Alive" and "Jeremy," propelled them to stardom as leaders of the grunge movement. They famously boycotted Ticketmaster in the mid-1990s, protesting the company's service fees and perceived monopoly on concert ticket sales.  They have released eleven studio albums and continue to tour extensively, maintaining a dedicated fanbase known for their fervent energy and sing-alongs.  What is the name of this Seattle-based rock band, whose music has become synonymous with the grunge era and alternative rock?

In a book from this country, three men in a Peach Garden swear an oath they will die on the same day. A character in this country is forced to help Tripitaka reach India after launching an attack on the Heavenly Kingdom, the domain of the Jade Emperor. The Romance of the Three Kingdoms and Journey to the West are two of the Four Great Classics of what country whose poets commonly wrote about the Great Wall?

This man unsuccessfully led a fleet at the Battle of Valcour Island and was briefly relieved of command after suffering leg wounds at Bemis Heights. This man was en route to Philadelphia when the Battle of Ridgefield broke out, which led to his promotion to major general. His most famous action was triggered when he was passed over for a promotion by the Continental Congress and was accused of malfeasance by other officers. This man showed great heroism at Fort Ticonderoga with Ethan Allen and at the Battle of Saratoga. Name this traitor who attempted to sell West Point to the British during the Revolutionary War.

This prefix to applies maps between groups that preserve the group operation, and to parts of living things that evolved from a common ancestor. It begins the name of a process that prevents fat from rising to the top of milk; that word is related to mixtures with uniform composition. It is the Greek prefix meaning "same", and the opposite of "hetero". Give this word that is also the genus in which humans are found, in which context it is followed by "sapiens".

President-elect Donald Trump has proposed a 25% tariff on goods coming from Mexico and this nation. In response, this country's Prime Minister flew south to Mar a Lago to meet with Trump. This country boasts the world's longest coastline, stretching for 151,019 miles and bordering three oceans.  It is a constitutional monarchy, with King Charles III as its head of state, represented by the Governor-General.  What is this North American country, known for its vast wilderness, maple syrup, and friendly people?

This nation controls Mawson Peak, an active volcano on Heard Island near Antarctica. One feature off its coast stretches from Lady Elliot Island to the Torres Strait. This continent's Snowy Mountains contain its highest point, Mount Kosciuszko, and its east is split by the Great Dividing Range. This continent contains Ayers Rock, a massive rock formation called Uluru by the Aboriginal people. The Great Barrier Reef surrounds what island continent?

This man said "Aggression unopposed becomes a contagious disease" in a speech addressing concerns of Soviet interference in the Middle East. Jerry Brown led an "anyone but" this man campaign in a presidential primary. This president addressed a "crisis of confidence" in the "malaise" speech and mediated an agreement between Menachem Begin of Israel and Anwar al-Sadat of Egypt in the Camp David Accords. Name this Democratic president who lost to Ronald Reagan in 1980.

This iconic video game character, created by Shigeru Miyamoto, made his debut in the 1981 arcade game Donkey Kong under the name "Jumpman."  His signature red and blue outfit and his ability to grow larger by consuming a Super Mushroom have become instantly recognizable symbols of the gaming world.  He has appeared in over 200 video games including various sports and party games. Who is this beloved character, known for his adventures in the Mushroom Kingdom and his battles against Bowser to rescue Princess Peach?

This athlete's historic four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Olympics defied Hitler's propaganda of Aryan supremacy and made him a global symbol of athletic excellence and human resilience.  He achieved the remarkable feat of setting three world records and tying another in a single hour at the 1935 Big Ten track meet. His victories in the 100-meter and 200-meter dashes, along with the long jump and 4x100-meter relay, showcased his exceptional speed and athleticism.  Who was this legendary track and field star, whose accomplishments transcended sports and became a powerful statement against racial discrimination?

In 1942, this country raised war funds by carrying out "If Day," a simulated Nazi occupation. This country's four divisions of troops were supported by the British at the Battle of Vimy Ridge in World War I, and its Queen's Own Rifles landed on Juno Beach during the D-Day invasion. An eastern city in this country was obliterated by the 1917 explosion of the SS Mont Blanc. The Halifax explosion killed roughly two thousand people in what country's province of Nova Scotia?

One of this man's poems claims "The armies of those I love engirth me and I engirth them."One of his elegies remarks "The ship has weather'd every crack, the prize we sought is won." This author wrote in one of his poems " I loafe and invite my soul, I lean and loafe at my ease observing a spear of summer grass." This man asked "what is the soul?" in "I Sing the Body Electric." Name this American poet of "O Captain my Captain" and "Song of Myself," which appeared in his collection Leaves of Grass .

This empire arose when the Seljuk sultanate collapsed. It captured the capital of Hungary in 1526 during the Battle of Mohacs. This nation's expansion to Greece and the Balkan Peninsula was followed by the capture of Constantinople in 1453. Identify this empire which dissolved in the early 20th century because of the Young Turk revolution and its ill-fated alignment with Germany and Austria-Hungary.

The use of "spectral evidence" during this event was discussed in Cotton Mather's The Wonders of the Invisible World. For his refusal to plead during this event, Giles Corey was pressed to death with stones. The slave Tituba was the first to be targeted by this event following accusations made by Betty Parris and Abigail Williams. Magic practitioners were hunted in what series of trials in 17th century Massachusetts?

U.S. border agents recently seized 3,000 of these items that arrived into Southern California from Asia. The items, which were counterfeit, included signature models played by Dave Grohl and ones that appeared to be signed by Slash. The seizure is the largest collection of counterfeit musical instruments. The instruments' modern form, with six strings and a fretted neck, evolved from earlier instruments like the lute and the vihuela. The iconic "Flying V" shape of these instruments, pioneered by Gibson in the 1950s, became a symbol of rock and roll rebellion. Name this popular stringed instrument.

This classic fantasy film features a memorable duel of wits between the protagonist, Westley, and the villainous Vizzini, who engage in a battle of intellect while sipping from poisoned goblets.  The film's iconic line, "Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die," spoken by Mandy Patinkin's character, has become a beloved quote among fans.  The film's story is framed as a grandfather reading a book to his grandson, adding a heartwarming layer to the adventure.  What is the title of this 1987 film directed by Rob Reiner, known for its blend of humor, romance, and swashbuckling action?

This basketball legend's Oscar-winning short film, "Dear Basketball,"  was a heartfelt ode to the sport he loved. He famously scored 81 points against the Toronto Raptors in 2006, the second-highest single-game point total in NBA history. His "Black Mamba" nickname reflected his killer instinct and relentless pursuit of victory on the court. He spent his entire 20-season career with the Los Angeles Lakers, winning five NBA championships and becoming a global icon. Who is this basketball superstar, tragically killed in a helicopter crash in 2020?

One type of this geologic feature separates horsts and grabens from each other. Low dip angles can lead to stratigraphic position changes in the thrust variety of these. The strike-slip variety can move laterally, as in the New Madrid set of these in the US Midwest. Name these geologic features related to plate boundaries, including California's San Andreas, where energy buildup is released in the form of earthquakes.

One work by this author predicted the birth of a "miraculous child," and is sometimes called the Bucolics; another includes the passage "Praises of Italy" and concerns rural agriculture. Those works are the Eclogues and Georgics, and his most famous work is about a man who escapes with Anchises and Ascanius, opens, "of arms and the man I sing," and sees a man leave Troy to found Rome. Name this Roman poet of the Aeneid.

This city's downtown features the Angel's Flight incline and the Mexican neighborhood of Olvera Street. Notable neighborhoods in this city include Echo Park, Westwood, and Venice Beach, while the San Fernando Valley attempted to secede from this city. The Watts Riots happened in this city, which is also the home of Hollywood. Name this largest city in California.

The absence of these features can cause isostatic rebound. These features create paternoster lakes and parallel ones are responsible for aretes. These features also create kames, which often form with kettle lakes. These features often form from firn in cirques and their retreat creates eskers and drumlins and leaves moraine. Name these features that can be tidewater, alpine, or continental, slow-moving rivers of ice.

This animated sitcom's long-running gag, featuring a drawn-out fight scene between Peter Griffin and Ernie the Giant Chicken, often interrupts the show's narrative with absurd and over-the-top violence.  The show's creators, Seth MacFarlane, also voices several of the main characters, including Peter Griffin, Brian Griffin, and Stewie Griffin. The show's cutaway gags, often featuring non-sequitur jokes and pop culture references, have become a signature element of its humor. What is the name of this animated sitcom, known for its irreverent and often controversial humor?

This team has a historic rivalry with the Houston Astros, a matchup that often ignites passionate fan bases in the Lone Star State.  They made their first World Series appearance in 2010, falling to the San Francisco Giants, and then again in 2011, where they lost to the St. Louis Cardinals. They won their only World Series in 2023, defeating the Arizona Diamondbacks.  What is the name of this Major League Baseball team, based in Arlington, Texas?

The Cascada de Basaseachi is located in this country's Copper Canyon. The highest point in this country is the Pico de Orizaba, and the Chihuahuan desert is located on this country's northern border. Tourist locations in this country include Cabo San Lucas and Cancun, and the Yucatan peninsula borders this country's namesake gulf. Name this Latin American country that shares a border with Guatemala as well as the United States.

On November 27, 2024 rebel groups from this nation launched an offensive against government forces in the city of Aleppo. This was the first offensive in the nation's civil war since 2020. Its capital, Damascus, is considered one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world. It is also where the Umayyad Mosque, one of the largest and oldest mosques in the world, stands as a testament to the country's rich Islamic heritage. What is this nation, where rebels recently forced Bashar al-Assad to flee?

In the aftermath of this event, troops were forced to withdraw to Castle Island despite promises made by Thomas Hutchinson. John Adams claimed that "facts are stubborn things" while defending this event's perpetrators. Henry Pelham created a depiction of this event which was then copied and attributed to Paul Revere. Crispus Attucks was killed during the opening volley of this event. Name this 1770 event in which British soldiers opened fire on a crowd in Massachusetts.
answers: The Incident on the King Street

question: One leader of this modern-day country stressed educating women alongside men in his "Kastamonu Speech." That leader of this country also passed the Hat Law of 1925, which banned the fez in favor of Western-style headgear. This country claims parts of Northern Cyprus as its territory, and the Dardanelles divide this country's "European" and "Asian" regions. This country arose after the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire. Name this country whose capital is Ankara and whose largest city is Istanbul.

A tambourine in this work accompanies woodwinds in the folk song "U Vurot," or "At the Gate."Cellos play the hymn "God Save Thy People" at this work's beginning. Near the end of this piece, the French national anthem "La Marseillase" fades out as "God Save the Tsar" begins, punctuated by cannon fire and church bells. Name this piece that celebrates the defeat of Napoleon by Russian troops, a Pyotr Tchaikovsky overture.

Lisa Murkowski's 2015 proposal regarding this place was blocked in Congress by the Ohio delegation; Sally Jewell, the Secretary of the Interior, enacted that Athabascan-championed proposal just prior to a presidential visit focusing on climate concerns in the Arctic. After nearly one century of commemorating the twenty-fifth US president, it was renamed in 2015. Name this tallest mountain in North America, formerly known as Mount McKinley.

Scholars who worked during this dynasty include Sima Qian, who wrote the Records of the Grand Historian. This dynasty's embassies into Central Asia helped build the Silk Road, which brought it into contact with the Romans. The Yellow Turban Rebellion opposed this dynasty, whose collapse in 220 AD led to the Three Kingdoms period. Name this ancient Chinese dynasty whose name is shared by the majority ethnic group of China.

This soccer team won its first MLS Cup in 10 years with a victory over the New York Red Bulls. This Major League Soccer team, boasting a record six MLS Cup titles, plays its home games at Dignity Health Sports Park in Carson, California. They were one of the league's ten charter clubs, beginning play in 1996.  Their roster has featured international superstars like David Beckham and Zlatan Ibrahimović, drawing global attention to the league.  What is the name of this team, whose crest features a quasar?

The highest mountain in this range is Mount Mitchell. The Adirondacks of New York are surprisingly not part of this range. The trail named for this range runs near the Blue Ridge Parkway in Virginia and North Carolina. Name this mountain range, home to the "AT" in the eastern United States.

The founder of this novel's central town left Riohacha after killing Prudencio Aguilar and settled near a riverbank after a dream. A rainstorm lasting five years begins after the massacre of 3000 banana plantation workers in this novel. Amaranta Ursula dies after her baby is born with a pig's tail in this novel, in which Remedios the Beauty vanishes by floating up to heaven. Most men in this novel's central family are named after Aracadio or Aureliano. Name this magical realist novel about the Buendia family's life in Macondo, written by Gabriel Garcia Marquez.
incorrect1: Love in the Time of Cholera

question: H. pylori is a bacterium commonly found in this organ. This organ, which is the site of chief cells, also contains parietal cells that secrete intrinsic factor. Foveolar cells produce the mucus that lines the inner walls of this organ, which protect the tissue of this organ from hydrochloric acid. Located between the esophagus and the small intestine is what organ that digests food after it is chewed?

Following a controversial declaration of martial law on December 3rd, 2024, this nation has been plunged into turmoil. The president of this democracy, facing mounting public pressure and impeachment proceedings, invoked emergency powers in a late-night address. This unprecedented move sparked widespread protests, with tens of thousands taking to the streets across the country to denounce the government's actions. The declaration has since been overturned and the president survived an impeachment vote. What is the name of this country, which shares a border with North Korea and is known for its technological advancements?

This neo-noir science fiction film, set in a dystopian Los Angeles in 2019, features a visually stunning cityscape with towering skyscrapers and neon-lit advertisements, creating a futuristic yet decaying atmosphere. The film's protagonist, Rick Deckard, played by Harrison Ford, is tasked with hunting down and "retiring" rogue replicants, bioengineered beings virtually indistinguishable from humans. The film's philosophical exploration of what it means to be human and the ethical implications of artificial intelligence has sparked countless discussions and debates. What is the title of this 1982 film directed by Ridley Scott?

This national park includes the brilliant blue-green Havasu Falls on the Supai Reservation. The Precambrian Vishnu Complex outcrops at the lowest point of this national park. Phantom Ranch provides accommodations for hikers on this park's Bright Angel Trail, which descends from its South Rim Visitor Center. Its main feature is over a mile deep and up to eighteen miles wide. Name this national park in Arizona where the Colorado River eroded the namesake steep-walled feature.

The CEO of this company,  Brian Thompson, was murdered in midtown Manhattan on the morning of a shareholder meeting. This company, the largest health insurance provider in the United States by revenue, serves over 130 million members through its diverse range of plans and services. It was founded in 1977 as Charter Med Incorporated, a health maintenance organization in Minnesota. It is a Fortune 500 company and a major player in the healthcare industry, offering employer-sponsored health plans, Medicare and Medicaid plans, and individual health insurance. What is the name of this company, headquartered in Minnetonka, Minnesota?

This Greek goddess is commonly associated with owls and olive trees. This goddess was said to have been born from the brain of Zeus. After winning a competition with Poseidon, a major Greek city-state was named after her. Name this Greek goddess of wisdom and justice.

This theory originated as an offshoot of Ernst Mayr's concept of genetic revolutions by speciation, but was greatly expanded by the author of a 1971 paper citing fossil records of trilobites, Niles Eldredge, as well as Stephen Jay Gould. It opposes the "phylectic" type of another idea and explains the lack of transitional forms in fossil records. Stating that most sexually reproducing species experience little change for most of their history and that their evolution occurs in short, rapid spurts is what evolutionary theory often contrasted with phylectic gradualism?

The Silla dynasty ruled in this country where Sejon the Great was an early ruler of the Choson Dynasty. A foreign invasion of it by Toyotomi Hideyoshi lost at the battle of Noryang with the help of this country's turtle ships. One war in this country featured a landing by Douglas Macarthur at Inchon, which led to its 38th-parallel demilitarized zone. Name this peninsula split into a northern half ruled by Kim Jong Un and a southern half with capital Seoul.

The book And the Band Played On criticized this president's lack of a response to the HIV/AIDS epidemic, which first became widespread during his administration. This man's administration illegally sold arms to Iran to fund Nicaraguan rebels in the Iran-Contra affair. "Trickle-down economics" was popularized by what Republican president who served through the 1980s?

This science fiction franchise features a diverse crew aboard the starship USS Enterprise, exploring strange new worlds and seeking out new life and civilizations. Its creator, Gene Roddenberry, envisioned a utopian future where humanity has overcome its differences. Iconic characters include Captain James T. Kirk, Spock, and Dr. McCoy. The franchise has expanded to include multiple television series and films. What is the name of this enduring franchise?

This baseball player, known for his exceptional plate discipline and ability to draw walks, led the major leagues in walks in both 2021 and 2022, showcasing his patient approach at the plate. He burst onto the scene as a teenager with the Washington Nationals, helping them win the World Series in 2019. He was traded to the San Diego Padres in 2022, and then played for the New York Yankees in the 2024 World Series. Name this outfielder who recently agreed to the largest contract in MLB History with the New York Mets.

Michel Barnier, the prime minister of this nation recently lost a no confidence vote leading to his resignation. This country's current president, leader of the centrist La République En Marche! party, won re-election in 2022, defeating his far-right rival Marine Le Pen. Its political system is a semi-presidential republic, with a dual executive consisting of the President as head of state and the Prime Minister as head of government. The current president of this country is Emmanuel Macron. What is this European nation, known for its rich history, culture, and political influence on the world stage?

This professional sports league, founded in 1996 as a counterpart to the NBA, tipped off its inaugural season in 1997 with eight teams and has since expanded to 13 franchises across the United States. The league's inaugural championship was won by the Houston Comets, led by Sheryl Swoopes, a dominant force in women's basketball. The league most recently added an expansion team in San Francisco called the Golden State Valkyries. What is the name of this league, which showcases the athleticism and talent of female basketball players?

This man allegedly invented a parabolic mirror that he used as a heat ray to burn ships attacking his city. Another invention of his uses a spiral blade inside of a cylinder to efficiently raise water and is called his namesake "screw." While taking a bath, this mathematician discovered the method of water displacement to measure volume and shouted "I have found it!" in Greek. Name this Ancient Greek scholar from Syracuse who exclaimed "Eureka!"

In a Shakespeare play, a pair of gravediggers agree that a women who died in this manner would have been buried outside the graveyard if she hadn't been a noblewoman. Laertes "forbids" his tears after learning that his sister has died this way in Hamlet. Ophelia falls from a willow tree before dying in what way, when she cannot get out of a "weeping brook?"
answers: throwing herself or jumping into Cabed-en-Aras

question: A Tatar assassin tried to kill this leader's youngest son, but was stopped by Altani, a woman whom this man honored as a bataar. This man's original successor, Jochi, led the Golden Horde before he was possibly poisoned, and his son Ogedei defeated the Jin Dynasty. This man's grandson founded the Yuan Dynasty, which expanded his empire south into China. Name this founder of the Mongol Empire and ancestor of Kublai Khan.

In this city, Danforth and Bloor Streets are connected by the Prince Edward Viaduct. This city's City Hall overlooks Nathan Phillips Square, its country's largest city square. In 2009, this city's CN Tower lost its title as tallest tower in the world. This city, often nicknamed "the Six," lies on the northwest shore of a Great Lake named for its Canadian province. Name this most populous city in Ontario and all of Canada.

This band's iconic album London Calling, released in 1979, featured a diverse range of musical styles, from punk and reggae to ska and rockabilly, showcasing their eclectic influences. The album's cover, a tribute to Elvis Presley's debut album, depicts bassist Paul Simonon smashing his Fender Precision Bass onstage. Their hit song "Rock the Casbah" became an anthem of anti-establishment sentiment, even gaining popularity in the Middle East despite its criticism of authoritarian regimes. What is the name of this influential British punk rock band?

Along with John Jay and Alexander Hamilton, this man wrote the Federalist Papers. Since he drafted it, this man is called the "Father of the Constitution." Name this fourth U.S. president, who fled the White House with his wife Dolly during the War of 1812.

This basketball player, known for his exceptional passing skills and court vision, became the first center since Wilt Chamberlain to lead the NBA in assists, achieving this feat in the 2020-21 season.  He was drafted in the second round of the 2014 NBA draft, a surprisingly low selection for a player who would become a three-time NBA MVP.  He led the Denver Nuggets to their first NBA championship in 2023, earning the Finals MVP award.  Who is this Serbian center, nicknamed "The Joker" for his playful demeanor and deceptive skills on the court?

In a book about this event, Eliahou is abandoned by his son while on a long march in the snow, and the protagonist and his father are told to say they are eighteen and forty years old after being separated from Tziporah, Hilda, and Bea. Moshe the Beadle's warning about this event is ignored in the first section of a 1960 book by a survivor of this event. Name this historical event that provides the backdrop for Elie Wiesel's Night, which describes atrocities committed in the Buchenwald and Auschwitz concentration camps?

Two decades after this ruler's death, a pair of his followers named Lysimachus and Antigonus fought each other at the Battle of Ipsus. This man won the Battle of Issus over Darius III of Persia in 333 BCE, ten years before he died in Babylon. This son of Philip II never lost a battle. Name this ruler of Macedon whose empire, stretching from Greece to India, was one of the largest empires of the ancient world.

In 1990, this city's Isabella Stewart Gardner museum was robbed of over $500 million worth of art. This city's downtown area is home to a Freedom Trail, where tourists can visit Dorchester Heights, Faneuil Hall, and the Old North Church. Colleges in and around this city include Emerson College downtown and, across the Charles River in Cambridge, MIT, and Harvard. Logan International Airport serves what capital city of Massachusetts?

This token recently hit a valution of $100,000 for the first time in its history. This digital currency, created in 2009 by the pseudonymous Satoshi Nakamoto, experienced a dramatic surge in value in 2021, reaching an all-time high of over $68,000 per coin. It operates on a decentralized technology known as blockchain, which allows for secure and transparent transactions without intermediaries. It has been embraced by some investors as a "digital gold," a hedge against inflation and economic uncertainty. However, its volatility and association with illicit activities have also drawn criticism. What is this cryptocurrency, the first and most well-known of its kind?

The outer portion of this organ contains layers named for Descemet and Bowman, and may contain Dua's Layer. Tay-Sachs disease causes a "cherry red spot" in a part of this organ. The fovea of this organ contains almost no rod cells, which are more plentiful outside this organ's macula. A ring of colored muscle in this organ, the iris, allows light to pass through the lens to the retina. Name this organ that passes information to the optic nerve to allow a person to see.

This river receives the Green River in Canyonlands National Park before flowing downstream into Lake Powell. Low water levels in Lake Mead, which this river flows through, have raised concern of a "dead pool" when this river will not be able to flow through Hoover Dam. This river forms the border between California and Arizona. The Grand Canyon was carved by what river named for a Rocky Mountain state?

This comedy series has garnered critical acclaim for its heartwarming tone, positive message, and exploration of themes like teamwork, resilience, and mental health. The show's protagonist, played by Jason Sudeikis, is known for his optimistic demeanor, folksy wisdom, and homemade shortbread cookies.  It follows an American football coach hired to manage a struggling English Premier League soccer team, AFC Richmond, despite having no experience with the sport. What is the name of this Emmy Award-winning Apple TV+ series?

This golfer, known for his calm demeanor and consistent play, achieved a remarkable feat in 2022 by winning four PGA Tour events in a span of six starts, including his first major championship at the Masters Tournament. He reached the number one spot in the Official World Golf Ranking in March 2022, a position he held for 30 consecutive weeks. He is recognizable for his distinctive swing and his habit of constantly chewing gum during rounds. Who is this American golfer, who made headlines this year for a brief arrest at the PGA Championship?

In the Michel decay, a muon decays into a neutrino, anti-neutrino, and this particle. These particles were fired at nickel in the Davisson-Germer experiment to demonstrate their wave nature. Its charge was measured by balancing an electric field against gravity in the Millikan oil-drop experiment, and it was discovered in cathode ray tubes by J.J. Thomson. Name this lepton whose antiparticle is the positron, a negatively-charged particle that exists in probabilistic namesake "clouds" outside atomic nuclei.

This ruler responded to the Kronstadt rebellion by taxing farmers instead of requisitioning their crops in his New Economic Policy. He wrote the April Theses on a train from Switzerland as he returned from exile in 1917, after Alexander Kerensky's provisional government was forced out by this man's Bolshevik forces. Name this leader in the Russian Revolution, the first premier of the Soviet Union, preceding Joseph Stalin.

This artist depicted himself sitting at a mirror and an easel and creating a sketch of himself with his right hand in his Triple Self-Portrait. This man also showed four U.S. Marshals accompanying Ruby Bridges to school in The Problem We All Live With. In one series he depicted two parents tucking their red-headed children into bed, a man in a tattered jacket rising to speak, and a woman placing a Thanksgiving turkey on a table. Name this artist of the Four Freedoms series, most famous for his works for the cover of the Saturday Evening Post .

Its tributaries include the Drava River in Croatia and the Tisza River in Serbia, the latter of which forms the border of Hungary and Slovakia. Flowing through ten nations before emptying into the Black Sea between Romania and Ukraine, this 1,771 mile long river passes through four European capitals, including Bratislava, Belgrade and Budapest. Originating near the town of Donaueschingen in the Black Forest of Germany identify this river that also flows through Vienna, Europe's second longest river.

As Governor of Virginia, this man was to be kidnapped by Gabriel Prosser's slave revolt. He took a hands-off approach to both the Missouri Compromise and the Panic of 1819, and his cordial approach to bipartisanship led to the "Era of Good Feelings," in which he ran unopposed for re-election. Name this U.S. President who stated that European intervention in the Western Hemisphere would be considered aggression against the U.S. in his namesake Doctrine.

A center-right party, Fianna Fáil, emerged with the most seats in this country's Parliament -- called the Dáil -- after its recent election. Fianna Fáil was founded by Eamon de Valera in 1926, five years after this country gained independence from England. Fianna Fáil leader Michéal Martin is the frontrunner to become this country's next Prime Minister -- known as a Taoiseach. Name this country, known for its green landscapes, rich literary and musical tradition, and Celtic culture.

This video game franchise, which debuted in 1986 with a gold cartridge for the NES, features a recurring protagonist named Link. Its iconic music, including the "Main Theme" and the "Lost Woods" theme, has become instantly recognizable to gamers worldwide.  The franchise's games are known for their exploration-based gameplay, intricate dungeons, and challenging puzzles.  What is the name of this popular Nintendo franchise featuing the Princess Zelda, which has spawned numerous sequels, spin-offs, and adaptations?

In one military campaign undertaken by this empire, the general Narses defeated and killed the Ostrogoth king Totila at the battle of Busta Gallorum. Under the rule of an emperor of this empire, the Vandals were conquered by the general Belisarius. This empire's capital featured the magnificent church the Hagia Sophia, which was turned into a mosque following the conquest of this empire in 1453. Name this empire ruled by men such as Justinian the Great from its capital at Constantinople.

It's not in Arizona, but this national park has its own "Grand Canyon" on a river with namesake waterfalls. Megafauna such as bison and elk can be found in this park that is three times larger than the state of Rhode Island. This park lies in Idaho, Montana, and Wyoming, and is noted for its geothermal features and the super volcano reportedly that lies underneath it. Name this National Park, founded in 1872, that contains "Old Faithful."

This basketball player, known for his crafty ball-handling and clutch scoring ability, led Villanova University to two NCAA championships in three years, earning the Most Outstanding Player award in the 2016 tournament.  He was drafted 33rd overall by the Dallas Mavericks in 2018, where he played alongside Luka Dončić and developed into a key contributor.  In 2022, he signed with the New York Knicks, becoming their starting point guard and leading them to their first playoff series win since 2013.  Who is this rising star in the NBA, known for his steady play and leadership on the court?

This composer wrote a tone poem inspired by a visit to Havana, his Cuban Overture. Another of this man's pieces begins with a clarinet glissando. "It Ain't Necessarily So" and "Summertime" are numbers from this composer's opera set in Catfish Row, Porgy and Bess. Identify this brother of Ira and composer of An American in Paris and Rhapsody in Blue.

George W. Harkins wrote a "Farewell Letter to the American People" before this event, in which the provisions of the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek were carried out. The Dade Massacre was part of a decade long war by the Seminoles to avoid this event, and the Supreme Court ruled that the Cherokee People would be forced into this journey as well. Spanning from the South to Oklahoma name this forcible relocation of Native Americans during the 1830s.

The US Department of Agriculture recently ordered the testing of milk for this virus. This influenza virus, which caused a global outbreak in 2022 and 2023, has a particularly high mortality rate in poultry, leading to the culling of millions of birds to contain its spread.  The virus is highly contagious among birds and can also infect humans, though human-to-human transmission is rare.  Symptoms in humans include fever, cough, sore throat, and muscle aches.  While there is no specific treatment for the virus, antiviral medications can help reduce the severity of the illness.  What is this virus, which poses a significant threat to both animal and human health?

This psychological horror film, featuring the iconic line "Here's Johnny!", showcases a chilling scene where blood pours out of an elevator, symbolizing the hotel's dark history and the protagonist's descent into madness.  The film's use of Steadicam shots creates a sense of unease and allows the audience to experience the hotel's vast and eerie corridors alongside the characters.  Jack Nicholson delivers a captivating performance as Jack Torrance, a writer who becomes the winter caretaker at the isolated Overlook Hotel, where supernatural forces prey on his sanity.  What is the title of this 1980 Stanley Kubrick masterpiece, based on the Stephen King novel?

Richard Dawkins described an "extended" form of this term, which becomes blended in incomplete dominance. The human skin color one is controlled by three genes, and crossing two heterozygous individuals usually results in a 3-to-1 ratio of this. In Mendel's pea plants, these included dwarf, yellow, and wrinkled. Name this term for an organism's physical traits that are determined by its genotype.

A senator from this state proposed the High Performance Computing Act of 1991. A violation of the Butler Act in this state was argued in court by Clarence Darrow and Williams Jennings Bryan, and focused on a man who claimed to have taught evolution in a public school in Dayton, John Scopes. Al Gore has represented what state whose cities include Memphis and Nashville?

This Slovenian basketball prodigy, known for his incredible court vision and scoring ability, became the youngest EuroLeague MVP in history at the age of 19, leading Real Madrid to a championship title. He was drafted third overall by the Atlanta Hawks in the 2018 NBA draft but was immediately traded to the Dallas Mavericks. He has quickly become one of the NBA's most exciting players, known for his step-back three-pointers and dazzling passes. Who is this young superstar, who has already earned five All-NBA First Team selections?

This mockumentary comedy, featuring a scene where the band struggles to navigate a labyrinthine backstage area, hilariously captures the eccentricities and excesses of the rock and roll lifestyle.  The film's amplifiers, which "go to eleven," have become a symbol of the band's comical pursuit of volume and excess. The film's fictional band, Spinal Tap, is known for their over-the-top stage shows, absurd song lyrics, and Spinal Tap's cluelessly arrogant lead singer, David St. Hubbins. What is the title of this 1984 cult classic directed by Rob Reiner, which has become a beloved satire of the music industry?

This social media platform has seen a surge of users since the election of Donald Trump in 2024. The decentralized social media platform aims to provide an alternative to centralized platforms like Twitter, offering users greater control over their data and interactions. It is built on the AT Protocol, an open-source framework that allows for interoperability between different social networks.  It was initially funded by Twitter, with Jack Dorsey serving on its board of directors. Name this Twitter/X alternative.

Cities on this body of water include Le Havre, Calais, Brighton, and Dover, whose sheer white cliffs sit on the shoreline of this body of water. In 1994, a Eurostar train tunnel underneath this body of water was opened. The islands of Jersey, Guernsey, and the Isle of Wight lie in what channel that separates France from the island of Britain?

One of the many tangents of the discussions in this philosophical work is the order in which people should learn various geometry concepts. Its first five books involve a series of discussions about justice, starting out with what makes an individual just, and eventually what makes a city-state just, which eventually leads to the concept of the philosopher-king. In book seven, the example of people finally realizing that shadows are being cast by real objects is a portion of the introduction of the theory of forms in the allegory of the cave. Name this work by Plato which also discusses the ideals of many forms of government.

One composer from this country ended a suite with a "cloudburst" movement and used trumpets to mimic the sound of crickets. Another composer from this country wrote a piece "for any instrument or combination of instruments" instructing the performer to sit silently for the title Four Minutes, Thirty-Three Seconds. Another composer from this country, Charles Ives, wrote the "Concord Sonata" as well as the "Three Places in New England" suite. Name this country home to the minimalist composer John Cage, as well as Star Wars composer John Williams.

The NASA Juno reached this body in 2016, where it observes the body's magnetic field and gravitational field. Its closest Galilean satellite is partially molten because of tidal forces, and is called Io. This planet contains cyclones called the Little and Great Red Spots. Name this gas giant, the largest planet in the solar system.

This film's innovative dolly zoom, a camera technique that disorients the viewer, was used to visually convey the protagonist's acrophobia.  The film's score, composed by Bernard Herrmann, features haunting and romantic themes that heighten the suspense and melodrama.  The film's plot revolves around a retired detective, Scottie Ferguson, who becomes obsessed with a mysterious woman named Madeleine Elster.  What is the title of this 1958 psychological thriller directed by Alfred Hitchcock?

Ludwig Wittgenstein's example of this phenomenon was a duck-rabbit. Some of these phenomena caused by lateral neural inhibition include the Hermann grid, which consists of white gridlines, black squares, and apparent grey dots at the intersections of the grids. Another example, the Rubin vase, can appear as the silhouette of two faces. Name this type of image that deceives the brain into perceiving something that is not there.

This artist depicted a skyscraper at night in Radiator Building, but her later work focuses on natural images, including a series of jack-in-the-pulpits. After the death of her husband, Alfred Stieglitz, this artist moved to New Mexico, where she painted Cow's Skull: Red, White, and Blue. Name this American artist known for depicting close-ups of flowers and bones.

Part of an annual race in this state follows the path of a 1925 diphtheria serum run to its city of Nome. A large species of brown bear is endemic to this state's Kodiak Island. This state's Seward Peninsula contains the finish line of the annual Iditarod sled dog race, which previously began in Anchorage. This is the largest state in the U.S. Name this non-contiguous state with its capital at Juneau.

Luigi Mangione, the suspected shooter of the UnitedHealthcare CEO in Manhattan, was arrested at a McDonald's in this state. He was found in the city of Altoona after being identified by a civilian. This state is home to the highest point in the eastern United States east of the Mississippi River, Mount Davis, which peaks at 3,213 feet above sea level. The Susquehanna River, the longest river on the American East Coast, flows through the state, providing a vital waterway for transportation and recreation. Name this "Keystone State" that is bordered by New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, West Virginia, and Ohio.

This man championed a domestic program termed the "Square Deal." This president won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the Treaty of Portsmouth, which ended the Russo-Japanese War. This president's administration saw the passage of the Pure Food and Drug Act and the creation of the National Park System. He ran for a third term with the Bull Moose Party. Name this 26th President of the United States, the supposed namesake of a toy bear.

This war names a syndrome whose symptoms included cramps, headaches, and short-term memory loss. General Norman Schwarzkopf helped launch this war, which was sparked over allegations of illegal use of the Rumaila oil fields. The 1st Armored Division's destruction during this war led to a road becoming known as the "Highway of Death." Name this war that included the American-led Operation Desert Storm against Saddam Hussein and Iraq.

This country will be the first from the Middle East to host the FIFA Women's World Cup in 2026, and will again make history by hosting the men's tournament in 2034.  Known for its vast deserts and the holy city of Mecca, it has invested heavily in sports infrastructure and tourism in recent years.  The country's bid was unopposed, reflecting its growing influence in the world of sports.  What is this nation, the largest in the Arabian Peninsula?

Ions of this element complex with cyanide to form Prussian blue. This element's sulfide is a cubic crystal often mistaken for gold. The Bessemer process alloys this element with carbon, and its oxide is found in the magnetic mineral magnetite. This element is found in pyrite and its ions are called either ferric or ferrous. Name this metal found in steel.

Many retailers in this city accept the Octopus cards needed to access its Mass Transit Railway. The densest housing settlement ever constructed was a now-destroyed "walled city" on this city's Kowloon Peninsula. This city on the Pearl River forms a megalopolis with Guangzhou and Macau. Name this Special Administrative Region, which Great Britain ceded to China in 1997.

In this modern-day country, the seventh of an ancient city's nine layers shows scorch marks consistent with a foreign siege. The neolithic cities of Catalhoyuk and Gobekli Tepe are located in this country, where Heinrich Schliemann excavated the site of ancient Troy. This country was home to the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire. Name this modern-day country once called "Asia Minor," where the Hittites complained about people from Constantinople.

This president engaged in the Kitchen Debates with Nikita Kruschev. After coming under fire for a suspicious campaign donation, this president emotionally invoked his dog in the Checkers Speech.
