Illinois shares the "Quad Cities" with what Midwestern state, the southern neighbor of Minnesota, whose capital is Des Moines?

After he was freed, this man studied at the Hampton Institute and the Wayland Seminary before ascending to his most well-known position. He was assisted by Henry Rogers of Standard Oil, who funded schools in the south, although this man garnered criticism from the NAACP and W.E.B. DuBois over his ideas of integrating African-Americans into society. Name this African-American who delivered the Atlanta Address and who founded the Tuskegee Institute.

This coach, known for his unconventional methods and interest in Eastern philosophy, earned the nickname "Zen Master" and holds the record for the most NBA championships with 11 titles. He led the Chicago Bulls to six championships in the 1990s, utilizing the triangle offense with Michael Jordan. He later guided the Los Angeles Lakers to five championships with Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant. Who is this legendary coach, known for his calm demeanor and ability to manage star-studded teams?

Starting with the 119th Congress, this politician now serves as US Senate majority leader. He began his career as an elected representative by winning his state's lone seat in the House of Representatives in 1996. He joined the Senate in 2005 representing his home state of South Dakota. Name this politician who served as the Whip for the Republican party in the Senate from 2019 to 2024 and is succeeding Mitch McConnell as leader of the Republicans in the Senate.

This quantity can be computed by taking the reciprocal of the apparent movement of an object in arcseconds. Recessional velocity is proportional to this quantity, according to Hubble's law. This quantity can be measured by observing the parallax of an object. The force between two astronomical bodies is proportional to the inverse square of this quantity. Name this quantity, which is measured in parsecs or kilometers.

This satirical black comedy features the iconic line "I'm as mad as hell, and I'm not going to take this anymore!", delivered by a news anchor who has a mental breakdown on live television.  The film's biting critique of the television industry and its exploitation of sensationalism earned it four Academy Awards, including Best Actress for Faye Dunaway's portrayal of a ruthless programming executive.  The film's protagonist, Howard Beale, becomes a messianic figure, urging viewers to express their outrage and reclaim their power.  What is the title of this 1976 film directed by Sidney Lumet?

This person's love of sweets gave her black teeth, which caused a fashion in which other women painted their teeth black to mimic her. Her spymaster, Francis Walsingham, detected and stopped numerous attempts on her life, including the Babington Plot. The aftermath of that plot, gave this person the opportunity to execute the main rival to her throne, Mary Queen of Scots. Sir Francis Drake and others helped her to defeat the Spanish Armada. Name this Queen of England who lead her nation into a golden age and maritime supremacy.

The ninety-sixth section of this work invokes the reader to "recite" in the name of the lord "who created man from a mere clot of blood." Mukham and mutashabeh are classifications of ayat that appear in this work, which includes basmalah in all but its ninth chapter. Those chapters are called sura, and were first delivered on Mount Hira by Jibreel. Name this Islamic religious text that was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad.

The wartime presidential election of this year featured the formation of The Texas Regulars, a political party designed to deny the incumbent President a majority of the Electoral College. Norman Thomas and Claude Watson were the candidates of the Socialist and Prohibition parties, while Robert Taft supported John Bricker for the Republican nomination, but Bricker later only served as the vice presidential candidate. Identify this election in which Republican Thomas Dewey lost to incumbent Franklin Roosevelt, who was running for his fourth and final term.

A rice dish and macaroni salad are included in this state's "plate lunch". The canned pork product Spam is extremely popular in this state, which also originated a raw fish dish called poke and a food derived from the taro plant called poi. This state's traditional food might be consumed at a luau, which might be attended by hula dancers. Name this state consisting of an archipelago in the Pacific Ocean.

In this novel, Catherine spreads a rumor that a rich bootlegger is Kaiser Wilhelm's cousin, and falsely claims that the narrator's cousin is Catholic to explain why Tom can't get divorced. In this novel, a new dog leash convinces George Wilson that Myrtle's affair led to her death, so he shoots this novel's protagonist in his pool. Daisy Buchanan runs over her husband's mistress in what novel narrated by Nick Carraway and written by F. Scott Fitzgerald?

This manager, known for his passionate and fiery personality, led the Los Angeles Dodgers to two World Series titles, in 1981 and 1988. He famously proclaimed, "I bleed Dodger blue," showcasing his unwavering loyalty to the team. He managed the Dodgers for 20 seasons, the second-longest tenure in franchise history. He also managed the United States Olympic baseball team to a gold medal at the 2000 Sydney Olympics. Who is this legendary manager, known for his animated personality and his love for the Dodgers?

This singer-songwriter's controversial performance at the 1965 Newport Folk Festival, where he plugged in an electric guitar and departed from his acoustic folk roots, marked a turning point in his career and sparked a debate about the evolution of folk music.  His 1965 hit song "Like a Rolling Stone" became an anthem of rebellion and social change, with its poetic lyrics and driving rhythm.  He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2016, "for having created new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition." Name this iconic musician who is the subject of a recent movie starring Timothée Chalamet.

During one of these events, Louis IX was captured at the Battle of Al Mansurah. Frederick Barbarossa drowned during one of these events, in which Saladin attacked Richard the Lionhearted at the Battle of Arsuf. The first of these events was called for by Pope Urban II and led to the capture of Jerusalem. Name these attempts by the Europeans to recapture the Holy Land.

The area of a segment of one of these objects is two thirds times the base times the height. This object is formed by the intersection of a cone and a plane parallel to its slant surface. This object can be defined as the set of points equidistant from a focus and a directrix. These objects can be formed by the graphs of quadratic functions. Name these objects expressed by the formula y equals x squared.

President Joe Biden recently blocked a merger of this company with the Japanese company Nippon Steel. This company, the world's the first billion-dollar corporation, was founded in 1901 by J.P. Morgan through a merger of several steel and iron companies, including Carnegie Steel Company.  Its headquarters in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, was one of the tallest buildings in the United States when it was completed in 1970. What is the name of this American steel producer, which has faced challenges in recent decades from global competition and shifting economic trends?

A terrorist attack where a man drove a truck into a large crowd occurred on the morning of January 1 in this US city. This city's iconic streetcars, including the St. Charles Avenue line, the oldest continuously operating streetcar line in the world, offer a charming way to explore its historic neighborhoods. Its vibrant music scene, with roots in jazz, blues, and Cajun traditions, fills the streets with lively rhythms and soulful melodies. Its unique cuisine, featuring dishes like gumbo, jambalaya, and beignets, reflects its diverse cultural influences. What is this city, known as the "Crescent City" for its location on a bend in the Mississippi River, which hosts the annual Mardi Gras celebration?

This manager, known for his fiery temper and record-setting 161 ejections throughout his career, led the Atlanta Braves to an unprecedented 14 consecutive division titles from 1991 to 2005. He managed the Toronto Blue Jays and Atlanta Braves, winning a World Series title with the Braves in 1995. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 2011, alongside fellow Braves legends Greg Maddux and Tom Glavine. Who is this legendary manager, also known for his signature toothpick chewing habit?

This book is dedicated to a taxi driver and the woman who gave the story its subtitle. In one scene from this book, a character obtains a pair of silver boots after a production of Cinderella, and that man later lives in a zoo with Montana Wildhack after being abducted by Tralfamadorians. Throughout this novel, a bird cries "Poo-tee-weet" and deaths are followed by the comment "so it goes." Identify this Kurt Vonnegut novel about Billy Pilgrim and the bombing of Dresden.
answers: The Children's Crusade: A Duty-Dance with Death
incorrect3: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest

question: During this war, Andrew Gould was stabbed with a pen-knife by Nathan Bedford Forrest, who he shot in the hip. In a battle in this war, Daniel Ruggles fired 50 cannons into the "Hornet's Nest." The victors of a battle in this war were reinforced on its second day by Carlos Buell. P. G. T. Beauregard took control of an army in this war after Albert Sidney Johnston's death at Shiloh. Name this war, in which the Confederacy seceded from the Union in 1861.

The sum of the infinite sequence whose terms are the reciprocals of these numbers equals pi squared over 6. The sum of the first n of these is n times n+1 times 2n+1 over 6, while the sum of the first n positive odd numbers is the nth of these. The difference between two of these numbers can be factored as a+b times a-b. Name these numbers equal to the an integer times itself.

This actress's 1996 film, "Striptease," though a critical flop, earned her a then-record-breaking $12.5 million salary, making her the highest-paid actress in Hollywood history at the time.  She appeared on the cover of Vanity Fair while pregnant, showcasing her baby bump and challenging societal norms.  Her breakthrough role came in 1990's "Ghost," a romantic drama that solidified her status as a leading lady.  She was married to Bruce Willis for 13 years.  Who is this actress, known for her roles in films like "A Few Good Men" and "G.I. Jane"?

This country used its caravel ships to trade with the people of Goa after sailing around the Cape of Good Hope along a route found by this country's explorer Bartholomew Dias. The first European to reach India by sea was an explorer from this country, Vasco da Gama. This country colonized Brazil, which now speaks this country's language. Name this country once ruled from the capital city of Lisbon.

An island country in this body of water was called Tylos by the Greeks when it was part of the Achaemenid dynasty; the modern-day country on that island has capital Manama. The Shatt al-Arab drains into this body of water, which is connected by the Strait of Hormuz to the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea. Bahrain lies in, and Qatar, Kuwait, and the United Arab Emirates lie on what Middle Eastern gulf?

Victorious soldiers in this war, worried about unfunded pensions, tried to organize the Newburgh Conspiracy. The Conway Cabal was a short-lived attempt to replace the winning leader. During this war, John Andre was hanged for his role in an attempted betrayal of the fort at West Point, a plan organized by Benedict Arnold. Name this war, which ended when Lord Cornwallis surrendered at Yorktown to George Washington.

Margaret Bourke-White photographed this man at the Birla House sitting behind a spinning wheel. This man, who agreed to a 1931 pact with Lord Irwin in advance of the Second Round Table Conference, was assassinated by Nathuram Godse, who believed this man had given too much power to Muslims during the partition of the British Raj. A nonviolent 1930 salt march was led by what independence leader who advocated for civil disobedience in India?

This athlete, a key figure in the US Women's National Team's fight for equal pay, co-captained the team to victory in the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup.  She has won two World Cup titles and an Olympic gold medal.  She played for the San Diego Wave FC in the National Women's Soccer League until her retirement in 2024.  She also co-authored a series of children's books, "The Kicks," which promote female empowerment and sportsmanship.  Who is this soccer star, known for her athleticism and advocacy for gender equality?

This actor's breakout role in the Hulu miniseries "Normal People," a coming-of-age romantic drama, earned him a Primetime Emmy Award nomination and widespread critical acclaim. He starred in the 2023 psychological thriller "God's Creatures," alongside Emily Watson, showcasing his versatility and range. He also appeared in the acclaimed 2022 drama "Aftersun," which earned him a nomination for Best Actor at the 95th Academy Awards. Who is this Irish actor, who recently starred in Gladiator II?

This state is the setting of many Bret Harte short stories. In a novel set in this state, a neighborhood throws a party for Doc. A man is shot by his friend to save him from a mob after he killed Curley's wife in this state, the setting of Cannery Row. In one novel, the Joad family travels West to this state. Name this western setting of John Steinbeck novels such as Of Mice and Men and The Grapes of Wrath.

The change in this value due to Compton scattering is proportional to one minus the cosine of the scattering angle. Massive particles have a de Broglie variety of this value equal to Planck's constant over momentum. For the electromagnetic spectrum, the product of this and frequency is equal to the speed of light. Name this quantity, symbolized lambda, that can be computed as the distance between two peaks of a wave.

A vehicle of this type exploded in front of the Trump Hotel in Las Vegas on New Year's Day. This vehicle's unconventional design, with its angular shape and stainless steel body, has sparked both curiosity and controversy since its unveiling in 2019. Its armored glass windows, demonstrated in a live demonstration that didn't go quite as planned, are claimed to be shatterproof. It boasts impressive performance capabilities, with a claimed 0 to 60 mph acceleration time of 2.9 seconds and a towing capacity of over 14,000 pounds. What is the name of this electric pickup truck, designed by Tesla?

This country's city of Antsiranana is near Cap d'Ambre, its northernmost point. The Meller's duck lives on Lake Alaotra in this country, the largest producer of vanilla in the world. The Merina people occupy the Central Highlands of this country west of Reunion where the native language is Malagasy. Comoros is northwest of this country separated from the mainland by the Mozambique Channel. Lemurs are endemic to what African island country with capital Antananarivo?

This thinker described taking an umbrella in case of rain as an irrational caprice in A Treatise on Probability. This man asserted that a "Carthaginian peace" was insufficient in The Economic Consequences of the Peace, which he published after attending the Paris Peace Conference in 1919. This man inspired a "revolution" toward demand-focused economics in another work. Name this British economist who wrote The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money.

A bald man dressed in blue and sitting on a chair next to a fire holds his head in his hands in this man's work At Eternity's Gate, while another features a white-coated waiter standing next to a billiards table inside the title structure, The Night Cafe. Five Dutch peasants sit in a dimly lit room around a table in his The Potato Eaters, and the title doctor sits at a table resting his head on his right arm in two different versions of a more famous work, Portrait of Dr. Gachet. Identify this brother of art dealer Theo, the Dutch artist behind Starry Night.

President Joe Biden awarded this honor to 18 individuals on January 4, 2025. The recipients included Magic Johnson, George Romney, and George Soros. This award, established in 1963 by President John F. Kennedy, is the highest civilian honor in the United States, recognizing individuals who have made exceptional contributions to the security or national interests of the country, to world peace, or to cultural or other significant public or private endeavors. What is the name of this prestigious award, symbolized by a gold medal with a white star on a blue enamel background?

This singer's record-breaking single, "7 Rings," which debuted at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, interpolates melodies from "My Favorite Things" from the musical The Sound of Music.  Her signature high ponytail and cat-eye makeup have become iconic elements of her style.  She began her career on Broadway, starring in the musical "13" before transitioning to television with roles on Nickelodeon shows like "Victorious" and "Sam & Cat."  Who is this pop star, known for her impressive vocal range and her hit songs like "Problem" and "Thank U, Next"?

This man defeated Desiderius at Pavia to conquer the Lombard kingdom, and then conquered Saxony and Bavaria. Advised by the scholar Alcuin of York and the subject of a biography by Einhard, this ruler's education reforms led to a namesake "renaissance." This king established Aachen as his capital and was a grandson of Charles Martel. He was crowned the first Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Leo III on Christmas Day, 800 CE. Name this "great" Frankish king.

In ancient times, the southern shore of this sea was split between Pontus, Paphlagonia, and Bithynia. The Strait of Kerch connects it to the oil-rich Sea of Azov, surrounding a peninsula home to Yalta and Sevastopol. The Dniester, Dnieper, and Danube Rivers flow into the west shores of this sea. The Crimean Peninsula juts into what Asian sea north of Turkey?

Betty Parris and Abigail Williams both claimed to be afflicted by these people, setting off a panic which hunted these people. The West Indian slave Tituba, after herself being accused of being one of them, accused Sarah Good and Sarah Osborne during that 1692 panic. A series of "trials" were held in Salem, Massachusetts targeting what purported evil magic users?

This team's iconic "Al Davis Memorial Torch," lit in honor of their legendary owner, stands as the largest 3D printed structure in the world. Their rebellious image and association with the "Black Hole" fan section have become synonymous with the franchise. They relocated from Oakland to Los Angeles in 1982, returning to Oakland in 1995, and finally settling in Las Vegas in 2020. They have won three Super Bowl titles, the last of which came in 1983. What is the name of this NFL team, known for their silver and black uniforms and their passionate fanbase?

This team's home stadium features a unique "California Spectacular" rock formation in center field, complete with a waterfall and geysers. They made history in 2002 by winning their first and only World Series title, led by a memorable performance from rookie pitcher John Lackey. Their iconic "rally monkey," introduced in 2000, became a symbol of the team's late-inning comebacks and energized their fanbase.  They are owned by Arte Moreno, the first Mexican-American to own a major sports team in the United States. What is the name of this team, based in Anaheim, California?

A newspaper owner allegedly told a reporter in this region "you furnish the pictures and I'll furnish the war." "Butcher" Valeriano Weyler was accused of killing residents of concentration camps on this island. James Buchanan wrote the Ostend Manifesto about the purchase of this island. The Platt and Teller amendments governed U.S. relations with this country after the Spanish-American War, which included the Battle of San Juan Hill near Santiago on this island. Name this country where the U.S.S. Maine exploded in Havana.

The Battle of Muret and Siege of Carcassonne took place during one of these events led by Simon de Montfort. Guy de Lusignan's army was crushed at the Horns of Hattin prior to one of these events, during which one leader drowned in the Saleph River. The Battle of Fariksur led to the ransom of Louis IX by the Ayyubids during the "Seventh" of these events. The first of these campaigns was led by Peter the Hermit, who responded to the call of Pope Urban II, while the fourth sacked Constantinople. Name these military expeditions to the "Holy Land."

This actor's iconic Vulcan salute, accompanied by the phrase "Live long and prosper," became a symbol of peace and goodwill in popular culture. He directed two of the "Star Trek" films, "The Search for Spock" and "The Voyage Home," showcasing his talent behind the camera. He also authored two autobiographies, titled "I Am Not Spock" and "I Am Spock," reflecting his complex relationship with his most famous role. Who is this actor, best known for portraying the logical and stoic Spock in the "Star Trek" franchise?

This river may originate at the usually-dry Trewsbury Mead, or at a location known as Seven Springs, which would make this river its country's longest, surpassing the Severn. This river, whose name comes from the Celtic for "dark," is called the Isis where it flows through Oxford. Tower Bridge crosses this river just east of St. Paul's Cathedral. Name this English river that flows through London.

This country's flag reflects the myth that a city in it was founded where an eagle was seen eating a snake atop a cactus. A civilization from this modern day country worshipped a god that took the form of a "feathered serpent," named Quetzalcoatl. At Tenochtitlan, a civilization from this country performed human sacrifice for its gods. The myths of the Aztec civilization are from what country?

A group of genes coding for lactose breakdown, known as the lac operon, was first discovered in this model organism. Although it is not Shigella, shiga toxins are produced in virulent strains of this organism such as its serotype O157:H7. They colonize the human gut at birth. Name these gram-negative bacteria that are a common cause of food poisoning and food recalls.

This awards show was hosted by Nikki Glaser on January 5, 2025. These awards, originally presented by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, are now presented by a group sharing a name with the ceremony. They recognize excellence in both film and television, with categories for both domestic and international productions.  The ceremony is known for its more relaxed and informal atmosphere compared to the Academy Awards, often featuring celebrities mingling and enjoying champagne.  The first ceremony was held in 1944 at the 20th Century Fox studios, and has since become a staple of the Hollywood awards season. What is the name of these awards, symbolized by a golden globe statue?

This rapper's record label, Shady Records, co-founded with his manager Paul Rosenberg, has launched the careers of successful artists like 50 Cent and Yelawolf. His song "Lose Yourself," from the 2002 film "8 Mile," became the first rap song to win an Academy Award for Best Original Song. He is known for his controversial lyrics, complex rhyme schemes, and alter ego, Slim Shady. He has sold over 220 million records worldwide, making him one of the best-selling music artists of all time. Who is this rapper, often considered one of the greatest of all time?

This quarterback holds the NFL record for the most wins by a quarterback in his first ten seasons, showcasing his consistent success and leadership. He is known for his "Dangeruss" nickname and his ability to extend plays with his mobility, led the Seattle Seahawks to their first Super Bowl victory in 2014. He was traded to the Denver Broncos in 2022, a move that surprised many fans and analysts.  He is married to singer Ciara, and their family life often makes headlines.  Who is this quarterback, who currently plays for the Pittsburgh Steelers?

The so-called "Battle of the Thames" took place as a result of this campaign, which saw a flotilla of fishing boats clash with another fleet led by Bob Geldof. A supporter of this action kissed a salmon the day before this action. After this action, David Cameron resigned as Prime Minister of the UK, and this vote meant Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon would be invoked. Name this landmark 2016 vote that ended with Britain voting to leave the European Union.

In one short story by this author, rats and the French Army free the protagonist from an execution device created by the Spanish Inquisition. This author also wrote about the walling in of a man wearing a jester costume who screams "For the love of God, Montresor!" This author of "The Pit and the Pendulum" described a maiden who was envied by angels and was interred in a "sepulchre by the sea." Name this author of "The Cask of Amontillado" and "Annabel Lee," who described a bird saying "nevermore" in "The Raven."

Many 16th and 17th century maps incorrectly depicted this modern-day U.S. state as an island. Francis Drake claimed the colony of New Albion in this state. Junipero Serra founded many missions along this state's Camino Real. The Donner Party died trying to reach this state, where an 1849 gold rush attracted thousands of migrants. Name this "Golden State".

The Djebel Chelia is the highest peak in the Aures Mountains, which are an eastern extension of this mountain range. Another part of this mountain range contains the Amour, Ksour, and Ouled-Nail mountains, and they run mostly parallel to the Tell Mountains, which are a part of this mountain range that lies near the shore. Its highest peak is the Jbel Toubkal, which is found in the High part of this mountain range. Also having Middle and Anti parts, it is formed by the continental collision of Iberia with Africa. Identify this mountain range in Morocco, Algeria, and Tunisia.

The only confirmed footprint of this dinosaur is in New Mexico. One specimen of this dinosaur is nicknamed Sue. Some debate exists over whether this theropod was a scavenger or a fierce predator. Name this large, powerfully-jawed carnivorous dinosaur with tiny arms.

This national leader announced he would step down as the head of his Liberal Party and prime minister once his party selects a new leader. Born in Ottawa, he went on to attend McGill University and University of British Columbia. He was elected to the House of Commons in 2008, and in 2013 he was chosen as the leader of the Liberal Party. His father, Pierre, was the 15th prime minister of Canada. Name this prime minister of Canada since 2015.

This artist's face tattoos, including a barbed wire across his forehead and the words "Stay Away" under his right eye, have become as recognizable as his music. His breakout single, "White Iverson," released in 2015, blended elements of hip-hop, R&B, and trap, showcasing his genre-bending style. He holds the record for the most songs with over one billion streams on Spotify, with nine tracks achieving this milestone. He has collaborated with a diverse range of artists, including Ozzy Osbourne, Kanye West, and Justin Bieber. Who is this singer and rapper, known for his distinctive vocal style and eclectic musical influences?

In degrees, this number is the lowest positive number for which the sine function is equal to zero. Pi radians are equal to this many degrees. An exterior angle of a polygon and its corresponding interior angle add to this number. Two supplementary angles sum to this number. The sum of a triangle's interior angles is what number which is equal to half the number of degrees in a full circle?

In this state, tourists can ride to the top of Sandia Peak via the longest aerial tram in the Americas. A minor-league baseball team in this state's largest city is named the Isotopes in honor of this state's role as the site of the Trinity nuclear test and the home of Los Alamos National Laboratory. Santa Fe is the capital of what Southwestern state with its largest city at Albuquerque?

Eleven detainees were recently transferred from this notorious military prison to Oman, bringing the remaining prison population down to 15. Established in 1903 through a lease agreement with Cuba, this prison is located on a US naval base on the southeastern tip of Cuba which covers 45 square miles. What is the name of this prison which has housed suspected terrorists without trial since 2002?

This running back, known for his bruising running style and his stiff arm that sends defenders flying, holds the NFL record for the most rushing yards in a single postseason, a feat he accomplished in 2019. He holds the record for most games with over 200 rushing yards and 2 touchdowns. He played college football at the University of Alabama, where he won the Heisman Trophy in 2015. Who is this current Baltimore Ravens running back, nicknamed "King Henry"?

His Piano Concerto No. 3 was originally intended to be a symphony but was published as a one-movement Allegro brillante posthumously. He wrote an un-numbered Manfred Symphony between his 4th and 5th, and his 7th was left unfinished at his death. The opening 36-bar Andante introduction is marked "sempre marcatissimo" in his Serenade for Strings, and his visit to inspired his Capriccio italien. Using part of La Marseillaise in one piece that often uses canons at the end, this is what Russian composer of the 1812 Overture and Symphony No. 6, Pathetique?

This King died when his horse bucked him after the horse stepped on hot ashes. A year before his death, this man ordered the creation of the Domesday Book, which listed all landholders and their lands in his new realm. His achievements are recorded in the Bayeux Tapestry. After the death of Edward the Confessor, this man fought against Harold Godwinson for the English throne. Name this duke of Normandy who was victorious at the Battle of Hastings in 1066 and became the first Norman King of England.

These people call themselves the Diné and traditionally lived in dried mud houses called hogans. Kit Carson forced these people to undertake the "Long Walk" to the Bosque Redondo. Several of these Athabaskan-speaking people provided unbreakable radio communications during the Battle of Iwo Jima and their major reservation completely surrounds the Hopi Reservation. Name this Native American people of the Four Corners region who provided "code talkers" in World War II.

During this conflict, a prisoner of war used Morse Code on a televised interview to spell "torture." A guerilla attack during a Lunar New Year truce in this war surprised American soldiers. The use of Agent Orange to defoliate trees during this conflict was controversial for its health effects on soldiers. During this war, one side captured Saigon and renamed it Ho Chi Minh City. Name this controversial war fought in a southeast Asian country.

This swimmer made history at the 2016 Rio Olympics by becoming the first African-American woman to win an individual gold medal in swimming, tying for first in the 100-meter freestyle. She also earned a gold medal in the 4x100-meter medley relay and a silver in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay at the same Olympics. She swam for Stanford University, where she won seven NCAA titles. Who is this swimmer, known for her powerful freestyle and her advocacy for diversity and inclusion in the sport?

In 1984, Bernard Goetz shot four black teenagers on this city's subway, claiming self-defense. In 1976 and 1977, six murders by the "Son of Sam" terrorized this city. The zero-tolerance for "broken windows" policy used by this city in the 1990s corresponds with a drop in the crime rate under mayor Rudolph Giuliani. Name this city, whose failed 2013 law banning large soft drinks was supported by former mayor Michael Bloomberg.

In this thinker's The Sand Reckoner, he estimates the number of grains of sand in the universe and proves several statements regarding exponents. This Syracusan thinker developed a water screw and a heat ray, and he was said to have calculated the density of a crown made of silver and gold. Name this ancient scientist and mathematician who, upon discovering the principle of buoyancy, legendarily ran naked through the streets, shouting "Eureka!"

This state contains deeply eroded ash deposits in the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes within Katmai National Park. The North Slope oil fields are found in this state, where the Chilkoot Pass can be accessed through this state's port city of Skagway on the historic Yukon Trail. The highest point in North America, Denali, is found in this state. Name this "North Star" state whose most populous city is Anchorage and whose capital is Juneau.

This artist hails from County Wicklow, Ireland, and his music often incorporates elements of Irish folk tradition. His breakthrough single, "Take Me To Church," a soulful ballad with gospel influences, reached number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and garnered a Grammy Award nomination for Song of the Year. He collaborated with Annie Lennox on a powerful rendition of "I Put a Spell on You" for the 2014 film "Fifty Shades of Grey."    Who is this singer-songwriter, known for his soulful voice and evocative lyrics?

A magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck this region on January 6th resulting in at least 126 deaths. Its spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, has lived in exile since 1959 due to political unrest.  Its capital city, Lhasa, is home to the Potala Palace, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that once served as the winter residence of the Dalai Lamas.  This region, known for its high altitude and mountainous terrain, is home to Mount Everest, the highest peak in the world. What is this region, often referred to as the "Roof of the World," which has a long history of spiritual and cultural significance?

In the book of Luke, the tax collector Zaccheus climbed on top of one of these objects to see Jesus. St. Boniface destroyed a large one of these things, many of which could be found in "sacred groves" used by Celtic druids. The Buddha sat under one of these plants, called the Bodhi, known for its heart-shaped leaves. An angel or a star often adorn what plants which are decorated at Christmas?

This metro area has been overwhelmed with fires starting on January 7 including one that has burned Pacific Palisades. Its Griffith Observatory, perched on a hill overlooking the city, offers stunning views of the Hollywood sign and the vast urban landscape. It hosted the Summer Olympics twice, in 1932 and 1984, and they are scheduled to host them in 2028. This city, known as the "Entertainment Capital of the World," is home to the iconic Hollywood Walk of Fame, a sidewalk embedded with over 2,700 stars honoring celebrities from the entertainment industry. What is this sprawling metropolis, the second-most populous city in the United States?

In one work by this author, a man claims he is in jail by the "implied contract", refusing to allow the titular friend to get him out. In another work, Alcibiades discusses the nature of love at a dinner party hosted by Aristophanes. This author of Crito and Symposium compared our perception of reality to prisoners watching shadows on a stone wall in what is called the "allegory of the cave". Name this Greek philosopher of The Republic and numerous dialogues featuring his teacher, Socrates.

This golfer, known for his distinctive "Happy Gilmore" swing and his calm demeanor on the course, became the first Norwegian to win a PGA Tour event when he captured the 2020 Puerto Rico Open.  He achieved a historic victory at the 2023 Memorial Tournament, becoming the first European player to win the event since its inception in 1976.  He has also represented his country in the Olympics and the Ryder Cup.  Who is this rising star in professional golf?

During this battle, Omar Bradley was detained after correctly stating that the capital of Illinois was Springfield. Joachim Peiper executed a group of American POWs during this battle's Malmedy Massacre. When asked to surrender during this battle, an American general defending Bastogne responded "Nuts!" Name this World War II battle named for the dent created in Allied lines.

This animation studio's first feature film, released in 1995, revolutionized animation with its groundbreaking computer-generated imagery and heartwarming story about a group of toys.  Its iconic lamp mascot, Luxo Jr., has appeared in the studio's production logo since its early short films.  The studio's films, known for their emotional depth and universal appeal, have garnered numerous Academy Awards, including Best Animated Feature for films like "Finding Nemo" and "Toy Story 3."  What is the name of this animation studio, a subsidiary of Walt Disney Studios, known for its innovative storytelling and beloved characters?

This artist's Charnel House concluded a series that began with his most famous piece, which also included The Weeping Woman. He created two paintings by the name of Three Musicians in 1921, and both are believed to feature his friend Guillaume Apollinaire. He painted Boy with a Pipe during his Rose Period that came after his Blue Period, and, with Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, developed the basic concepts of cubism. Identify this Spanish-born artist, best known for Guernica.

One monument in this city was built for the 1889 World's Fair to mark the centennial of its country's revolution. The Arc de Triomphe is located in this capital city, which the Seine River flows through. A cathedral in this city inspired The Hunchback of Notre Dame. Name this capital of France.

These rocks are classified by their silicon content as mafic, such as scoria, and felsic, such as rhyolite. These rocks are further classified as extrusive or intrusive, and most of the youngest rock on earth is this kind of rock. Volcanic activity produces what type of rock which includes pumice and basalt and is contrasted with metamorphic and sedimentary?

This river forms a lake-like widening that is occupied by M'Bamou in its center. That area of this river is known as Pool Malebo. Soon after joining with the Ubangi River, this river narrows and forms a series of cataracts known as Livingstone Falls. This river is fed by Lake Tanganyika and it separates the two geographically closest non-contiguous capitals in the world. This river was formerly known as the Zaire River under the Mobuto dictatorship. Name this second longest river in Africa that separates Kinshasa and Brazzaville.

The US Supreme Court recently heard a case about the constitutionality of a law which would ban this popular app. This app's algorithm, which personalizes content based on user interactions, has been praised for its effectiveness in keeping users engaged.  It has launched the careers of numerous influencers and creators, who have amassed millions of followers through their entertaining and creative content.  What is the name of this short-form video app, which has become a cultural phenomenon, especially among younger generations?

This government moved its capital to Richmond in 1861, although it was never recognized as an independent country. Its vice president was Alexander Stephens, and its president was Jefferson Davis. Name this group of states that seceded from the Union prior to the U.S. Civil War.

In natural units, this quantity's square is the difference between the squares of energy and momentum. This property's units include electronvolts over c squared, and daltons. Objects with this property have inertia and can interact with each other via gravity. This is the quotient of force and acceleration. Name this quantity that is divided by volume to find density and is often measured in grams.

This novel's protagonist searches for water for Jimmie Rogers and fights with Wilson over a flag. One man in this novel mistakes a traveling companion for Tom Jamison; another stumbles upon a dead soldier in a clearing after fleeing from a battle. That man travels with a Tattered Soldier and witnesses the death of his friend, Jim Conklin. Name this novel about Civil War soldier Henry Fleming, written by Stephen Crane.
incorrect3: All Quiet on the Western Front

question: This ruler was targeted in the Ridolfi and Throckmorton Plots, but both were foiled by this ruler's spymaster Francis Walsingham. This monarch gave the Tilbury Speech after a victory at the Battle of Gravelines, which repelled the Spanish Armada. Pro-Catholic forces schemed to depose this ruler and replace her with Mary, Queen of Scots. Name this English monarch, a daughter of Henry VIII known as the "Virgin Queen."

This animation studio's iconic opening sequence features a boy fishing from the moon, a whimsical image that has become synonymous with its brand. Its first feature film, "Antz," released in 1998, showcased the studio's commitment to computer-generated animation.  The studio's franchises, including "Shrek," "Madagascar," and "Kung Fu Panda," have achieved global success and spawned numerous sequels and spin-offs.  What is the name of this animation studio, founded by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg, and David Geffen?

This swimmer, who became the youngest individual swimming world champion in over a decade when she won the 200-meter butterfly at the 2022 World Aquatics Championships, holds the world record in the 400-meter individual medley.  She also excels in freestyle events, capturing gold in the 400-meter freestyle at the 2024 World Short Course Championships.  Who is this Canadian swimming sensation, known for her versatility and potential to become one of the sport's all-time greats?

This footballer, the first player to win the Ballon d'Or Féminin twice, achieving the feat in 2021 and 2022, is known for her creative playmaking and clinical finishing as a midfielder.  She plays for FC Barcelona Femení, where she has won numerous trophies, including the UEFA Women's Champions League.  She suffered a serious knee injury in 2022, which sidelined her for a significant period, but she made a triumphant return to the pitch in 2023.  Who is this Spanish midfielder, considered one of the best players in the world?

Mount Springer and Katahdin mark the southern and northern termini of a hiking trail spanning this mountain range. The Catskills and Blue Ridge Mountains are subranges of this larger mountain range. The natural beauty of the region named for this mountain range is threatened by mountaintop removal for coal mining in states like West Virginia. Name this largest mountain range east of the Mississippi.

This city recently implemented congestion pricing which charges vehicles for entering busy neighborhoods during the day. The policy was surprisingly scrapped before being revived at the end of 2024 at a lower price point. This city's iconic subway system, the largest in the world by number of stations, with 472 stations in operation, transports millions of passengers daily, navigating a complex network of underground tunnels.    It is home to the Empire State Building, an Art Deco masterpiece that held the title of the world's tallest building for nearly 40 years.  What is this city, nicknamed the "Big Apple," the most populous city in the United States?

This programming language's Django framework is used for web development, while its BeautifulSoup library scrapes data from websites. Pip is a package manager for this language. Data scientists use this language's "pandas," "num," and "sci" libraries. This language, which does not require the use of semicolons after each statement, uses indents to denote code blocks as opposed to curly braces. Name this easy-to-read programming language that isn't actually named for a snake.

This actor, who learned to play the guitar for his role as a struggling musician in the 2000 film "Proof of Life," famously threw a telephone at a hotel concierge in 2005, an incident that led to his arrest and a public apology. He gained international recognition for his portrayal of the Roman general Maximus Decimus Meridius in the 2000 historical epic "Gladiator," which earned him an Academy Award for Best Actor. He also starred in the 2003 naval warfare film "Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World," showcasing his versatility and range. Who is this New Zealand-born actor, known for his intense performances and occasional off-screen controversies?

This ruler brought back his country's traditional religion after it was changed to a monotheistic one-deity religion by his father Akhenaten. Studies of this ruler's injuries have led to theories that he died in a chariot accident. This ruler's tomb in the Valley of the Kings supposedly cursed Lord Carnarvon and was found by archaeologist Howard Carter. Name this "Boy Pharaoh" of Egypt who died at age 19.

This treaty set the Saint Croix River as the northeastern boundary of the US. Article III of this treaty declared the right of Native Americans to trade and travel between the US and Canada. American merchants wanted the British West Indies reopened for trade, which was not achieved, but the British did vacate six western forts by June 1796. It notably failed to deal with the impressments of American sailors into the Royal Navy, which became a key issue in the War of 1812. Identify this 1794 treaty that negotiated compensations between the US and Britain, named after a Supreme Court justice.

In what is now this country, the militant Katipunan society was founded after Jose Rizal's peaceful movement for independence failed. Emilio Aguinaldo fought for this country's freedom against both the Spanish and the Americans, who took Puerto Rico, Guam, and this land from Spain after winning the Spanish-American War. Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos led this country, to which Douglas MacArthur vowed "I shall return." Name this Pacific island country where George Dewey fought the Battle of Manila Bay.

This actor's production company, Mundy Lane Entertainment, is named after the street he grew up on in Mount Vernon, New York. He has received a record four Black Reel Awards for Best Actor, showcasing his impact on African-American representation in film. He won his first Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor in 1990 for his portrayal of a defiant Civil War soldier in "Glory." He also directed and starred in the 2007 historical drama "The Great Debaters," about a black debate team from Wiley College. Who is this acclaimed actor, known for his powerful performances in films like "Malcolm X," "Training Day," and "Fences"?

The US Surgeon General recently called for warnings about an increased risk of cancer on this substance. The substance is produced by the fermentation of sugars by yeasts or other microorganisms. Its consumption has been a part of human culture for millennia, with evidence of its production dating back to 7000 BC in China. Its effects on the human body vary depending on the amount consumed, ranging from mild relaxation and euphoria to impaired coordination and judgment. What is this psychoactive substance, the most widely consumed drug in the world?

A group supporting this cause that held signs demeaning "Kaiser Wilson" outside the White House were the "Silent Sentinels" led by Alice Paul. The "Declaration of Sentiments" was written to support this cause at the 1848 Seneca Falls Convention. The 19th Amendment granted and Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony supported what right of a certain group to participate in elections?

The island of Bornholm is in this body of water, which is connected by the Kiel Canal to the North Sea. One arm of this sea is the Gulf of Bothnia, and the large island of Saaremaa guards its Gulf of Riga. Five national capitals lie on this body of water, including Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, and Stockholm. Name this sea south of Scandinavia.

This scientist confirmed Gauss's Law using a namesake "ice-pail" and showed that the charge on closed conductors remains on their surface. His namesake law states that when a magnet passing through a coil of wire produces a current, the induced electromotive force is equal to the negative rate of change of the magnetic flux. The inventor of the dynamo and a device where the interior electric field is always zero, his namesake "cage," is what physicist whose namesake law explains magnetic induction?

This musician dedicated his Symphony No. 4 in F Minor to his financial supporter Nadezhda von Meck, though they never met. His Sixth Symphony, nicknamed Pathetique, premiered nine days before his death. In one of his ballets, the sorcerer Von Rothbart curses Odette; another includes the "Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy". Name this Russian composer of Swan Lake, The Nutcracker, and the 1812 Overture.

This man's political views included that of the Third International Theory, which applied to 3rd-world countries, as well as the concept of Jamahiriya, or "state of the masses"; both of which were defined in this man's Green Book. This man's country was the target of US bombings in Operation El Dorado Canyon, and he gave a hero's welcome to the perpetrator of the Lockerbie bombing. This man gained power after toppling Idris I and was overthrown by a rebellion assisted by a NATO no-fly zone. Name this longtime dictator of Libya executed in 2011.

This golfer, known for his fiery intensity and passionate celebrations, achieved a remarkable feat in 2023 by winning both the Masters Tournament and the Open Championship, becoming the first Spanish player to win the Claret Jug since Seve Ballesteros in 1988. He reached the number one spot in the Official World Golf Ranking in 2020, a position he has held for several weeks. He is recognizable for his powerful swing and his occasional outbursts of emotion on the course. Who is this golfer, often considered one of the most talented players of his generation?

This athlete, whose parents own the Buffalo Bills and Buffalo Sabres, reached a career-high ranking of world No. 3 in singles tennis in 2023.  She is known for her powerful groundstrokes and aggressive style of play, often dictating the pace of rallies.  She has won two WTA 1000 titles in doubles, partnering with Coco Gauff.  She also reached the quarterfinals of all four Grand Slam singles tournaments in 2022, showcasing her consistency at the highest level. Who is this American tennis star?

The three-month average of the concentration of this molecule is proxy-measured via the hemoglobin A1c test. The beta cells in the Islets of Langerhans become more active when levels of this molecule increase. An increase in the levels of this molecule stimulates the production of insulin. This substance is deficient in hypoglycemia. This molecule has formula C6H12O6, and is more abundant in individuals with diabetes. Name this sweet molecule.

This organization was founded due to Henri Dunant's description of the Battle of Solferino, which inspired the formation of a committee based in Geneva. The American branch of this organization was founded by Clara Barton after the Civil War. Although it is also symbolized by a crystal and a crescent, this organization's main emblem is a color reversal of the Swiss flag. Three Nobel Peace Prizes have been won by, What organization that protects and cares for the victims of war?

This character's memorable line, "Remember who you are," serves as a powerful reminder of Simba's royal heritage and his destiny to rule the Pride Lands. His untimely death, orchestrated by his brother Scar in a wildebeest stampede, is one of the most iconic and heartbreaking moments in Disney animation history. His spirit appears to Simba in a vision, urging him to take his rightful place as king. He is voiced by James Earl Jones, whose deep and resonant voice adds to the character's regal presence. Who is this beloved character, the wise and benevolent king of the Pride Lands in Disney's "The Lion King"?

This religion's (and the word's) largest gathering, the Maha Kumbh Mela, is held every 12 years. This year it is happening at the city of Prayagra. It attracts millions of pilgrims who bathe in sacred rivers for purification and spiritual renewal.  Its traditional practice of yoga, a system of physical and mental disciplines, has gained global popularity for its health benefits and spiritual significance.  Its concept of reincarnation, the belief that the soul is reborn after death, is a central tenet.  What is this religion, the world's oldest major religion, with over a billion followers, primarily in India and Nepal?

This author's novel about Laura Hawkins coined the term "the Gilded Age." This author wrote about a lawyer who uses fingerprints to prove that Tom Driscoll had been switched at birth with Valet de Chambers. This author of Pudd'nhead Wilson created a character who tricks his friends into whitewashing a fence, and gets lost in McDougal's Cave with Becky Thatcher. Another of his protagonists floats down the Mississippi with the escaped slave Jim. Name this author of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and a sequel about Huckleberry Finn.

This country's traditional percussion orchestra, popular among the Sundanese people, is called the gamelan. A massive Buddhist temple called Borobudur is found in this country, where many Hindus live on the island of Bali. This country is the largest Muslim-majority country in the world, and it borders Malaysia and Brunei on the island of Borneo. Name this island country led from Jakarta.

During this battle, Confederate armies attempted to drive their opponent towards Owl Creek, but Union forces fell back towards an area known as the Hornet's Nest instead. Albert Sidney Johnston was killed on the first day of this battle, and the arrival of General Buell's troops sent the Confederates packing after day two. Name this April 6, 1862 battle fought in Tennessee.

In 2012 an unknown disk-shaped object was found on the floor of this sea. Arms of this sea include the Gulf of Riga and Gulf of Bothnia. The Kiel Canal bypasses Kattegat Bay and Skagerrak Strait to connect this sea to the North Sea. Germany and Poland are on its southern shore. Name this sea bordered by Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, its namesake "States," as well as Finland and Sweden.

This figure was imprisoned on the Isle of Pines before going into exile in Mexico, returning home on the yacht Granma. After failing to seize Moncada barracks, his "History will absolve me" speech helped organize the 26th of July movement to depose Fulcengio Batista, after which he resisted the Bay of Pigs invasion along with his brother Raul. Name this leader who, with Che Guevara, established a long-standing Communist government in Cuba.

The title character of this novel studies the works of Cornelius Agrippa and Albertus Magnus. The oriental languages scholar and friend Henry Clerval nurses him back to health in Ingolstadt. We hear about this from the letters of the ship's captain Robert Walton to Margaret Saville about meeting that title character in the Arctic. The central creation admires Felix and Agatha and saves a girl from drowning but kills William in revenge for his own eight-foot height and hideous appearance. Name this Gothic novel subtitled "The Modern Prometheus" by its author Mary Shelley.

This coach began his NFL coaching career as a special assistant with the Baltimore Colts in 1975, earning a mere $25 per week. He has a reputation for being tight-lipped with the media, often giving short and concise answers in press conferences. Known for his stoic demeanor and his preference for hoodies on the sidelines, he holds the record for the most Super Bowl wins as a head coach, with six championships to his name. Who is this coach, who led the New England Patriots to a record six Super Bowl titles and now leads the University of North Carolina?

This gaming console's revolutionary motion controls, utilizing a wireless controller, allowed players to physically interact with games, swinging a virtual tennis racket or bowling a virtual ball. Its family-friendly games attracted a wide audience, including casual gamers and families. Its innovative design and focus on motion-controlled gameplay made it a commercial success, selling over 100 million units worldwide. What is the name of this Nintendo console, released in 2006?

This phylum's skeleton is composed of miniscule networks of calcium carbonate known as stereom. These animals possess ampullae in their tube feet, which is part of their water vascular system used for feeding, moving, and breathing. Examples of this phylum include class Asteroidea. The only deuterostome phylum other than the Chordates name this phylum which includes sea urchins, starfish, and sand dollars.

This director passed away on January 25, 2025 at age 78. His films, known for their surreal imagery and dreamlike sequences, often feature enigmatic characters and unsettling narratives that defy easy interpretation. His 1980 film, "The Elephant Man," a biographical drama about a severely deformed man, earned him critical acclaim and eight Academy Award nominations. He created the cult classic television series "Twin Peaks," which captivated audiences with its quirky characters and mysterious plotlines. Name this director of Mulholland Drive.

One former leader of this organization, Don Black, created the hate website Stormfront. Nathan Bedford Forrest was an early leader of this organization, glorified in D.W. Griffith's Birth of a Nation, which opposed carpetbaggers and scalawags. Members of this group sometimes burned crosses and lynched blacks, following the instructions of their "Grand Wizard." Name this white supremacist group famous for its white hooded costumes.

Adjuvants, like aluminum salts, are sometimes included with these treatments to boost immune response to them. Thiomersal is a mercury-containing compound used as a preservative for these treatments, which can be either attenuated or inactivated. Andrew Wakefield promulgated the now-debunked theory that the MMR type of these treatments caused autism. Jonas Salk created one of these treatments for polio. Name these immunizations that build immunity by exposing patients to a weakened or dead virus.

This type of agreement was made between forces in Gaza. Another such agreement, signed on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month in 1918, ended World War I. Another, reached in 1953 after three years of fighting, divided the Korean Peninsula and established a Demilitarized Zone.  Yet another, signed in 1973, aimed to end the Vietnam War but ultimately proved ineffective.  What are these agreements, intended to bring a pause in hostilities?

This figure met his demise when he was struck by a piece of wood from his own vessel. While in Colchis visiting King Aeetes, he accomplished such tasks as yoking fire-breathing oxen and dispatching a group of warriors that sprang forth after dragon teeth were sown into the ground, all to get the Golden Fleece. He was aided in these tasks by his future wife Medea. Name this leader of the Argonauts.

Edward Larson won a Pulitzer Prize for the book Summer for the Gods, a work focusing on this event. Witnesses included future Senator Tom Stewart, judge John Raulston, and H.L. Mencken, who covered this event for the Baltimore Sun. Taking place in Rhea County, it resulted in a one hundred dollar fine from the violation of the Butler Act by a high school teacher from Dayton, Tennessee. Identify this 1925 court case that saw Clarence Darrow and William Jennings Bryan argue about the legality of teaching evolution in school.
answers: The State of Tennessee vs. John Thomas Scopes

question: This handheld gaming device, first released in 1989, featured a monochrome green-tinted display and interchangeable cartridges, revolutionizing portable gaming. Its iconic game, Tetris, a puzzle game where players fit falling blocks together, became a global phenomenon and a bestseller for the device. Its battery life, which could last for over 30 hours on two AA batteries, made it a popular choice for on-the-go entertainment. What is the name of this Nintendo handheld console, which sold over 118 million units worldwide?

This new golf league, founded by Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy, is set to revolutionize the sport with its innovative team format and high-tech approach. It will feature six teams of three PGA Tour players competing in a custom-built arena, utilizing advanced technology to track shots and enhance the viewing experience. Matches will be played on Monday nights, offering a primetime alternative to traditional golf tournaments. What is the name of this league, which aims to attract a younger audience and bring a new level of excitement to the sport?

One participant in this event sent a letter to Father Garnet asking for help in raising an army but his pleas were rejected. This event was uncovered when a letter sent by Francis Tresham to Baron Monteagle was delivered to Robert Cecil. Several perpetrators of this event died or were captured at Holbeche House, where they fled after raiding Warwick Castle. This event was orchestrated by a man angered at the lack of rights given to Catholics by James I, Robert Catesby. Identify this 1605 plot to assassinate the king by blowing up the British Parliament that led to the conviction of Guy Fawkes.

Cities in this country include the capital of the IOC, Lausanne, and Davos, which is home to the annual World Economic Forum. It includes Romansh as one of four official languages, and its states, known as cantons, include Lucerne, Geneva, and Zurich. The Matterhorn lies on this country's southern border with Italy. The International Red Cross is based in what famously neutral Alpine country with capital Bern?

This Grand Slam tennis tournament, the first of the four majors to be held each year, is known for its extreme heat, with temperatures on the court often exceeding 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius). Its iconic blue Plexicushion courts have been a distinctive feature since 2008.  The tournament's retractable roof stadiums, Rod Laver Arena and Margaret Court Arena, allow for uninterrupted play in case of rain or extreme heat.  What is the name of this tournament, held annually in Melbourne, Australia?

This city's Paseo de la Reform is home to the "Angel of Independence" victory column and runs through Chapultepec Park. Overlooked by the mound volcano Ajusco, this city north of Puebla was built on an island in Lake Texcoco over the sacked ruins of Tenochtitlan; as a result, the artificial valley prevents wind from clearing out heavy smog. The most populous North American city is what capital city?

The "Great Relief" ended this state's siege of Fort St. Angelo on Malta. This empire's Edict of Gulhane began its Tanzimat reforms, while its devshirme recruited young boys to be trained for civil and military service. This empire's Hayreddin Barbarossa was defeated by Don John of Austria's Holy League fleet at Lepanto, while Poland's "Winged Hussars" drove off its 1683 siege of Vienna. The "sick man of Europe" was what empire ruled by Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent from Istanbul?

It reportedly began with the false accusations of a wigmaker's apprentice, which supposedly led a crowd to throw snowballs. The first person to die in this incident was Crispus Attucks, and in total five people died out of the three hundred estimated to be in the crowd surrounding Captain Thomas Preston's British troops. Identify this 1770 incident named for the New England city where it occurred.

On January 20, 2025, this ceremony was held to swear in Donald Trump as the president of the United States. The ceremony was moved inside the Capitol building for the first time in 40 years due to cold weather. The word stems from the Latin augur, which refers to the rituals of ancient Roman priests seeking to interpret if it was the will of the gods for a public official to be deemed worthy to assume office. Name this ceremony at which William Henry Harrison gave a historically long outdoor address for his historically short presidency.

This reality dating show, known for its elaborate rose ceremonies and dramatic eliminations, features a single bachelor who must choose a potential wife from a pool of eligible bachelorettes. The show's iconic mansion, located in Agoura Hills, California, serves as the backdrop for romantic dates and cocktail parties. The final rose ceremony is often a highly anticipated and emotional event. What is the name of this ABC series, which has spawned numerous spin-offs and international versions?

This man listens to a poem in which Finn kills Hengest being sung by the Shaper and Unferth has misgivings about a swimming race between this man and Breca. This figure defeats Ongentheow and Wiglaf is the only character to help this man when he fights a dragon. This man's most famous exploits are saving Heorot from a descendent of Cain and killing Grendel's mother. Name this titular character of an Old English epic translated by Seamus Heaney.
incorrect2: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight

question: Users of this language can use the command "pip" to install external modules. Instead of curly brackets, this language uses syntactic indentation to distinguish blocks of code. This programming language emphasizes human readability and uses keywords like "and" and "not" instead of symbols. Name this popular programming language named after a British comedy group that shares its name with a type of snake.

This composer wrote three Venetian boat songs for piano, and his fifth symphony honored an anniversary of the Augsburg Confession. This composer of Songs Without Words was inspired by the sight of Fingal's Cave to write the Hebrides Overture. The Reformation, Italian, and Scottish symphonies were composed by what German composer whose "Wedding March" was written as incidental music for A Midsummer Night's Dream?

This baseball player, known for his powerful swing and consistent hitting, achieved the rare feat of hitting 700 career home runs, joining the exclusive club of Barry Bonds, Hank Aaron, and Babe Ruth. He won three National League MVP awards and was a key member of the St. Louis Cardinals' World Series championship teams in 2006 and 2011. He returned to the Cardinals for his final season in 2022, receiving a warm welcome from fans and a fitting farewell to his illustrious career. Who is this Dominican-American slugger, known for his humble demeanor and his impact on the game?

This president's train refused to stop to aid the victims of a platform collapse that killed thirteen people who were waiting to hear him speak on his "Swing Around the Circle" speaking tour, in which this man ranted against the Radical Republicans. Edwin Stanton barricaded himself in his office rather than allow this man to fire him as Secretary of War. The first US president to be impeached was what man who succeeded Abraham Lincoln?

The elastic rebound theory provides an explanation for how energy is released during these events, whose damage is measured on the Mercalli scale. These events are caused by the movement of P and S waves along faults at boundaries of tectonic plates. The Richter scale measures these events' magnitude, and if their epicenter is in the ocean, tsunamis may form. In what geologic events may the ground shake?

This musician's iconic cardigan, worn during Nirvana's MTV Unplugged performance in 1993, sold for a record-breaking $334,000 at auction in 2019. His left-handed Fender Mustang guitar, often seen in music videos and live performances, has become a symbol of his raw and expressive playing style. His struggles with addiction and depression were well-documented, and his tragic death in 1994 at the age of 27 shocked the world. Who is this grunge icon, the lead singer and guitarist of Nirvana?

This Middle Eastern country recently elected Joseph Aoun to be president after a two year vacancy. It is known for its delicious cuisine and stunning landscapes, is home to the ancient city of Byblos, one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world. Its capital, Beirut, was once known as the "Paris of the Middle East" for its vibrant cultural scene and cosmopolitan atmosphere. The country has a rich history, with influences from Phoenician, Roman, Ottoman, and French civilizations. What is this country, famous for its cedar trees and its diverse population?

The sniper Vasily Zaytsev scored 225 kills during this battle where the Mamayev Kurgan heights changed hands several times due to their position above the battle. A building known as "Pavlov's House" held out for 60 days in this battle, part of the Case Blue offensive launched against the Caucasus. Georgy Zhukov led this battle's Operation Uranus, which encircled the German Sixth Army under Friedrich Paulus. Name this World War II battle fought over a Russian city on the Volga River.

The flooding of this river creates seasonal varzea forests. A cliff on Nevado Mismi is the source of this river, which is called the Solimoes until it meets the Rio Negro at Manaus. This river, whose delta nearly reaches French Guiana, is the namesake habitat for a pink river dolphin. Name this massive South American river that flows through the largest rainforest on Earth.

It was discovered by Carl Gustav Mosander in its oxide form, which is used today in camera lenses. It is found in monazite and bastnasite and its isotope 138 is sometimes used with barium to date rocks, although its 139 isotope is more common. It is often found with cerium and its name means "to lie hidden", although it is one of the most common rare earth metals. Name this metal that is the namesake of the series that fills the 4f orbital and which lies above actinium.

The 1638 Portsmouth Compact established a settlement that would become part of this colony. Its founder published The Bloody Tenet of Persecution in 1644 and purchased land for this colony from the Narragansett Indians. Anne Hutchinson fled religious persecution in Massachusetts to join this colony with the support of Roger Williams, its founder. Name this colony in New England with capital Providence.

The famous ritornello that begins this work switches to a syncopated rhythm before the solo violin enters with high trills and repeated notes to imitate a birdcall. This collection makes up the first third of The Contest Between Harmony and Invention and is an early example of program music, as the composer included sonnets describing the musical depictions such as a shepherd and sheepdog, thunderstorms, and an icy path. Name this set of concerti grossi for violin, string quartet, and basso continuo which includes "La Primavera," or "Spring," written by Antonio Vivaldi.

This pitcher's name is enshrined on the award given annually to the best pitchers in Major League Baseball, an honor first awarded in 1956. He holds the MLB record for most career wins, with an astounding 511 victories. He pitched for five different teams during his 22-season career, including the Cleveland Spiders and the Boston Americans (now Red Sox). He also holds the record for most career losses, with 316 losses, a testament to his longevity and the different era in which he played. Who is this legendary pitcher, whose name has become synonymous with pitching excellence?

This reality competition show, where aspiring fashion designers compete, features a signature catchphrase, "One day you're in, and the next day you're out," spoken by its longtime host. The show's challenges, which often involve unconventional materials and tight deadlines, test the designers' creativity and technical skills. Its judges, including Nina Garcia, Heidi Klum, and Michael Kors, have become fashion icons in their own right. What is the name of this long-running Bravo series, which has launched the careers of successful designers like Christian Siriano and Mondo Guerra?

This man destroyed the Sacred Band of Thebes while leading the cavalry wing of his father's army at Chaeronea. One of his castles was known as the Castle of the White Demon, and in one siege, he built a mile-long causeway to transport siege engines. In one battle, he surprised King Pyros at the Hydaspes River with his horse Bucephalus. After his death, Diadochi ruled his empire, which was split among his many generals. He defeated the King Darius at the Battles of Gaugemela and Issus. Name this son of Philip of Macedon who founded a Hellenistic Empire.

One sub-range in this mountain range's northern section is the Tatra Mountains. This range's highest point is Gerlach Peak, and it forms the northern, eastern, and southern borders of Transylvania. The Iron Gates gorge on the Danube River separates this range from the Balkan Mountains. Name this mountain range in Eastern Europe that runs primarily through Slovakia, Poland, the Ukraine, and Romania.

This man was recently confirmed to become secretary of defense in Donald Trump's administration. He served as a national guardsman at Guantánamo Bay and in Iraq and Afghanistan. Since 2014, he has been a political commentator for Fox News and a weekend co-host of Fox & Friends from 2017 to 2024. He was previously the executive director of Vets for Freedom and Concerned Veterans for America. Name this veteran and television personality.

This musician's iconic song, "One Love," with its message of peace and unity, became a global anthem, covered by artists worldwide and adopted by Amnesty International as a symbol of human rights.  His Rastafarian faith, reflected in his music and lifestyle, promoted social justice, equality, and a connection to nature.  He popularized reggae music, blending Jamaican folk rhythms with elements of ska and rocksteady.  Who is this legendary musician, whose music continues to inspire and uplift people around the world?

One of this country's ships accidentally killed three British fisherman in the Dogger Bank incident. When this country was denied use of the Suez Canal in 1904, it launched a months-long journey around Africa to reinforce its Pacific Fleet; this country then lost much of its navy in the Battle of Tsushima Straits against Japan and had its admiral, Zinovy Rozhestvensky, taken prisoner. Name this country whose navy received orders from Moscow.

From this state's city of Medford, one can visit a lava formation known as the Upper and Lower Table Rock. A fungus located in this state is said to be the world's largest organism. A national park in this state is named after a feature that formed from the caldera of Mount Mazama. The Willamette river valley is home to a large portion of this state's population. That valley includes its largest city, from which one can see Mount Hood. This state is home to Crater Lake. Name this state south of Washington, home to cities such as Eugene, Salem, and Portland.

Beings of this type include the six-headed Thrudgelmir, his flood-surviving son Bergelmir, and the half-angel Nephilim of the Bible. Ymir was a primordial one of these beings in Norse myth, of whom Thor crushed one named Hrungnir, and the term jotunn often refers to their "frost" type. Greek ones included Orion and a bronze one named Talos. Name these large mythological beings which include the antagonist of Jack and the Beanstalk and Goliath.

This midfielder, renowned for his exceptional passing accuracy and vision, holds the record for the most appearances for FC Barcelona, with 767 appearances for the club. He was a key figure in Barcelona's dominant era under Pep Guardiola, winning numerous trophies, including four Champions League titles and eight La Liga titles. He also played a pivotal role in Spain's victories at the 2010 World Cup and the 2008 and 2012 European Championships.  Who is this Spanish football legend who managed Barcelona from 2021-24?

The FDA has ordered a ban on a dye of this color in food. The dye's No. 3 variant has been shown to cause cancer in rats. This color, associated with passion and excitement, is the color of the iconic double-decker buses in London. It is also the color of the traditional phone booths in the United Kingdom and the mailboxes in the United States. In nature, it is the color of ripe strawberries, tomatoes, and roses. What is this color, located at the end of the visible light spectrum?

This ship's captain, Christopher Jones, and his crew stayed with this ship's passengers through a brutal winter in Cape Cod. This ship took on passengers from the Speedwell before crossing the Atlantic. Name this ship that brought the Pilgrims to Plymouth Colony in 1620.

Because helium has a lower value for this property than normal air, your voice sounds higher in helium. Strangely, ice has a lower value for this property than water, whereas most solids have a higher value for this property than their liquid forms. This property of matter will cause an object to float or sink compared to the water it is placed into. Name this property of matter which is calculated by dividing mass by volume.

An election to this post in 1855 took 133 ballots to declare a winner, Nathaniel Banks. James Polk was the only holder of this post to later become president. The Contract with America was written by a holder of this post, Newt Gingrich. Holders of this post sign impeachment articles before delivery to the Senate, and are second in the line of succession. Name this post currently held by Mike Johnson.
answers: US Speaker of the House of Reps
Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
incorrect3: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court

question: Planck's constant is divided by this quantity to find a particle's wavelength in the de Broglie relation. In Noether's theorem, this quantity is conserved as a result of translational invariance. Impulse is a change in this quantity, which is conserved in collisions. According to Newton's second law, force is the time derivative of this quantity. Name this quantity, symbolized p, which is equal to mass times velocity.

A holiday celebrating this man was observed on January 20, 2025. This civil rights leader was assassinated in 1968 in Memphis, Tennessee, where he had traveled to support a sanitation workers' strike. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964 for his nonviolent resistance to racial segregation. His iconic "I Have a Dream" speech, delivered during the 1963 March on Washington, called for an end to racism and envisioned a future of equality. Who was this influential figure in the American civil rights movement?

This man was recently elected into baseball's Hall of Fame. This player, who achieved the rare feat of recording 200 hits in ten consecutive seasons, holds the record for the most career hits in professional baseball, with a combined 4,367 hits in Japan and Major League Baseball.  He won the American League MVP award in 2001, his rookie season with the Seattle Mariners, becoming the first Japanese position player to win the award.  He is known for his unique batting stance, with his bat held high above his head, and his exceptional throwing arm from right field.  Who is this legendary outfielder, who retired in 2019 after a 19-year MLB career?

Geographic features of this country include the Rann of Kutch and the Thar Desert. This country owns the Andaman and Nicobar Islands and the Lakshadweep Islands as union territories. Several mountain ranges pass through this country, including the Hindu Kush and Himalayas. The Ganges is this country's longest river. Name this country with a capital at New Delhi.
