The protagonist of this author's most famous novel is kidnapped by Tralfamadorians to be put in a zoo, and survives the firebombing of Dresden in the title structure. Billy Pilgrim becomes unstuck in time in what author's novel Slaughterhouse-Five?

This quantity equals the square root of the product two, times mass, times kinetic energy. It's not force, but according to Newton's Second Law, the rate of change of this quantity equals mass times acceleration. Rockets generate thrust after ejecting mass, since this quantity is conserved. Impulse equals the change in this quantity. Name this quantity equal to mass times velocity.

This musician's deep, resonant voice and somber stage presence earned him the nickname "The Man in Black." His rebellious attitude and outlaw image were solidified by his live recordings at Folsom Prison and San Quentin State Prison. His hit songs, including "A Boy Named Sue," "Ring of Fire," and "I Walk the Line," have become country music classics. Name this influential figure who helped shape the sound of country and folk music.

In 1934, the controversial construction of the Parker Dam on this river required the National Guard to muster the Arizona Navy. Dams on this river form the Glen Canyon Dam and Lake Mead, which is formed by the Hoover Dam. Name this river of the American West that flows through the Grand Canyon and starts in the Rocky Mountains of its namesake state.

The term "War Hawk" was first used to describe supporters of this war, and during the lead up to this war the Chesapeake-Leopard affair led to outrage over impressment. Despite the signing of the Treaty of Ghent, Andrew Jackson fought a battle at New Orleans in this war. During one event in this war, Dolly Madison was forced to flee the capital. Name this war during which the British burned Washington D.C.

In this city, Wissahickon Creek goes through Fairmount Park. This city can be entered by crossing the Delaware River on the Betsy Ross Bridge. One of its buildings, where the Second Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence, is Independence Hall. The Liberty Bell is found in what city in Pennsylvania?

Early in this man's administration, he fired the entire White House Travel Office. He allegedly made an illegal loan to Susan McDougal, a partner in a land deal named Whitewater, and in another case, Linda Tripp provided evidence of perjury that led this President to be impeached by the House. An inappropriate relationship with Monica Lewinsky blemished the legacy of what U.S. President, the husband of Hillary Rodham?

This holiday was observed on February 17, 2025 in the United States. The holiday was initially established in 1879 to celebrate George Washington's birthday, which falls on February 22nd. It is observed on the third Monday of February, coinciding with Abraham Lincoln's birthday on February 12th. It is often celebrated with sales and special promotions by retailers, making it a popular shopping weekend. Name this federal holiday that honors all U.S. presidents.

This sport is hosting an inagural Four Nations tournament between USA, Canada, Sweden, and Finland. The sport's first organized indoor game was played in Montreal, Canada, in 1875. The sport's iconic trophy, the Stanley Cup, is the oldest professional sports trophy in North America. Its origins trace back to Canada in the 19th century, where it was played on frozen lakes and ponds. What is this sport, often referred to as "the fastest game on ice"?

This kingdom was first unified after the Battle of Kawela and a battle atop Pali Lookout, which were won by a ruler of this country who built the "Brick Palace" in Lahaina. William Hooper established the first sugar plantation in this country, the site of the 1888 Wilcox Rebellion. Lorrin Thurston wrote this country's Bayonet Constitution before overthrowing its government and establishing Sanford Dole as president. Kamehameha and Lili'uokalani led what kingdom ruled from Iolani Palace in Honolulu?

One of these creatures named Ladon guarded the golden apples of the Hesperides. A Babylonian one of these creatures known as Tiamat was slain by Marduk. One in Norse mythology was named Fafnir and was slain for his gold. Puff is a "magic" example of what kind of legendeary reptile that breathed fire and was allegedly slain by Saint George?

This actor appeared as Uncle Sam in Kendrick Lamar's Super Bowl halftime show. This actor's distinctive voice and commanding presence have made him a sought-after figure in Hollywood, with a career spanning over four decades. He has appeared in numerous iconic films, from Quentin Tarantino's "Pulp Fiction" to the Marvel Cinematic Universe, where he portrays Nick Fury. Who is this versatile and celebrated actor?

This force causes the type of redshift observed in the Pound-Rebka experiment. This effect is responsible for tides, and its namesake constant was first approximated using a torsion balance by Henry Cavendish, who found it to be close to 6.67 times 10 to the negative 11 newton-meters squared per kilogram squared. On Earth, the acceleration due to is approximately 9.8 meters per second squared. Name this exclusively attractive force that was "discovered" by Newton after an apple fell on his head.

This city hosted the 2025 NBA All-Star Game which featured a new mini-tournament format. This city hosted the 1906 Summer Olympics, which were originally scheduled for Chicago but were moved due to the devastating earthquake and fire that struck the city earlier that year. The "Sneaker Wars" of the 1980s, fueled by the city's basketball culture and the popularity of Nike shoes, led to a surge in shoe-related crime. The city's iconic Candlestick Park, once home to both the Giants and the 49ers, was demolished in 2015, making way for a new housing development. What is the name of this city, known for its rich sporting history and passionate fans?

This animal's Merino breed is common in New Zealand, where the population of these animals outnumber humans six to one. The first species to be successfully cloned by humans was one of these animals named Dolly. This animal's meat is cooked into mutton, and sleeping children may be told to imagine these animals jumping over a fence. Name these farm animals often sheared to harvest their wool.

President Donald Trump talked to this foreign leader on the phone with the aim of starting peace negotiations over a war in eastern Europe. His grandfather was a personal cook to Vladimir Lenin and Joseph Stalin. This man worked as a KGB foreign intelligence officer for 16 years. He was president from 2000-2008 and was relected in 2012. Name this leader of Russia.

Al Smith's adherence to this faith may have caused his election loss to Herbert Hoover. Prejudice against Italian immigrants to America was partially driven by their adherence to this faith, along with Irish-American immigrants such as the Kennedys. In 2020, Joe Biden became the second president in American history to be a member of what "Roman" Christian denomination?

The Gulf of Tonkin incident was used by the Johnson administration to escalate America's involvement in this war. Agent Orange was used during this war as part of a campaign that also targeted Cambodia and Laos. In the aftermath of this war, the losing side's capital at Saigon was renamed Ho Chi Minh City. Name this war in which the United States failed to prevent the spread of communism to a Southeast Asian nation.

In 2007, a bridge carrying I-35 over this river near Saint Anthony Falls collapsed. This river begins at Lake Itasca, and later flows through cities such as Memphis and St. Louis. The Ohio River and Missouri River flow into this river, which flows into the Gulf of Mexico near New Orleans. Name this longest river in the United States, which shares its name with a Southern state.

This show is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year. This show's first episode, hosted by George Carlin, aired on October 11, 1975, with a cast that included Chevy Chase, John Belushi, and Gilda Radner. Its original opening sketch featured Chase introducing himself as the show's first "Weekend Update" anchor. The show's catchphrase, "Live from New York, it's Saturday Night!", has become synonymous with its late-night comedy format. The show's musical performances have featured iconic artists like the Rolling Stones, Prince, and Taylor Swift. What is the name of this long-running show that has launched the careers of numerous comedians and actors?

This goddess may have conceived children by eating lettuce. This "cow-eyed" goddess had a wagon pulled by peacocks. She sent a gadfly to sting a cow who had escaped from the hundred-eyed monster Argus. That cow, Io, was one of the women seduced by her philandering husband. Name this queen of the Olympians and wife of Zeus.

This mountain range lies above the world's largest rail tunnel, the Gotthard tunnel, which opened in 2016. A subrange of these mountains reaches into Slovenia and is named for Julius Caesar. The Saint Bernard Pass cuts through this mountain range in a ridge between Monte Rosa and Mont Blanc, its two highest peaks. The Matterhorn is in what European mountain range that is primarily in France, Italy, and Switzerland?

This annual cycling race, known as the "Grand Boucle" (meaning "the big loop"), covers over 3,000 kilometers (1,864 miles) across France, incorporating various terrains like mountains, flatlands, and cobbled roads. It is one of the three Grand Tours, alongside the Giro d'Italia and the Vuelta a España. The leader of the race wears a distinctive yellow jersey, symbolizing the overall standings. What is the name of this grueling yet prestigious race, considered the most prestigious in professional cycling?

As rocket fuel, the metastable metallic form of this element would produce a specific impulse 3 times greater than the Space Shuttle main engine. The fuel hydrazine features four atoms of this element surrounding a pair of nitrogen atoms, and the external tank of a Space Shuttle held liquid forms of oxygen and this diatomic gas. The most abundant element in the universe is what element with atomic number 1 and atomic symbol H?

This president sent troops to clear out the Bonus Army. Homeless people built communities named after this president after the Great Depression occurred during his term in 1929. Name this president whose term also included the beginning stages of building the dam named for him.

This ruler legendarily dissolved the world's largest pearl in vinegar, then drank it to win a bet. A carpet was used to sneak this ruler into the headquarters of Julius Caesar. After losing the Battle of Actium, this ruler supposedly asked for and received a basket of figs, which hid an asp that she then used to commit suicide. Name this Egyptian pharaoh, the lover of Julius Caesar and Marc Antony.

This folk singer and activist's performance of "We Shall Overcome" at the 1963 March on Washington became an anthem of the civil rights movement. Her a cappella rendition of "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot" at the 1969 Woodstock festival showcased her powerful voice and social activism. Her close friendship with Bob Dylan introduced her to a wider audience and led to collaborations on songs like "Blowin' in the Wind." Name this influential figure in folk music and social activism, known for her distinctive voice and commitment to peace and justice.

Some of his lesser known works are Gertrude and Demian. In one of his novels, the protagonist joins the monastic Order of Castalia after being found by the Magister Musicae. That protagonist is taught in Waldzell and after Thomas von der Trave dies, becomes Magister Ludi. In another of this author's novels, the protagonist goes to the Black Eagle Tavern and meets Hermine whom he later stabs. Identify this author who wrote of Joseph Knecht in The Glass Bead Game and of Harry Haller in Steppenwolf.

Linda McMahon, a former professional wrestling performer and President Donald Trump's pick to lead this US Department, recently finished her Senate confirmation hearing. This US Cabinet department's roots trace back to 1867 when a department with the same name was founded, but only lasted a year. President Jimmy Carter signed the bill creating this department in 1979. It oversees federal student aid programs, including grants and loans, and collects data on America's schools to guide policy and funding decisions. Name this department that is which was recently led by Miguel Cardona, and is often in the news regarding student loan forgiveness.
incorrect1: Department of Health and Human Services

question: During this event, participants run back and forth between two hills to commemorate one woman's search for water. One ritual in this event takes place on the Jamarat Bridge, where large crowds can cause participants to be trampled; that ritual is the "Stoning of the Devil." Participants in this event must be in a state of ihram, which involves wearing distinctive white garments. A central ritual in this event is tawaf, or circling the Kaaba. Name this pilgrimage to Mecca that one of the Five Pillars of Islam.

One leader of this country when asked how far he would go to maintain order responded well, just watch me. After giving that statement that leader invoked the use of the War Measures Act to bring an end to the October Crisis. In this country's namesake caper it participated in a joint operation with the CIA to rescue six American Diplomats from Iran. Name this North American country whose capital city is Ottawa.

This river is the location of the reservoir Lake Nasser, formed by the Aswan High Dam being built on this river. This river has two major tributaries that are named the "Blue" and "White". Those rivers converge at Khartoum, the capital of Sudan, and the "White" begins at Lake Victoria in Uganda. Name this African river which often flooded to bring nutrients to the farms of ancient Egypt, the longest river in the world.

This cult classic comedy, filmed in Aurora, Illinois, features a memorable scene where the protagonists, Wayne and Garth, headbang to Queen's "Bohemian Rhapsody" in their iconic "Mirthmobile." The film's catchphrases, like "Party on!" and "Excellent!" have become ingrained in popular culture. The film's low-budget aesthetic and self-referential humor contributed to its surprise success, grossing over $183 million worldwide. Name this 1992 film that spawned a sequel and solidified Mike Myers and Dana Carvey as comedy stars.

Along with Egbert Benson, he was the representative of New York at the Annapolis Convention, and he wrote the First Report on Public Credit while serving in the position he is best known for. "Ambition must be made to counteract ambition" is a quote from the fifty-first of the eighty-five essays published under the pseudonym Publius that this man wrote along with Madison and Jay. Killed by the third vice president, he was the main author of the Federalist papers. This was what first secretary of the treasury who was shot in a duel by Aaron Burr.

The US Justice Department filed to have this politician's corruption case dropped. Multiple federal attorneys and Justice Department officials resigned after they were asked to help file for the charges to be dropped. Multiple of this man's top aides also resigned due to his re-alignment on immigration policy to align with President Trump. Name this former Brooklyn Borough President and current mayor of New York.

These organisms have sclerocytes that generate their spicules, part of their asconoid or syconoid bodies. Made of a gelatinous substance called mesohyl, these organisms are the only animals to display no symmetry, and all examples are sessile in adulthood. They feed from the water that flows through their osculum; in many cases, that flow is generated by flagellated cells called choanocytes. Name these simplest animals that make up phylum porifera.

This organization, founded in 1906, oversees and regulates student athletics at over 1,100 colleges and universities in the United States. Its headquarters are located in Indianapolis, Indiana. The organization hosts over 90 championships in various sports each year, including the popular March Madness basketball tournament.  The organization's "Power Five" conferences included the ACC, Big Ten, Big 12, Pac-12, and SEC, but have recently undergone a shake-up. What is the name of this governing body for college athletics?

This state is home to a Robert Smithson-designed earthwork sculpture titled Spiral Jetty. Sandstone landforms such as the Fiery Furnace and the Organ can be found in this state's Arches National Park. The transcontinental railroad was officially completed in Promontory Summit in this state. Its capital hosted the 2002 Winter Olympics. Name this Western state that contains the Great Salt Lake.

Henry Clinton predicted that a few more battles like this one would "put an end to British dominion in America," since over 100 officers were killed or wounded here. In this battle, William Howe ordered cannons on Copp's Hill to fire on the Americans. The legendary quote "don't fire until you see the whites of their eyes" was given during what Revolutionary War battle fought outside Boston, mostly on Breed's Hill, near the beginning of the war?

Notes in the sheet music for these works describe a "languor caused by heat" and note that "the drunkards have fallen asleep." Sonnets that accompany this section of The Contest Between Harmony and Invention describe "leafy branches" and "icy snow." In these works, a string soloist imitates nature imagery like birdsong and rain. Name this set of violin concertos by Antonio Vivaldi that depict Spring, Summer, Fall, and Winter.

This property is the defining characteristic of an Abelian group. Composition of functions and matrix multiplication do not generally have this property. Subtraction also does not have this property because 8 minus 5 is 3, but 5 minus 8 is negative 3. Name this property that states a+b=b+a, that is, that swapping the order of the numbers does not change the result.

This film recently took home the top award from the BAFTAs. This film, directed by Edward Berger, is based on the novel of the same name by Robert Harris. It features a fictional behind-the-scenes look at the election of a new pope, a process shrouded in secrecy and tradition. The film's ensemble cast includes Jonathan Pryce, Anthony Hopkins, and Ralph Fiennes. What is the title of this 2024 historical drama?

This video game company, founded in 1982, is known for its popular sports franchises, including Madden NFL, FIFA, and NHL. Its headquarters are located in Redwood City, California. The company's Sports division has revolutionized sports gaming with its realistic graphics and immersive gameplay.  Its controversial "loot box" monetization strategy, where players can purchase virtual items with real money, has drawn criticism and legal challenges. What is the name of this gaming giant, whose franchises have become synonymous with sports gaming?

In 1888, this country's Princess Imperial emancipated all of its slaves with the Golden Law. This country allied with Uruguay and Argentina during the War of the Triple Alliance. This country's monarchs were given the honorific Dom, and included Pedro I and II. Name this South American country with cities like Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, which contains most of the Amazon rainforest.

This NFL team, established in 1919, is the only community-owned franchise in the league. The team's colors are green and gold, and they have won four Super Bowl championships, including the first two Super Bowls. Their passionate fanbase is known as "Cheeseheads," who often wear foam cheese-shaped hats to games. What is the name of this team, whose home stadium is Lambeau Field in Wisconsin?

This NBA team's home arena, Fiserv Forum, opened in 2018 and features a unique zinc-paneled exterior that shimmers in the sunlight.  Their logo, featuring a stylized deer with outstretched antlers, is a nod to the state's wildlife. They have won two NBA championships, the first in 1971 with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Oscar Robertson, and the second in 2021 with Giannis Antetokounmpo. What is the name of this team, whose green and cream colors represent the state's lush landscapes?

One law based on this effect was challenged by Olbers, who claimed the universe was static and did not expand. Light undergoes chromatic aberration at velocities near the speed of light due to the relativistic form of this effect. Edwin Hubble used this effect to explain why some galaxies will never be visible from Earth. This effect explains why the sound of the siren of an ambulance passing a stationary observer will decrease as it passes them, an example of blueshift or reverse redshift. Name this effect which governs how a perceived frequency changes depending on the relative velocity of the source.

This app was recently added back to the App and Google Play Stores after being removed. This social media platform, known for its short-form videos and viral trends, has faced scrutiny over data privacy and security concerns, particularly regarding its ownership by a Chinese company. Its algorithm, which personalizes content based on user interactions, has been praised for its effectiveness in keeping users engaged. It has launched the careers of numerous influencers and creators, who have amassed millions of followers. What is the name of this app, which has become a cultural phenomenon, especially among younger generations?

A "Southern" group with this name contains Aoraki, or Mount Cook, in New Zealand. Karl Blodig climbed all major "four-thousanders" in the European range of this name. Lakes Lucerne and Geneva, as well as the origins of the Rhone and the Rhine Rivers, are found in this range. Mont Blanc and the Matterhorn are tall peaks in what mountain range on the border between Switzerland and Italy?

The first black woman with this job, Bessie Coleman, died in a 1926 accident. A man with this job had his son kidnapped by Bruno Hauptmann in the "Crime of the Century." Fred Noonan assisted a woman with this job during a trip in which they both disappeared near Howland Island. The "Spirit of St. Louis" was used by a man with what job of Charles Lindbergh and Amelia Earhart?

This 2008 comedy, directed by Adam McKay, features a memorable scene where the two middle-aged protagonists, Brennan Huff and Dale Doback, engage in a destructive drum battle in their family's living room. The film's quotable lines, like "Did we just become best friends?", have become ingrained in popular culture. The film's success led to an animated spin-off series and talks of a sequel. Name this buddy comedy starring Will Ferrell and John C. Reilly as two immature stepbrothers forced to live together.

An often excerpted "Chaconne" is part of J.S. Bach's Six Sonatas and Partitas for this instrument. Pieces nicknamed "The Hunt" and "The Devil's Laughter" are a part of Nicolo Paganini's 24 Caprices written for this instrument. The concertmaster of an orchestra plays this four-stringed instrument that is smaller than a viola. What is the highest-pitched string instrument in an orchestra?

One ruler of this modern-day country had his dead body concealed in a fish cart so his chancellor could forge his will. This country adopted Legalism and book-burning under a ruler who was buried with the Terracotta Army. This country was first unified by Shi Huangdi, whose dynasty was overthrown by the Han. Name this country, whose Qin dynasty began construction of the Great Wall.

This first-person shooter game, released in 1993, revolutionized the genre with its fast-paced action, 3D graphics, and violent gameplay. Its protagonist, a space marine, battles hordes of demons from Hell, utilizing weapons like the shotgun, chainsaw, and BFG 9000. Its shareware release model, which allowed players to try the first episode for free, contributed to its widespread popularity and influence. What is the name of this groundbreaking game, which spawned a franchise and inspired numerous other first-person shooters?

According to an impossible legend, after this thinker heard blacksmith hammers, he discovered the mathematical relationships behind musical tuning. A ten-dot triangle was sacred to the followers of this thinker, who supposedly drowned a man who discovered an irrational number. Name this ancient Greek philosopher who names a theorem about the side lengths of right triangles, commonly written as a squared plus b squared equals c squared.

A plane created by the company Boom reached this speed. The plane, XB-1, is the first privately developed aircraft to reach this speed. This speed, which is faster than the speed of sound, is measured in Mach numbers, with Mach 1 representing the speed of sound at a given altitude and temperature. The Concorde, a passenger jet that operated from 1976 to 2003, could travel at Mach 2, crossing the Atlantic Ocean in under 3.5 hours.  Chuck Yeager, an American test pilot, became the first person to break the sound barrier in level flight in 1947, flying the experimental Bell X-1 aircraft.  What is this speed, which creates a sonic boom when an object travels through the air faster than sound waves can propagate?

This function gives the y-coordinate of a point rotated from standard position along the unit circle. This odd function, which passes through the origin and has a period of two pi, is the reciprocal of cosecant. For an acute angle in a right triangle, it is the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse. Name this trigonometric function, which gives the tangent function when divided by cosine.

This golfer's signature drink, a blend of iced tea and lemonade, became a popular refreshment and a testament to his widespread appeal. He was known for his aggressive playing style and his charismatic personality, which earned him the nickname "The King" and a devoted following known as "Arnie's Army." He won seven major championships, including four Masters Tournaments. Who is this legendary golfer, who helped popularize the sport and inspire generations of players?

One deity of these natural entities pursued the nymph Arethusa. In one myth, two of these called Alpheus and Peneus were used to help Hercules complete his fifth labor with the Augean stables. One of these consisting of fire was called Phlegethon. Drinking from one of these caused forgetfulness, and Charon ferried people across one of these entities. The Lethe and Styx are examples of what type of geographic feature with running water?

Bikku Bitti, the highest peak in this country, is located in the Tibesti Mountains on this nation's border with Chad. This country's eastern region of Cyrenaica contains its namesake desert, which extends into Egypt in the east and makes up the northeastern part of the Sahara. Bordering the Mediterranean Sea, this country is found to the east of Tunisia and Algeria. Name this North African nation whose capital is Tripoli.

Twenty-one soldiers crossed the Canadian border and robbed three banks in St. Albans, Vermont during this war. This conflict's western theater ended after the Battle of Glorieta Pass. Great Britain paid damages to the victor of this war in the Alabama claims. One side of this war reduced the other's cotton exports by following Winfield Scott's Anaconda plan, which was completed after a naval battle that allegedly saw the line "damn the torpedoes." David Farragut won the battle of Mobile Bay in what war against the Confederacy?

A plane operated by this airline's subsidiary crashed and flipped after landing in Toronto. Nobody was killed and the airline has offered every passenger $30,000. This airline's hub at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the world's busiest airport, handling over 100 million passengers annually. It was founded in 1924 as Huff Daland Dusters, a crop-dusting company, before transitioning to passenger flights in 1929. It is a founding member of the SkyTeam airline alliance, which includes airlines like Air France-KLM and Korean Air. What is the name of this major American airline, known for its extensive network and its focus on customer service?

This general ordered William Shippen to inoculate all troops against variola, and used fog as cover to evacuate his troops to Manhattan after the Battle of Brooklyn Heights. A force of Hessian mercenaries were routed by this man in a surprise attack after Christmas Day, 1776. Name this Commander in Chief of the Continental Army and first President of the United States.

This iconic video game character's shape is based on a pizza with a slice missing. Its "wakka wakka" sound effect, created by the game's sound designer, has become synonymous with the character and the game.  The game was a massive success upon its release in 1980, becoming a cultural phenomenon and spawning numerous sequels, spin-offs, and merchandise.  What is the name of this arcade classic, where the player navigates a maze, eating dots and avoiding ghosts?

Litharge, an oxide of this element, is a component of fine crystal. This final element in the uranium decay chain was once used as an antiknock agent added to gasoline. Patients undergoing an x-ray wear an apron with this element as shielding. This element's high toxicity prevents its modern use in paint and water pipes. Name this metallic element used in bullets, but not pencils, whose symbol is Pb.

Otto Skorzeny organized the rescue of this man from the Imperatore Hotel in the Gran Sasso raid. This man captured Addis Ababa during his reign, forcing the exile of the Ethiopian emperor. This dictator's National Fascist Party came to power after he led the Blackshirts during his March on Rome. Name this leader, also known as II Duce, who was the Italian Prime Minister from 1922 to 1943.

This athlete's remarkable performance at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics, where he won gold medals in both the pentathlon and decathlon, led King Gustav V of Sweden to proclaim him "the greatest athlete in the world." He played professional baseball and football, even playing alongside legendary baseball player Babe Ruth on the same team. His Olympic medals were stripped in 1913 due to a technicality regarding his amateur status, but were posthumously reinstated in 1983.  Who is this legendary athlete, considered one of the most versatile athletes of all time?

This city is home to the Heinz food company headquarters, and tourists often eat sandwiches dressed with coleslaw and fries at this city's Primanti Brothers. Steelworkers traditionally ate pierogis in this city, which sits at the confluence of the Monongahela, Allegheny, and Ohio rivers. Name this western Pennsylvania city, the state's second largest city after Philadelphia?

This god hung himself from Yggdrasil for nine days and nights in order to obtain the knowledge of runes. This owner of the spear Gungnir gives all his food to his wolves Geri and Freki and receives information about the world through his ravens Hugin and Munin. This husband of Frigg was known as the "Allfather" and will be killed at Ragnarok by the wolf Fenrir. Name this chief god of Norse mythology.

This NFL linebacker's ferocious pass-rushing skills and relentless pursuit of quarterbacks revolutionized the linebacker position, forcing offenses to adapt their blocking schemes. He won three NFL Defensive Player of the Year awards and was named NFL MVP in 1986, a rare feat for a defensive player. He played his entire 13-season career with the New York Giants, leading them to two Super Bowl victories. Who is this Hall of Fame linebacker, known for his explosive speed and his impact on the game?

The most winning woman he ever knew was hanged for poisoning three little children for their insurance-money. Irene Adler, always THE woman to this man, outwitted him during his investigation of "A Scandal in Bohemia." This man returned in "The Adventure of the Empty House" after battling Professor Moriarty to the death. Name this detective faithfully accompanied by John Watson.

Joseph Priestly liberated this element by heating the compound red mercury. This element's namesake reaction involves loss of electrons. The triatomic form of this element is called ozone, and its more common diatomic gas is needed to generate a candle flame. Name this element, a vital gas that is inhaled during respiration.

This musical's iconic song, "Defying Gravity," a powerful ballad about breaking free from societal expectations, has become a popular anthem for self-empowerment. The musical's story, based on the novel by Gregory Maguire, reimagines the classic story of "The Wizard of Oz" from the perspective of the Wicked Witch of the West. Its characters, including Elphaba, Glinda, and the Wizard, offer a nuanced and complex look at the traditional heroes and villains of the Oz universe. What is the name of this long-running Broadway musical, known for its stunning visuals, catchy songs, and thought-provoking story?

Justice Ward Hunt decided this woman's guilt before her trial began and told the jury to declare her guilty. In post-trial remarks, this woman argued that she had the "right to a voice" in government and threatened that she would never pay a one hundred dollar fine that was levied in June 1873. Name this American suffragist who was convicted of illegally voting, and who is honored on a one-dollar coin.

Bombolai Hill is the only volcano in this nation, which has its highest point at Low's Peak on Mt. Kinabalu. A city-state is separated from this nation by the Straits of Johor, and off its northwest coast is Penang Island. Its states of Sabah and Sarawak are separated from its capital, which is home to the Petronas Towers. Name this nation split between Borneo and its namesake peninsula, ruled from Kuala Lumpur.

This company passed Walmart in 4th quarter revenue for the first time, making it the largest company in the world by revenue. This company's headquarters, nicknamed "The Spheres," features three glass domes filled with over 40,000 plants from around the world, creating a unique work environment for its employees. Its annual Prime Day shopping event, launched in 2015, has become a major online sales phenomenon, rivaling Black Friday and Cyber Monday. Its founder, Jeff Bezos, originally envisioned the company as an online bookstore named Cadabra. What is the name of this multinational technology company, known for its e-commerce platform, cloud computing services, and digital streaming?

This man wanted to acquire Schleswig and Holstein so he started the Seven Weeks war and he sent the forged Ems Dispatch to France in order to start a war ended by the Treaty of Frankfurt. Dismissed by William II and hired by William I, he started a campaign against the Catholic church called the Kulturkampf and won the Franco-Prussian War. Notable for giving the Iron and Blood speech, this is what German Chancellor nicknamed the Iron Chancellor.

This species was infected with T2 phage DNA in the Hershey-Chase experiment. The lac and trp operons were first discovered in this species, which generates vitamin K for its hosts. Undercooked beef may be contaminated with this prokaryote that can divide every 20 minutes in a Petri dish. Name this Gram-negative, rod-shaped species that is normally found in the human large intestine, the most important bacterial model organism.

According to one myth from this country, there were originally ten suns, but nine of them were shot out of the sky by the archer Houyi. This country's traditional folklore features legendary figures called the Eight Immortals and a deity known as the Jade Emperor. Chang'e is the moon goddess of what country whose mythology was influenced by Confucianism and Taoism?

This baseball player's record-breaking streak of 2,632 consecutive games played, surpassing Lou Gehrig's long-standing record, earned him the nickname "Iron Man." He was a two-time American League MVP and a 19-time All-Star, playing his entire career with the Baltimore Orioles. He famously hit a home run in his final All-Star Game appearance in 2001, a memorable moment that capped off his illustrious career. Who is this Hall of Fame shortstop and third baseman, known for his durability, consistency, and leadership?

Amazon MGM movie studio recently acquired the rights to this famous British character. This fictional British Secret Service agent's preferred drink, a vodka martini, is famously ordered "shaken, not stirred." His gadgets, including a Walther PPK pistol and an Aston Martin DB5 equipped with ejector seats and machine guns, have become iconic symbols of the franchise. His code number, 007, signifies his license to kill in the line of duty. He has been portrayed by numerous actors, including Sean Connery, Roger Moore, and Daniel Craig. Who is this suave and sophisticated spy, created by author Ian Fleming?

This country's northernmost major island is home to the native Ainu people and the winter resort city of Sapporo. The southernmost of the prefectures dividing this country is named after the Ryukyu Archipelago. This country's city of Yokohama is located in the world's most populous metro area, which is on its largest island, Honshu. The islands of Hokkaido and Okinawa are controlled by what country, which is governed from Tokyo?

This writer noted that "Tyranny, like Hell, is not easily conquered" in the opening paragraph of a work that opens "These are the times that try men's souls." This author of The Crisis wrote an "Investigation of True and Fabulous Theology" that advocated deism, as well as a 1776 work that argued for independence from Britain. Name this early American pamphleteer who wrote The Age of Reason and Common Sense.

This event was caused by a drought combined with the failure of farmers to use methods such as crop rotation. It caused thousands of "Okies" to migrate to California. Name this weather event that often caused black clouds to appear over the Great Plains in the 1930s.

This musical's Jellicle Ball, a dazzling spectacle of dance and song, is the central event where the Jellicle cats gather to celebrate their unique identities. The musical's song "Memory," a poignant ballad about longing and regret, has become a beloved standard, performed by numerous artists. Its costumes and makeup, designed to transform the actors into feline creatures, are a distinctive feature of the show. What is the name of this Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, based on T.S. Eliot's poetry collection "Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats"?

During this event, Attorney General Elliot Richardson and Deputy Attorney General William Ruckelshaus resigned in the Saturday Night Massacre. It attempted to cover up C.R.E.E.P.'s attempt to bug the Democratic Party headquarters. It was uncovered by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein with the help of Deep Throat. What scandal caused President Nixon to resign following his reelection?

This multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) game, where two teams of five players battle to destroy each other's base, features a diverse cast of over 160 champions, each with unique abilities and playstyles. Its ranked mode allows players to compete against others of similar skill levels, climbing the ladder to reach the top. Its annual World Championship, a global esports event with millions of viewers, showcases the highest level of competitive play. What is the name of this popular game, developed and published by Riot Games?

This quarterback's iconic "fake spike" play, where he pretended to spike the ball to stop the clock but instead threw a game-winning touchdown pass, became a legendary moment in NFL history. He holds the NFL record for most passing yards and touchdowns in a single season, a feat he accomplished in 1984. He played his entire 17-season career with the Miami Dolphins, leading them to the Super Bowl in 1985. Who is this Hall of Fame quarterback, known for his quick release and his accuracy as a passer?

One novel by this author details an encounter between an escaped convict and the protagonist, who is later supposedly sent by Miss Havisham to become a gentleman. A street urchin created by this author is discovered to be the half­brother of Monks after joining with Fagin's gang. Name this author who, along with writing Great Expectations and Oliver Twist, created the character Ebenezer Scrooge in his A Christmas Carol.

This thinker's wife Harriet Taylor aided his defense of gender equality in The Subjection of Women. He cited Alexis de Tocqueville's phrase "tyranny of the majority" and advocated the harm principle in defending one book's title concept, and argued that actions should be judged by "the proportion to which they promote happiness" in a work named for a moral system founded by Jeremy Bentham. Name this author of On Liberty and Utilitarianism.

This public figure was hospitalized with pneumonia and experienced kidney failure. This religious leader became the first pope from the Americas and the first from the Southern Hemisphere. He is known for his emphasis on social justice, environmental protection, and interfaith dialogue. He has written encyclicals on climate change and economic inequality, urging action to address these global challenges. Who is this head of the Catholic Church, born Jorge Mario Bergoglio in Argentina?

During the Civil War, this city was defended by Fort St. Philip and controversially occupied by Union general Benjamin Butler. The Sieur de Bienville led a group of French settlers here in 1718. This city's suburb of Metairie contains the southern end of the Lake Pontchartrain Causeway. Its Lower Ninth Ward was damaged when levees were weakened by a 2005 storm. What Louisiana city was devastated by Hurricane Katrina?

Colloidal particles of this element are attached to antibodies to stain in one form of electron microscopy, and this element that is purified in the Miller process is alloyed with silver in electrum. This element has the highest ductility and malleability of the transition metals. Geiger and Marsden shot alpha particles through a foil of this element in an experiment that led to the discovery of the atomic nucleus under Ernest Rutherford. Name this precious metal with chemical symbol Au.

This basketball legend's single-game scoring record of 100 points, achieved in 1962, remains one of the most remarkable feats in sports history. He also holds the record for most rebounds in a single game, with 55 rebounds. He led the NBA in scoring seven times and in rebounding eleven times, showcasing his dominance on both ends of the court.  He played for the Philadelphia/San Francisco Warriors, the Philadelphia 76ers, and the Los Angeles Lakers, winning two NBA championships. Who is this Hall of Fame center, known for his incredible athleticism and his larger-than-life personality?

This desert's Tibesti Mountains are home to the Toubou people. In the east of this desert, the salty Lake Turkana is threatened by a dam on the Omo River. The large-eared fennec fox lives in this desert, where two Grand Ergs lie in the rain shadow of the Atlas Mountains to its north. This desert is north of a transition zone that passes from Sudan to Mali called the Sahel. Name this African desert, the largest in the world.

In 1786, this state passed a Statute for Religious Freedom that its drafter prominently mentioned on his tombstone. This state's namesake university was founded as a secular school in response to weak leadership at the College of William and Mary. The estate of Monticello was built in this state by one of the eight US presidents to have been born in it. Name this largest of the thirteen original colonies, where Thomas Jefferson was once governor in Richmond.

Microsoft recently announced a breakthrough in this field with the announcement of their Majorana 1 chip. Unlike classical computers that use bits to represent information as 0s or 1s, the field uses qubits, which can represent 0, 1, or both simultaneously. This phenomenon, known as superposition, allows these computers to perform calculations exponentially faster than classical computers for certain types of problems.  What is this field of computer science based on the principles of quantum mechanics?

The Mollweide map projection preserves this quantity, which is given for solids of revolution by Pappus's first theorem. Gabriel's horn has an infinite amount of this quantity. It can be found "under a curve" via integration, and for triangles using the semiperimeter in Hero's formula. For a circle, pi r squared gives what quantity that for a rectangle is expressed as width times length?

This anime series' protagonist, whose Saiyan name is Kakarot, was sent to Earth as a baby to escape the destruction of his home planet.  His signature move, the Kamehameha, a powerful energy blast fired from his hands, has become one of the most recognizable attacks in anime history.  The series features epic battles against powerful villains, including Frieza, Cell, and Majin Buu.  What is the name of this popular anime series, which follows the adventures of Goku and his friends as they train in martial arts and protect the Earth from threats?

This man drove a chariot as the archer Pandarus was killed in it. He defeats the Rutulian leader Turnus, and enters a cave near Lake Avernus after the Golden Bough grants him safe passage in the Underworld. This hero had a boulder thrown at his pelvis by Diomedes, married Lavinia, and loved a queen of Carthage named Dido who he abandoned during his journey from Troy to Italy, where this son of Venus met the Latins. Name this hero of a Roman epic by Virgil.

This leader gave the name Second Polish War to his invasion of Russia, which included the Battle of Borodino. After losing the War of the Sixth Coalition, this general, who had previously won the Battle of Austerlitz, was exiled to Elba. This leader was more famously exiled afterwards to the island of Saint Helena after losing a battle to the Duke of Wellington. Name this French leader who lost the Battle of Waterloo.

More than 65% of this state's population lives in Maricopa County, and two of its biggest cities are Chandler and Glendale. The northeast part of this state includes most of the Navajo Nation, and this state contains the Painted Desert. Most of this state's islands are in Roosevelt Lake and Lake Mead, which is a reservoir behind Hoover Dam on the Colorado River. Identify this state home to the Grand Canyon, whose capital is Phoenix.

NASA is tracking one of these, called 2024 YR4, that it says had up to a 1.5 percent chance of hitting Earth. These celestial bodies, remnants from the early formation of the solar system, range in size from small pebbles to dwarf planets hundreds of miles in diameter. Most of them reside in a belt between Mars and Jupiter, but some have orbits that bring them close to Earth.  One such object, measuring about 10 kilometers in diameter, is believed to have caused the extinction of the dinosaurs 66 million years ago. What are these rocky objects that orbit the Sun?

This surfer's record of 11 world surfing championships, achieved between 1992 and 2011, solidified his status as the most successful surfer of all time. He is known for his innovative aerial maneuvers and his ability to read waves, adapting his style to different conditions. He founded a company which created a revolutionary artificial wave pool that produces perfect waves for surfing. He also co-founded Outerknown, a sustainable clothing company that focuses on environmentally friendly practices. Who is this surfing legend, who continues to compete at a high level even in his 50s?

This figure's actions led to the killing of 800 men in Susa over two days, and a festival commemorating this successor to Queen Vashti features the reading of this figure's Megillah, which describes her triumph over Haman. She used her influence over Xerxes to save the Jews, leading to a celebration named for the casting of lots. The triumph of Mordecai and what Jewish queen is celebrated with Purim?

This anime series' protagonist, who dreams of becoming Hokage, the leader of his village, has a powerful nine-tailed fox demon sealed within him.  His signature move, the Shadow Clone Jutsu, allows him to create multiple copies of himself to aid in battle.  The series follows his journey as he trains to become a ninja and faces challenges from rival villages and powerful enemies.  What is the name of this popular anime series, known for its action-packed battles and its exploration of themes like friendship, determination, and the power of believing in oneself?

This empire crumbled after the Battle of Nedao. These people, who originated east of the Volga in Scythia, also lost to Flavius Aetius at the 451 Battle of Chalons. One ruler of these people came to power after possibly murdering his brother Bleda; that leader was known as the "Scourge of God" for his cruelty. Name these nomadic people who frequently battled the Romans and were led by Atilla.

A five-month-long one of these events started in San Francisco and was an attempt to bring attention to the historical treatment of Native Americans. One of these events was led by Jacob Coxey after the Panic of 1893 caused widespread unemployment. In 1963, Martin Luther King led one of these events named for Jobs and Freedom, at the end of which he gave his "I have a Dream" speech. Name this act of walking to the capital of the United States.

The Philadelphia type of this structure results from a translocation error. Another example of these structures can condense into a Barr body. The centromere is important to the separation of these structures. They are organized by length in pictures called karyotypes, which can show the presence of a trisomy in people with Down syndrome. X and Y are the sex types of what DNA structures found in 23 pairs in human cells?

William Plumer prevented this man from becoming the second unanimously elected president in 1820. A policy created by this man was modified by the Roosevelt Corollary. This man launched a goodwill tour of America, causing a newspaper to declare that the country had entered an "Era of Good Feelings." Name this fifth President of the United States whose namesake doctrine limited European involvement in North America.

Early in this work, babies are given an electrical shock to condition them to dislike books and nature, part of the Bokanovsky Process. People in the work actively take Soma, a drug that provides instant gratification, and is integral to a solidarity service that worships Henry Ford attended by Bernard. This novel also features a man who reads the Complete Works of Shakespeare and the voice of Mustapha Mond. John the Savage is a prime example of modern man in what 1932 dystopian novel by Aldous Huxley?

This work suggests that all history is "the history of class struggles," and discusses the opposing classes of bourgeoisie and proletariat. A new ideology based on workers owning the means of production is described in what revolutionary pamphlet by Friedrich Engels and Karl Marx that inspired the politics of Soviet Russia?
answers: The Manifesto of the Communist Party

question: This state's city of Beaumont near Port Arthur is home to Spindletop, the site of a 1901 discovery that triggered an economic boom. Geologists in this state have a hard time studying its Barnett Shale, a formation with massive natural gas reserves, because it lies underneath a sprawling metroplex that includes Plano and Fort Worth. Name this southern US state where the oil industry grew the cities of Dallas and Houston.

This religious event began on the evening of February 28, 2025. This holy month in the Islamic calendar, observed by Muslims worldwide as a month of fasting, prayer, reflection, and community, concludes with the joyous festival of Eid al-Fitr. During this month, Muslims abstain from food and drink from dawn until sunset, a practice known as Sawm. The Quran, Islam's holy book, is believed to have been first revealed to the Prophet Muhammad during this month, a night known as Laylat al-Qadr, or the "Night of Power." What is the name of this month, the ninth month of the Islamic calendar?

This actor died in February 2025. This actor's portrayal of the tough and determined Popeye Doyle in the 1971 film "The French Connection" earned him an Academy Award for Best Actor and became one of his most iconic roles. He also starred in the 1992 Western "Unforgiven," which won the Academy Award for Best Picture and earned him a second Oscar, this time for Best Supporting Actor. He served in the United States Marine Corps for four and a half years before pursuing his acting career. Who is this actor, known for his versatile performances in films like "The Conversation," "Hoosiers," and "The Royal Tenenbaums"?

The aliquot sequence is constant for these numbers, whose examples other than the first one have digital root 1. Currently-known examples of them are in one-to-one correspondence with Mersenne prime numbers, and there are a number of restrictions on-- but no proof about--the existence of odd versions of these numbers. Equaling the sum of its proper divisors give this type of number whose first two examples are 6 and 28.

This basketball legend recently announced her retirement. This player, known for her clutch performances and her fiery competitiveness, is the WNBA's all-time leading scorer, showcasing her longevity and scoring prowess. She has won three WNBA championships with the Phoenix Mercury and a record six Olympic gold medals with the U.S. national team. She played college basketball at the University of Connecticut, where she won three national championships under legendary coach Geno Auriemma. Who is this basketball legend, often considered one of the greatest female basketball players of all time?

This leader attempted to escape from Beaurevoir Castle by jumping out of a seventy-foot tower into a dry moat. Because heresy only carried the death penalty if it was a repeat offense, this woman was charged with cross-dressing so that she could be burned at the stake. This woman told the future Charles VII that she was on a divine mission, prompting him to send her to relieve the Siege of Orl´eans. Name this French peasant girl who became a hero during the Hundred Years War.

This man announced a run for New York City mayor in an attempt to return to politics. This politician, who served as the 56th Governor of New York, comes from a prominent political family, following in the footsteps of his father, Mario, who also served as governor of New York. He gained national attention for his daily briefings during the COVID-19 pandemic. His governorship ended in 2021 after multiple allegations of sexual harassment surfaced. Who is this former governor, known for his assertive leadership style and his role in New York politics?

This man hosted the 97rd Annual Academy Awards.This comedian's late-night talk show, which followed "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno," was known for its quirky humor, offbeat sketches, and his self-deprecating style. He began his career as a writer for "Saturday Night Live" and "The Simpsons," showcasing his talent for comedy writing before transitioning to hosting. His signature hairstyle, a tall and voluminous pompadour, has become a recognizable part of his persona. Who is this comedian, known for his talk show appearances and his "Clueless Gamer" segments?

Employees of this organization included secretary Helen Gandy, associate director Clyde Tolson, and W. Mark Felt, who leaked information during the Watergate scandal as Deep Throat. The first head of this organization had a personal feud with John F. Kennedy that escalated to this agency wiretapping Kennedy's house. Name this governmental agency, once led by J. Edgar Hoover, that is the primary law enforcement agency of the US.

The coastal resort of Provincetown lies on the tip of this state's eastern region, and cities like New Bedford lie on Buzzards Bay in this state's south. Myles Standish State Forest is found in a coastal region of this state, which includes the islands of Chappaquiddick, Martha's Vineyard, and Nantucket. Plymouth Colony was established in what is now what New England state that borders both Connecticut and Rhode Island?

One of this man's works ends with "Thy firmness makes my circle just, / And makes me end where I begun." Another one of his works asks a "cruel and sudden" creature "hast thou since / Purpled thy nail in blood of innocence?" and calls it both a "marriage bed" and a "marriage temple," and in another he claims that the titular entity "art slave to Fate, Chance, kings, and desperate men," and that it "shalt die." "A Valediction Forbidding Mourning" and "The Flea" are by  what British metaphysical poet whose Holy Sonnets include the 10th one, "Death be not proud"?

This sport's highest governing body, the FIVB, organizes major international competitions, including the Olympic Games and the World Championships. The sport was invented in 1895 by William G. Morgan, a YMCA physical education director, who originally called it "Mintonette." The libero player, a defensive specialist introduced in 1998, wears a contrasting jersey color to easily identify them on the court. What is the name of this team sport played by two teams of six players on a court divided by a net?

An analog of this statement, the Poiseuille equation, models the flow of blood through the circulatory system. A phasor diagram can help apply this statement to cases where impedance is present. This statement predicts a linear relationship between I and V, while the reciprocal of each resistor's value must be summed to apply this law to parallel circuits. Name this law stating voltage equals current times resistance.
incorrect2: The law of conservation of energy

question: The Christian Democratic party (CDU/CSU) led by Friedrich Merz, won the most seats in the Bundestag after recent elections in this nation. This European country is home to the world-famous Oktoberfest, a 16-day festival celebrating Bavarian culture with beer, food, and traditional costumes. Its capital city, Berlin, is a vibrant metropolis that was once divided by the Berlin Wall, a symbol of the Cold War. It is the birthplace of classical music composers like Johann Sebastian Bach, Ludwig van Beethoven, and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. What is this country, the most populous member state of the European Union?

This country's capital city was designed in the shape of an airplane around a "Monumental Axis" by architect Oscar Niemeyer. "Cariocas" are residents of this country's second most populous city, which was the origin of bossa nova music and hosts massive parades in the Sambodrome during Carnaval. Name this Portuguese-speaking country in South America which contains most of the Amazon rainforest.

This flim won the Best Picture award at the Academy Awards. This film, which premiered at the 2024 Cannes Film Festival, is directed by Sean Baker, known for his previous films that explore marginalized communities. Its narrative delves into the world of sex work and the complexities of relationships and power dynamics. The film's protagonist is played by Mikey Madison, who previously collaborated with the director on the film "Red Rocket." What is the title of this film, which won the prestigious Palme d'Or at Cannes?

One of this artist's bronze creations depicts several men, including a biblical king, sitting around a table. In addition to the Feast of Herod, this artist created an equestrian statue of the recently deceased Erasmo da Narni, called the Gattamelata. His most well-known works were created while he was in Florence, including a statue of St. George, a wooden Mary Magdalene, and that of a nude figure standing over the head of Goliath. Identify the sculptor of the bronze David.

A member of this family was involved in a car accident that killed Mary Jo Kopechne in the Chappaquiddick incident. Another member of this family was killed at the Ambassador Hotel by Sirhan Sirhan. A president from this family ordered the Bay of Pigs invasion after dealing with the Cuban Missile Crisis and was assassinated by Lee Harvey Oswald in 1963. What family included the 35th US president, John F?

Cyclin-dependent kinase 4 and 6 are needed in this phase to cross the restriction point, where protein p53 may trigger apoptosis. Most mature nerve cells are permanently arrested in this phase, which directly follows cytokinesis. Its S subphase is when DNA is replicated, while its G1 and G2 portions are devoted to cell growth. Name this "resting phase" of the cell cycle that must be completed before mitosis can begin.

This sport features a variety of disciplines, including artistic, rhythmic, and trampoline variations, each requiring a unique blend of strength, flexibility, and coordination. The perfect score in artistic gymnastics was traditionally a 10.0, but the scoring system has evolved to emphasize difficulty and execution. The Olympic Games have been a major showcase for this sport, with legendary gymnasts like Nadia Comăneci and Simone Biles captivating audiences with their incredible feats. What is the name of this sport, which involves performing sequences of movements on apparatus or the floor?

A group of these people established the Rurik dynasty in Novgorod and formed the Byzantine Varangian Guard. Charles the Simple gave Rollo, one of these people, control of the Duchy of Normandy. These people attacked the Lindisfarne monastery, and Cnut the Great, one of their leaders, controlled both Denmark and England. These people established a settlement at L'Anse aux Meadows in Newfoundland. Name these Scandinavian seafarers once led by Leif Erikson.

The artists Christo and Jeanne-Claude installed 5,703 fabric-covered gates in this place in 2005. Features called the Lake and the Ramble are in this place, whose layout was primarily designed by Frederick Law Olmstead. This place, which divides the Upper West and Upper East Sides of Manhattan, is the origin of Shakespeare in the Park. Name this large park in New York City.

This summer this musical group is setting off on a tour that they say will be their last. This hip-hop group's iconic logo, a stylized "W" with a sword, has become a symbol of their influence and their impact on music and culture. Their debut album, released in 1993, revolutionized hip-hop with its raw energy, innovative production, and intricate lyrical style. The group is composed of nine members, each with a distinct persona and rapping style, including RZA, GZA, Method Man, and Raekwon. Their music often draws inspiration from martial arts films, philosophy, and comic books. What is the name of this influential hip-hop group from Staten Island, New York?

The Gazimestan speech commemorated a 1389 battle fought on this region's Blackbird's Field. This region, the subject of the EULEX policing plan, was targeted after the 1999 Rambouillet Agreement by Slobodan Milosevic, prompting NATO to bomb Yugoslavia. The ICJ and George W. Bush recognized its 2008 declaration of independence. With an ethnic majority of Albanians and a capital at Pristina name this secessionist region southwest of Serbia.
answers: Autonomous Province of Kosovo and Metohija

question: This racquet sport, played with a shuttlecock, which is a high-drag projectile, requires players to hit the shuttlecock over a net and land it within the boundaries of their opponent's court. The shuttlecock's feathers create significant air resistance, making it decelerate rapidly, which distinguishes it from other racquet sports. The sport is governed internationally by the BWF. What is the name of this sport, which originated in ancient Greece and Egypt, but gained popularity in its current form in England in the 19th century?

This author wrote about an old woman who refused payment to a thieving doctor because she couldn't see her belongings. In other stories by this man, a mouse saves a lion from hunters and a farmer kills a goose that lays golden eggs. Another of his tales teaches that "slow and steady wins the race." "The Tortoise and the Hare" and "The Boy who Cried Wolf" are by this ancient Greek author of namesake fables.

The English Statute of Laborers set a maximum wage in response to deaths caused by this event. Jews were falsely accused of poisoning wells during this event, whose victims are supposedly described by the nursery rhyme "Ring Around the Rosie." This event was likely caused by merchant ships transporting flea-infested rats from Asia. Name this pandemic that sickened and killed tens of millions of people in Europe in the 14th century.

Factors of 1 plus this value all to the nth power appear in both the numerator and denominator of the amortization formula. Dividing a final value by the nth power of one plus this quantity yields present value. Factors of one plus this quantity to the nth power and one plus n times this quantity, when multiplied by a principal value, represent its compound and simple types. Name this quantity that represents the cost of borrowing money.

Recent outbreaks of this disease have sickened over 100 people in the U.S. causing at least one death. This highly contagious disease, characterized by a distinctive rash that starts on the face and spreads down the body, is caused by a virus in the paramyxovirus family. It was once a common childhood illness, but widespread vaccination efforts have significantly reduced its prevalence. Its symptoms include fever, cough, runny nose, and conjunctivitis (pink eye). What is the name of this disease, which is preventable through the MMR vaccine?

In one work, this man criticized Robert Filmer's view of monarchy and argued that revolution is needed if the government fails to serve the interests of citizens. He wrote that knowledge is gained from experience alone because the human mind at birth is a tabula rasa, or "blank slate," in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding. Name this English philosopher who described social contract theory in Two Treatises of Government.

When given temperatures and enthalpy values, the Clausius-Clapeyron equation estimates this value, which, for volatile substances, is higher at low temperatures. At equilibrium, the partial pressure of a substance is equal to its mole fraction times this quantity, according to Raoult's Law. A boiling substance will have equal values for atmospheric pressure and what other type of pressure exerted when a gas co-exists with its liquid or solid phase?

This poet wrote about his travels through Asia, as well as his observations of Haiti and the Soviet Republic in his autobiography, I Wonder as I Wander. He also stated that, "They send me in the kitchen when company comes" in his poem, "I, Too, Sing America." Lorraine Hansberry took the title for her play, A Raisin in the Sun, from this man's poem, "Harlem," in which he asks, "What happens to a dream deferred?" Name this African American author of the Harlem Renaissance that wrote "for me, life ain't been no crystal stair," in "Mother to Son"in addition to "The Negro Speaks of Rivers."

This river joins with the Rio Negro at the Meeting of the Waters. Iquitos, one of the most inland ports in the world, sits on the banks of this river. The city of Manaus also lies on this river, and is located in a state named for it. This river has the highest discharge volume, and is second-longest, in the world. What very long river in Brazil is named for a group of Greek-warrior women?

Adrien Brody won the Best Actor Oscar for his role in this film. This film, directed by Brady Corbet, explores the life and work of a visionary architect whose career spans decades. It features Adrien Brody, who also starred in Corbet's previous film, "Vox Lux," alongside Felicity Jones and Guy Pearce. The film's title refers to a style of architecture characterized by its raw concrete aesthetic and monumental forms, a style that reflects the architect's artistic vision. What is the name of this film, which delves into themes of ambition, legacy, and the artistic process?

This sport's perfect game, achieved by throwing twelve consecutive strikes, results in a score of 300. The pins, arranged in a triangular formation, are knocked down by a ball with finger holes, allowing for a variety of throwing styles. The sport has its roots in ancient Egypt, with evidence of a similar game dating back to 3200 BC, but the modern version evolved in Germany. What is the name of this sport, played indoors on a long, narrow lane?

The losing side in this war created the Saint Patrick's Battalion from Irish defectors of the winning side. A "Bear Flag Republic" in this war enjoyed independence for three weeks before being annexed by the U.S. Abraham Lincoln introduced the Spot Resolutions to protest the legal basis for this conflict. This conflict's first fighting, known as the Thornton Affair, took place in the disrupted Nuances Strip outside Fort Texas. It was ended by the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, which seized California and New Mexico. Name this 1846 to 1848 war fought by the U.S with its southern neighbor.

This official had a heated discussion with President Donald Trump in the Oval Office which led to him leaving without signing a propose deal mineral deal in exchange for defense. This political figure, a former actor and comedian, gained international prominence for his leadership of Ukraine during the Russian invasion that began in 2022. He was elected President of Ukraine in 2019, winning by a landslide. Who is this president, whose defiance and resolve have made him a symbol of resistance?

One version of this law states that heat cannot flow spontaneously from low temperature to high temperature. Another version of this law states that it is impossible to convert heat completely into work in a cyclic process. Maxwell proposed a thought experiment in which sorting air molecules seems to violate this law. Identify this law, credited to French physicist Sadi Carnot, which states that "in a closed system, a process that occurs will tend to increase the total entropy of the universe."

This ceremony occurred on March 2, 2025 in Los Angeles, California. These awards, presented annually by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS), are considered the most prestigious awards in the film industry, recognizing excellence in cinematic achievements. The ceremony is known for its iconic golden statuette, often referred to as "Oscar." The first ceremony was held in 1929 at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, and it has since become a global event, broadcast live in over 200 countries. What is the name of these awards, with categories including Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Actor/Actress?

A figure circled this deity and his wife to win a race with the prize of a magic mango, proposed by this god. This god is depicted with matted hair and a crescent moon on his head. After this god swallowed halahala created during the churning of the ocean, this god's throat turned blue due to the potency of the poison. Name this three-eyed destroyer deity who makes up the Trimurti with Brahma and Vishnu.

This show is currently airing its long-awaited second season. This science fiction thriller series, set in a mysterious corporate environment, explores the concept a surgical procedure that divides an employee's memories between their work life ("innie") and personal life ("outie"). The series' unique visual style, with its sterile office spaces and unsettling atmosphere, creates a sense of unease and intrigue. The show's central mystery revolves around the employees of Lumon Industries and their quest to uncover the truth about their work. What is the name of this critically acclaimed Apple TV+ series?

This event's Main Event, the No-Limit Texas Hold'em World Championship, is the most prestigious tournament in poker, attracting thousands of players from around the world. The winner of the Main Event receives a multimillion-dollar prize and the coveted bracelet, a symbol of poker excellence. The event originated in 1970 at Binion's Horseshoe Casino in Las Vegas, Nevada, and has since grown into a global phenomenon. What is the name of this series of poker tournaments, held annually in Las Vegas?

This leader's body was hung upside down in the Square of the 15 Martyrs. He led the Republic of Salo after Otto Skorzeny's glider raid on Gran Sasso freed him from Victor Emmanuel III's policemen. In 1935, his army deposed Haile Selassie in an invasion of Ethiopia. He rose to power in 1922 as the Blackshirts marched on Rome. Name this fascist dictator, known as "Il Duce," who led Italy during World War II.

This man was targeted in the Conway Cabal, which was partially due to his losses at Germantown and Brandywine. He declared political parties to be a "frightful despotism" and warned against engaging in "entangling alliances" in his Farewell Address, after which his former Vice President John Adams became President. Name this leader of the Continental Army who became the first President of the United States.

In this mountain range, accountant-turned-fugitive James "Bismarck" Hammes avoided capture by hiking for six years on a trail that extends from Springer Mountain to Mount Katahdin. Mount Mitchell is its highest peak, and this range includes the Piedmont and Blue Ridge subranges in Virginia and North Carolina. Name this mountain range that impedes east-west travel as it extends from Georgia to Maine.

This show is currently airing its third season. This anthology series, created by Mike White, explores themes of wealth, privilege, and social dynamics against the backdrop of luxurious resort locations. Each season features a new cast of characters and a different setting, with the first season taking place in Hawaii and the second in Sicily. The series is known for its dark humor, its satirical portrayal of the upper class, and its exploration of complex relationships and moral dilemmas. What is the name of this critically acclaimed HBO series, which has garnered numerous awards and nominations?

Mount San Antonio is the tallest mountain in this state's San Gabriel Mountains. The highest point in this state, Mt. Whitney, is also the highest point in the contiguous United States. It contains the western shore of the largest alpine lake in North America. Five hours to the south of Mt. Whitney lies the lowest point in North America. This third largest state in the U.S. contains Lake Tahoe and Death Valley. Its San Fernando Valley holds the majority of this state's most populous city, Los Angeles. Name this state with capital at Sacramento.

Winston Churchill's The River War documented a revolt in this country that included the death of General "Chinese" Gordon and the Battle of Omdurman. The Janjaweed militia participates in this country's ongoing genocidal war in Darfur, for which president Omar al-Bashir was indicted for war crimes. A 2019 wave of mass protests shook Khartoum, the capital of what African country whose southern region declared independence in 2012?

This city was burned to the ground during a rebellion against William Berkeley. Residents of this city were saved by the arrival of relief ships under Lord De La Warr. Before leading its inhabitants through the "starving time" of 1609, this settlement's governor was said to have been saved from execution by the Powhatan woman Pocahontas. Name this Virginia settlement governed by John Smith, the first permanent English settlement in the New World.

This sport, considered one of the oldest field games in the world, is often described as a cross between lacrosse, hockey, and baseball. Players use a stick called a hurley (or camán) to hit a small ball called a sliotar, with the aim of scoring by driving the sliotar between the opponent's goalposts. A goal, worth 3 points, is scored by hitting the sliotar under the crossbar into a net guarded by a goalkeeper. What is the name of this fast-paced and physical team sport, a national game of Ireland?

Evidence from NASA's Dawn spacecraft suggests that Ceres could be home to an ice type of this geologic feature. Io has an abundance of these features, which are responsible for its surface color. The largest one of these features in the solar system is the Martian Olympus Mons, which is of the "shield" variety and could be active. Name these geologic features that can erupt with lava.

Wildfires broke out in this US state leading Governor Henry McMaster to declare a state of emergency. This U.S. state, known for its beautiful coastline and historic cities, is home to Fort Sumter, where the first shots of the American Civil War were fired. Its city of Charleston is famous for its colorful Rainbow Row, a series of historic houses painted in pastel hues. It is also a major producer of peaches, earning it the nickname "The Peach State," though the official nickname is "The Palmetto State." What is this state, one of the original thirteen colonies, located in the southeastern United States?

In a novel by this author, Arronax, Conseil, and Ned Land flee the Maelstrom, which threatens to sink a strange vessel. In another of this man's novels, Aouda is saved from being burned alive by Passepartout and a man who later uses the international dateline to win a bet. Phileas Fogg and Captain Nemo's submarine, the Nautilus, appear in what French author's novels Around the World in Eighty Days and Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea?

Norman Mushari uses the philanthropy of one of this author's characters to try to prove him insane. Maniacs in the Fourth Dimension was written by a character in this author's novel Breakfast of Champions. Besides Eliot Rosewater and Kilgore Trout, he created a character who goes to Tralfamadore and saw the firebombing of Dresden. Name this author who wrote about Billy Pilgrim in his novel Slaughterhouse-Five.

This war was instigated by the "reconcentration" tactics of Valeriano "Butcher" Weyler. Only one American sailor died at a major victory for George Dewey in this war. The losing side ceded Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Philippines to the United States after this "splendid little war." An explosion on the USS Maine in Havana sparked what 1898 war in which Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders fought in Cuba against their parent country?

This body of water was refilled by the Zanclean flood over five million years ago, ending the Messinian salinity crisis. The Barbary Coast was along this body of water, which lies west of the Levant and south of Asia Minor. The Strait of Gibraltar separates this sea from the Atlantic Ocean, and its Aegean and Adriatic Seas were considered part of "the Great Sea" by the ancient Greeks and Romans. Name this sea that separates Europe and Africa.

The costly ransom of one king in this war caused the peasants of one country to rise in the Jacquerie Rebellion. Edward the Black Prince fought in this war before dying of dysentery, and he won the battles of Poitiers and Crecy against King John II of France in this war. What war fought between England and France in the 14th and 15th centuries was actually 16 years longer than its name implies?

This holiday was celebrated with a parade in New Orleans on April 4, 2025. This celebration, known for its elaborate parades, vibrant costumes, and festive atmosphere, culminates on "Fat Tuesday," the day before the start of Lent in the Christian calendar. Its signature colors are purple (justice), green (faith), and gold (power), which are prominently displayed in decorations and costumes.
