The tradition of throwing beads, doubloons, and other trinkets from parade floats has become a hallmark of the celebration. What is the name of this annual carnival celebration, most famously associated with New Orleans, Louisiana?

This film's iconic dance scene, featuring Uma Thurman and John Travolta in a twist contest, is set to Chuck Berry's "You Never Can Tell," becoming one of the most memorable moments in cinema history. Its nonlinear narrative structure, weaving together multiple storylines, revolutionized storytelling in independent film. Its dialogue, filled with pop culture references and witty banter, has become widely quoted and celebrated. What is the title of this 1994 film, directed by Quentin Tarantino, which won the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival?

The "extended" version of this man's algorithm gives solutions to Diophantine equations. He proved that there are an infinite number of prime numbers, and his aforementioned namesake algorithm is used to find the greatest common denominator. He names a claim about the existence of a unique parallel line, his fifth postulate. This "father of geometry" is what Greek mathematician who wrote The Elements?

This team sport, popular in Commonwealth countries, is played on a rectangular court divided into three sections, with a goal ring at each end. It features seven players on each team, each assigned to specific positions with defined areas of the court where they can operate. The objective is to score goals by passing a ball and shooting it through the opponent's goal ring. What is the name of this sport, similar to basketball but with restrictions on player movement with the ball?

A large O-shaped lake in this province was formed when a reservoir filled an ancient impact crater. This Canadian province's largest city is known for smoked-meat sandwiches and a unique style of bagel. Tourists in another city in this province can visit the massive Chateau Frontenac and the Plains of Abraham, which overlook the St. Lawrence River. Montreal is in what French-speaking Canadian province?

Intuitive Machines, a private company based in Texas, attempted to land their craft Athena on this satellite planet. However, the lander missed its mark toppled over and died 24 hours after touching down. This celestial body became the target of intense space exploration during the Cold War, leading to a historic race to land humans on its surface. The first unmanned spacecraft to achieve a soft landing was Luna 9 in 1966, paving the way for future crewed missions. The Apollo program, launched by the United States, ultimately achieved this goal with the Apollo 11 mission in 1969. What is the name of this celestial body, the Earth's only natural satellite?

The speaker of this poem asks its subject "is there - is there balm in Gilead?" before ordering it "back into the tempest and the Night's Plutonian shore". The title animal of this poem is perched on a "pallid bust of Pallas just above my chamber door". "Once upon a midnight dreary" is the opening of what poem by Edgar Allan Poe in which the title bird declares "nevermore"?
incorrect3: The Fall of the House of Usher

question: This film's iconic car chase scene, featuring a dangerous game of "chicken" with two cars speeding towards a cliff, became a symbol of teenage rebellion and reckless abandon. Its star, James Dean, became a cultural icon and a symbol of youthful angst and alienation, despite his tragically short career. The film explores themes of juvenile delinquency, generational conflict, and the search for identity. What is the title of this 1955 film, directed by Nicholas Ray, which has become a classic of American cinema?

The yacht Granma transported revolutionaries to this country in the 26th of July movement. An Argentine revolutionary in this country was shown with a stoic face and a beret in Alberto Korda's photo Guerrillero Heroico. A leader of this country overthrew Fulgencio Batista along with his second-in-command Che Guevara and brother Raul. Name this Caribbean island country once led by Fidel Castro.

This NFL player recently signed a 3-year $100 million contract with the Seattle Seahawks after playing one year with the Minnesota Vikings. This quarterback, known for his strong arm and his ability to make throws from various arm angles, was drafted third overall by the New York Jets in the 2018 NFL Draft. He played college football at the University of Southern California (USC), where he won the Pac-12 South Division title in 2017. Name this player who has also played for the Carolina Panthers and the San Francisco 49ers.

This author of the letter "To the Inhabitants of America" suffered a gruesome leg injury in an attack on Quebec City that killed Richard Montgomery. This man's wife, Peggy Shippen, connected him with John Andre, who was hanged in October 1780 after being caught with papers written by this man. Name this officer in the American Revolution who became infamous for his failed attempt to betray West Point to the British.

This type of interaction is responsible for the high crystallinity of nylon, and it explains why hydrofluoric acid has a higher boiling point than hydrochloric acid. These interactions occur between base pairs in DNA. Ice has lower density than water due to the behavior of what type of bonding, a strong dipole-dipole interaction named for element 1 on the Periodic Table?

This nation's Liberal Party chose Mark Carney as their new leader making him the next Prime Minister of the nation. This country is a major exporter of energy, minerals, and agricultural products, and it has a strong automotive industry. This country borders the United States to the North and Justin Trudeau used to lead it. What is the name of this country, a member of the G7 and known for its vast natural resources and its advanced industrial economy?

Salvador was the capital of this country until it was replaced by an Oscar Niemeyer planned city in 1956. Tourist sites in this country include Ipanema Beach, Sugarloaf Mountain, and the statue of Christ the Redeemer, and its ecotourist destination city Manaus is located in the world's largest rainforest. Porto Alegre, Sao Paulo, and Rio de Janeiro are located in what largest country in South America?

This politician tried to transfer Guantanamo Bay prisoners to Thomson, Illionis, but was stymied when Congress refused to provide appropriate funds. In the late 2000s, Rod Blagojevich tried to sell this man's vacated senate seat. Partially fueled by slogans like "Yes We Can," this man defeated John McCain in the 2008 presidential election. Joe Biden was the vice president for what first Black president of the United States?

This king of Pessinus once found the satyr Silenus when he was lost. As a result, Dionysus offered this king any power. Later this king had his ears turned into those of a donkey. Name this king who chose the power to turn everything he touched into gold.

King Victor Emmanuel III failed to stop this country's "Blackshirts" from marching on its capital. Haile Selassie gave a failed request for help to the League of Nations after this country invaded Ethiopia in 1935. This country's fascist leader Benito Mussolini signed a "Pact of Steel" with Adolf Hitler. The Axis Powers in World War II were Germany, Japan, and what country, the site of the March on Rome?

This actor's piercing blue eyes and charismatic screen presence made him a Hollywood icon, starring in films like "Cool Hand Luke," "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid," and "The Sting." He was also a successful race car driver and team owner winning numerous IndyCar championships. His philanthropic efforts included the founding of a food company whose profits are donated to charity. Who is this actor, known for his talent, his philanthropy, and his striking good looks?

The Zeisel test can be used to detect them, and the compound THF is a very polar example of one. The "crown" varieties are cyclic and can be used as solvents in Grignard reagents due to their low reactivity. These compounds can be produced by the Williamson synthesis or by the dehydration of alcohols. Identify these chemical compounds, characterized by two alkyl groups single bonded to an oxygen, whose diethyl version used to be used as an anesthetic.

This NFL player was recently traded from the Seattle Seahawks to the Las Vegas Raiders where he signed a contract extension. This quarterback, once considered a journeyman, experienced a career resurgence with the Seattle Seahawks, earning NFL Comeback Player of the Year honors in 2022. He was drafted by the New York Jets in the second round of the 2013 NFL Draft and has also played for the New York Giants and the Los Angeles Chargers. He played college football at West Virginia University, where he set numerous school records. Who is this quarterback, known for his resilience and his impressive performance in recent seasons?

This number is squared in the solution to the Basel problem. One experiment to calculate this number exploits the Buffon's needle problem. Archimedes approximated this number, the number of radians in 180 degrees, by bounding it by the perimeters of 96-sided polygons, finding that it is less than 22 over 7. Give this ratio of a circle's circumference and diameter, an irrational number approximately equal to 3.14.

This Formula One driver, known for his qualifying prowess and his ability to extract the maximum performance from his car, achieved his first Formula One victory at the 2019 Belgian Grand Prix. He drives for Scuderia Ferrari, one of the most iconic and successful teams in Formula One history. He is a member of the Ferrari Driver Academy, a program that develops young racing talent. Who is this racing driver, hailing from Monaco?

After this man made his brother Joseph an unpopular King of Spain, he had to fight the Peninsular War to defend Joseph's rule. This man forced the Treaty of Pressburg, which gave this man large amounts of land from the Austrian Empire. This man beat the Third Coalition at the Battle of Austerlitz in 1805, two months after his navy lost at Trafalgar. Name this emperor who was exiled to Saint Helena in 1815 after his French army was defeated at Waterloo.

This holiday was celebrated on Friday, March 14 in India. This Hindu spring festival, also known as the "Festival of Colors," is celebrated with vibrant displays of colored powder and water, symbolizing the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil. Its origins are rooted in Hindu mythology, with various stories associated with the festival, including the legend of Holika and Prahlad. The festivities typically include music, dancing, and the sharing of sweets. What is the name of this joyous festival, a major celebration in India and Nepal?

This nation is home to the city of Mariupol, which is located on the Sea of Azov. The Pripyat River flows into Belarus in the north and then back into this country, which is home to most of the Dnieper River. In July 2015, Dmitry Medvedev said that this nation's southernmost section, called Crimea, had been fully integrated with Russia. Name this Eastern European nation with capital at Kiev.

This author wrote of a character who was "more brave than me:more blond than you." That "conscientious object-or" had a "heart that recoiled at war." This man wrote the poem "maggie and milly and molly and may," which has almost no capital letters, and described a man who "sang his didn't and danced his did." "anyone lived in a pretty how town" is by what American poet known for his strange punctuation and capitalization?

This musician's 1959 album, "Kind of Blue," considered one of the greatest jazz albums of all time, popularized modal jazz, a style characterized by its improvisational freedom and harmonic ambiguity. His innovative use of the Harmon mute, which he often placed close to the microphone, created a distinctive and intimate sound. He was a key figure in the development of bebop, cool jazz, hard bop, and modal jazz, constantly pushing the boundaries of the genre. Who is this trumpeter and composer, known for his influential contributions to jazz music?

A followup to this Supreme Court case said that the ruling should be carried out "with all deliberate speed." This Supreme Court case overturned the Plessy v. Ferguson decision. The majority opinion in this case stated that "separate educational facilities are inherently unequal." The organization that lost this case was based in Topeka, Kansas. Name this 1954 Supreme Court case that worked to desegregate schools.
answers: Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas

question: This animated film's iconic characters, Woody and Buzz Lightyear, have become beloved figures in popular culture, representing friendship and adventure. Its groundbreaking use of computer-generated imagery (CGI) revolutionized animation and paved the way for future animated films. Its story, which explores themes of growing up and the importance of imagination, has resonated with audiences of all ages. What is the name of this 1995 Pixar film, the first full-length computer-animated feature film?

This religious action is described in Paul's letter to the Ephesians as a result of having "one lord" and"one faith." The son of Elizabeth, John, saw the Holy Spirit descend "like a dove" onto Jesus during this ritual in the Jordan River. In Catholicism, this action is typically performed on infants and in Eastern Orthodoxy, it can be performed through full immersion. Name this Christian ritual, also called "christening," in which a person is inducted into the church by being blessed with water.

This Formula 1 driver, known for his consistent performances and his popular presence on social media, achieved his first Formula 1 victory at the 2024 Miami Grand Prix. He drives for McLaren, a historic team in Formula 1. He is often seen as a rising star in the sport. Who is this British driver?

President Donald Trump has threatened to cut the staff of this agency which is associated with a US national deadline on April 15. This agency's primary function is to enforce the tax laws of the United States, collecting taxes and providing assistance to taxpayers. Its origins can be traced back to the Civil War, when it was established to help finance the war effort. The agency is responsible for processing millions of tax returns each year, a complex task that involves verifying information and ensuring compliance. What is the name of this bureau of the Department of the Treasury?

This state's tallest peak is Mount Elbert, and its official flower, the blue columbine, was discovered during the first ascent of a mountain discovered by Zebulon Pike. Over 50 "fourteeners," or mountains over 14,000 feet tall, are found in what "Mile High" state in the Rockies, with capital Denver?

An equation named for Konstantin Tsiolkovsky is used to calculate the motion of these machines, because they get lighter through fuel loss as they travel. Robert Goddard and Werner von Braun are scientists best known for their work with these machines, which may be comprised of multiple stages which fall off as they fly. What vehicles such as Saturn V and Falcon 9 are used to launch into space?

This president's policies were frequently blocked by the "Four Horsemen," a conservative block of the Supreme Court, and he failed in a controversial attempt to "pack" more justices on the Court. This man used bank holidays and new agencies like the Tennessee Valley Authority and WPA to fight the Great Depression. Name this president who expanded the federal government through his New Deal policies while suffering from polio.

A holder of this title controversially pushed his people away from polytheism in favor of a solar god worshiped at Amarna. Lord Carnavon funded Howard Carter's 1922 expedition to discover the burial grounds of one of these people at Luxor; that mission found a sarcophagus containing a solid gold funerary mask and mummified remains. Name this title given to Akenhaten, King Tut, and other ancient Egyptian rulers.

Following the 2003 Goodridge case, Massachusetts became the first state to grant the right to perform this action, which California took away in Proposition 8. After the case Obergefell v. Hodges legalized this action nationwide by striking down the Defense of Marriage Act, the White House was temporarily lit up with rainbow pride colors. Name this action that might involve two men becoming husbands.

This footballer's philosophy, known as "Total Football," revolutionized the sport with its fluid formations and emphasis on positional interchangeability. He won the Ballon d'Or three times and was a key player for both Ajax and Barcelona, two clubs that are synonymous with his style of play. He also managed both Ajax and Barcelona, continuing to implement his tactical vision and shaping the future of football. Who is this Dutch football legend, known for his technical brilliance and his profound influence on the game?

This director's 2019 film, "Parasite," made history by becoming the first non-English language film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture. His films often blend genres, incorporating elements of thriller, comedy, and social commentary, exploring themes of class inequality and social injustice. He has directed acclaimed films such as "Memories of Murder," "The Host," and "Snowpiercer," showcasing his versatility and his ability to create compelling and thought-provoking cinema. Who is this South Korean filmmaker, known for his masterful storytelling and his unique cinematic vision?

This event will occur in the Northern Hemisphere on March 20, 2025. This astronomical event, marking the beginning of spring occurs when the Sun crosses the celestial equator, resulting in roughly equal lengths of day and night. It has been celebrated in various cultures throughout history with festivals and rituals symbolizing renewal and rebirth. Its date varies slightly each year due to the Earth's elliptical orbit and axial tilt. What is the name of this event, a significant point in the Earth's annual cycle around the Sun?

When preceded by the German root "zwitter", this term describes a molecule that is simultaneously dipolar. Bases are classified as strong or weak by their ability to completely dissociate into these things; for example, lye breaks apart into hydroxide molecules and sodium atoms. Give this term for chemicals that have lost or gained electrons and thus have a positive or negative electric charge.

During this battle, the Chateau of Hougoumont was besieged. British troops in this battle protected themselves from artillery fire by lying down on the reverse slope of La Haye Sainte. British infantry squares repeatedly turned back cavalry led by Marshal Ney at this battle. This battle concluded when the British were relieved by a Prussian Army under General von Blucher. Name this 1815 battle in Belgium in which the Duke of Wellington defeated Napoleon.

The Adelie and emperor species of a certain bird only live in this region. Penguins live on this continent, which is home to the South Pole. In this novel, "with sheets" is added to one of the Seven Commandments, which are written on a wall after Jones and his men are defeated at the Battle of the Cowshed. In this novel, Old Major teaches the song "Beasts of England," Boxer repeats "Napoleon is always right," and Snowball teaches the motto "Four legs good! Two legs bad!" to a group of sheep. A Marxist revolution is led by pigs in what George Orwell novel?

The former president of the this nation, Rodrigo Duterte, was arrested on the basis of an International Criminal Court warrant charging him with crimes against humanity during his national war on drugs. This Southeast Asian country, known for its stunning beaches and vibrant coral reefs, is comprised of over 7,000 islands, making it an archipelago. Its capital city, Manila, is a bustling metropolis with a rich history and a mix of modern and colonial architecture. It is the world's leading exporter of coconut oil and a major producer of rice and other agricultural products. What is this country known for its iconic jeepney transportation?

This singer-songwriter's introspective lyrics and gentle acoustic guitar style, often exploring themes of personal struggles and emotional healing, helped define the singer-songwriter movement of the 1970s. His album "Sweet Baby James," released in 1970, catapulted him to fame and featured his signature song of the same name. His distinctive voice and his fingerpicking technique have become instantly recognizable, earning him a dedicated fanbase. Who is this musician, known for his hits like "Fire and Rain," "You've Got a Friend," and "Carolina in My Mind"?

This cricketer, known as the "God of Cricket" in India, holds numerous records in both Test and One Day International (ODI) cricket, including the most runs scored and the most centuries. He was the first player to score 100 international centuries, a feat that cemented his legendary status. He played for India for over two decades, becoming a national icon and an inspiration to aspiring cricketers. Who is this Indian cricketer, widely regarded as one of the greatest batsmen of all time?

An army from this modern-day nation attempted to invade the Joseon dynasty but was repelled by turtle ships. One general in this nation led "winter" and "summer" campaigns to try to capture his enemy's recently rebuilt castle. In 1281 this nation's defeat of the navy of Kublai Khan with the help of a typhoon was attributed to a "divine wind." The siege of Osaka occurred in this nation, which Tokugawa Ieyasu once led. After a great storm, this man was marooned without supply on Jamaica for one year in 1503. Accusations of brutality such as cutting off a someone's ears and nose for stealing corn led to this man's imprisonment after a governorship. This man made contact with Arawak Indians on San Salvador, and his major discovery occurred during his voyage on the Nina, the Pinta, and the Santa Maria. A Lucas cell can be used to detect one element in this group that causes lung cancer. Ununoctium is the newest member of this group. Shorthand electron configurations features abbreviations for elements in this group in brackets. Each one of these elements is monatomic with a full valence shell. Name this group of unreactive elements on the far right of the periodic table, whose members include xenon, radon, and helium.

He's not Apollo, but this god sent a monster to ravage the land when King Laomedon didn't reward him for building the walls of Troy like promised. After being taunted by the hero Odysseus, Polyphemus prayed to this god, his father. This god lost a contest in which he created the first horse to Athena to become the patron god of Athens. The highest point in this nation is Jebel Toubkal, and foreign enclaves surrounded by this nation include Melilla and Ceuta. Its cities include Safi and Marrakech, and this country is home to the western terminus of the Atlas Mountains. It is north of the disputed Western Sahara and south of the Strait of Gibraltar. Name this country that includes the cities of Casablanca and Rabat.

Before amylase enzyme was isolated, this compound was used to turn corn starch into glucose syrup. The"fizz test" for calcium carbonate applies a muriatic solution of this compound to rocks. Gold will dissolve in a mixture of nitric acid and this compound, called "aqua regia." Water and table salt are the products when this compound reacts with sodium hydroxide. Stomach acid consists of which strong acid with formula HCl?

One of this author's works sees a scorpion bite Coyotito, the son of two pearl fishers, and in another novel, the knowledge that Cathy Ames was a prostitute drives her son, Aron Trask, to death. This documentary series, which has significantly increased the popularity of Formula 1 racing, provides an inside look at the drivers, teams, and rivalries that make up the sport. Its dramatic storytelling and behind-the-scenes access have attracted a new generation of fans. The series is produced by Netflix and has been praised for its ability to capture the intensity and excitement of Formula 1. What is the name of this show?

This desert is home to the Tibesti Mountains. The Tuareg people are indigenous to the central regions of this desert. This desert is bordered to the south by a region called the Sahel and also contains the cities of Niamey and Timbuktu. Sankore University was built by the Mali Empire on the edge of this desert. This singer-songwriter's music, often celebrating the beauty of nature and the simplicity of life, made him a prominent figure in the folk and country music scenes of the 1970s. His love for aviation led him to become an experienced pilot, a passion that tragically ended in his death in a plane crash. Who is this musician, known for his hits like "Rocky Mountain High," "Annie's Song," and "Leaving on a Jet Plane"?

Ukraine attacked this city with drones on the eve of discussions with the United States about their ongoing war. This city's iconic Red Square, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is home to St. Basil's Cathedral, a colorful and ornate structure with distinctive onion-shaped domes. Its metro system, known for its elaborate stations decorated with mosaics, sculptures, and chandeliers, is considered one of the most beautiful in the world. It is the political and economic center of Russia, and it has a rich history dating back to the 12th century. What is the name of this city, the capital of Russia, located on the Moskva River?

This man's donation founded the University of Chicago, the alma mater of his only son. This man once owned the companies that became ExxonMobil and Chevron, and he clashed with Andrew Carnegie. This man integrated his company both vertically and horizontally, leading to criticism from the muckraker Ida Tarbell. In this conflict, the slogan "Work, Family, Fatherland" was adopted by a regime led by former war hero Philippe Petain. In this conflict, a French regime based in the city of Vichy was resisted by the "Free French". Name this conflict during which France was led by a Nazi puppet government.

A hypothetical type of this structure is the 20-mile long O'Neill cylinder, and Wernher von Braun's design for one is based on a rotating wheel. The most recently completed one of these is China's Tiangong-2. Valery Polyakov holds the endurance record for spending 437 days aboard one of these called Mir, and due to a calculation error, the American one, Skylab, crashed in Australia upon re-entry. Name this type of structure whose International example houses astronauts and their experiments in outer space.

After this event, the Hotline Agreement was signed between its two major parties. This event was triggered in part by the photographing of bases at San Cristobal by a U-2 spy plane. As part of a compromise to resolve this event, the United States agreed to remove Jupiter missiles from Turkey, and during this event John F. Kennedy ordered the blockade of a Communist island. Name this 1962 Cold War incident in which the United States and Soviet Union stood on the brink of nuclear war.

This empire's "Great Interregnum" ended with the ascension of the House of Luxembourg. Local leaders of this empire met in the Imperial Diet. Within this empire, France rivaled the Hapsburgs for influence with its electors. This empire was ruled by Spanish kings in the 1500s after the election of Charles V. Name this fragmented Central European empire, which ruled much of medieval Germany.

This basketball legend's silhouette is the basis for the NBA's iconic logo, a testament to his impact on the sport. He was a 14-time NBA All-Star and won an NBA championship with the Los Angeles Lakers in 1972. He also served as a successful coach and executive in the NBA, showcasing his diverse contributions to the league. It is bordered by the United Kingdom, Norway, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, and France. Its shipping lanes are some of the busiest in the world, connecting major European ports. What is the name of this sea, known for its strong winds and its role in European trade and energy production?

One novel by this author is about a thieving woman whose many husbands include a banker, a "Lancanshire" man, and her half-brother. Like Samuel Pepys, this author offered an account of the 1665 Plague in his A Journal of the Plague Year. Another novel follows a man who rescues a prisoner from cannibals. His songwriting partnership with John Lennon produced some of the most iconic and beloved songs in music history. He formed the band Wings after the breakup of The Beatles, achieving further success with hits like "Band on the Run" and "Live and Let Die." Who is this legendary musician, known for his prolific career as a singer, songwriter, and multi-instrumentalist?

This country is home to the second largest nickel reserves in the world, after Russia. question: This basketball player is known for his clutch performances and his ability to hit game-winning shots. He played his entire 18-season career with the Indiana Pacers, becoming a beloved figure in the state. He was a five-time NBA All-Star and is considered one of the greatest three-point shooters of all time. Who is this Hall of Fame shooting guard, famous for his rivalry with the New York Knicks in the 1990s?

This leader went on the Great Embassy with his diplomats, and faced revolt from a group of guards supporting his brother Ivan V, the streltsy. This cultural and religious holiday, traditionally celebrated on March 17th, is associated with the color green, shamrocks, and leprechauns. The cross-cousin form of this practice was common among the Iroquois. Under the Napoleonic Code, men could do this at age 18 and women at age 15. Obergefell v. Hodges was ruled in favor of same-sex couples being able to do this. Name this process, which usually involves a wedding ceremony.

Angular momentum is quantized as an integer multiple of the reduced form of this quantity, which is equal to this quantity over two pi and is denoted with a bar. The de Broglie wavelength is equal to this quantity over momentum. The product of the standard deviations of position and momentum is at least this quantity over four pi by the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and the energy of a photon is equal to this constant times the speed of light over wavelength. Give this constant, denoted lowercase h, named for a German founder of quantum theory.

The phrases ma non troppo and con moto may be appended to terms describing this property. Using rubato allows a performer to adjust this aspect of a piece. The terms accelerando and ritardando suggest a change in this musical property. A common term for marking this property of music, allegro, is typically realized at about 120 beats per minute. Name this term describing how fast or slow a musician should perform music.

A character in this novel battles wineskins and fights Samson Carasco disguised as the Knight of Mirrors. This novel's title character rides the old horse Rocinante and tries to honor his fictional lady-love, Dulcinea, with the help of a farmer named Sancho Panza. Name this Miguel de Cervantes novel in which the title man tilts at windmills he thinks are giants while imagining he's a knight.
answers: The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quijote of La Mancha
El Ingenioso hidalgo Don Quixote de la Mancha

question: A nightclub fire in the city of Kočani in this natino killed at least 59 people and injured more than 155 others. Composition of these mathematical objects make the codomain of one of them the domain of the other. The vertical line test can easily determine whether a given graph describes one of these objects. In these relations, every input has exactly one possible output. Name these mathematical objects, often written in "f of x" form, often taught in algebra as "machines" that turn a number into a new number.

This operation had sites at Hanford, Washington and Oak Ridge, Tennessee; 60,000 acres of the latter were bought by the Army Corps of Engineers. Its military leader was Leslie Groves, and "Trinity" was one experiment from this project conducted at Los Alamos, New Mexico, on J. Robert Oppenheimer's watch. This man led a raid to rescue his wife with his friend Jamuka, who later turned on him as a rival warlord. This ruler destroyed the Khwarezmian empire by sacking Samarkand. He was succeeded by his son, Ogedei, and his descendants founded China's Yuan dynasty. This man's grandson was named Kublai; that grandson would control the largest land empire in history. This artist recently released a pop album titled "Mayhem". Her debut album, "The Fame," released in 2008, catapulted her to stardom with hits like "Just Dance" and "Poker Face." The Capsian people lived in the northern foothills of this mountain range. This range, whose easternmost subrange is the Aures Mountains, was home to an extinct species of bear, the only bear native to the continent. It is south of the Rif Mountains, and its highest peak, Jebel Toubkal, is visible from Marrakesh, Morocco. Name this North African mountain range named for a Titan who held up the heavens.

The new-music "Kronos" ensemble plays instruments in this family. This country lies southeast of Mayotte, a French departement that is claimed by Comoros. While it itself was under French control, this country became known as the Malagasy Republic for two decades before its full independence. Shortly after this event, photographs were taken of three "tramps" with disputed identities walking under police escort. This tournament's bracket, a visual representation of the tournament's structure, has become a cultural phenomenon, with millions of people participating in bracket pools to predict the winners of each game. The tournament culminates in the Final Four, where the four remaining teams compete for the national championship. It features a single-elimination format, meaning that a single loss eliminates a team from contention. The London equations describe this phenomenon. In a theory of this phenomenon, electrons near the Fermi level form Cooper pairs; that theory, an alternative to Ginzburg-Landau theory, is the BCS theory of this phenomenon. YBCO displays the high-temperature variety of this phenomenon. Materials that exhibit this phenomenon are perfect diamagnets, as they expel magnetic fields in the Meissner effect, which allows them to levitate. In this nation, 53 people were killed after the United States launched air and naval strikes against the Houthi rebel group. Its ancient city of Sana'a is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world, boasting a rich history and unique architecture. It is located on the Arabian Peninsula. What is the name of this country, bordered by Saudi Arabia and Oman?

This American military officer controversially kept Emperor Hirohito from facing war crimes trials, and helped write the constitution of Japan. During the Korean War, he had wanted to cross the Yalu River to attack the Chinese, and was eventually removed from command after trying to drum up support for this offensive in Congress. He also was in charge of removing the Bonus Army from Washington. This actor's passion for Italian cuisine led to the creation of his popular CNN series, "Searching for Italy," where he explores the diverse regional dishes and culinary traditions of the country. He has also written cookbooks and has become a respected figure in the world of food and wine. His versatile acting career includes roles in films like "The Devil Wears Prada," "The Hunger Games," and "Spotlight." This actor's signature move, a high-flying spinning back kick, has become synonymous with his action film persona. His martial arts background includes training in karate, kickboxing, and Muay Thai, which he incorporates into his film roles. Who is this actor, known for his action films and his nickname, "The Muscles from Brussels"?

Segregation in the area around this structure was the subject of a 1964 Zonian protest over display of the American flag. John Hay negotiated a treaty for the construction of this project with Philippe-Jean Bunau-Varilla that allowed the construction of Gatun Lake near Colon, as well as a series of artificial locks that transport cargo through this waterway. President Donald Trump has threatened to withdraw from this multinational organization. This organization's Article 5, a cornerstone of its collective defense principle, states that an attack on one member is considered an attack on all members, requiring a response. Its headquarters are located in Brussels, Belgium. It was established in 1949 with the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty. What is the name of this intergovernmental military alliance between North American and European countries?

Early reforms made by this ruler include imposing a beard tax and abolishing the Boyar-controlled Duma. This ruler studied shipbuilding in the Netherlands while on his Grand Embassy to Western Europe. A bronze equestrian statue of this ruler stands in his namesake city on the Gulf of Finland. Name this Tsar who modernized Russia in the early 18th century.

This baseball player has won three American League MVP awards, showcasing his sustained excellence and dominance in the sport. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest baseball players of his generation. He plays center field for the Los Angeles Angels. Who is this player, known for his exceptional combination of power, speed, and fielding ability?

This figure, when traveling to Gerar openly claimed that his wife was his sister, which prompted the king in that area to have her brought to him. This figure was also visited by 3 men who had come to tell him that his wife would bear a child. This was to reflect and honor the covenant that he had made with God about populating the land with his numerous descendants. He sent away Hagar and Ishmael at the request of his wife, and had earlier sent his nephew Lot away towards Sodom. Name this "father of many nations", whose wife Sarah gave birth to his son Isaac.

This river's name is followed by "do norte" and "do sul" in the names of two Brazilian states, and a change in its path was the basis of the Chazimal border dispute. This river rises in the San Juan Mountains before passing Laredo and Matamoros and receiving water from the Conchos and Pecos Rivers. One version of this law states that heat cannot flow spontaneously from low temperature to high temperature. Another version of this law states that it is impossible to convert heat completely into work in a cyclic process. Maxwell proposed a thought experiment in which sorting air molecules seems to violate this law. Identify this law, credited to French physicist Sadi Carnot, which states that "in a closed system, a process that occurs will tend to increase the total entropy of the universe."

The speaker of this poem thinks that a phrase "caught from some unhappy master" is the only answer possible for the question "is there balm in Gilead," which he asks a character who has "perched upon a bust of Pallas." The speaker tries to forget about a "radiant maiden" named Lenore, but is tormented by the title bird, who repeatedly caws "nevermore." Name this poem by Edgar Allen Poe.
incorrect3: The Fall of the House of Usher

question: The ratio between this quantity for a substance and this quantity for water is the specific gravity. Antoine Baume invented a pair of hydrometer scales to measure this quantity. That device works based on Archimedes' principle, which can calculate the mass of an object based on the volume of fluid displaced. This quantity is symbolized rho, and strangely ice has a lower value for this quantity than liquid water. Name this quantity, the ratio of mass to volume.

This international organization recently elected its first female leader. This organization's five-ring symbol, designed by Pierre de Coubertin, represents the union of the five continents and the universality of the Olympic Games. Its headquarters are located in Lausanne, Switzerland. It was founded in 1894 to revive the ancient Olympic Games. What is the name of this governing body of the modern Olympic Games?

One notable volcano located on this continent is Mount Erebus. Vinson Massif is the highest mountain on this continent. Argentina claims part of this continent as part of its Tierra del Fuego Province; however, an international treaty suspends all claims to parts of this continent in order to advance scientific activity such as studying emperor penguins and ice cores. Name this icy continent, the location of the South Pole.

Disney recently released a live action version of a classic film with Rachel Zegler starring in its namesake role. This character's iconic song, "Someday My Prince Will Come," expresses her hope for true love and a better future. Her stepmother, the Evil Queen, is driven by jealousy and seeks to eliminate her, leading to the famous poisoned apple plot. She finds refuge in a cottage with seven dwarfs, each with a distinct personality and name. This event was led by Mirabeau and Abbe Sieyes. It happened when the Third Estate went to discuss the new reforms proposed by Jacques Necker that would've changed voting in the Estates-General to be by head instead of by estate. It was necessitated because the participants were locked out of the room where they normally met, and represented an assertion of the sovereignty of the people over the king. This is what event where the participants swore to not disband until a constitution was written while in a sporting arena.

Heathrow Airport outside of this major city had to close for a day due to a fire at an electrical substation. This city's iconic Big Ben, officially known as the Elizabeth Tower, is a famous clock tower that has become a symbol of the city and the United Kingdom. Its River Thames is a major waterway that flows through the city, spanned by numerous historic bridges. It is home to Buckingham Palace, the official residence of the British monarch. Frederick Muhlenberg was the first person to hold this office. This office is granted appointment power for select and conference committees. It confers the ability to schedule legislation for the floor and the person in this position controls the flow of debate. It is second in the line of presidential succession. answers: Speaker of the House of Representatives

question: Google announced an agreement for their largest acquisition ever with the company Wiz which is headquarted in this nation. This Middle Eastern country, known for its technological innovation and its significant role in the development of modern agriculture, is home to the ancient city of Jerusalem, a holy site for Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Its Dead Sea, the lowest point on Earth's surface, is a unique geographical feature. It was established as a modern state in 1948, following the end of World War II. What is the name of this country, located on the eastern shore of the Mediterranean Sea?

This country contains the ruins of Catalhoyuk, a Neolithic city north of the Taurus Mountains. Mount Arafat, the traditional landing site of Noah's Ark, is in this country. The northwestern tip of this country is separated by the Dardanelles and the Bosporus from the rest of this country on the Anatolian Plateau in Asia Minor. Bordered on the north by the Black Sea and on the south by the Mediterranean Sea, name this country that spans two continents, and whose most populous city is Istanbul.

This city's tallest building, completed in 2017, is the Comcast Technology Center, and Lancaster Avenue runs through this city's "Main Line", including its suburbs of Wayne and Bryn Mawr. Universities in this city lying along the Delaware and Schuylkill Rivers include Drexel, Temple, and the University of Pennsylvania. Name this fifth-largest city in the United States, the "city of brotherly love" and cheesesteaks which is home to Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell.

This team recently sold for an NBA record $6.1 billion dollars.
