Their rivalry with the Los Angeles Lakers, a matchup known for its intensity and star power, is considered one of the greatest rivalries in sports history. They have won a record 18 NBA championships. What is the name of this team, known for its rich history, its passionate fanbase, and its iconic green and white colors?

Thalassemia patients have a reduced quantity of these cells, which can be measured using the mean corpuscular volume. The schizont phase of malaria is found within these cells. At the end of their lifespan, which is about 120 days, these cells are relocated to the spleen and destroyed. The body condition when a low number of these cells are present is anemia. These cells, which do not have nuclei, gain their color from an iron-containing protein known as hemoglobin. Name these cells in the bloodstream, which carry oxygen throughout the body.

A new version of this game set in Japan was released in 2025. This video game series' unique Animus device allows players to relive the memories of their ancestors through genetic memory, a core element of its narrative. The series often features historical figures and events, blending historical fiction with action-adventure gameplay. Its iconic hidden blade, a retractable wrist-mounted weapon, is a signature tool for its assassins. What is the name of this popular video game franchise, developed by Ubisoft, which explores the historical conflict between the Assassins and the Templars?

This brother of Chrysaor created the Hippocrene fountain. This figure was credited with helping a hero slay the Chimera and was tamed with a special girdle given by Athena to that hero, Bellerophon, in a dream. Eventually employed as Zeus' bolt-carrier, this figure sprang from the neck of Medusa after she was decapitated by Perseus. Name this winged horse from Greek myth.

In one novel from this country, the protagonist is born with a sentient mineral in his mouth, Dream of The Red Chamber. Another work from this country centers on a band of 108 outlaws with a stronghold in a marsh. Another work from here details Pigsy and Sandy's journey to India. Identify this country whose four great classics include Water Margin and Journey to the West, home to such writers as Li Po.

The tawny frogmouth is often mistaken as this type of animal. These animals are divided into two families called Strigidae and Tytonidae, which are more commonly known as the "true" and "barn" varieties. These animals have serrated feathers that allow them to fly silently and they can turn their heads 270 degrees in either direction. Types of this animal include the Snowy and Great Horned species. Name these nocturnal birds.

Pope Francis, who is from this nation, was recently released from hospital after battling pneumonia and related illnesses. He is the first pope from the Americas and the first from the Southern Hemisphere. This nation is also the homeland of tango. Its capital city, Buenos Aires, is a vibrant metropolis known for its European-influenced architecture and its rich cultural heritage. What is the name of this country, located in South America and known for its gauchos, its vast pampas grasslands, and its football rivalry with Brazil?

One city near this body of water, Ulan-Ude, is the capital of the region named for the indigenous Buryats, who inhabit the largest island in this lake, Olkhon. Another city near this lake is Irkutsk, which lies on the only river flowing out of this lake, the Angara. The Serenge and Lena Rivers flow into this lake, which is the oldest in the world. Name this incredibly deep lake in Russia, the largest freshwater lake in the world by volume.

This boxer turned businessman recently passed away at the age of 76. Known for his devastating punching power, he made a remarkable comeback in his later career, winning the heavyweight championship again at the age of 45, becoming the oldest heavyweight champion in history. He achieved legendary status with his "Rumble in the Jungle" fight against Muhammad Ali in 1974. He is also known for his successful line of grilling products. Who is this former heavyweight boxing champion?

This man was originally only supposed to act as regent for his infant nephew, Amyntas IV. Held as a hostage in his youth by Thebes, he received his military and diplomatic education from Epaminondas of Thebes. While in power, this man intervened in the Social War to gain land and resources for his kingdom, fought the Third Sacred War, and made threats on Sparta. However his reign over Greece ended in 336 BC when he was assassinated by one of his bodyguards. Name this King of Macedonia, father of Alexander.

Marinus van der Lubbe was blamed for one of these events that occurred at the Reichstag building, and 146 garment workers died during one of these at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory. Mrs. O'Leary's cow is blamed for one of these events in Chicago, and Nero apocryphally played a lyre during another one in Rome. Name these natural disasters, one of which broke out after the 1906 earthquake in San Francisco.

A figure on the left of this painting wears a cameo brooch that may depict Persephone over a polka-dotted brown apron, and looks uneasily toward another figure. A strangely ornate window in the Dibble House in Iowa inspired the background of this painting, for which the artist's dentist modeled as a man wearing denim overalls and holding a pitchfork. Name this painting of a stern-looking couple, created by Grant Wood.

This film, directed by the Coen brothers, features a chilling performance by Javier Bardem as the relentless and enigmatic hitman Anton Chigurh. Its stark and violent depiction of the American West is adapted from a novel by Cormac McCarthy. The film won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Supporting Actor for Bardem. What is the name of this 2007 neo-Western thriller?

This natural feature is located off the coast of Queensland and contains no atolls. The calcium carbonate shells of the creatures who live here have experienced coral bleaching. Name this Australian natural feature which is the largest living structure in the world.

One character in this work is a consul named Sharpless, to whom the titular character declares that her child's name is Sorrow. Another character is a marriage broker named Goro, who shows a house to a naval officer. That officer marries the title character and later deserts her to marry an American named, prompting to kill herself with her father's knife. Lieutenant Pinkerton is a character in what Giacomo Puccini opera about a Japanese woman?

Adrian Smith used a Y-shaped design for one of these structures located next to the Dubai Fountain. An early architect of these structures, Louis Sullivan, designed one of them named for Elias Wainwright. William Van Alen designed the Chrysler Building, one of these structures in New York. The Burj Khalifa is the tallest of what towering buildings often found in large cities?

This baseball player is known for his exceptional all-around skills, excelling both offensively and defensively. He won the American League MVP award in 2018 with the Boston Red Sox and World Series titles with the Los Angeles Dodgers in 2020 and 2024. He is a versatile player, capable of playing multiple positions, including outfield and second base. Who is this player, known for his power hitting, speed, and Gold Glove-caliber defense?

The Trump administration deported two planeloads of migrants accused of being a part of a Venezuelan gang to this country. This Central American country, the smallest in the region, is known for its surfing destinations and its black sand beaches along the Pacific coast. It is also the first country in the world to adopt Bitcoin as legal tender. Its capital city, San Salvador, is a bustling metropolis located in a volcanic region. What is the name of this country, bordered by Guatemala and Honduras?

This band's album "OK Computer," released in 1997, is often hailed as a masterpiece and a defining album of the 1990s, exploring themes of technology, identity, and alienation. Their lead singer, Thom Yorke, is known for his distinctive vocals and his introspective songwriting. The band is known for their experimental approach to rock music, incorporating elements of electronic and alternative music. What is the name of this British rock band, known for their innovative sound and their critically acclaimed albums like "The Bends" and "Kid A"?

The Speedwell failed twice while sailing with this ship, which was captained by Christopher Jones. It landed in Provincetown Harbor in Cape Cod, where men like military officer Miles Standish and governor William Bradford signed a namesake "Compact" outlining the government of their new colony, Plymouth Plantation. Name this ship that, in 1620, crossed the Atlantic to bring the first Pilgrim families to North America.

A nurse born on this island ran the "British Hotel" during the Crimean War. This island, the birthplace of Mary Seacole, faced the Morant Bay Rebellion and wars involving escaped slaves called "Maroons." From his base on this island, Henry Morgan raided Spanish settlements in Panama. On this island, the nickname "Sodom of the New World" was given to the notorious pirate haven of Port Royal. What Caribbean island has its capital at Kingston?

This sport, one of the oldest known team sports, is traditionally played on horseback, with players using long-handled mallets to drive a small ball down a field and into the opponent's goal. Matches are divided into periods called chukkers, each lasting seven minutes. The sport has a rich history, with evidence of similar games played in ancient Persia as early as the 6th century BC. What is the name of this sport, often associated with royalty and the elite?

The Drake Passage separates the South Shetland Islands of this landmass and Hornos Island of a nearby landmass. Seas that border it include Scotia Sea and Bellingshausen Sea. Part of the landmass is named Queen Maud Land, and that is bordered by the Weddell Sea. The Ellsworth mountain range contains the largest mountains on this continent. Several features of the continent are named after Amundsen including a bordering sea and an ice shelf. This is what continent notable for having penguins and the South Pole.

Robert Merton's strain theory seeks to explain why this phenomenon exists. A late 20th century decrease in this activity may be the result of unleaded gasoline. Jeremy Bentham argued that those that participated in this type of activity should be put in the Panopticon, in which one central guard could observe everyone. Name this type of deviant activity that is investigated and punished by law enforcement.

Two astronauts from this national agency, Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore, recently returned to Earth, ending a nine-month trip to space that was supposed to last eight days. This agency's iconic Apollo program achieved the historic feat of landing the first humans on the Moon in 1969. Its Hubble Space Telescope has provided stunning images of the universe, revolutionizing our understanding of astronomy. What is the name of this independent agency of the U.S. federal government responsible for civilian space programs?

This man coined the term "satyagraha" to describe his philosophy of political resistance, as exemplified by the 240-mile-long Salt March he undertook to protest British salt monopolies. This man launched the "Quit India Movement" to demand independence from Britain. In 1948, a Hindu nationalist assassinated what Indian nonviolent activist and independence leader?

This poet wrote that "the Windows failed and then I could not see to see," in one poem where this poet "heard a Fly buzz when" she "died." In another poem, this poet wrote that she "paused before a House that seemed A Swelling of the Ground" and "surmised the Horses' Heads Were toward Eternity" in a "Carriage" that "held but just Ourselves And Immortality." Name this author of "Because I could not stop for death," known as the "Belle of Amherst."

This band's lead singer, David Byrne, is known for his unique stage presence and his quirky dance moves. Their music blends elements of new wave, funk, and art rock, creating a distinctive and innovative sound. Their 1980 album, "Remain in Light," is considered a landmark album of the era, showcasing their rhythmic complexity and their experimental approach. What is the name of this American rock band, known for songs like "Psycho Killer," "Burning Down the House," and "Once in a Lifetime"?

One leader of this polity first distinguished himself by rescuing two surrounded soldiers on the eve of a battle; that man was Mirabeau Lamar. The Battle of San Jacinto secured the independence for this polity, which had endured the Goliad massacre. A namesake hurricane in 1900 devastated the city of Galveston in this polity, which was also the home state of a president who passed the Civil Rights Act and championed the "Great Society," Lyndon B. Johnson. Name this home state of George W. Bush, a former republic and home of the Alamo.

This annual long-distance sled dog race, held in Alaska, covers a grueling course of approximately 1,000 miles, testing the endurance and resilience of both mushers and their dog teams. The race commemorates a historic trail which was a former supply route that once connected communities in Alaska. Mushers face extreme weather conditions, challenging terrain, and the need for exceptional dog care throughout the race. What is the name of this iconic race, which typically begins in Anchorage and ends in Nome?
answers: The Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race

question: Edna St. Vincent Millay described the coastline of this state in "Renascence" and its northernmost point is Estcort Station, while its largest city lies on Casco Bay. The Kennebec River drains into a namesake gulf from this state's Moosehead Lake, and Baxter State Park is the site of its highest peak, Mt. Katahdin. Part of the border with its northern neighbor is formed by the Saint John River, which flows into the Bay of Fundy, and it largest cities include Bangor, Lewiston, and Portland. Identify this U.S. state, the site of Acadia National Park and eastern neighbor of New Hampshire, with capital at Augusta.

One example of these objects is an equilateral triangle whose center is removed to create three new equilateral triangles, each of whose centers is similarly removed, and so on. The Sierpinski triangle is one of these images, as is the Mandelbrot set. Name these mathematical images that resemble themselves at intense zooming levels.

Anti-government protests broke out across Turkey following the arrest of mayor Ekrem Imamoglu of this city. He was thought to be a potential opposition candidate to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. This city is home to Hagia Sophia. Its Bosphorus Strait, a narrow waterway, divides the city between Europe and Asia, making it a transcontinental city. Its Grand Bazaar, one of the largest and oldest covered markets in the world, offers a vibrant and bustling shopping experience. What is the name of this city, formerly known as Constantinople, located in Turkey?

After he was freed, this man studied at the Hampton Institute and the Wayland Seminary before ascending to his most well-known position. He was assisted by Henry Rogers of Standard Oil, who funded schools in the south, although this man garnered criticism from the NAACP and W.E.B. DuBois over his ideas of integrating African-Americans into society. Name this African-American who delivered the Atlanta Address and who founded the Tuskegee Institute.

This HBO series, set in a lawless 1870s South Dakota mining town, features a rich ensemble cast and a gritty portrayal of the American West. Its creator, David Milch, is known for his complex characters and his use of poetic and profane language. The series was praised for its historical accuracy and its exploration of themes like civilization, corruption, and the struggle for power. What is the name of this critically acclaimed Western drama, which ran for three seasons?

One attempt on the life of this son of Robert the Devil was foiled when the would-be assassin stabbed a child sleeping next to this man by accident, and this man put down an insurrection against his rule at the Battle of Val-es-Dunes. This man ordered the Harrying of the North, which devastated Northumbria and he was often aided by his half-brothers Odo and Robert. This man's greatest victory is depicted on the Bayoux Tapestry and was preceded by the Battle of Stamford Bridge. That battle saw this man defeat Harold Godwinson for control of a kingdom which this man issued the Domesday Book for. Name this victor at the Battle of Hastings, the first Norman king of England.

One work by this composer includes the sections "O Death, where is thy sting?" and "I know that my Redeemer liveth." He included two bourrees in a collection of three suites first played on barges on the River Thames for George I. This composer of Water Music composed a fugue on the line "and he shall reign for ever and ever" in a chorus named "Hallelujah." Name this composer of Messiah.

The title character in one of this man's works is killed by Diana Moon Glampers, while in another work Felix Hoenikker's invention of "ice-nine" leads to the destruction of the world. This author of "Harrison Bergeron" also wrote about a character that alternates between Tralfamadore and the fire bombings of Dresden after becoming "unstuck in time". Name this author of Cat's Cradle, who wrote about Billy Pilgrim in Slaughterhouse Five.

This puzzle game's unique gun, also known as the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, allows players to create interconnected portals between two flat surfaces, revolutionizing puzzle-solving in video games. The game's antagonist, GLaDOS, a sarcastic and malevolent artificial intelligence, provides darkly humorous commentary and challenges throughout the game. Its innovative gameplay mechanics and its witty writing have earned it critical acclaim and a dedicated fanbase. What is the name of this game, developed by Valve, known for its iconic portals and its memorable characters?

One building in this city is home to six captive ravens, which are said to guard the security of the nation. Piccadilly Circus is located in this city's West End. This city, home to landmarks such as Trafalgar Square and Hyde Park, also contains the Tower Bridge, which crosses the River Thames. What city, home to Buckingham Palace and the British Museum, is the capital of the United Kingdom?

According to the US Census Bureau, the top two fastest-growing metro areas between 2023-24 were located in this US state. This state, known for its extensive coastline and its warm, sunny climate, is home to Walt Disney World, a major tourist attraction that draws millions of visitors each year. Its Everglades National Park, a unique ecosystem of wetlands and mangrove forests, is home to a diverse array of wildlife. What is the name of this state, located in the southeastern United States?

This cue sport, played on a large table covered with a green cloth, features a set of colored balls and a white cue ball, with players aiming to pot the balls in a specific sequence. Its highest possible break, a score of 147, is achieved by potting all the red balls with blacks and then all the colored balls. The sport's origins can be traced back to the British Army in India in the late 19th century. What is the name of this cue sport, known for its strategic gameplay and its iconic green table?

In these objects an outside observer can only observe angular momentum, electric charge, and mass via the No-Hair theorem. They are surrounded by an accretion disk and are thought to contain a point of infinite density, or singularity, at their center. Their event horizon is the point inside which the escape velocity exceeds the speed of light. What objects are so massive that even light cannot escape them?

This man's military career began in disaster when his forces killed a neutral French commander at Jumonville Glen, sparking a war. This former aide to Edward Braddock was forced to surrender Fort Necessity. The Conway Cabal failed to depose this general, who later personally put down the Whiskey Rebellion during his presidency. Name this commander-in-chief of the Continental Army.

While serving as Chancellor of the Exchequer under Stanley Baldwin, this man controversially returned his country to the gold standard. As Lord of the Admiralty, he oversaw the disastrous Gallipoli landings during World War One. He said "I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears, and sweat" in his first speech in his highest office, and he reached that post upon the resignation of Neville Chamberlain. Name this Prime Minister of Britain during World War II.

This figure ordered the Goliad Massacre, and he was severely injured by French cannon fire at Veracruz during the Pastry War. The Treaties of Velasco were signed following this leader's capture after the Battle of San Jacinto, and he was responsible for the deaths of Jim Bowie and Davy Crockett. Name this self-styled "Napoleon of the West," a Mexican general infamous for his attempt to seize the Alamo.

This American fashion brand recently filed for bankruptcy for the second time. This fashion retailer, known for its trendy and affordable clothing, originally began as a small store in Los Angeles. Its fast-fashion business model, characterized by quickly adapting to the latest trends and offering a wide variety of styles, has made it a popular destination for young shoppers. What is the name of this clothing chain, often associated with a youthful and budget-conscious demographic?

A ruler with this first name employed Francis Drake as an admiral in a conflict against the Spanish Armada and declared she had the "heart and stomach of a king." Shakespeare lived during the "era" of that ruler with this name. Another ruler with this name lost her daughter in-law Diana in a car crash and is the mother of Charles, Prince of Wales. Give this name of the most recent queen of the United Kingdom.

This country's walled port city of Saint-Malo was a historic center of piracy and is the starting point for a sailing race that ends at this country's overseas territory of Guadeloupe. The only Celtic language in mainland Europe is spoken in this country's region of Brittany, which is west of Normandy. The Seine River passes through this nation's capital city. In what country is the Eiffel Tower found?

This sport involves using a small, narrow boat propelled by a double-bladed paddle. It can be practiced in various settings, including rivers, lakes, and oceans. Different types of this sport include whitewater, sea, and recreational versions. What is the name of this activity which is competed at the Olympics?

This toy's iconic interlocking bricks, designed with studs and tubes, allow for endless creative possibilities and have become a symbol of imaginative play. Its name is derived from the Danish phrase "leg godt," meaning "play well." The company that produces it has expanded into various themes, including licensed properties like Star Wars and Harry Potter, alongside its own original creations. What is the name of this popular construction toy, enjoyed by children and adults worldwide?

One author with this surname wrote a novel in which a clergyman's daughter works for the Bloomfield and Murray families, and another described the death of Helen Burns at Lowood. Agnes Grey is a work by one of these authors, whose sister wrote about Catherine Earnshaw's doomed love for Heathcliff. Name these literary sisters, including Emily and Charlotte, whose collective novels include Jane Eyre and Wuthering Heights.

The coelom forms the haemal systems of members of this phylum, which is the second largest phylum of deuterosomes. Some members of the Ophiuroidea class in this phylum have a double row of ambulacra. Organisms in this phylum contain ampullae, which form tube feet, and a water vascular system. All members of this phylum exhibit fivefold radial symmetry, and its name derives from the Greek for "spiny skin." Name this phylum, which includes sand dollars, sea urchins, and starfish.

The hydrocarbon haze surrounding Titan contributes to the "anti-" form of this process. The termite fumigant sulfuryl fluoride is 160 times more potent an emitter than methane in this process. Svante Arrhenius linked this effect to a rise in carbon dioxide concentration, and a "runaway" form of it caused Venus to develop extreme global warming. Name this effect in which atmospheric gases absorb thermal radiation and redirect it back to Earth's surface, generating higher average temperatures.

This Formula One driver, known for his intense rivalry with James Hunt in the 1970s, made a remarkable comeback after a horrific crash at the 1976 German Grand Prix, suffering severe burns and inhaling toxic fumes. He won three Formula One World Championships, driving for Ferrari and McLaren. He later became an airline entrepreneur, founding Lauda Air. Who is this Austrian racing legend?

Three days before this battle, Jubal Early's troops turned the tide at Blackburn's Ford. Wilmer McLean's house served as headquarters for one side in this battle, which was decided when Irvin McDowell's forces retreated after Joseph Johnston reinforced P.G.T. Beauregard. Stonewall Jackson earned his nickname at what first major battle of the Civil War, also the site of a second battle one year later?

In this novel, Madame de Thoux [duh THOH] and Cassy reunite with their lost relatives and Ophelia is charged with educating Topsy. Eliza escapes with her son over the frozen Ohio River in this novel, and reunites with her husband, George, who had been owned by Mr Harris. This novel's protagonist rescues Eva St Clare and dies after being sold to Simon Legree. Name this novel about a title slave, written by Harriet Beecher Stowe.

This science fiction series, set in a future where humanity has colonized the solar system, features a unique and diverse cast of characters, including the crew of the Rocinante and various political factions from Earth, Mars, and the asteroid belt. The show's realistic portrayal of space travel, with its emphasis on physics and the challenges of living in zero gravity, sets it apart from other science fiction series. The discovery of the protomolecule, a mysterious alien substance, drives the central plot and introduces complex moral and philosophical dilemmas. What is the name of this critically acclaimed television series, based on the book series by James S.A. Corey?

Jair Bolsonaro, this country's former president, will face trial for an attempted coup. This South American country, known for its vibrant Carnival celebrations, is home to the Amazon rainforest, the world's largest tropical rainforest. Its iconic Christ the Redeemer statue overlooks the city of Rio de Janeiro. It is also the birthplace of samba music and the martial art Capoeira. What is the name of this country, the largest in South America?

This province's city of Gatineau is part of its National Capital Region. This province forms the majority of the Labrador Peninsula. Its largest city, on an island in the confluence of the Ottawa and St. Lawrence Rivers, hosted the opening ceremonies of the 1976 Summer Olympics in the Stade Olympique. Name this French-speaking Canadian province, home to Montreal.

Congressman Charles Wilson pushed to covertly supply this country with Stinger missiles in Operation Cyclone. The Saur Revolution installed a socialist regime in this country, leading to an ill-fated 1979 Soviet invasion that was countered by its mujahideen. In the wake of the September 11th attacks, a US-led NATO coalition invaded what country that was liberated by the 2001 ousting of the Taliban from its capital, Kabul?

Each of these structures has a different angular momentum described by its azimuthal quantum number. One variety of this concept is dumbbell- shaped as it has two lobes, while the lowest configuration of these objects are spherical. The plum pudding model preceded the atomic model of this structure. Name these electron-housing probability regions which come in s, p, d and f varieties.

This Formula One driver, known for his charismatic personality and his playboy lifestyle, won the 1976 Formula One World Championship in a dramatic season-long battle with Niki Lauda. He drove for teams like Hesketh and McLaren, and his rivalry with Lauda was famously portrayed in the 2013 film "Rush." He retired from racing in 1979 and became a commentator for BBC television. Who is this British racing driver?

Several U.S. officials, including the vice president and the defense secretary, used this app to discuss plans to attack Houthi rebels in Yemen. This messaging app, known for its strong emphasis on privacy and security, uses end-to-end encryption by default for all messages, ensuring that only the sender and recipient can read them. It was endorsed by Edward Snowden, who highlighted its commitment to user privacy. What is the name of this app?

This film, directed by Wes Anderson, is known for its meticulous and symmetrical set design, its pastel color palette, and its quirky characters. It tells the story of a legendary concierge and his lobby boy at a famous European hotel between the first and second World Wars. The film's ensemble cast includes Ralph Fiennes, Tony Revolori, F. Murray Abraham, and Willem Dafoe. It won four Academy Awards, primarily in technical and design categories, including Best Production Design and Best Costume Design. What is the title of this visually stunning and whimsical 2014 film?
incorrect3: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou

question: The last words of one person attempting to reach this location were "I'm just going outside and may be some time." The Endurance and Nimrod expeditions to reach this location were captained by Ernest Shackleton. After attempting to use horses to reach this location, Robert Smith was beaten to this location by the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen. Name this location near the center of Antarctica.

In this country, Walter Burley Griffin designed a planned city focused around a Parliamentary Triangle. The Carlton Gardens, in one of this nation's state capitals, contains a hall that hosted this country's 1888 centennial celebration. A through-arch bridge nicknamed "the coathanger" and a white-sailed opera house are in this country, in the capital city of New South Wales. Name this country governed from Canberra, whose largest cities include Melbourne and Sydney.

This country's Chubut province is home to the largest Welsh community outside of the British Isles. To this day, it disputes the Falklands, a group of islands in the southern Atlantic Ocean, with the United Kingdom. The Rio de la Plata separates this country from Uruguay, and it controls the eastern half of Tierra del Fuego. Name this South American country whose capital is Buenos Aires.

In one poem by this author, a character is said to be "all pine" while the narrator is "all apple orchard," and "good fences" are said to make "good neighbors." This poet of "Mending Wall" has "miles to go before" he sleeps in his "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening." This poet's most famous work sees a young man take a path which "has made all the difference" after "two roads diverged in a yellow wood." Name this poet of "The Road Not Taken."

This baseball player, whose rare T206 baseball card is one of the most valuable and sought-after collectibles in the world, was nicknamed "The Flying Dutchman" for his speed and agility on the basepaths. He was one of the first five players inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1936. He played shortstop for the Pittsburgh Pirates for most of his career, winning eight batting titles. Who is this baseball legend, considered one of the greatest shortstops of all time?

Beehive-shaped rock formations are found in this country's Bungle Bungle Range, while crocodile attacks are common in its Kakadu National Park. Rock art in this country often includes images of the Rainbow Serpent. This country's longest river, the Murray, flows into the Indian Ocean just outside Adelaide. A large sandstone rock that appears to glow red at sunset named Uluru is found in this country's arid interior, the Outback. Name this country with many native marsupials such as koalas and kangaroos.

This man authorized John Sullivan to attack the Iroquois. This man was defeated by Louis Coulon de Villiers, and was forced to surrender Fort Necessity, a move which prompted the Braddock expedition. This general was criticised by Thomas Conway after failing to defend against the Philadelphia Campaign, and he surprised Hessian soldiers after crossing the Delaware River. Name this first President of the United States.

A civilization in this modern-day country employed elite jaguar knights that fought for three city-states called the Triple Alliance. El Castillo is a step pyramid in this country's Chichen Itza temple complex. This modern-day country's cities of Tlacopan and Tenochtitlan were destroyed in Hernan Cortes' conquest. What modern-day country was home to the northern part of the Maya and the Aztecs?

R. A. Fisher suggested this scientist falsified data because of the exactness of his ratios, and his most significant paper was Experiments in Plant Hybridization. One result of this man's work was the law of independent assortment, discovered by examining traits like tall vs. dwarf and round vs. wrinkled. Name this biologist and monk whose breeding of pea plants led to the basic principles of heredity.

This dark fantasy film, set in post-Civil War Spain, weaves together a realistic portrayal of the political climate with a fantastical story of a young girl's escape into a magical world. It features creatures designed by Guillermo del Toro, including the Pale Man and the Faun, which are both terrifying and mesmerizing. The film explores themes of innocence, obedience, and the struggle between good and evil, using symbolism and allegory to convey its message. What is the title of this 2006 Spanish-language film, directed by Guillermo del Toro?

This chemical was legally banned from being added to drinking water in Utah. This naturally occurring mineral, found in water, soil, and rocks, is added to many public water supplies and dental products due to its effectiveness in preventing tooth decay. It strengthens tooth enamel, making it more resistant to acid attacks from bacteria and sugars in the mouth. While beneficial in small amounts, excessive intake can lead to fluorosis, a condition that affects tooth and bone development. What is the name of this mineral, commonly associated with dental health?

Due to illness, this novel's protagonist moves to the small country town of Yonville. In one scene in this novel, the title character's husband Charles ruins his reputation as a country doctor after a botched operation on Hippolyte's club foot. The title character is frequently bored of her humdrum life, leading her to engage in extravagant affairs with men like Leon Dupis and Rodolphe Boulanger, who will not help her with her debts, leading to the title character's suicide. Name this novel centering around Emma, a work by Gustave Flaubert.

This baseball player, a legend of the Negro Leagues, was known for his flamboyant personality and his colorful nicknames, including "Satchelfoot" and "The Midnight Rider." He claimed to have invented the "hesitation pitch," a changeup delivery that disrupted batters' timing. He finally made his Major League Baseball debut at the age of 42, pitching for the Cleveland Indians. Who is this Hall of Fame pitcher, whose career spanned several decades and whose talent and showmanship captivated audiences?

Two men associated with the development of this tactic are British officers Liddell Hart and JFC Fuller, and another early proponent of this idea was the author of The Army of the Future, Charles de Gaulle. This tactic includes the creation of a center of gravity, or Schwerpunkt, on a front, as well as the coordinated use of artillery and air power to take out strong points in a line, leading to encirclement by armor. Famously put into use by the Nazis in their invasions of Poland, France and Russia name this combined-arms tactic from World War II, German for "lightning war."

This first-person shooter game, set in the underwater city of Rapture, a failed utopia built by Andrew Ryan, explores themes of objectivism, free will, and moral choice. The player character can use plasmids, genetic enhancements that grant superhuman abilities, and various weapons to combat mutated splicers and Big Daddies. The game's narrative is heavily influenced by the philosophies of Ayn Rand and George Orwell. What is the name of this critically acclaimed 2007 game, developed by Irrational Games?

This country was the epicenter of a magnitude 7.7 earthquake leading to over 2000 deaths. This Southeast Asian country, formerly known as Burma, is home to the ancient city of Bagan, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with thousands of Buddhist temples and pagodas. Its Irrawaddy River is a major waterway, vital for transportation and trade. The country is known for its production of jade and teak. What is the name of this country, bordered by India, Bangladesh, China, Laos, and Thailand?

These animals build nests called drays. Some species of this animal can rotate their back paws and go down a tree head-first. The flying type of this animal glides using its skin like a parachute. Name these furry rodents, whose diets mostly consist of nuts and acorns that these animals hide.

In the buildup to this battle, the losing commander set up a fortification at Gloucester shortly after retreating from Williamsburg. A key turning point in this battle was the arrival of reinforcements under Count Rochambeau. British naval forces under Thomas Graves failed to break through the French blockade. Name this final Revolutionary War battle, after which Lord Cornwallis surrendered.

In one story by this author, a man is told that his wife died "in a fit of passion" after finding people playing nine pins in a tavern. In another story by this author, a horse named Gunpowder refuses to cross a bridge. A character created by this author discovers he has fallen asleep for 20 years. This author of "Rip Van Winkle" wrote about discovering the only remains of the love rival of Brom Bones in a smashed pumpkin and a hat. Name this author, who wrote about Ichabod Crane in "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow."

Uros, Amantani, Taquile, and Isla del Sol are a few islands located in this body of water, and the Taraco and Yampupata Peninsula protrude into this body of water. This body of water is fed by the Ilave, Coata, and Ramis Rivers among others, and it empties into the Desaguadero River. Divided into two parts by the Strait of Tiquina, it has the highest elevation of any major lake in the world. Located on the border of Peru and Bolivia is what second largest lake by area and largest by volume in South America?

The smallest type of this value is represented by aleph null. In a thought experiment, David Hilbert's "Grand Hotel" features this many rooms, all occupied, and is still able to accommodate more guests. The set of whole numbers has a "countable" type of this size. Give this value, the number of digits in the decimal expansion of pi, that is represented by a sideways eight.

This state's ski resort of Lake Placid, the site of the 1980 Winter Olympics, and its highest point, Mount Marcy, are both located in the Adirondack Mountains. In the 19th century, its growth was aided by the Erie Canal, which brought settlers west from the Hudson River valley. This state's largest city is composed of five boroughs, including Staten Island, Queens, and the Bronx. Name this Empire State.

This handheld digital pet, created in Japan by Akihiro Yokoi of WiZ and Aki Maita of Bandai, requires users to feed, clean, and play with it to ensure its survival. Its popularity sparked a global craze in the late 1990s, with millions of units sold worldwide. The toy's name is a portmanteau of the Japanese word "tamago" (egg) and "watch." What is the name of this virtual pet, known for its pixelated display and its demanding care requirements?

The Sigsbee Deep is the lowest point in this body of water, and oil is produced in its Bay of Campeche. Rivers that empty into this body of water include the Coosa, Pearl, and Sabine, and cities on its shore include Tampico, Veracruz, and Corpus Christi. Home to Galveston Island and the end of the Rio Grande and Mississippi River name this site of the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

This basketball player, nicknamed "The Big O," is the first player in NBA history to average a triple-double (at least 10 points, 10 rebounds, and 10 assists) for an entire season, a feat he accomplished in 1961-62. He was a member of the 1960 U.S. Olympic gold medal-winning team and won an NBA championship with the Milwaukee Bucks in 1971. He is known for his all-around skills, excelling in scoring, rebounding, and passing. Who is this Hall of Fame guard?

This holiday occurred on March 30, 2025. This Islamic holiday, celebrated at the end of Ramadan, the holy month of fasting, is marked by festive gatherings, the sharing of meals, and the giving of gifts. The exact date of the holiday varies each year, as it is determined by the sighting of the new crescent moon. It is a time for Muslims to express gratitude to Allah for the strength and blessings received during Ramadan. What is the name of this joyous celebration, often referred to as the "Festival of Breaking the Fast"?

One character in this work robs her father and runs away on a ship with Mercy Lewis. In one scene of this play, Ezekiel Cheever finds a doll which was a gift from Mary Warren, and Giles Corey dies asking for "more weight." Ruth and Betty fall into a stupor that is blamed on Tituba, and Abigail Williams accuses John Proctor's wife, Elizabeth, of being a witch. Communism is represented by the Salem Witch Trials in this play by Arthur Miller.

Edward Oxford tried to assassinate this ruler, whose early reign also witnessed the Hastings scandal. This monarch succeeded William IV to the throne and would be the last member of the House of Hanover to rule the United Kingdom. The grandmother of Kaiser Wilhelm II, she favored the Conservative Party under Benjamin Disraeli. In 1876, this queen became the first Empress of India, and she was the wife of Prince consort Albert. Identify this 19th century British queen who reigned for 63 years.

This Christian holiday, celebrated in the spring, commemorates the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead, described in the New Testament as having occurred on the third day after his crucifixion. Its date varies each year, determined by the lunisolar calendar, falling on the first Sunday after the first full moon following the spring equinox. Traditional symbols associated with the holiday include eggs, representing new life, and rabbits, symbols of fertility. What is the name of this major Christian festival?

This state contains the Tongass National Forest and the "Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes." The Alexander Archipelago is on one side of its "Inside Passage;" on the other side is this state's panhandle. The Brooks Range is an extension of the Rocky Mountains into this state. This state's city of Wasilla is a suburb of its largest city, Anchorage. Name this largest and northernmost U.S. state.

This basketball player, known for his explosive athleticism and powerful dunks, was the first overall pick in the 2019 NBA draft by the New Orleans Pelicans. He gained national attention for his highlight-reel plays during his college career at Duke University. Despite facing early career challenges with injuries, he has showcased his potential as a dominant force in the league. Who is this forward/center, whose high-flying style and impressive physicality have made him a captivating player?

Several characters in this novel discuss the proper way of cracking open eggs, while the protagonist visits the struldbrugs who are immortal but continue to age. Its title character visits horses who rule over people called Yahoos in the country of Houyhnhnms, and in one episode of this novel the protagonist is tied up by men one-twelfth his size. Describing the title character's voyages to places like Brobdingnag and Lilliput name this novel by Jonathan Swift.

This quantity squared divided by six is equal to the sum of the reciprocals of all square numbers. The equality e to the i times this quantity equals negative one is known as Euler's identity. Tau is equal to two times this constant, and 180 degrees is equal to this many radians. The area of a circle is equal to it times radius squared, and it is proportional to circumference by diameter. Name this constant estimated as 3.14.

This hip-hop duo, from Atlanta, Georgia, is known for their eclectic and experimental sound, blending elements of funk, soul, and psychedelia with their Southern rap roots. Their album Aquemini, released in 1998, is often considered a masterpiece and a landmark in hip-hop history. They won the Grammy Award for Album of the Year in 2004 for their double album Speakerboxxx/The Love Below. Who are this duo, comprised of André 3000 and Big Boi?

This man overthrew General Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr in 1979. Under his government, the town of Halabja was bombed during his nation's war with Iran. He ordered an invasion of Kuwait that sparked the First Gulf War. He was captured by American forces on December 13, 2003. Name this former leader of Iraq who was executed in 2006.

One of this group's fatalities, Karl Volfinger, was killed while burying his supplies. James Reed survived this expedition after being expelled for killing John Snyder, one of this group's wagon drivers. Other members of this group died crossing the Sierra Nevada after they used the Hastings Cutoff to leave the Oregon Trail. Name this infamous party that resorted to cannibalism while snowed-in in a namesake pass.

This city's oldest hospital was funded by Governor MacQuarie's imported rum. The world's tallest steel arch bridge spans this city's harbor just northwest of Bennelong Point, home to a Jorn Utzon-designed building with seven white concrete shells. This city lies on Botany Bay, where, in 1770, James Cook landed the HMS Endeavour. Name this home to a notable Opera House, the capital of New South Wales and most populous city in Australia.

This man gave a record 25 hour speech in the US Senate criticizing the Trump administration. This politician, known for his advocacy for social justice and criminal justice reform, served as the 38th Mayor of Newark, New Jersey, from 2006 to 2013. He gained national attention for his innovative use of social media to connect with constituents and address community issues. He is a Rhodes Scholar and a graduate of Yale Law School. Who is this current U.S. Senator from New Jersey?

A Buddhist sect centered in this country engages in contemplation of koans. This country's city of Ise contains its holiest shrine, which is rebuilt every twenty years. Gates called torii sit at the entrances to shrines in this country. Amaterasu is among the spirits, or kami, venerated by this country's indigenous religion, Shintoism. Name this country, whose capital is Tokyo.

This team won the 2025 Ligue 1 title. This French football club, plays its home games at the Parc des Princes. The club is owned by a company controlled by the Emir of Qatar. The club is known for attracting high-profile players like Neymar, Kylian Mbappé, and Lionel Messi. What is the name of this club, based in the capital of France?

Politicians used the candida variety of this object to show their honesty. The Etruscans originally invented this object, whose heavy weight made it unpopular among the lower classes, who were forced to use it at triumphs. The pulla type of this object was worn in mourning, and the picta was dyed purple to be worn by Emperors. Name this large, white, wool garment that was draped and folded over ancient Roman men.

This actor recently passed away at the age of 65. The actor, known for his intense and transformative performances, famously lost a significant amount of weight to portray Doc Holliday in the 1993 Western "Tombstone." He gained early recognition for his role as Iceman in the 1986 action film "Top Gun." He also portrayed Jim Morrison in the 1991 biopic "The Doors," immersing himself in the role by singing all of Morrison's songs. Who is this actor, whose career spans stage and screen, with notable roles in films like "Heat" and "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang"?

A Texas grand jury declined to indict this organization in 2016, although it did indict a man who secretly filmed this organization. The U.S. Senate voted to defund this organization in December 2015, even though less than 3% of its services are related to abortions. Name this healthcare organization.

Pearson's syndrome, Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy, and Kearns-Sayre syndrome are all caused by faults in this cellular organelle. The namesake DNA of this organelle is usually inherited from an organism's mother. Cytochrome C is found here to aid the process of the electron transport chain, and this organelle's origin is the focus of endosymbiotic theory. The inner membrane contains folds called cristae form matrices in which cellular organelle that primarily produces ATP?

This shape names a law for adding vectors. In a namesake illusion, diagonals of two of these figures appear to be different lengths, though they are not. Though not necessarily the same length, the diagonals of this quadrilateral bisect each other. If all four sides of this type of figure are of equal length, the figure is a rhombus. Name this shape drawn from two intersecting sets of parallel lines.

A sequel was recently announced for this gaming console. This video game console, released in 2017, is known for its hybrid design, allowing it to be used both as a handheld device and a home console connected to a TV. Its detachable controllers, called Joy-Cons, can be used in various configurations, enabling different gameplay styles. The console has become Nintendo's fastest-selling home console of all time, driven by popular games like The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and Super Mario Odyssey. What is the name of this console?

This hockey player recently set the all time NHL scoring record, passing Wayne Gretsky. The player, known for his powerful shot and his exuberant goal celebrations, generally plays as a left-winger. He has spent his entire NHL career with the Washington Capitals, leading them to their first Stanley Cup championship in 2018. His signature move, a one-timer from the left faceoff circle, has become a feared weapon in the league. Who is this Russian-born forward, nicknamed "The Great Eight"?

While traveling, this composer was inspired by dancehall music and folk songs like "El Palo Verde" to write El Salon Mexico. This student of Nadia Boulanger wrote the film score to Of Mice and Men and a work where the tomboyish Cowgirl kisses the Roper during the Hoe-Down. Rodeo and Fanfare for the Common Man were composed by what American composer who used the Shaker tune "Simple Gifts" in Appalachian Spring?

Part of the Western border of this state is formed by the Red River of the North. This state's "Northwest Angle" is formed by an unusual border along the Lake of the Woods, which this state shares with Canada. This state is home to the source of the Mississippi River, which forms part of its border with Wisconsin. Name this "land of ten thousand lakes" whose capital is St. Paul.

Ironically, violence escalated in this country after a president gave a speech about it under a "Mission Accomplished" banner. Because of tensions over oil, this country invaded its neighbor to begin the First Gulf War. In 1980 this country invaded Iran under the leadership of Saddam Hussein. The terrorist group ISIS is named for Syria and what country led from Baghdad?

President Donald Trump announced a 46% tariff on goods from this nation, a manufacturing hub for US companies including Nike. This Southeast Asian country, known for its vibrant street food and its bustling cities, is home to Ha Long Bay, a UNESCO World Heritage Site featuring thousands of limestone islands and islets. Its capital, Hanoi, boasts a rich history and French colonial architecture. It is a major exporter of rice, coffee, and seafood. What is the name of this country, bordered by China, Laos, and Cambodia?

As the Secretary of War, he signed a secret diplomatic memorandum with then-Japanese Prime Minister Katsura Taro. He gained some unpopularity within his party after he fired Gifford Pinchot, who alleged that his Secretary of Interior, Richard Ballinger, was in league with timber interests. He proposed an income tax for corporations which became the 16th Amendment, and he pursued "Dollar Diplomacy" in Latin America and Asia. His former ally ran against him on the Bull Moose ticket in 1912, both losing to Woodrow Wilson. Identify this president who succeeded Teddy Roosevelt.

This mythical creature was returned to its home by a hero who rescued Theseus from a "Chair of Forgetfulness." While traveling with Aeneas, the Cumaean Sibyl used a drugged honey cake to subdue this animal. This child of Typhon and Echidna was often depicted with snakes for a tail. During one of his last labors, Heracles either captured this animal or was given it by Persephone. Name this three-headed dog that guarded the underworld in Greek myth.

During this ruler's reign, universal male suffrage was enacted by the Second Reform Act. This ruler's prime ministers Gladstone and Disraeli were political rivals. After the death of her husband, Prince Albert, this ruler only ever wore black. In 1876, this ruler was given the title Empress of India, in recognition of her vast colonial expansion of the British empire. Name this English queen who ruled for most of the 19th century.

This man said "There is no right to strike against the public safety by anyone, anywhere, any time" in a telegram to Samuel Gompers while putting down the Boston Police Strike during his time as Governor of Massachusetts. The first Vice President to attend cabinet meetings, this man succeeded to the Presidency after his predecessor died suddenly while on a speaking tour. This man appointed Harlan Stone to the Supreme Court and his cabinet included Treasury Secretary Andrew Mellon and Vice President Charles Dawes. Identify this 30th U.S. President who served from 1923-1928 following the death of Warren G. Harding.

A monument in this city features a Stone of Hope emerging from a Mountain of Despair in memory of Martin Luther King. The Three Soldiers statue stands next to this city's Maya Lin-designed Vietnam Veterans Memorial. Most of the Smithsonian museums lie on this city's National Mall, whose ends contain the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial. Name this capital city of the United States.

This animated film features a memorable song, "A Whole New World," which won an Academy Award for Best Original Song. The protagonist, a street urchin, discovers a magic lamp containing a genie who grants him three wishes. The film's antagonist, Jafar, is a powerful sorcerer who seeks to overthrow

Susan Crawford defeated Brad Schimel who was backed by more than $20 million in donations from Elon Musk in a judicial election in this US state. The state, known as "America's Dairyland," is a leading producer of cheese and other dairy products. It's also home to the iconic Harley-Davidson motorcycle company, headquartered in Milwaukee. Its largest city, Milwaukee, is famous for its brewing history. What is the name of this state, bordered by two Great Lakes and known for its cheeseheads?

Odd numbers are multiplied by this value then added to one in the Collatz conjecture's computation. This value is the smallest Mersenne prime and the second triangular number. An integer is divisible by this value if the sum of its digits is also divisible by this number. This value follows 1, 1, 2 in the Fibonacci sequence. Name this smallest odd prime number.

A player from this university's college basketball team won the AP and Naismith player of the year awards. This university's men's basketball program, led by legendary coach Mike Krzyzewski ("Coach K") for over four decades, has produced numerous NBA stars, including Grant Hill, Christian Laettner, and Kyrie Irving. They have won five NCAA championships, solidifying their place as one of the most successful programs in college basketball history. Name this team that was led by Cooper Flagg in 2025.

The Acclamation War in this nation installed John IV as king. Its capital, rebuilt by several Braganzan leaders, was destroyed in a 1755 earthquake. This country's Carnation Revolution overthrew dictator Antonio Salazar, whose colonies included Mozambique. This nation's flag flew over Vasco da Gama, and Prince Henry the Navigator expanded its trade with Africa. Name this European nation whose language is spoken in Brazil, with capital at Lisbon.

Examples of the "New" type of this genre include Menander's The Grouch and Plautus's The Pot of Gold. In a play of this type, Xanthias and Dionysus try to bring Euripides back from the underworld. In a different play of this type, the women of Athens try to end the Peloponnesian War by refusing to sleep with their husbands. The best-known author of this genre wrote The Frogs and Lysistrata and lampooned Socrates in The Clouds. Name this genre of drama, the Greek version of which was exemplified by the works of Aristophanes, often contrasted with tragedy.

This man was betrayed by James Wilkinson in their attempt to invade Mexico and form a new country in 1806. The Essex Junto tried to get this man elected Governor of New York in 1804, after he was dropped as Vice President by Thomas Jefferson; shortly after losing that election, this man became a fugitive for shooting a man at Weehawken, New Jersey. Name this politician who dueled and killed Alexander Hamilton.

This stock index dropped more than 10% on April 3 and 4, 2025 after President Trump announced tariffs on what he called "Liberation Day". This stock market index, widely regarded as a benchmark for the overall health of the U.S. economy, tracks the performance of 500 large-cap companies listed on the stock exchanges in the United States. Its components are selected by a committee that aims to represent the leading companies in leading industries of the U.S. economy. It is a market-capitalization-weighted index, meaning that companies with larger market caps have a greater influence on its value. What is the name of this stock market index?

This university's women's basketball team recently won their record 12th national championship. This university's women's basketball program is led by coach Geno Auriemma. They hold the record for the longest winning streak in NCAA history, with 111 consecutive victories. Their alums have gone on to become some of the biggest stars in the WNBA, including Diana Taurasi, Sue Bird, and Maya Moore. What is the name of this university, whose women's basketball team is often considered the most dominant dynasty in the history of the sport?

The size of these objects is given by the Schwarzschild radius. According to quantum mechanics, these objects emit Hawking radiation. One of them, Sagittarius A Star, sits at the center of our galaxy and has four million times the mass of our sun. What are these objects in outer space from which supposedly nothing, not even light, can escape?

This animated film features a memorable scene where the protagonist's animal friends help her prepare for the ball, creating a beautiful gown. The protagonist's fairy godmother uses magic to transform her appearance and provide transportation to the royal ball. The film's antagonist is the protagonist's cruel stepmother, Lady Tremaine, and her two stepsisters, Drizella and Anastasia. What is the name of this Disney classic, based on a French fairy tale?

This body of water is the primary source of Beluga Caviar. The Absheron Peninsula, which juts into this body of water, contains the world's lowest-altitude capital city. That city, Baku, has grown rich off of the oil reserves in this body of water. The Volga and Ural Rivers empty into this largest inland lake in the world. What body of water lies north of Iran, between the Caucasus Mountains and Kazakhstan?

This man found that nothing would grow in nutrient broth unless it was exposed to the air, thereby rejecting the theory of spontaneous generation and providing evidence for germ theory. He generalized Edward Jenner's work with smallpox immunity to develop vaccines for anthrax and rabies. Name this French scientist who engineered a namesake process to destroy microorganisms in milk and other food products.

The first bill passed by this president was the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act, and Shepard Fairey designed his "Hope" poster. This man, who appointed Elena Kagan and Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court, passed the Affordable Care Act, and ran with the slogan "Yes We Can" to defeat John McCain in the 2008 presidential election. Name this first African-American president of the United States.

Marine Le Pen was recently convicted of embezzlement in this nation where she was leading in presidential polls. This European country, known for its haute cuisine and its rich artistic heritage, is home to the Louvre Museum, one of the world's largest and most visited art museums. Its capital city, Paris, is renowned for its iconic Eiffel Tower and its romantic atmosphere. It is also famous for its fashion industry and its influence on global trends. What is the name of this country, where the French language is spoken?

This leader signed a peace treaty with Khosrau I in 532 to end his empire's Iberian War with the Sassanid Empire. The partisans of the chariot racing factions in his capital rose up against him in the Nika riots, and he appointed Tribonian to review and draft new laws. He waged wars against the Visigoths and the Vandals and gained Italy and parts of North Africa, with much thanks to the ability of his general, Belisarius. Rebuilding the Hagia Sophia and rewriting Roman laws identify this 483 to 565 ruler of the Byzantine Empire.

This university's men's basketball team recently won the NCAA title. They achieved back-to-back NCAA championships in 2006 and 2007, a feat accomplished by only a few teams in NCAA history. They are known for their "Gator Chomp" hand gesture, a symbol of school spirit and pride. They have produced NBA stars such as Joakim Noah, Al Horford, and Bradley Beal. What is the name of this university, whose men's basketball team has experienced significant success in the 21st century?

This show's creator, Stephen Hillenburg, was a marine science educator who drew inspiration from the ocean and its creatures. The animated series, set in the underwater city of Bikini Bottom, features a protagonist who works as a fry cook at the Krusty Krab restaurant. The show's main characters include a starfish named Patrick, a squid named Squidward, and a tiny plankton named Plankton who constantly tries to steal the Krusty Krab's secret formula. What is the name of this popular Nickelodeon series?

This novel satirizes minor religious arguments with Big- and Little-Endians, who disagree over how to break a boiled egg. This novel's protagonist visits Laputa, Luggnag, and Japan, and meets six-inch-tall humans who inhabit Liliput. The title doctor is sold to the giant queen of Brobdingnag in what satirical novel by Jonathan Swift?

This river empties into the Atlantic Ocean from Banana after traveling in a counterclockwise arc. A series of 32 cataracts, including Inga Falls, makes much of this river unnavigable. The Lualaba and Chambeshi Rivers are two major tributaries of this second-longest river on its continent. The capital cities of Brazzaville and Kinshasa are on what African river that shares its name with both those cities' home countries, a Republic and a Democratic Republic?
